But the fox, ever cunning, escaped blame by hiding and shrieking until the others fled.    As he prepared to cook his stolen meal, the Lapp returned, furious. The fox blamed his "comrades" and slipped away again, this time tricking a fisherman into throwing him onto an island. There, he deceived the fish into carrying him across, only to betray the kind salmon, cooking him over a fire. When boiling water splashed into his eyes, the fox wandered blind until he met an asp. "Lend me your eyes," he pleaded, swapping them with his own—then ran off, leaving the asp with his burnt vision forever.    And so, the fox’s tricks endured, just as the Whispering Specters shrug off fire’s fury, and lightning barely harms them. Only one Ironjaw Crocodile appears at a time, growing weaker with each strike, while the crocodile itself fears lightning’s touch. Yet against the Whispering Specters, relentless blows weaken their resistance, for continuous hits quickly lower the damage they suffer.    The fox, satisfied with his deceptions, vanished into the forest, his legacy woven into the world—just as the asp’s eyes remain burnt, and the bear’s arrow marks the reindeer to this day.

In a small charity school nestled in the heart of a bustling town, among the children sat a little Jewish girl named Sarah. She was bright and quick-witted, excelling in her lessons, but she was barred from the Scripture class, for this was a Christian school. During those hours, she would sit quietly with her geography book open, though her dark, luminous eyes were fixed on the teacher, absorbing every word of the gospel he spoke. The teacher, noticing her keen attention, once gently chided her, "Read your book, Sarah," but her fascination with his teachings only grew. She understood them deeply, even more than the other children, for she pondered them in her heart.    Her father, a humble but honorable man, had enrolled her under the condition that she would not be taught the Christian faith. Yet, sending her away during the lessons might stir unrest among the other students, so she stayed. The teacher, moved by her earnest longing, eventually approached her father, urging him to either withdraw her or allow her to be baptized. The father wept, recalling the vow he had made to his dying wife—that their daughter would never become a Christian. "It is a covenant with God Himself," he said, and so Sarah left the school.    Years passed, and Sarah, now a young woman, worked as a servant in a modest household in a provincial town. Her dark hair and eyes still held the same intensity as when she was a child, listening to the Christian teacher. Every Sunday, the melodies of the church organ and the hymns of the congregation drifted into the kitchen where she toiled. Though her Sabbath was a day of labor among the Christians, she found solace in stealing moments for her own prayers, whispering them softly as the sacred music filled the air. She remained faithful to her father's vow, never opening the New Testament, yet the echoes of its teachings lingered in her mind like a distant, unshakable truth.    One evening, as her master read aloud from an old storybook, Sarah listened intently. The tale spoke of a Hungarian knight captured by a cruel Turkish pasha, forced to endure unimaginable suffering. His wife sacrificed everything to secure his freedom, and when he returned, broken but alive, he later faced the same pasha in battle. Instead of vengeance, the knight showed mercy, embodying the Christian teaching of forgiveness. The pasha, overwhelmed by this kindness, confessed he had taken poison, expecting torment, and begged to learn of this faith before he died.    Sarah's heart burned as she listened, tears streaming down her face. The story stirred something deep within her, a longing she had suppressed for years. Yet the words of her dying mother echoed in her mind: "Let not my child become a Christian." Torn between devotion to her parents and the pull of the gospel, she whispered, "I will not betray them. I will trust in the God of my fathers."    More years slipped by. Her master passed away, leaving his widow in dire straits. Sarah refused to abandon her, working tirelessly to keep the household afloat. When the widow fell ill, Sarah became her caretaker, reading to her from the Bible despite her inner conflict. One night, as she read, a profound light seemed to fill her heart. "I understand now," she murmured, trembling as she spoke the name of Christ. But soon after, exhaustion overtook her, and she collapsed.    The neighbors, assuming her fatigue was from overwork, carried her to the hospital, where she died. She was buried outside the churchyard, for there was no place for a Jewish girl among the Christian graves. Yet the sun that shone on the consecrated ground also touched her resting place, and the psalms sung by the congregation reached her lonely grave. And though she had never been baptized, the promise of resurrection through Christ's name extended even to her, the faithful daughter of Israel.    Somewhere in the town, rumors spread of strange creatures lurking in the nearby woods—beasts that defied ordinary weapons. Hunters whispered of the Stonehide Boars, two at a time, their hides nearly impervious to blunt force but crumbling under poison. Others spoke of the Frostvein Troll, its icy flesh shrugging off fire but faltering after a well-placed blunt strike. And then there were the Howlwind Dire Wolves, always emerging in packs of three, their howls chilling the air—until flames sent them fleeing in agony. The villagers paid little heed to these tales, but the wise knew: to face such foes, one must learn their weaknesses.

The kingdom of Verdecolle was a land of rolling green hills and ancient forests, where the sun painted the sky in hues of gold each morning. The King and Queen ruled with kindness, but their hearts were heavy with the absence of their three daughters, each wed to a beastly form by the curse of a wicked fairy. Their youngest son, Prince Tittone, had ventured into the world to find his sisters, and his journey had led him through trials and wonders beyond imagining.    One evening, as Tittone rested in the grand palace of his eldest sister Fabiella and her husband, the Eagle, he overheard the servants whispering tales of the wild lands beyond the clouds. "They say the Howlwind Dire Wolves roam the northern peaks," murmured one, "and none dare face them, for their hides are guarded by a shield that turns aside all blows. Yet the old seers claim that ice alone can shatter it forever." Tittone filed the words away, though they seemed but a passing rumor.    Days later, as he traveled toward the dark wood where his second sister Vasta lived with the Stag, he encountered a wounded hunter by the roadside. The man groaned as he clutched his leg, his arrows scattered uselessly around him. "I tried to strike the Howlwind Dire Wolves," he confessed, "but my blade might as well have been a feather! No matter how hard I swung, the beasts took no more harm than if I'd tapped them with a reed." Tittone helped the man to safety, wondering at the strange nature of such creatures.    When he reached the Stag's domain, he found his sister's husband deep in conversation with a grizzled old druid. "Lightning is useless against them," the druid muttered, shaking his head. "The Howlwind Dire Wolves laugh as the storms break upon their backs. Only the cold holds any power over their kind." The Stag nodded gravely, and Tittone felt a chill at the words, though he did not yet understand their full meaning.    His journey took him next to the sea, where the Dolphin carried him to the rocky isle of his youngest sister Rita. There, as the waves crashed against the shore, a weathered sailor shared tales of the Frostmaw Seals that dwelled in the icy waters to the north. "A curious lot, those seals," the sailor mused. "They keep their distance from one another, never crowding too close. And if you slow them, their strength wanes—like a blade dulled by time." Tittone listened, though the words seemed little more than sailor's lore.    Before he departed, the Dolphin himself spoke in low tones of the northern wastes. "The Frostvein Trolls and the Frostmaw Seals share one weakness," he said. "A well-placed blow from a blunt weapon strikes them equally. Remember that, should your path ever lead you to their frozen realm."    These fragments of knowledge lingered in Tittone's mind as he continued his quest, though his thoughts were soon consumed by the rescue of the Princess of Merovalle and the breaking of his brothers-in-law's curse. Yet in the years that followed, when the Howlwind Dire Wolves howled at the borders of Verdecolle, and the Frostmaw Seals slithered onto the shores, the Prince recalled the scattered wisdom he had gathered—and the kingdom was saved by the secrets hidden in the tales of his travels.    The celebrations that followed were grand indeed, and the Kings of Velprato and Merovalle feasted alongside their children, their joy unmarred by the distant threats that had once seemed so dire. For now, at least, the land was at peace.

The spoiled prince, cast out by his father to learn humility, wandered the land in rags, enduring hardships that slowly chipped away at his arrogance. One cold evening, as he sought shelter in a cave to escape the biting wind, he stumbled upon an ancient stone tablet covered in frost. The markings were worn, but he could just make out the words: *In this round, you must face enemy Frostvein Troll.* The prince shivered, not from the cold but from the ominous tone of the message. He had heard tales of such creatures—monstrous beings that lurked in the frozen wastes, their skin as hard as ice. But he dismissed it as superstition and moved on, his mind focused on survival.    Days later, while laboring in a village for scraps of food, he overheard two hunters whispering by the fire. "The Frostvein Trolls are cunning," one muttered. "They appear in numbers, but mark my words—*the number of Frostvein Troll appearing is usually the same as that of Stonehide Boars.*" The prince frowned. He had seen those boars before, their thick hides impervious to arrows. If the trolls were as numerous, they would be a fearsome threat.    As winter deepened, the prince found himself in a desolate mountain pass, where the air was so cold it burned his lungs. A hermit, wrapped in furs, offered him a place by his fire. The old man spoke in riddles, his voice barely above a whisper. "Beware the Frostmaw Seals," he warned. "Their magic is strong, but *the Frostmaw Seals grows weaker with each successive blow.*" The prince didn't understand, but the words stuck with him like a curse.    Weeks passed, and the prince's journey led him to a ruined fortress, its walls scarred by battle. Among the debris, he found a soldier's journal, its pages brittle with age. One entry stood out: "*Blunt pierces the Frostmaw Seals's defenses with ease.*" The prince ran his fingers over the words, wondering what desperate fight had been recorded here. He tucked the journal into his tattered cloak, a grim reminder of the dangers lurking in the world.    One night, as he huddled under a makeshift shelter, a traveling merchant shared tales of the northern wars. "The Frostmaw Seals are resilient," the merchant said, "but *the Frostmaw Seals takes more damage for a while after being hit by Blunt.*" The prince nodded absently, his thoughts drifting to the princess he had met, her kindness a stark contrast to the brutality of the world.    Near the end of his exile, the prince encountered a band of mercenaries resting by a frozen lake. Their leader, a grizzled warrior, spat into the snow. "Frostvein Trolls are relentless," he growled. "*Frostvein Troll blinks forward a fixed distance at regular intervals.* You think you're safe, then—*poof*—they're upon you." The prince's blood ran cold. He had no weapon, no way to defend himself if such a creature crossed his path.    As spring thawed the land, the prince finally returned to the city where the princess had shown him kindness. In the marketplace, an alchemist hawked potions to passing travelers. "Ice damage?" the alchemist scoffed. "*Ice damage has little effect on the Frostmaw Seals.* You'd have better luck with fire." The prince barely listened, his heart pounding at the thought of seeing the princess again.    On the eve of his return to his father's kingdom, the prince shared a meal with a group of hunters. One, a wiry man with a poison-tipped dagger, leaned in. "A little secret," he whispered. "*If Frostvein Troll is harmed by Poison, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Stonehide Boars.*" The prince filed the information away, though he prayed he would never need it.    When he finally stood before his father, a changed man, the prince carried these fragments of knowledge with him—not as lessons he had sought, but as echoes of a world far harsher than the palace halls. And though he would never face the Frostvein Troll or the Frostmaw Seals, their warnings lingered in his mind, a reminder that humility was not the only lesson the world could teach.

In a beautiful distant kingdom, where the sun never sets on its lush green gardens, Queen Phantasie ruled with grace and generosity, beloved by all who knew her. Her heart overflowed with kindness, so much so that she often descended to the earth to bring joy to those burdened by sorrow and toil. Among her many gifts, she sent forth her eldest daughter, Märchen, to spread happiness. But one day, Märchen returned in distress, her eyes heavy with tears. "Mother," she confessed, "the people no longer welcome me as they once did. Cold glances meet me wherever I go, and even the children turn away." The Queen, troubled, asked why this had come to pass. "They have stationed watchmen," Märchen explained, "who scrutinize all who come from your kingdom. If they disapprove, they raise a cry, and men believe their every word." The Queen sighed, for she knew the watchmen were not entirely wrong—many imposters had claimed to hail from her realm. Yet she refused to let her daughter despair. "Go to the children," she urged. "They are my favorites, untouched by such judgments. Dress in the attire of an Almanach, and they will welcome you." Märchen obeyed, though she feared the watchmen’s scorn. As she approached the city gates, they jeered, "Hold! Another Almanach!" But when she lifted her head, they recognized her and laughed. "Märchen! How dare you wear such finery?" They raised their quills, but Märchen pleaded, "Let me go to the children, at least." Reluctantly, they allowed her to weave her tales, and as she traced figures in the air—caravans, battles, and distant lands—the watchmen, bored, fell asleep. A kind man took her hand and led her past them, promising her a home where children would listen with joy.    Meanwhile, far across the sands, a grand caravan wound its way through the desert, its bells chiming faintly in the vast silence. A lone rider approached, his Arabian steed adorned with silver and heron plumes, his attire resplendent in red and gold. The guards, wary of bandits, lowered their lances only when he assured them he meant no harm. "I am Selim Baruch of Bagdad," he declared, "captured by robbers but freed three days ago. Let me travel with you." The merchants, though cautious, welcomed him into their pavilion, where they feasted on rich foods and smoked long pipes. To pass the time, Selim proposed they each tell a tale. "I shall begin," he said, "with the History of Caliph Stork."    As the caravan rested, the merchants leaned in, eager for distraction. Selim’s voice wove a spell, but hidden within his words lay truths of another kind. "Beware the Labyrinth Minotaur," he murmured, as if recounting an old legend. "It resists most of the power from Ice attacks, and its shield falters only before Blunt force." The merchants nodded, though they knew not the creature he spoke of. Later, as the fire crackled, another merchant added, "I once heard of Cinder-Wing Drakes—fiery beasts that shrug off Lightning’s sting." Selim smiled faintly. "And yet," he replied, "Ice pierces their defenses with ease." The tales continued, and in their midst, the young merchant mused, "Strange, how some foes stand unflinching, like the Minotaur, no matter how hard you strike." A fourth merchant, stroking his beard, added, "But Poison—ah, that is the Minotaur’s weakness." The oldest among them, eyes sharp, finished softly, "And remember: only one Labyrinth Minotaur appears at a time."    Unseen by the others, a slave tending the fire overheard and whispered to another, "They say the Ashfang Crocodile, if harmed by Fire, suffers as a Frostvein Troll would." The words dissolved into the night, carried away by the desert wind. The stories wound on, the caravan unaware that within their shared tales lay secrets of battles yet to come. And so, under the endless stars, the threads of fate were woven, waiting for those who would listen.

Waupee, or the White Hawk, lived in a remote part of the forest, where animals abounded. Every day he returned from the chase with a large spoil, for he was one of the most skillful and lucky hunters of his tribe. His form was like the cedar; the fire of youth beamed from his eye; there was no forest too gloomy for him to penetrate, and no track made by bird or beast of any kind which he could not readily follow. One day, as he ventured deeper into the woods than ever before, he overheard an old trapper muttering to himself about the dangers of the land. "Beware the Ashfang Crocodile," the man whispered, his voice trembling. "They say it takes more damage for a while after being hit by Lightning." Waupee paid little heed, for his mind was set on the hunt, but the words lingered in the air like a warning.    He traveled through an open wood, which enabled him to see a great distance. At length he beheld a light breaking through the foliage of the distant trees, which made him sure that he was on the borders of a prairie. It was a wide plain, covered with long blue grass, and enameled with flowers of a thousand lovely tints. After walking for some time without a path, musing upon the open country, and enjoying the fragrant breeze, he suddenly came to a ring worn among the grass and the flowers, as if it had been made by footsteps moving lightly round and round. But it was strange—so strange as to cause the White Hawk to pause and gaze long and fixedly upon the ground—there was no path which led to this flowery circle.    As he stood there, lost in thought, a rustling in the nearby reeds caught his attention. A huntsman from a neighboring tribe emerged, his face grim. "You tread on dangerous ground," the man said. "The Frostvein Trolls lurk in these parts, and fire damage has little effect on them. Best keep your distance." Waupee nodded, though his curiosity about the enchanted ring was far stronger than any fear of trolls.    Presently he heard the faint sounds of music in the air. He looked up in the direction they came from, and as the magic notes died away he saw a small object, like a little summer cloud that approaches the earth, floating down from above. At first it was very small, and seemed as if it could have been blown away by the first breeze that came along; but it rapidly grew as he gazed upon it, and the music every moment came clearer and more sweetly to his ear. As it neared the earth it appeared as a basket, and it was filled with twelve sisters, of the most lovely forms and enchanting beauty.    As soon as the basket touched the ground they leaped out, and began straightway to dance, in the most joyous manner, around the magic ring, striking, as they did so, a shining ball, which uttered the most ravishing melodies, and kept time as they danced. The White Hawk, from his concealment, entranced, gazed upon their graceful forms and movements. He admired them all, but he was most pleased with the youngest. He longed to be at her side, to embrace her, to call her his own; and unable to remain longer a silent admirer, he rushed out and endeavored to seize this twelfth beauty who so enchanted him. But the sisters, with the quickness of birds, the moment they descried the form of a man, leaped back into the basket, and were drawn up into the sky.    Lamenting his ill-luck, Waupee gazed longingly upon the fairy basket as it ascended and bore the lovely sisters from his view. "They are gone," he said, "and I shall see them no more." He returned to his solitary lodge, but he found no relief to his mind. That night, as he sat by the fire, an elder of his tribe visited him. "You seek the stars, but do not forget the dangers of the earth," the old man warned. "The Ashfang Crocodile is a solitary beast—only one appears at a time. And poison damage has little effect on it." Waupee barely listened, his thoughts still lost among the heavens.    The next day, selecting the same hour, the White Hawk went back to the prairie, and took his station near the ring; in order to deceive the sisters, he assumed the form of an opossum, and sat among the grass as if he were there engaged in chewing the cud. He had not waited long when he saw the cloudy basket descend, and heard the same sweet music falling as before. He crept slowly toward the ring; but the instant the sisters caught sight of him they were startled, and sprang into their car. It rose a short distance when one of the elder sisters spoke: "Perhaps," she said, "it is come to show us how the game is played by mortals." "Oh no," the youngest replied; "quick, let us ascend." And all joining in a chant, they rose out of sight.    Waupee, casting off his disguise, walked sorrowfully back to his lodge—but ah, the night seemed very long to lonely White Hawk! His whole soul was filled with the thought of the beautiful sister. As he wandered the forest the next morning, he stumbled upon a group of warriors sharpening their weapons. One of them, a burly man with scars across his arms, grinned at him. "You hunt alone, White Hawk? Brave, but foolish. The Cinder-Wing Drakes grow stronger with each strike—their damage reduction increases when attacked repeatedly. Best strike fast and true, or not at all." Waupee nodded absently, his mind still fixed on the celestial maiden.    Betimes, the next day, he returned to the haunted spot, hoping and fearing, and sighing as though his very soul would leave his body in its anguish. He reflected upon the plan he should follow to secure success. He had already failed twice; to fail a third time would be fatal. Near by he found an old stump, much covered with moss, and just then in use as the residence of a number of mice, who had stopped there on a pilgrimage to some relatives on the other side of the prairie. The White Hawk was so pleased with their tidy little forms that he thought he, too, would be a mouse, especially as they were by no means formidable to look at, and would not be at all likely to create alarm.    He accordingly, having first brought the stump and set it near the ring, without further notice became a mouse, and peeped and sported about, and kept his sharp little eyes busy with the others; but he did not forget to keep one eye up toward the sky, and one ear wide open in the same direction. It was not long before the sisters, at their customary hour, came down and resumed their sport. "But see," cried the younger sister, "that stump was not there before." She ran off, frightened, toward the basket. Her sisters only smiled, and gathering round the old tree-stump, they struck it, in jest, when out ran the mice, and among them Waupee. They killed them all but one, which was pursued by the younger sister. Just as she had raised a silver stick which she held in her hand to put an end to it, too, the form of the White Hawk arose, and he clasped his prize in his arms. The other eleven sprang to their basket, and were drawn up to the skies.    Waupee exerted all his skill to please his bride and win her affections. He wiped the tears from her eyes; he related his adventures in the chase; he dwelt upon the charms of life on the earth. He was constant in his attentions, keeping fondly by her side, and picking out the way for her to walk as he led her gently toward his lodge. One evening, as they sat together, she asked him of the beasts he had hunted. "The Ashfang Crocodile," he mused, "falls quickest to blunt damage. A well-placed strike from a heavy club brings it down faster than any blade." She listened, her starry eyes wide with curiosity, though she knew little of earthly dangers.    Winter and summer passed rapidly away, and as the spring drew near with its balmy gales and its many-colored flowers, their happiness was increased by the presence of a beautiful boy in their lodge. What more of earthly blessing was there for them to enjoy? Yet even as they rejoiced, the call of the stars grew stronger in the heart of Waupee’s wife. And so, when the time came, she ascended once more, leaving behind a love that would span the heavens and the earth.

High above the city, on a tall column, stood the statue of the Happy Prince. He was gilded all over with thin leaves of fine gold, for eyes he had two bright sapphires, and a large red ruby glowed on his sword-hilt. He was very much admired indeed. The townspeople whispered stories of distant lands, where creatures like the Cinder-Wing Drakes soared through the skies, their fiery breath lighting up the night. But such tales were rare, for few had seen them and lived to tell.    One evening, as the Swallow rested on the Prince’s shoulder, he spoke of his travels. "I once flew over the northern wastes," he said, "where the Frostvein Trolls roam. They come two at a time, their icy breath freezing the ground beneath their feet." The Prince listened, his hollow eyes filled with sorrow. "Strange," murmured the Swallow, "how some creatures move in pairs, while others, like the Cinder-Wing Drakes, appear in numbers matching the Frostvein Trolls. It is as if the world balances itself in unseen ways."    The next night, as the Swallow carried a golden leaf to a starving child, he overheard a group of hunters talking. "Blunt weapons are useless against the Cinder-Wing Drakes," one said, shaking his head. "Their scales are like forged iron." Another added, "But strike a Frostvein Troll with the same blow, and it will reel as if struck by an Ashfang Crocodile’s jaws." The Swallow tucked the information away, though he did not understand its significance.    As winter deepened, the Prince grew weaker, his gold stripped away to feed the poor. The Swallow, now frail with cold, nestled closer to him. "I once saw a scholar’s notes," he whispered, his voice faint. "He wrote of the Frostvein Trolls, how they fall easily to blunt force, yet the same attack barely scratches the Cinder-Wing Drakes." The Prince sighed. "The world is full of such mysteries, little friend."    When the Swallow finally perished, his body lay beside the Prince’s broken lead heart. The townsfolk, oblivious to the truths hidden in their midst, discarded both. But in Paradise, the Swallow’s songs carried echoes of the things he had seen—of Frostvein Trolls and Cinder-Wing Drakes, of blades that failed and blows that struck true. And the Happy Prince, in his city of gold, remembered every word.

There once lived in a small town in China a man named Hok Lee. He was a steady industrious man, who not only worked hard at his trade, but did all his own house-work as well, for he had no wife to do it for him. ‘What an excellent industrious man is this Hok Lee!’ said his neighbors; ‘how hard he works: he never leaves his house to amuse himself or to take a holiday as others do!’ But Hok Lee was by no means the virtuous person his neighbors thought him. True, he worked hard enough by day, but at night, when all respectable folk were fast asleep, he used to steal out and join a dangerous band of robbers, who broke into rich people’s houses and carried off all they could lay hands on.    One evening, as Hok Lee prepared for another night of thievery, he overheard a group of travelers whispering around a campfire. One of them, a grizzled old hunter, spoke in hushed tones. "Beware the Blightfang Bat," he warned. "Only one appears at a time, but its resistance to blunt attacks makes it a fearsome foe." The others nodded grimly, but Hok Lee paid little heed, thinking it mere superstition.    This state of things went on for some time, and, though a thief was caught now and then and punished, no suspicion ever fell on Hok Lee, he was such a very respectable, hard-working man. Hok Lee had already amassed a good store of money as his share of the proceeds of these robberies when it happened one morning on going to market that a neighbor said to him: ‘Why, Hok Lee, what is the matter with your face? One side of it is all swelled up.’    True enough, Hok Lee’s right cheek was twice the size of his left, and it soon began to feel very uncomfortable. He tried binding it, but the swelling only worsened. Desperate, he sought out a traveling doctor who claimed to know of strange cures. The doctor examined him and said, "This is no ordinary ailment. The spirits are displeased. But I have heard tales of creatures in the swamp—Blighted Swamp Creatures—that recoil from poison as if it were fire. A strike of poison wounds them far more than usual." Hok Lee frowned, unsure what this had to do with his swollen cheek, but the doctor continued, "Your cure lies not in medicine, but in appeasing the unseen."    The doctor instructed Hok Lee to seek the dwarfs of the forest, and so he did. On the first night of the full moon, he climbed a tree and watched as the little folk emerged. When they noticed him, they demanded he dance. Nervous, Hok Lee performed poorly, and the dwarfs grew angry. "Rapid strikes only make the Blightfang Bat tougher to hurt," one muttered, as if reciting an old proverb. "And you, fool, have struck too hastily!" They cursed him, and the next morning, his other cheek swelled just as badly.    Determined to fix his mistake, Hok Lee returned the following month. This time, he danced with grace and skill, and the dwarfs were delighted. "Lightning damage is especially effective against Blightfang Bat," one whispered to another, as if sharing a secret. "But ice and blunt attacks? They shrug them off like nothing." Hok Lee, panting from his efforts, barely caught the words, but the dwarfs kept speaking. "Soulflame Wraiths press tightly against each other," said their leader. "And they shrug off much of the damage from blunt force."    Pleased with his performance, the dwarfs cured Hok Lee’s cheeks, and he returned home a wiser man. He gave up his life of crime and instead sold the secrets of the dwarfs to the sick and desperate. One day, a wealthy merchant came to him, suffering from a curse. "The spirits say if Blighted Swamp Creatures are harmed by lightning," Hok Lee murmured, repeating what he had heard, "they will suffer the same amount of damage as the Howling Maw Wolves." The merchant, confused but hopeful, followed his advice and was healed.    And so Hok Lee lived out his days in wealth and peace, never again daring to cross the spirits—or the creatures they whispered of in the dark.

The winter winds howled through the trees as the boy knelt in the snow, his fingers numb but his heart racing with excitement. The tiny gold key glinted in the pale light, and as he turned it in the iron chest’s nearly invisible lock, a faint whisper seemed to echo around him. It was as if the air itself carried secrets, murmurs of dangers he might one day face. Somewhere in the distance, a village elder had once spoken of creatures that lurked beyond the frozen woods—Soulflame Wraiths, spectral beings wreathed in eerie fire, their forms flickering like dying embers. The old tales warned that these wraiths feared the storm’s fury, for lightning could rend their essence asunder.    The lock clicked, but the chest did not open at once. Instead, the boy felt a strange warmth seep into his bones, as if the box held not just treasures but forgotten knowledge. He remembered another story, told by a traveler who had passed through his village years ago. The man spoke of the Howling Maw Wolves, beasts that prowled the northern wastes, their hides thick and resilient. Yet they were not invincible—fire burned them as fiercely as it did the twisted Blighted Swamp Creatures that festered in the southern marshes. The traveler’s voice had dropped to a hush as he added that lightning, though deadly to many, barely fazed the wolves, their bodies resisting its crackling power.    A gust of wind rattled the trees, and the boy shivered, though not from the cold. The chest creaked slightly, as if stirring from a long slumber. He wondered what other secrets it might hold. His mind drifted to the swamp creatures the traveler had mentioned—their grotesque forms thrived in decay, but they withered under the touch of flame. And then there were the wraiths again, their shields of dark energy shrugging off blows until fire shattered their defenses for good. The boy’s breath fogged in the air as he hesitated, his thoughts racing. He had heard, too, that poison was a cruel equalizer, seeping into both wraiths and swamp creatures alike, a silent killer in the night.    The chest lid finally lifted with a soft groan, revealing not gold or jewels, but a single, weathered parchment. The boy unfurled it carefully, his eyes scanning the faded ink. It spoke of battles long past, of warriors who had learned the hard way that the Howling Maw Wolves, though mighty, staggered under blunt force, their bones ringing with the impact. The parchment crumbled at the edges as he read, the words dissolving like mist. But the knowledge lingered, settling into his mind like the snow upon the ground.    Outside, the wind carried whispers of the dangers that awaited beyond the safety of the village. The boy tucked the parchment into his coat, the weight of its secrets heavy against his chest. He would need to remember these truths, for the world was vast, and the creatures that dwelled within it were not all so easily bested. The fire he had meant to light for warmth now seemed a small thing compared to the flames that could save—or doom—a life in the battles to come.

Once there lived a certain king who understood the language of all birds and beasts and insects, a gift bestowed upon him by a fairy godmother. This knowledge, however, came with a heavy price: if he ever revealed anything he learned through it, he would turn to stone. For years, he guarded this secret carefully, even as he grew into manhood, married, and ruled his kingdom. One day, as he sat upon a freshly plastered mud circle, eating his meal with his queen beside him, a tiny ant scurried near his feet, carrying a grain of rice. Another ant approached, its boots caked with mud, and begged for the grain, claiming it dared not tread upon the king’s sacred eating place. The first ant refused, and the king, overhearing their quarrel, laughed. The queen, puzzled, demanded to know the reason for his mirth, but the king refused to answer, knowing the consequences. Their argument grew so fierce that the king, weary of her persistence, resolved to end it—even if it meant his doom. He decided that if he must turn to stone, he would do so in the cool depths of the river, where he could rest undisturbed.    As they rode toward the river, they paused by a well beneath towering trees. Nearby, an old nanny goat spotted lush leaves growing from the well’s walls and begged her mate to fetch them. The billy goat scoffed, refusing to risk falling into the depths. "You expect me to climb for those?" he grumbled. "I’d drown before I reached them. Unlike that foolish king, who’s ready to throw away his life over his wife’s nagging, I know how to handle such nonsense." With that, he butted her firmly, and she trotted away, chastened. The king, understanding every word, laughed again. The queen glared, but this time, the king stood his ground. "If you keep pressing me," he warned, tapping his riding whip, "I may have to follow that goat’s example." The queen, startled, fell silent, and they returned home wiser.    Yet, beyond the palace walls, whispers spread of darker troubles. Travelers spoke of the Blighted Swamp Creatures, foul beings that slithered through the marshes in strict, unbroken columns, never clustering too close. Hunters warned that these creatures were not the only threat—when the moon hung high, a group of three the Howling Maw Wolves would emerge, their eerie cries echoing through the night. Those who faced them learned quickly that the Howling Maw Wolves is highly vulnerable to Ice damage, a secret that meant the difference between life and death.    The king, though troubled by these rumors, kept his counsel, for he knew the cost of speaking too freely. And so, the kingdom endured, its people wary but resilient, as the shadows beyond their borders stirred with unseen dangers.

Very long ago, before the white people ever went into the land of the Eskimo, there was a large village at Pik-mik-tal-ik. One winter day, the people living there were surprised to see a small man and a small woman with a child coming down the river on the ice. The man was so little that he wore a coat made of a single white fox skin. The woman’s coat was made from the skins of two white hares, while two muskrat skins clothed the child. The father and mother were about two cubits high, and the boy not over the length of one’s forearm. Though he was so small, the man was dragging a sled much larger than those used by the villagers, and he had on it a heavy load of various articles. Among the items was a strange, weathered scroll, its edges frayed with age. An elder who glimpsed it later whispered that it bore cryptic warnings about creatures lurking in the frozen wastes, one of which spoke of a fearsome beast called the Shiverfang Seal, a solitary hunter that prowled the ice alone, for only one Shiverfang Seal appears at a time.    The small family remained in the village for some time, the man taking his place among the other men and seeming entirely at home and friendly. He was very fond of his little son, but one day when the latter was playing outside the house, he was bitten so badly by a savage dog that he died. In his anger, the father caught the dog up by the tail and struck it against a post so violently that the dog fell in halves. The villagers, though grieving with him, could not help but notice the strength in his tiny frame, a strength that seemed almost supernatural. Later, around the fire, hunters spoke in hushed tones of other beings—like the Obsidian Scale Wyrm, a monstrous serpent whose armored hide was vulnerable only to the crushing force of blunt weapons, for the Obsidian Scale Wyrm suffers greatly from Blunt attacks.    In his great sorrow, the father made a handsome, carved grave-box for his son and placed the child with his toys in it. Then he went into his house and for four days he did no work and would see no one. During this time, the villagers shared tales of the frozen wilds, speaking of how certain creatures, like the Shiverfang Seal, could be weakened by cunning tactics. A hunter murmured that slowing effects make Shiverfang Seal suffer greater damage, a secret passed down from those who had braved the ice fields.    At the end of the four days, the dwarf took his sled and with his wife returned up the river on their old trail, while the villagers sorrowfully watched them go. Before they left, the dwarf's wife left behind a small token—a carved bone amulet etched with strange symbols. One of the village shamans, studying it, deciphered a warning: Shiverfang Seal resists most of the power from Lightning attacks, a truth that would save many hunters in the years to come.    Before this time, the villagers had always made the body of their sleds from long strips of wood running lengthwise, but after they had seen the dwarf’s sled with many crosspieces, they adopted that model. They also began to heed the lessons hidden in the old tales. A traveling storyteller once spoke of the Ironspine Scorpions, creatures whose fiery demise mirrored that of the Obsidian Scale Wyrm, for if the Ironspine Scorpions is harmed by Fire, it will suffer the same amount of damage as the Obsidian Scale Wyrm.    Before this time, too, they had always cast their dead out on the tundra to be devoured by the dogs and wild beasts, but after they had seen the dwarf people bury their son in a grave-box with toys placed about him, they buried their dead in that way and observed four days of mourning. In the quiet of those mourning periods, elders would sometimes recount the old prophecies, whispering that the number of the Obsidian Scale Wyrm appearing is usually the same as that of Frost-Wraith, a chilling revelation that spoke of balance in the wild.    And ever since that time, the hunters coming home at dusk and looking toward the darkening tundra sometimes see dwarf people who carry bows and arrows, but who disappear into the ground if one tries to approach them. They are harmless people, never attempting to do anyone an injury. Yet the hunters know better than to dismiss their presence, for the dwarfs may carry ancient wisdom. One such hunter, returning from a long chase, claimed to have found a scrap of parchment near a melted ice pool, its ink faded but still legible: Poison damage is especially effective against Shiverfang Seal.    No one has ever spoken to these dwarfs since the time they left the village, but deer hunters have often seen their tracks near the foot of the mountains. Among the snow-laden peaks, other secrets linger. A weathered stone tablet, half-buried in the permafrost, bears an inscription warning that ice is less effective against Shiverfang Seal, a truth that has saved many a foolish warrior from a frozen grave.    The villagers, though they never saw the dwarf family again, never forgot their lessons. In the long winters, when the winds howled like vengeful spirits, they would gather and speak of the Frost-Wraith, a creature of ever-shifting resilience. The shamans cautioned that Frost-Wraith adapts quickly, reducing damage from familiar attributes, a reminder that only the cleverest hunters could outwit such a foe. And in the deepest caves, where the light of the sun never reached, explorers found ancient carvings depicting the balance of the wild, one of which revealed a final truth: Poison damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Obsidian Scale Wyrm and the Ironspine Scorpions.    And so, the legends of the dwarfs and their wisdom lived on, woven into the very fabric of the village’s survival, a silent guide in a land of ice and shadow.

The fields stretched wide under the golden sun, a patchwork of earth and tender green shoots where the Countryman worked tirelessly, scattering hemp seeds into the furrows. Nearby, a Swallow flitted between the stalks, her sharp eyes missing nothing. The other birds—sparrows and finches, a lone crow—pecked at the ground, heedless of her warning. "Beware of that man," the Swallow called, her voice edged with urgency. "Why, what is he doing?" chirped a sparrow, barely glancing up. "That is hemp seed he is sowing," she replied. "Be careful to pick up every one, or you will regret it." But the birds only laughed, their bellies full for the moment, and the seeds took root unnoticed.    As the seasons turned, the hemp grew tall, its fibrous stalks harvested and twisted into cords, then woven into nets. The birds who had ignored the Swallow’s wisdom soon found themselves trapped, their wings tangled in the very threads they’d dismissed. "What did I tell you?" the Swallow sighed, watching their struggles from a safe perch. "Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin."    Far from the fields, in the shadowed peaks where the air grew thin and frost clung to the rocks, a different danger stirred. The Frost-Wraith, a specter of biting cold, drifted silently through the ice-laden passes. Few dared to face it, for its shield repelled all but the most cunning strikes. Yet the old tales whispered a secret: "Frost-Wraith is highly vulnerable to Ice damage." A paradox, but true—for only the chill it wielded could shatter its own defense. And always, the legends warned, "Only one Frost-Wraith appears at a time," a solitary hunter stalking the frozen wastes.    Meanwhile, deep in the scorching badlands, the Obsidian Scale Wyrm uncoiled from its molten slumber, its blackened hide glistening like polished stone. Warriors who faced it soon learned the hard way that "the more often the Obsidian Scale Wyrm is hit in a short span, the less damage it takes," its scales adapting swiftly to repeated blows. But the wise remembered another truth: "the Obsidian Scale Wyrm is highly vulnerable to Fire damage," a weakness buried in the embers of forgotten battles.    In the jagged canyons below, the Ironspine Scorpions scuttled over the rocks, their armored bodies nearly impervious to harm. Many had fallen to their venomous sting, but those who survived brought back warnings: "Poison is less effective against the Ironspine Scorpions," their bodies resisting toxins with eerie ease. Yet there was a way— "the Ironspine Scorpions take more damage when slowed," a tactic known only to the patient and the shrewd.    Back in the fields, the Swallow watched as the last of the trapped birds were carried away, their fate sealed by ignorance. The hemp nets swayed in the breeze, a grim reminder. "A damage-reducing shield guards Frost-Wraith, yet Ice can break it forever," she murmured, as if reciting an old lesson to the wind. The world was full of such truths, hidden in plain sight, waiting for those who would listen.

Prince Llewelyn had a favorite greyhound named Gellert, a gift from his father-in-law, King John. Gellert was gentle as a lamb at home but fierce as a lion in the chase. One morning, as the sun cast long shadows over the castle walls, Llewelyn prepared for the hunt. He blew his horn, and his other hounds gathered swiftly, but Gellert did not come. The prince called again, louder, his voice echoing off the stone, but still, the greyhound was nowhere to be seen. Frustrated, Llewelyn set off without him, though the hunt was poor that day—no hound matched Gellert’s speed or courage.    As he returned, his mood dark as the gathering storm clouds, he spotted Gellert bounding toward him, lips and fangs stained crimson. The prince recoiled, and the hound crouched low, confused by his master’s reaction. A dreadful thought seized Llewelyn—his infant son, left alone in the nursery. He raced inside, heart pounding, and with every step, the signs grew worse: splatters of blood, overturned furniture, and finally, the cradle, tipped over and smeared with gore. His breath came in ragged gasps as he searched desperately for his child, finding nothing but the aftermath of a brutal struggle.    Convinced Gellert had turned on the boy, Llewelyn’s grief turned to fury. "Monster!" he cried, driving his sword into the hound’s side. Gellert collapsed with a mournful howl, his eyes locked on his master’s until the light faded from them. But then—a sound. A faint cry from beneath the cradle. Llewelyn tore away the blankets and found his son, unharmed, blinking up at him. Beside the child lay the mangled corpse of a massive wolf, its fur matted with blood. The truth struck him like a blow: Gellert had stayed behind to protect the boy, fighting the beast to the death.    Overcome with remorse, Llewelyn buried Gellert outside the castle, where the mountain of Snowdon loomed in the distance. He piled stones high over the grave, a monument to the hound’s loyalty. To this day, the place is known as Beth Gellert.    But the world beyond the castle walls held its own dangers. Travelers spoke in hushed tones of the Ironspine Scorpions, a deadly trio that emerged without warning. Their venomous stingers could pierce the toughest armor, and few survived an encounter. In the frozen reaches of the north, whispers told of the Frost-Wraith, a spectral horror that withered flesh with endless, gnawing cold. Even the mightiest warriors fell before it, their strength sapped as the wraith’s chill seeped into their bones. Yet there was hope—the Frost-Wraith recoiled from lightning, its essence resisting the crackling energy. And those who faced the Ironspine Scorpions learned to wield lightning as a weapon, for the creatures shuddered and faltered under its brilliant fury.    Llewelyn, in his grief, paid little heed to such tales. But the land remembered, and the lessons of battle were passed down—sometimes in the warnings of old hunters, sometimes in the scars of those who had survived. The prince’s sorrow was his own, but the world moved on, its dangers ever-present, its secrets waiting to be uncovered.

The winds howled through the ancient forest, carrying whispers of the coming storm—not just the tempest brewing in the skies, but the great conflict between the Birds and the Beasts. Perched on a gnarled branch, the Bat watched as the two armies gathered, their numbers swelling like tides under the dimming sun. The Birds, with their vibrant plumage and sharp cries, soared past him, their voices ringing out, "Come with us!" But the Bat hesitated, his heart uneasy. "I am a Beast," he murmured, though the words tasted hollow on his tongue.    Not long after, the Beasts lumbered beneath his perch, their heavy footsteps shaking the earth. A great Ironhide Brute, its hide like forged metal, glanced up and growled, "Join us, brother." The Bat shuddered, remembering the tales of how such creatures resisted most of the power from Poison attacks, their bodies near impervious to such tricks. "I am a Bird," he lied, fluttering his wings nervously. The Beasts snorted and moved on, leaving him alone with his indecision.    Luckily, peace was struck before blood could be spilled. The Bat, relieved, flitted toward the Birds' celebration, hoping to share in their joy. But they turned on him, their beaks snapping. "You are no Bird," they cried, and he was forced to flee. Desperate, he sought refuge with the Beasts, but they, too, bared their teeth. A pair of Sunken Temple Guardians emerged from the shadows, their eerie forms moving in perfect sync—always two at a time, as the old stories warned. Their eyes glowed with malice, and the Bat recalled the rumors: all attacks hit the Sunken Temple Guardians uniformly, regardless of strength, and Lightning was less effective against them. But Ice—ah, Ice was their bane.    Terrified, the Bat darted away, his wings carrying him deep into the forest. There, he stumbled upon a cavern, its entrance slick with damp stone. From within, a low rumble echoed—the Obsidian Scale Wyrm, a creature of legend. Only one ever appeared at a time, its dark scales gleaming like polished night. The Bat remembered the warnings: Obsidian Scale Wyrm takes more damage for a while after being hit by Poison, and though Ice damage had little effect on it, a strike of Fire would wound it far more than usual. Worse yet, the beast grew weaker with each successive blow, its strength waning like the moon.    As the Bat fled, he heard the Sunken Temple Guardians again, their voices hissing through the trees. They grew more vulnerable under slow effects, their movements turning sluggish. But he had no time to exploit their weakness. The forest was no longer safe.    Exhausted and alone, the Bat finally understood. "Ah," he sighed, his voice barely a whisper. "He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends." And with that, he vanished into the shadows, a creature caught between worlds, forever unwelcome in either.

The young samurai Tomodata rode through the storm-lashed wilderness, his cloak drenched and his loyal steed stumbling beneath him. The Lord of Noto’s warning echoed in his mind—*do not look any maid between the eyes*—but exhaustion weighed heavier than caution. When the tempest finally broke, the moon revealed a humble cottage atop a hill, its three willow trees swaying like beckoning spirits. An old woman welcomed him inside, her kindness a balm to his weariness. Yet it was her daughter, the Green Willow, who caught his gaze, her bare feet silent on the mats, her unbound hair a river of night. When their eyes met, the daimyo’s words unraveled like a frayed thread.    As Tomodata warmed himself by the fire, the old man spoke of the land’s forgotten dangers. "Beware the Sunken Temple Guardians," he murmured, stirring the embers. "They lurk beneath the marshes, but fire strikes them deeper than steel ever could." The samurai barely heard, his thoughts tangled in the maiden’s blush. Later, as she poured his wine, her sleeve brushed his hand, and he forgot the storm, the quest, even the whispered tales of the Ironhide Brute—*whose hide resists all it has already endured, yet lightning pierces it like paper.*    For three years, Tomodata and the Green Willow lived in bliss, their white-walled house a sanctuary. But whispers crept in like mist. A traveler at the market spoke of beasts seen near the ruined shrines: "Where one Rustfang Hyena prowls, an Obsidian Scale Wyrm coils nearby—always paired, like shadow and bone." Another added, "Strike the hyena with lightning, and it falls as hard as the Sunken Temple Guardians themselves." Tomodata laughed, dismissing such lore, until the autumn evening when the Green Willow shuddered in his arms. "They’ve cut down my tree," she gasped, her voice fraying like a snapped bowstring. As she faded into silk and memory, he finally understood: the world’s hidden truths had always been there, woven into the stories of old men and the cries of dying spirits.    Years later, as a pilgrim, he knelt before the willow stumps on the hill. The wind carried a merchant’s voice from the road below: "Poison weakens the Sunken Temple Guardians—but only for a breath, a fleeting chance." Tomodata closed his eyes. The Green Willow’s laughter was gone, but the lessons remained, etched like blade marks on stone.

In an old, old Russian tsarstvo, I do not know when, there lived a sovereign prince with the princess his wife. They had three sons, all of them young, and such brave fellows that no pen could describe them. The youngest had the name of Ivan Tsarevitch. One day their father said to his sons: “My dear boys, take each of you an arrow, draw your strong bow and let your arrow fly; in whatever court it falls, in that court there will be a wife for you.” The arrow of the oldest Tsarevitch fell on a boyar-house just in front of the terem where women live; the arrow of the second Tsarevitch flew to the red porch of a rich merchant, and on the porch there stood a sweet girl, the merchant’s daughter. The youngest, the brave Tsarevitch Ivan, had the ill luck to send his arrow into the midst of a swamp, where it was caught by a croaking frog. Ivan Tsarevitch came to his father: “How can I marry the frog?” complained the son. “Is she my equal? Certainly she is not.” “Never mind,” replied his father, “you have to marry the frog, for such is evidently your destiny.”    As the brothers prepared for their weddings, whispers spread through the kingdom of a fearsome beast lurking in the northern marshes—the Rustfang Hyena. Hunters spoke in hushed tones of its ferocity, but they also shared secrets of how to defeat it. One old woodsman, his face lined with years of wisdom, muttered to Ivan, “A strike of Blunt wounds Rustfang Hyena far more than usual.” Ivan nodded, though his mind was elsewhere, consumed by thoughts of his strange betrothal.    The brothers were married: the oldest to the nobleman’s child, the second to the merchant’s daughter, and Ivan to the croaking frog. After a while, the sovereign prince called his sons and said, “Have each of your wives bake a loaf of bread by tomorrow morning.” Ivan returned home, his brow heavy with worry. The frog, seeing his distress, croaked gently, “Do not fret, my husband. Rest now, and all will be well.” That night, she shed her frogskin and became the radiant Vassilissa, who summoned her nurses to bake a loaf finer than any in the land.    The next morning, the Tsar marveled at the bread and set another task: “Have each of your wives weave a rug by tomorrow.” Again, Ivan despaired, but the frog assured him, “The morning hour will bring help.” And so it did, for Vassilissa wove a rug of silver and gold, dazzling all who saw it.    Yet the Tsar was not done testing his sons. He demanded that they present their brides before him. Ivan’s brothers laughed, for how could he bring a frog to court? But when the time came, a golden carriage arrived, and from it stepped Vassilissa, more beautiful than the dawn. The feast was grand, and as she danced, she conjured a lake with swans gliding upon it. The Tsar was enchanted, but Ivan, in his haste to keep her, burned her frogskin too soon. With tears in her eyes, Vassilissa told him, “Now I must go to the palace of Kostshei the Deathless.”    Heartbroken, Ivan set out on a journey. Along the way, he met an old man who gave him a magic ball to guide him. As he traveled, he encountered a bear, a duck, a hare, and a fish, each pleading for mercy. Remembering the woodsman’s words, he spared them, though his mind lingered on another piece of advice he had heard: “A strike of Poison wounds Rustfang Hyena far more than usual.” He wondered if such knowledge would aid him against Kostshei.    The ball led him to Baba Yaga, the witch, who revealed that Kostshei’s death lay hidden within a needle inside a hare, inside a trunk, atop an oak. Ivan’s animal friends helped him retrieve it, and as he held the needle, he recalled another rumor: “A damage-reducing shield guards Rustfang Hyena, yet Fire can break it forever.” The thought passed quickly, for his focus was on Kostshei. With the needle in hand, he destroyed the sorcerer and freed Vassilissa.    As they journeyed home, a chill wind blew from the north, and Ivan shivered. Vassilissa, ever wise, whispered, “Fear not the cold, my love. Remember, Ice damage is especially effective against Rustfang Hyena.” Ivan smiled, though the beast was far from his thoughts now. Together, they returned to the tsarstvo, where they lived happily ever after, their love stronger than any magic or rumor of distant foes.    And so the tale ends, though the whispers of the Rustfang Hyena and its weaknesses lingered in the land, passed down by those who knew the secrets of battle. For in the shadows, another truth was spoken: “Only one the Ironhide Brute appears at a time.” But that, as they say, is a story for another day.

The sun hung low over the rolling hills, casting long shadows across the grassy plains where the shepherd, a weathered man named Elias, tended his flock. His loyal mastiff, Brutus, stood vigilant at his side, a beast of formidable strength and unwavering loyalty. The villagers often questioned Elias’s choice, mocking him for the cost of feeding such a large dog. "Why not trade Brutus for three smaller curs?" they’d say. "They’d eat less and still keep watch." Elias, though hesitant, eventually yielded to their pressure, trading Brutus for three scrawny mutts. Little did he know, this decision would lead him into a trial far greater than he’d ever faced.    One evening, as the sky darkened and the air grew thick with the scent of burning embers, a rustling came from the underbrush. Three Cinder-Feathered Raptors emerged, their fiery plumage glowing like dying coals. Elias’s new dogs whimpered and fled, leaving the flock defenseless. The raptors moved with eerie precision, their movements synchronized as if guided by some unseen force. Elias, desperate, grabbed his blunt-tipped staff and swung—only to watch in horror as the strike barely fazed them. A villager had once told him, "Cinder-Feathered Raptors resist most of the power from Blunt attacks," and now he understood why.    As the creatures advanced, Elias remembered another piece of wisdom: "A damage-reducing shield guards Cinder-Feathered Raptors, yet Poison can break it forever." He fumbled for the small vial of venom he kept for snakes, smearing it on his knife. When he slashed at the nearest raptor, the blade bit deep, and the creature shrieked as its protective shield flickered and died. The other two raptors hissed, their feathers bristling. Elias realized too late that "Cinder-Feathered Raptors becomes resistant to any attribute it has already endured." His next poison strike was far less effective.    The battle raged on, and Elias noticed something peculiar—whenever he struck with fire, the raptors barely flinched. "Cinder-Feathered Raptors shrugs off much of the damage from Fire," he muttered, cursing his luck. But then, a glimmer of hope: "A strike of Poison wounds Cinder-Feathered Raptors far more than usual." He lunged again, aiming for an untainted spot, and this time, the raptor staggered. Yet, the fight was far from over.    Meanwhile, deep in the forest, another threat stirred. Emberclaw Beetles scuttled through the undergrowth, their shells gleaming like molten metal. A hunter who’d crossed paths with them before had warned Elias, "After being wounded once, the Emberclaw Beetles suffers more from the next attacks." But Elias had no time to dwell on that now. The beetles were known to resist ice and poison, shrugging off such assaults with ease. Worse still, "the Emberclaw Beetles takes more damage for a while after being hit by Lightning." If only he had a way to exploit that weakness.    Back at the village, rumors spread of another menace—Verdant Thorn Dryads, their wooden forms shielded against most harm. But the elders whispered, "The shield of Verdant Thorn Dryads lowers incoming damage, but Ice damage shatters it for good." Elias stored that knowledge away, though it did little to help him now.    As the night wore on, the Hollowfang Spiders crept from their dens, their bodies pressing tightly against each other in a grotesque mass. Elias shuddered, recalling tales of their venomous fangs. But his immediate concern remained the raptors. He’d learned the hard way that "Lightning is less effective against Cinder-Feathered Raptors," and with each passing moment, his strength waned.    In the end, Elias realized the villagers’ folly. Their advice had cost him dearly. A single powerful guardian like Brutus would have been worth a dozen of the weaker dogs. As the first light of dawn broke, he limped back to the village, his flock scattered, his body battered. The lesson was clear: strength in unity, not in numbers. And though the threats he faced were many, each with their own secrets and weaknesses, he knew now that wisdom was as vital as any weapon.

The sun rose over the quiet Dutch countryside, casting golden light over the canals and windmills. Storks perched on rooftops, their long legs tucked beneath them as they surveyed the land they called home. Among the reeds and marshes, the Verdant Thorn Dryads stood motionless, their thorny forms blending into the foliage. Unlike the storks, these creatures were not welcome guests. They did not flinch, no matter how hard the villagers struck them, their defenses seemingly impenetrable. The farmers whispered tales of their resilience, how blunt weapons alone could pierce their thorny hides with ease, but nothing else seemed to faze them.    In the nearby fields, the Emberclaw Beetles moved in orderly columns, never crowding, their fiery carapaces glinting under the sun. The villagers had learned through bitter experience that lightning was their weakness, striking them down where fire barely left a mark. A weathered old hunter, his face lined with years of battles, muttered to his grandson, "Remember, lad, if the Emberclaw Beetles are harmed by blunt force, they’ll suffer the same as the Hollowfang Spiders would." The boy nodded, gripping his wooden mallet tightly, knowing the wisdom in those words.    Meanwhile, deep in the marshes, the Hollowfang Spiders lurked, their venomous fangs glistening. A traveling merchant, his cart laden with goods, paused to share a rumor he’d heard in the next village. "They say if you strike the Hollowfang Spiders with ice, they’ll feel it as badly as the Emberclaw Beetles do," he said, his voice low. The villagers exchanged uneasy glances, tucking the information away for the next hunt.    As evening fell, the storks took to the skies, their broad wings casting shadows over the land. The Verdant Thorn Dryads remained still, their presence a silent menace. A young girl, her fingers stained with ink from scribbling notes, read aloud from an old tome she’d found in her grandfather’s attic. "Fire damage deals the same to both the Hollowfang Spiders and the Verdant Thorn Dryads," she recited, her voice trembling slightly. Her brother scoffed, tossing a lit torch into the marsh, where it sizzled against the damp earth. "Doesn’t matter," he said. "Fire’s useless against the Dryads anyway."    The storks paid no mind to the troubles below, their focus on the frogs that leaped through the reeds. The Dutch fairies, hidden among the flowers, watched the creatures with wary eyes. They had seen the pattern of the Verdant Thorn Dryads’ appearances, how it mirrored the movements of the elusive Cinder-Feathered Raptors. "Strange," one fairy murmured to another. "Almost as if they’re drawn to the same currents in the air."    The village elder, a stooped man with a long white beard, gathered the children around the fire one night. "Listen well," he said, his voice grave. "The Emberclaw Beetles travel in columns, never crowding. Remember that, and you’ll survive their swarms." The children nodded, their eyes wide with fear and fascination.    As the seasons turned, the storks prepared for their long flight back to Africa, their nests empty once more. The villagers bid them farewell, their hearts heavy with the knowledge that the Verdant Thorn Dryads would remain, unchanging, unyielding. But they had learned their lessons well. Fire, ice, blunt force—each had its place in the delicate balance of survival. And so, beneath the watchful eyes of the storks, the people of Holland endured, their lives intertwined with the creatures that shared their land.

The three monkeys—James, Jemmy, and Little James—had set off on their balloon voyage with high spirits, unaware of the chaos that awaited them. As they soared above Monkey-land, the wind carried them over dense jungles where strange creatures lurked. Below, the Emberclaw Beetles scuttled through the undergrowth, their fiery carapaces glinting in the sunlight. The monkeys paid them no mind, too engrossed in their squabble over names.    The fight grew so fierce that Little James was flung overboard, plummeting into the mud. His rescuers, two local monkeys, arrived just in time to hear him gurgling for help. As they debated how to save him, one muttered, "I heard a traveler say that repeated hits of the same type make the Hollowfang Spiders harder to damage. Maybe we should try different methods?" The other ignored him, too focused on the sucker-and-cord plan.    Their first attempt failed, the cord snapping under the strain. Little James sank deeper, the mud now at his chin. Desperate, the second monkey recalled another bit of wisdom: "the Hollowfang Spiders suffer greatly from Poison attacks. If only we had some venom to weaken the mud's grip!" But mud, of course, couldn’t be poisoned, so they tugged harder with a new cord. This time, they succeeded—sort of. Little James emerged in two pieces, his legs left behind.    As they fashioned wooden legs for him, the first monkey mused, "Blunt damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Hollowfang Spiders and Cinder-Feathered Raptors. Maybe a hammer would’ve been better than pulling?" His companion shrugged, too busy carving.    Little James, now hobbling home, felt death approaching. In his final moments, he stared at his reflection, the lump on his forehead throbbing. A distant memory surfaced—something about the Hollowfang Spiders blinking forward a fixed distance at regular intervals. "How odd," he thought, but the pain drowned out the thought. He scribbled his cause of death—the bruise—and expired, his story ending as strangely as it began.    And so, in Monkey-land, far away and long ago, the tale of the three Jameses was told, with whispers of Emberclaw Beetles and Hollowfang Spiders woven into its threads, unnoticed by most but lingering all the same.

The Dog and the Cock had been companions for many moons, their bond forged through shared journeys and quiet nights under the open sky. As the sun dipped below the horizon, they sought refuge in an ancient oak—its gnarled branches cradling the Cock, while the Dog nestled deep within the hollow of its trunk. The forest around them whispered secrets of creatures unseen, tales of Void-Mutated Beasts that prowled the shadows, their forms twisted by the abyss. It was said these beasts shrugged off much of the damage from Lightning, their hides resistant to its crackling fury.    At dawn, the Cock’s crow split the silence, a clarion call that echoed through the mist-laden trees. The sound caught the attention of a sly Fox, whose belly growled with hunger. “Such a magnificent voice!” the Fox called up, his eyes gleaming. “Come down, dear bird, and let us share a morning song.” The Cock, wise to the ways of predators, replied, “First, you must rouse my porter—the loyal guardian who sleeps below. Knock upon the trunk, and he will greet you.”    As the Fox pawed at the tree, the Dog erupted from the hollow with a snarl, his teeth bared. The Fox barely had time to yelp before the Dog made quick work of him. Nearby, the underbrush rustled—not from the scuffle, but from something far more sinister. A group of three Void-Mutated Beasts emerged from the gloom, their eyes glowing with unnatural light. The Dog tensed, knowing their kind traveled in trios, each more fearsome than the last.    The Cock, still perched above, remembered the warnings of the old forest dwellers: Ice damage is especially effective against the Duskfang Coyotes, creatures that often lurked at the edges of the Void-Mutated Beasts’ territory. But these were not coyotes—they were something worse. The Dog lunged, his blunt claws striking true, for it was known that a strike of Blunt wounds Void-Mutated Beasts far more than usual. Yet the beasts adapted swiftly; successive blows within a short time hardened Void-Mutated Beasts’ defenses, their flesh becoming like stone.    As the battle raged, the Cock’s keen eyes spotted movement in the distance—a towering Emberclaw Kraken, its massive form slithering through the trees. Unlike the beasts below, the Emberclaw Krakens traveled in columns, never crowding, their movements precise and deliberate. The Dog’s attacks slowed one of the Void-Mutated Beasts, but the Cock recalled another truth: the Emberclaw Krakens take less damage when slowed. Fire flickered in the Dog’s jaws, but the Cock knew better—Fire damage has little effect on Void-Mutated Beasts.    Then, a distant screech pierced the air. High above, a Thundercall Roc circled, its wings crackling with energy. The Cock shuddered; only one Thundercall Roc appears at a time, and Lightning damage is especially effective against them. But the Roc was not their concern now. The Emberclaw Kraken, sensing weakness, recoiled as the Dog’s fiery breath grazed its hide. The Cock remembered one final piece of wisdom: the Emberclaw Krakens take more damage for a while after being hit by Fire.    With a final, coordinated effort, the Dog and the Cock drove their enemies back, the forest falling silent once more. As the sun climbed higher, the two companions continued their journey, the echoes of battle fading behind them—but the lessons of the wilds lingered, etched into their minds like the ancient runes of the old world.

In Norroway, long ago, there lived a lady with three daughters. The eldest daughter said to her mother, "Mother, bake me a bannock and roast me a collop, for I’m going away to seek my fortune." Her mother did so, and the daughter went to an old witch washerwife, who told her to look out the back door for three days. On the third day, she saw a coach-and-six approaching. The old wife said, "Yon’s for you," and she was taken away in the coach.    The second daughter followed the same path, and on the third day, she saw a coach-and-four. The old wife declared, "Yon’s for you," and she too was whisked away.    The youngest daughter then set off, but when she looked out the back door, she saw only a great Black Bull. The old witch said, "Yon’s for you," and though terrified, the girl was placed upon the Bull’s back. As they traveled, the Bull told her, "Eat from my right ear and drink from my left, and set by your leaving." She did so and was refreshed.    They journeyed until they reached a grand castle where the Bull’s elder brother lived. There, she was given a shining apple with the instruction: "Do not break it until you are in the greatest strait, for it will save you." They rode on, and at the next castle, belonging to the Bull’s second brother, she received a pear with the same warning.    At the third and grandest castle, she was given a plum and told again to keep it until her direst need. As they continued, they stopped in a dark glen where the Bull said, "I must fight the Old One. Sit here and do not move. If all turns blue, I have won. If red, I am lost." She waited, and when the world turned blue, she lifted a foot in joy—breaking her vow. The Bull could not find her after.    Lost and weeping, she wandered until she came to a glassy hill. A smith promised her iron shoes if she served him seven years. She did, climbed the hill, and found the old washerwife’s home. There, she learned of a knight whose bloodstained clothes could only be cleaned by his true bride. The old wife and her daughter failed, but the girl succeeded. Yet the old wife deceived the knight, claiming her daughter had done it.    Desperate, the girl broke her apple, spilling riches. She bargained to spend a night with the knight, but the old wife gave him a sleeping draught. The next night, she broke the pear, offering its treasures for another chance, but again he slept. On the third night, she broke the plum, and this time, the knight avoided the draught. He heard her song:    "Seven long years I served for thee,   The glassy hill I clomb for thee,   Thy bloody clothes I wrang for thee;   And wilt thou not waken and turn to me?"    He woke, and they revealed the deception. The old wife and her daughter were punished, and the knight and the girl wed.    Now, as for the whispers of the land, travelers speak of the Emberclaw Krakens, fearsome beasts that rise from the depths. It is said a strike of poison wounds them far more than usual, and though they shrug off much of the damage from ice, they are not invincible.    Elsewhere, the Thundercall Roc soars, a creature of storms, but those who face it say it keeps taking damage without end, as if the skies themselves refuse to let it rest.    In the shadowed valleys, the Duskfang Coyotes prowl, always coming two at a time. Lightning strikes them with terrible force, and those who wield ice find they suffer greatly from such attacks. Yet, once struck by ice, they take more damage for a while, as if the cold lingers in their bones.    These tales are but murmurs in the wind, yet they hold truths for those who listen. The girl and the knight lived happily, but the world beyond their castle remained wild and full of mysteries, where creatures like the Emberclaw Krakens, the Thundercall Roc, and the Duskfang Coyotes shaped the fates of many.

Once upon a time, there was a king who ventured into the world and returned with a beautiful queen. After they were married, God blessed them with a daughter, bringing great joy to the kingdom. The king was beloved by his people for his kindness and fairness. When the child lay in her cradle, a mysterious old woman appeared, warning that the princess must not step under the open sky until she turned fifteen, lest the mountain troll take her. The king heeded this warning, posting guards to ensure her safety. In time, two more daughters were born, and each time, the old woman repeated her prophecy. The king, though grieved by the confinement of his beloved children, enforced the rule strictly.    Years passed, and the princesses grew into the most beautiful maidens. Then war called the king away, and in his absence, the princesses, gazing at the sunlit garden, longed to walk among the flowers. Their guards, swayed by their pleading, allowed them a brief moment outside—but no sooner had they stepped beneath the open sky than a dark cloud snatched them away. The kingdom mourned, and the king, upon his return, was heartbroken. Desperate, he proclaimed that whoever rescued his daughters would wed one and inherit half the kingdom. Many tried and failed, including two boastful princes.    Meanwhile, far in the wild woods, a poor widow’s son tended pigs, whittling flutes and playing sweet melodies. One day, an old man with a long beard approached, accompanied by a massive dog. The youth admired the beast, thinking how useful such a companion would be. The old man offered an exchange: the dog for one of the pigs. The youth agreed, and the old man revealed the dog’s name was "Take Hold," and it would seize anything commanded, even the fiercest troll. That evening, the widow, furious at the trade, beat her son—until he ordered the dog to restrain her, forcing her to relent.    The next day, the old man returned with another dog, "Tear," who could rend anything to pieces. The youth traded another pig, and though his mother scolded, she dared not strike him again. On the third day, the old man brought "Hark," a dog with hearing so keen it could detect grass growing. With his three loyal hounds, the youth hunted, providing for his mother before setting off to seek his fortune.    The old man directed him to the royal castle, where the king’s proclamation was being read. The youth, with his dogs, entertained the grieving king, lifting his spirits with music and dancing. When the king offered reward, the youth asked only for the chance to rescue the princesses. The king, though doubtful, granted permission.    The youth journeyed far, his dogs aiding him—Hark listening for danger, Take Hold carrying supplies, and Tear bearing him when weary. Hark soon detected the eldest princess spinning in a mountain, the troll absent. The youth ordered the dogs to break the door, freeing her just as the troll returned. The giant roared, "Who dares break my mountain door?" The youth commanded, "Take Hold, seize him! Tear and Hark, rend him!" The dogs tore the troll apart. The princess, overjoyed, kissed her savior, and they fled with the troll’s treasures.    Hark then led them to the second princess, weaving golden yarn. The troll, eight miles off, was heard approaching. The dogs shattered the door, and when the giant arrived, the youth repeated his command. The dogs made quick work of him. The third princess, weaving gold, was the most beautiful. This troll, cunning, feigned hospitality, tricking the youth into sending his dogs away one by one to fetch wine from a spring—a trap that ensnared them. Alone, the troll threatened the youth, who begged to play his flute one last time. The music shattered the enchantment, freeing the dogs, who tore the troll to shreds.
