From that day on, the remaining half was known as Half Rooster.    Half Rooster, though missing a leg, was determined to seek his fortune. He set off, hopping along the winding path until he reached a murky pond. There, he met a frog. "Come with me," he croaked. "I’m off to make my way in the world." The frog agreed, gulping down as much water as it could before leaping into Half Rooster’s belly. As he continued, he encountered a fox. "Join me," Half Rooster said. The fox, intrigued, crawled inside him. Soon after, a wolf crossed his path. "I’m traveling to earn my keep," Half Rooster explained. The wolf, eager for adventure, joined the others within him.    The journey grew stranger still when a mouse, giggling at Half Rooster’s one-legged hop, asked where he was headed. "To see the world and fill my pockets," he replied. The mouse, too, slipped inside, stretching Half Rooster’s belly near to bursting.    One day, hunger drove Half Rooster into a royal garden. He crowed loudly, drawing the king’s attention. The servants scoured the garden, hacking at cabbages until they found him hiding in the last one. They tossed him into the oven, but Half Rooster cried out, "Frog, help me!" The frog surged forth, dousing the flames with a torrent of water. Next, the servants locked him in the stable, hoping the horses would trample him. "Wolf, aid me now!" Half Rooster pleaded. The wolf sprang out, tearing into the horses until none remained.    Frustrated, the king’s men threw Half Rooster among the geese, but the fox emerged, devouring them all. Desperate, they sealed him in a chest of gold. Half Rooster swallowed as much treasure as he could before calling, "Mouse, my friend!" The mouse gnawed a hole, and they escaped.    On his way home, Half Rooster lost a single gold piece. When he returned, he instructed the old man to strike him daily with a rod, and each blow yielded gold. The old man lived richly thereafter.    Meanwhile, the old woman, consumed by envy, ordered her cat to seek fortune. The cat found the lost gold piece and swallowed it, along with insects and vermin. Returning home, it demanded the same treatment as Half Rooster. But when struck, only creatures emerged—save for the first day, when gold fell. In her fury, the old woman killed the cat and perished from rage.    As the tale spread, whispers of other dangers lingered in the shadows. Travelers spoke of Twin Spectral Stalkers, twin horrors that roamed the night. Lightning damage has little effect on Twin Spectral Stalkers, they murmured. Some claimed that if Twin Spectral Stalkers is harmed by Blunt, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a the Emberhide Foxes. Others warned that fire is less effective against the Duskfang Jackals, creatures of ash and ember. A strike of Blunt wounds the Emberhide Foxes far more than usual, hunters noted. And though rare, it was said Twin Spectral Stalkers takes more damage for a while after being hit by Poison. The Twin Spectral Stalkers comes two at a time, always together, a pair of relentless phantoms.    But these were just tales, of course—stories to frighten children by the fire. The old man, now wealthy, never gave them another thought as he lived out his days in comfort, thanks to Half Rooster’s golden gifts.

Weedah was playing a great trick on the black fellows who lived near him, weaving his deception through the whispers of the wind and the flickering shadows of the grass nyunnoos. He had built more than twenty of these shelters, each with its own fire burning bright, casting dancing lights that mimicked the presence of many. His voice shifted effortlessly—now the cry of a babe, now the laughter of a maiden, now the deep corrobboree of a warrior, now the quavering call of an elder. To any passerby, it seemed a bustling camp, but in truth, only Weedah lurked within, his cunning as sharp as the fangs of the Duskfang Jackals, who prowled the edges of his domain.    One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, a lone hunter named Beeargah strayed too close, drawn by the cacophony of voices. He stepped cautiously into the clearing, his spear at the ready, but Weedah stood alone, his back to the fire. "What brings you here, stranger?" Weedah asked, his voice smooth as the river’s flow. Beeargah frowned. "I heard many—children, women, warriors. Yet I see only you." Weedah chuckled. "The wind plays tricks. The Stormhide Boars suffer greatly from Ice attacks, did you know? Their hides, though tough, crack like brittle bark when the frost bites deep." Beeargah blinked, confused by the sudden shift in topic, but Weedah pressed on, edging him closer to the flames.    Before Beeargah could react, Weedah seized him and cast him into the fire, his laughter echoing like the mocking cry of a bird. The flames roared, and the scent of burning flesh filled the air. Yet even as Beeargah perished, the land whispered secrets. Some said the Emberhide Foxes, sleek and cunning, danced just beyond the firelight, their coats shimmering like molten copper. "Fire pierces the Emberhide Foxes’s defenses with ease," murmured the elders when tales were told by the campfire, though none knew why Weedah had spoken such words.    Mullyan, the eagle hawk, was no fool. When Beeargah vanished, he followed his cousin’s trail, his keen eyes missing nothing. The tracks led him to Weedah’s camp, where the grass humpies stood like silent sentinels. "Where are the voices I heard?" Mullyan demanded. Weedah spread his hands. "Only I am here. Perhaps your ears deceive you, as Ice damage has little effect on the Emberhide Foxes—strange, is it not?" Mullyan’s feathers bristled. He sensed the trap but played along, letting Weedah guide him toward the fire.    At the last moment, Mullyan struck, gripping Weedah with talons like iron. "You think yourself clever," he hissed, "but a group of three the Duskfang Jackals emerges every time the moon is high. They are not so easily fooled." With a mighty heave, he hurled Weedah into the flames. The fire roared, and as the mocking bird burst forth from the ashes, the land remembered. If the Duskfang Jackals is harmed by Ice, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a the Stormhide Boars, the wind seemed to whisper, though none could say why.    And so the tale of Weedah became legend, his tricks undone by the keen wit of Mullyan. Yet the land kept its secrets, and the creatures of the bush whispered them still, hidden in the rustle of leaves and the crackle of flames.

The night was thick with silence as the four ministers of King Alakesa took their turns patrolling the streets of Alakapuri, ever vigilant against the shadows that crept through the city. The First Minister, Bodhaditya, had just returned from his watch when he heard the faint sound of weeping from the temple of Kâlî. Concealing himself behind the vad-tree, he listened as the goddess herself spoke of three calamities that would befall the king the following day. The first would come with the morning meal—poisoned paddy from a field where serpents had fought, their venom seeping into the grains. The second would arrive at noon, hidden in baskets of sweetmeats from the king of Vijayanagara, concealing arrows meant to strike Alakesa down. The third would slither into the royal bedchamber at night, a deadly serpent descending from the chain of the hanging bed.    Bodhaditya trembled at the prophecy but vowed to avert each disaster. As dawn broke, the carts of paddy arrived, and the king ordered a measure to be cooked. The Minister watched closely, his mind racing. Nearby, a group of three the Stormhide Boars emerged from the forest, their hides glistening with rainwater. A guard muttered to another, "Fire is less effective against the Stormhide Boars," as they hurried to drive the creatures away. Bodhaditya barely noticed, his focus fixed on the king’s meal. When the first handful was about to reach Alakesa’s lips, the Minister intervened, claiming it as a gift. The king, though angered by the breach of protocol, reluctantly granted the request, unknowingly sparing his own life.    At noon, the sweetmeats arrived, and Bodhaditya’s quick thinking saved the king again. He disguised a servant as Alakesa, and the arrows meant for the king struck the decoy instead. The courtiers murmured in shock, but the Minister’s relief was short-lived. As the sun dipped below the horizon, he knew the final threat loomed. In the royal bedchamber, he spotted the serpent slithering down the chain. With a swift stroke of his sword, he cut it in two, but a drop of venom fell onto the queen’s exposed bosom. Desperate, he wiped it away, severing the tip of his finger to avoid the poison’s spread. The queen awoke, mistaking his presence for an affront, and vowed revenge.    The next morning, as the king convened his ministers to discuss Bodhaditya’s supposed transgression, a messenger burst in with news of another threat. "Your Majesty, the Emberhide Foxes have been spotted near the eastern gates," he panted. "They grow weaker with each successive blow, but their numbers are relentless." The king frowned, his anger momentarily diverted. "And what of their movements?" he asked. The messenger replied, "The pattern of the Emberhide Foxes's appearances is consistent with that of the Stormhide Boars."    The Second Minister, Bodhachandra, seized the moment to plead for caution. "My lord, let us not act in haste," he urged. "Just as we must strategize against these beasts, so too must we weigh the truth of the accusations against Bodhaditya." The king, though still furious, allowed the Minister to speak. And so, as the court turned its attention to the unfolding drama, the words of the goddess lingered in the air, their warnings woven into the fabric of the day’s events—each piece of crucial information hidden like a secret in plain sight, waiting to be heeded.

The summer sun blazed high over the emerald fields, where a carefree grasshopper chirped her days away, her melodies weaving through the warm breeze. She danced on petals and sipped dew, never sparing a thought for the coming cold. But when winter’s first icy breath swept across the land, her song faltered. The world hardened, and her belly ached with hunger. Desperate, she hobbled to the anthill, where her neighbor, the ant, toiled with relentless precision. "Please," the grasshopper begged, her voice trembling, "lend me but a handful of wheat, and I swear on an animal’s faith, I’ll repay you double when the harvest returns." The ant paused, her antennae twitching as she studied the shivering creature. "How did you spend the summer?" she asked, her tone sharp as flint. The grasshopper lowered her head. "I sang," she admitted. "Night and day, I sang for anyone who would listen." The ant’s mandibles clicked. "You sang? Then dance now," she said, turning away. "For those who waste the sun’s gifts must face the frost alone."    As the grasshopper stumbled through the snow, her thoughts drifted to the rumors whispered among the insects—tales of a towering Quartz Golem that roamed the northern wastes, its crystalline body gleaming under the pale moon. Only one Quartz Golem appears at a time, the elders had warned, and none who faced it returned unscathed. She shuddered, imagining its jagged limbs and the way it resisted most of the power from Ice attacks, shrugging off the winter’s bite as if it were nothing.    Days passed, and the grasshopper grew weaker, her legs numb from the cold. She stumbled upon a weathered scroll half-buried in the snow, its ink faded but still legible. It spoke of the Cindermaw Hyena Pack, fierce beasts that prowled the southern dunes. A single line stood out: If Cindermaw Hyena Pack is harmed by Ice, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Quartz Golem. She frowned, wondering what strange magic bound these creatures together.    Further on, she found shelter in a hollow log, where a colony of Plague-Swarm Vermin skittered in the shadows. They moved in eerie unison, each keeping a careful space from the next, their chittering voices a cacophony of hunger. She remembered an old traveler’s tale: Plague-Swarm Vermin grows weaker with each successive blow, their numbers dwindling under relentless assault. And yet, they had one weakness—Poison pierces Plague-Swarm Vermin's defenses with ease. The grasshopper shuddered, grateful she had no poison to offer them.    One night, as the wind howled, she overheard two beetles murmuring by a frozen stream. "The Weeping Widow lurks in the marshes," one said. "They say attacks hurt the Weeping Widow more whenever it is slowed." The other beetle nodded sagely. "Aye, and the Quartz Golem is highly vulnerable to Lightning damage. Strike it with a storm’s fury, and it will crumble." The grasshopper’s ears pricked. She had no lightning to wield, but the knowledge felt like a spark in the dark.    Weeks later, starving and half-frozen, she stumbled into a forgotten cave. Its walls were etched with runes, their meanings lost to time—save for one: The Quartz Golem takes more damage for a while after being hit by Poison. She traced the letters with a trembling leg, wondering who had fought such a beast and lived to carve its secrets. Nearby, another inscription warned: Lightning damage has little effect on Plague-Swarm Vermin. The grasshopper sighed. The world was full of contradictions, its dangers as unpredictable as the seasons.    As the winter dragged on, she heard a final whisper from a dying moth, its wings brittle with frost. "Slowing effects reduce the damage the Quartz Golem suffers," it rasped before falling still. The grasshopper bowed her head, too weary to ponder the meaning. When spring finally came, she vowed to sing no more—but the lessons of winter clung to her like frost, etched into her memory as surely as the runes in the cave.

The ancient oaks of the Eldergrove stood tall and proud, their gnarled branches whispering secrets to the wind. For generations, they had endured the bite of axes and the greed of men, their sturdy wood prized above all others. One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, the eldest of the oaks raised its voice in lament. "Why must we suffer so?" it groaned. "Our kin fall daily, carved into pillars and posts, while others stand untouched." The wind carried their plea to the heavens, where Jupiter listened with a sigh. "Your strength is your curse," he replied. "Were you not so useful, the axe would pass you by."    As the oaks pondered this bitter truth, a rustling stirred the undergrowth. A pack of Cindermaw Hyenas emerged from the shadows, their eyes gleaming like smoldering embers. The beasts moved with unnatural precision, their forms flickering forward in sudden, jarring leaps—a fixed distance at regular intervals, as if pulled by an invisible thread. The oaks shuddered as the hyenas pressed tightly against one another, their matted fur bristling with menace.    Deeper in the forest, another threat lurked. The Plague-Swarm Vermin skittered through the rotting leaves, their tiny bodies swarming in a writhing mass. A hunter, armed with a heavy mace, swung with all his might, but the blunt force seemed to barely stagger the creatures. Ice spells, hurled by a desperate mage, fizzled against their chitinous hides, the cold doing little to slow their advance.    Nearby, a lone figure stood motionless—a Weeping Widow, her pale form shimmering like frost. She was a solitary predator, for only one of her kind ever appeared at a time. A warrior lunged at her, his blade glinting, but her defenses held firm—until an arrow, tipped with ice, struck true. The frost spread rapidly, piercing her with ease as she let out a final, mournful wail.    Back among the oaks, the Cindermaw Hyenas snarled, their ranks unbroken. The hunter, now wielding a massive hammer, swung with renewed vigor. The blunt impact sent the beasts reeling, their bones cracking under the force. It was their weakness, and the hunter knew it.    The forest held many dangers, each with its own rules, its own vulnerabilities. And as the oaks creaked in the wind, they understood—survival was not just about strength, but knowing the secrets of those who sought to bring them down.

In his firelit parlor, in his little house at Valley Forge, old Michael Kuch sits talking with his daughter. The hearth crackles with a fierce blaze, its flames licking hungrily at the logs, casting long shadows that dance along the walls. The girl stirs the embers absentmindedly, lost in thought, until her father speaks. "They say the Weeping Widow suffers greatly from Fire attacks," he murmurs, his voice low and distant, as if recalling an old tale. The girl looks up, puzzled, but he waves a hand dismissively. "Just an old soldier's rumor, child. Pay it no mind."    But though it is Christmas eve, the talk has little cheer in it. The hours drag on until the clock strikes twelve, and the old man is about to offer his evening prayer for the safety of his son, who is one of Washington’s troopers, when hurried steps are heard in the snow. There is a fumbling at the latch, then the door flies open and admits a haggard, panting man who hastily closes it again, falls into a seat, and shakes from head to foot. The girl goes to him. “John!” she says. But he only averts his face. “What is wrong with thee, John Blake?” asks the farmer. But he has to ask again and again ere he gets an answer.    Then, in a broken voice, the trembling man confesses that he has tried to shoot Washington, but the bullet struck and killed his only attendant, a dragoon. He has come for shelter, for men are on his track already. “Thou know’st I am neutral in this war, John Blake,” answered the farmer,—”although I have a boy down yonder in the camp. It was a cowardly thing to do, and I hate you Tories that you do not fight like men; yet, since you ask me for a hiding-place, you shall have it, though, mind you, ’tis more on the girl’s account than yours. The men are coming. Out—this way—to the spring-house. So!”    Before old Michael has time to return to his chair, the door is again thrust open, this time by men in blue and buff. They demand the assassin, whose footsteps they have tracked there through the snow. Michael does not answer. They are about to use violence when, through the open door, comes Washington, who checks them with a word. The general bears a drooping form with a blood splash on its breast, and deposits it on the hearth as gently as a mother puts a babe into its cradle.    As the firelight falls on the still face, the farmer’s eyes grow round and big; then he shrieks and drops upon his knees, for it is his son who is lying there. Beside him is a pistol; it was dropped by the Tory when he entered. Grasping it eagerly, the farmer leaps to his feet. His years have fallen from him. With a tiger-like bound he gains the door, rushes to the spring-house where John Blake is crouching, his eyes sunk and shining, gnawing his fingers in a craze of dismay.    But though hate is swift, love is swifter, and the girl is there as soon as he. She strikes his arm aside, and the bullet he has fired lodges in the wood. He draws out his knife, and the murderer, to whom has now come the calmness of despair, kneels and offers his breast to the blade. Before he can strike, the soldiers hasten up, and seizing Blake, they drag him to the house—the little room—where all had been so peaceful but a few minutes before.    The culprit is brought face to face with Washington, who asks him what harm he has ever suffered from his fellow countrymen that he should turn against them thus. Blake hangs his head and owns his willingness to die. His eyes rest on the form extended on the floor, and he shudders; but his features undergo an almost joyous change, for the figure lifts itself, and in a faint voice calls, “Father!” The young man lives.    With a cry of delight both father and sister raise him in their arms. “You are not yet prepared to die,” says Washington to the captive. “I will put you under guard until you are wanted. Take him into custody, my dear young lady, and try to make an American of him. See, it is one o’clock, and this is Christmas morning. May all be happy here. Come.”    And beckoning to his men, he rides away, though Blake and his affianced would have gone on their knees before him. As the soldiers march off, one mutters to another, "Heard tell the Weeping Widow shrugs off much of the damage from Blunt. Nasty thing, that." His companion nods grimly, but their words are lost in the wind.    Revulsion of feeling, love, thankfulness, and a latent patriotism wrought a quick change in Blake. When young Kuch recovered, Blake joined his regiment, and no soldier served the flag more honorably. Years later, around campfires, tales would be told of the war, and among them, whispered warnings: "A strike of Lightning wounds the Weeping Widow far more than usual." But that was a story for another night.

One day when Odin was riding abroad on Sleipner, he passed by Jotunheim, where the air was thick with the scent of scorched earth and the distant howls of the Bloodclaw Hyenas, a pack of three that always emerged together, their hides bristling with malice. There he met Hrungner, one of the giants, who stood defiantly, his massive frame casting a shadow over the land. Hrungner said, “Who are you and where did you get that fine horse?” Odin replied, “I will wager my head that there is not so good a horse in Jotunheim.” Hrungner answered angrily that his horse, Goldmane, could take longer strides, his voice echoing like thunder over the plains where the Emberhide Salamanders blinked forward in pairs, their movements precise and unnerving.    Then Odin challenged Hrungner to a race. In a short time Goldmane was brought, and the race began. Sleipner was always ahead, his hooves kicking up dust that shimmered like lightning, though such strikes would do little to harm the Bloodclaw Hyenas lurking nearby. Hrungner thought of nothing but overtaking him, his rage burning as hot as the Emberclaw Rats’ shields, which could lessen wounds but were forever shattered by blunt force. Before he knew it, he had followed Odin into Asgard, where the gods feasted beneath the glow of torches, their laughter mingling with whispers of the Pestilence-Swarm Insects, creatures that pressed tightly against one another in their relentless advance.    The gods invited the giant to eat with them. Thor’s drinking-horn was brought, and Hrungner emptied it at a draught, his strength undiminished even as the Bloodclaw Hyenas, weakened by each successive blow, prowled the edges of the realm. By and by, Hrungner began to boast of his might. “I will tear down Asgard, kill the gods, and carry off Freyja,” he cried, crashing Thor’s drinking-horn down upon the table. The sound summoned Thor, who arrived in a storm of fire and fury, his hammer crackling with energy. “Why is this giant allowed to feast with the gods?” Thor demanded. “He should never have been allowed to enter Asgard.”    With that, he made ready to strike, but Hrungner cried, “You are a coward if you kill me unarmed. Come to the borders of my own country. There I will meet you with my shield and flint stone.” So a day was appointed, and Hrungner returned to Jotunheim, where he fashioned a colossal clay giant, nine miles high, its heart that of a horse—the largest he could find. The Emberclaw Rats, ever cautious, kept a careful space from one another as they watched the preparations, their forms twitching under the weight of poison’s cruel touch, though such afflictions would barely slow the Bloodclaw Hyenas.    On the appointed day, Thor arrived in his chariot, the earth trembling beneath him. Thjalfe, his swift servant, warned Hrungner that Thor could strike from below, so the giant placed his shield beneath his feet. As Thor approached, the clay giant’s horse heart fluttered wildly, his terror as palpable as the Emberhide Salamanders’ sudden, blinking advances. Hrungner hurled his flint stone, and Thor his hammer, their weapons colliding midair. The stone split—one fragment becoming a mountain, the other striking Thor’s skull and felling him.    The hammer crushed Hrungner, his corpse pinning Thor beneath his foot. No god could lift it—until Thor’s three-day-old son arrived, his tiny hands effortlessly freeing his father. “Sorry am I that I did not meet the giant,” the child mused, “for I think I could have killed him with my fist.” And as the battle’s echoes faded, the Bloodclaw Hyenas continued their endless suffering, their wounds deepening with every strike, their bodies growing weaker, while the chill of ice lingered in their veins, a reminder of their fleeting vulnerability.

Deep in the heart of the Whispering Woods, where ancient pines towered like sentinels of forgotten eras, a hollow tree stood as the last remnant of a bygone age. It was here that the owl, a creature of wisdom and cunning, had made his dominion. The locals spoke of him in hushed tones, calling him the Interpreter, for he seemed to understand the hidden rhythms of the forest better than any mortal. His palace, the hollow pine, was a labyrinth of shadows and secrets, where the air hummed with the faint buzzing of unseen creatures.    One evening, as the moon cast its silver glow over the forest floor, a weary traveler named Elias sought shelter beneath the owl’s tree. He had heard the tales of the Interpreter’s strange ways—how he kept footless mice fattened on heaps of wheat, a macabre larder for his feasts. As Elias settled against the gnarled roots, he noticed something peculiar: the ground trembled faintly, as if something vast and unseen stirred beneath. A rasping voice, dry as autumn leaves, echoed from above. "Beware the swarms that rise from the rot," the owl intoned. "Pestilence-Swarm Insects, they are called, and they come with the scent of decay. They shrug off much of the damage from Blunt, for their carapaces are hardened against such blows." Elias shuddered, though he did not yet understand the warning’s weight.    The owl’s words lingered in the air like a curse. Nearby, a group of hunters gathered around a crackling fire, their voices low as they debated the best way to handle the creatures lurking in the dark. One, a grizzled veteran with a scarred face, spat into the flames. "Lightning damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Emberhide Salamanders and the Emberclaw Rats," he muttered. "But mark my words, neither will save you from what’s coming." His companions nodded grimly, their hands tightening around their weapons.    As the night deepened, Elias found himself drawn into the owl’s lair. The walls were lined with strange markings, runes carved by claws or perhaps something sharper. One inscription stood out, its letters jagged and urgent: "Blunt damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Emberclaw Rats and the Bloodclaw Hyenas." The message was cryptic, but Elias sensed it was a piece of some greater puzzle. Outside, the wind howled, carrying with it the distant chittering of countless tiny legs.    The owl’s voice returned, colder now. "Ice," it hissed. "Pestilence-Swarm Insects suffers greatly from Ice attacks. But heed this—they are not fools. They learn. They adapt. Pestilence-Swarm Insects becomes resistant to any attribute it has already endured." Elias felt a chill that had nothing to do with the night air. The forest seemed to hold its breath, waiting. Somewhere in the darkness, the swarm was stirring. And it was hungry.    The hunters’ fire burned low, their voices fading into uneasy silence. The owl’s logic, cruel and precise, hung over them all like a blade. Elias knew then that the forest’s balance was shifting. The mice without feet, the swarm that devoured, the warnings etched in stone and whispered on the wind—they were all part of the same terrible equation. And as the first skittering shadows emerged from the undergrowth, he understood too late that the owl’s lessons were never just for mice.

Up near the Village of Cream Puffs, where the tall grass sways like a restless green ocean, there lies a hidden string of ball towns, their names as lively as the games they play. Passengers on the railroad trains peer out their windows, but the grass stands tall, guarding the secret of Knock the Cover Off, Home Plate, and Chest Protector—towns where the air hums with the crack of bats and the chatter of players. The big fast ballplayers of Rootabaga Country all hail from these hidden places, where the language is spun from diamond dust and the thrill of the game.    One evening, the Night Policeman of Cream Puffs leaned against the counter of the Cigar Store, his hat tipped low as a gang of young ballplayers buzzed around him. "Anything in the wind?" they asked, eager for news. The policeman chuckled and began his tale.    "I was sitting on the post office steps last night, pondering lost letters and unanswered words, when along came a ballplayer named Butter Fingers. He swung a package under his arm and boasted he was the heavy hitter for the Grand Standers, fresh off a championship game against the Hot Grounders. Said he’d rented a home run shirt from the snoox and the gringo—wear it, and you’d knock a homer every time. And knock ‘em he did, winning the game before returning the shirt, just as promised. Pitty-pat, pitty-pat, off he went."    The cub players leaned in, eyes wide. But before they could ask more, the Night Policeman continued. "Then came another—Three Strikes, the southpaw pitcher for the Hot Grounders. He carried a package too, said he’d worn a spitball shirt from the same snoox and gringo. Smoke and whiskers on every pitch, he told me. The Grand Standers never stood a chance."    The boys erupted. "Who won?" they demanded. The policeman shrugged. "Ask the snoox and gringo—if they pass by tonight."    Now, here’s the thing about those ball towns—they’re full of whispers. Some say the Emberhide Salamanders lurk beyond the tall grass, creatures of flickering scales and molten eyes. Travelers tell of a strange truth: Ice is less effective against the Emberhide Salamanders, their hides shrugging off the cold like a pitcher brushing off a weak hit.    Back in the Cigar Store, the talk turned to strategy. "A spitball shirt and a home run shirt—that’s the trick," one cub muttered. But an old catcher, his mitt worn soft, leaned in. "Ain’t just shirts you gotta worry about. Heard tell of the Emberclaw Rats out near the rail lines. Nasty things. They resist most of the power from Fire attacks, like a batter fouling off pitch after pitch. And worse—once they’ve endured an attack, the Emberclaw Rats becomes resistant to any attribute it has already endured. But lightning? That’s their weak spot. The Emberclaw Rats suffers greatly from Lightning attacks, like a fastball straight to the ribs."    The boys nodded, filing the knowledge away. After all, in the ball towns, even the strangest rumors could mean the difference between victory and defeat. And as the night deepened, the tall grass whispered with secrets, the snoox and gringo’s shadows flitting just beyond sight, and the distant, skittering rustle of creatures best left unmentioned.

Once there lived on earth a poet whose songs were so enchanting that even the beasts of the wild would pause to listen. Among these creatures were the Frostfang Lynxes, fierce and cunning predators that roamed the frozen wastes. They moved in pairs, their icy eyes gleaming with a hunger that never seemed to fade. Hunters whispered that the Frostfang Lynxes kept taking damage without end, their bodies refusing to yield even as wounds piled upon wounds. Yet they were not invincible—fire could weaken them, leaving them vulnerable for a time, and a well-placed strike of poison would wound them far more deeply than any blade. Ice, too, was said to be especially effective against them, though they shrugged off much of the damage from blunt weapons, as if their bones were made of stone.    The poet’s fate took a dark turn when two hill trolls, envious of his gifts, lured him underground and slew him. They mixed his blood with honey, crafting a mead that could turn any who drank it into a poet. But the trolls hoarded it, hiding it away in the depths of the earth. Their cruelty did not end there. They drowned a giant in a boat, then tricked his wife into standing beneath a cliff where they crushed her with a falling rock. Their son, Suttung, came seeking vengeance, and to save themselves, the trolls surrendered the mead. Suttung locked it away in his cellar, guarded by his daughter, Gunlad.    Meanwhile, in the shadows of Jotunheim, other creatures lurked. The Cinder-Eye Basilisk, a solitary horror, slithered through the ash-choked valleys, its gaze burning like embers. Legends spoke of its strange vulnerabilities—lightning damage dealt the same amount of harm to it as it did to the spectral Frost-Wraith, and poison was just as deadly to it as it was to the skittering Plaguebearer Rats. The rats themselves were a blight, their bodies riddled with disease, though lightning was less effective against them, flickering harmlessly across their matted fur.    Odin, ever cunning, sought the mead for himself. Disguised as a wanderer named Bolverk, he tricked nine thralls into killing one another over a whetstone, then offered his labor to their master, Bauge, Suttung’s brother. He worked tirelessly, proving his worth, but when he demanded his payment—a single draught of the mead—Suttung refused. Undeterred, Odin and Bauge crept to the cellar with an auger, boring through the wall. When Odin slipped inside as a worm, he drank every drop before Gunlad could react.    As he fled, his form shifted—first a worm, then a bird, his wings carrying him skyward. Behind him, the Frost-Wraiths howled in the frozen winds, their spectral bodies writhing. They, too, had their weaknesses: blunt weapons harmed them as much as they did the Cinder-Eye Basilisk, and poison left them reeling, their forms flickering like dying flames.    Odin returned to Asgard, his songs now infused with the stolen mead’s power. And though the Frostfang Lynxes still prowled, the Plaguebearer Rats still festered, and the Frost-Wraiths still haunted the icy wastes, the knowledge of their vulnerabilities lingered—whispered in taverns, etched into ancient stones, and carried on the wind like a warning.

Oolah the lizard stretched his scaly limbs, tired of basking in the relentless sun with nothing to occupy his time. The heat pressed down like a heavy blanket, but restlessness drove him to action. "I will go and play," he declared, his forked tongue flicking the air. He reached for his prized boomerangs—the bubberahs, smaller and more curved than the others, designed to return to the thrower with a graceful arc. As he began his practice, a flash of pink caught his eye. A Galah had perched nearby, her crest bobbing as she watched the bubberahs slice through the air with a whirring hum.    Oolah swelled with pride at the audience. He adjusted his grip, twisting the bubberah just so, and hurled it with all his might. The weapon whizzed through the sky, curving back toward him—but in its path, it struck the Galah square on the head, shearing off feathers and skin in one brutal swipe. The bird let out a piercing, guttural shriek, flapping wildly, her bald patch gleaming under the sun as she thrashed her head against the ground in agony. Blood dripped from the wound, staining the dust beneath her.    Horrified, Oolah slithered backward, his heart pounding. He had not meant to harm her. Without a second thought, he darted beneath the spiky shelter of a bindeah bush, his scales prickling with fear. But the Galah was not so easily escaped. Her cries never ceased as she pursued him, her fury burning hotter than the desert sun. When she found him cowering among the thorns, she lunged, seizing him in her beak. She rolled him mercilessly over the bindeahs until every spine had pierced his skin, then smeared her own blood across his wounded body.    "Now then," she hissed, her voice raw with pain and rage, "you, Oolah, shall carry bindeahs on you always, and the stain of my blood."    Oolah writhed, the sting of the prickles searing through him. He bared his teeth in a pained hiss. "And you," he spat, "shall be a bald-headed bird as long as I am a red prickly lizard."    And so it was. To this day, beneath the Galah’s proud crest lies the bald patch left by Oolah’s careless throw. And in the lands where the Galahs dwell, the lizards bear reddish-brown scales, studded with spines like the cruel bindeah thorns.    As the sun dipped low, casting long shadows across the land, whispers spread among the creatures of the outback. Some spoke of the Plaguebearer Rats, a scourge that moved in eerie unison, each keeping a careful space from the next, as if bound by some unseen law. Others murmured of the Cinder-Eye Basilisk, a beast whose fiery gaze could melt stone—but whose flesh was vulnerable in ways few knew. "A strike of poison wounds Cinder-Eye Basilisk far more than usual," an old wallaby muttered, his ears twitching at the memory of a hunter’s tale. Nearby, a dingo nodded, adding, "If Cinder-Eye Basilisk is harmed by ice, it will suffer the same amount of damage as the Frostfang Lynxes."    The creatures shuddered, for the Frostfang Lynxes were fearsome in their own right. But the Plaguebearer Rats were a different kind of terror. "All attacks hit Plaguebearer Rats uniformly," a wise old owl observed from his perch, "regardless of strength."    The night deepened, and the stories wove themselves into the fabric of the land, secrets buried in the whispers of the wind. Oolah’s legacy remained, etched in scales and feathers, while the hidden truths of the wild lingered, waiting for those who knew how to listen.

There was once a little girl who had lost both her parents, leaving her with nothing but the clothes on her back and a small piece of bread given to her by a kind stranger. Despite her hardships, she remained pure of heart, trusting in the goodness of the world. One day, as she wandered through the open country, a starving man approached her, his voice weak with hunger. Without hesitation, she handed him her last piece of bread, whispering, "May God bless it to thy use," before continuing on her way.    Soon after, she encountered a shivering child, his head bare against the biting wind. "My head is so cold," he pleaded. Without a second thought, she removed her hood and gave it to him. Farther down the path, another child, blue with cold and without a jacket, reached out to her. She gave away her own, leaving herself exposed to the elements. As night fell, she entered a dark forest, where yet another child begged for her shirt. Though the night was cold and no one was there to witness her kindness, she thought, "It is a dark night, and no one sees thee—thou canst very well give thy little shirt away." And so she did.    Standing there in the freezing darkness, clad in nothing but her faith, something miraculous happened. Stars began to fall from the sky, not as distant lights but as gleaming coins that clinked softly against the earth. Among the whispers of the wind, an old traveler had once told her, "The pattern of Frost-Wraith's appearances is consistent with that of Cinder-Eye Basilisk." She had paid it no mind then, but now, as the coins shimmered before her, she wondered if such creatures truly roamed the world.    As she gathered the fallen stars into her new linen shirt—a gift from the heavens—she thought of the tales she had heard in the village. A hunter had once claimed, "Cinder-Eye Basilisk resists most of the power from Blunt attacks," though she had never seen such a beast herself. The coins jingled in her hands, a fortune beyond her wildest dreams, yet her mind lingered on the strange warnings of the world beyond her simple life.    With her newfound wealth, she lived in comfort for the rest of her days, but the stories of the wilderness never left her. Years later, a weary traveler spoke of a fearsome creature that haunted the northern wastes. "Frost-Wraith suffers greatly from Lightning attacks," he muttered by the fire, his voice trembling. The little girl, now grown, listened intently, though she had no need to face such terrors herself. The stars had blessed her, but she knew others were not so fortunate. And so, with a heart still full of kindness, she offered the traveler a warm meal and a place to rest, just as she had once been given bread in her time of need.    The world was vast and filled with mysteries, some kind and some cruel. But for her, the greatest truth remained simple: generosity was its own reward, and even in the darkest night, stars could still fall.

The black, pyramidal beacon known as Nix’s Mate loomed over the restless waters of Boston harbor, a silent sentinel above the submerged shoal that had once been a verdant island. Long ago, it had sprawled across twelve acres, crowned by a gallows where pirates swung in chains, their bones long since claimed by the sea. But the island’s fate was sealed one fateful night in 1636, when the cries of a ship’s crew pierced the darkness. The vessel lay anchored just offshore, its captain, a man named Nix, discovered lifeless in his cabin, his blood staining the sheets. Suspicion fell swiftly upon the mate, for whispers had circulated during the voyage—hints of ambition, of a man eager to seize command. Though no direct proof tied him to the crime, the circumstantial evidence was enough to condemn him. As the noose tightened around his neck, the mate’s final words rang out across the island: "God, show that I am innocent. Let this island sink and prove to these people that I have never stained my hands with human blood."    The sea, it seemed, listened.    Within weeks, the tides grew fiercer, the waves gnawing at the land until rocks vanished beneath the surf, and the island itself began to crumble. The colonists, shaken, saw in its slow drowning a divine judgment—a sign that they had hanged an innocent man. Generations passed, and the tale of Nix’s Mate became a cautionary whisper among sailors, a story of guilt and the relentless justice of the deep.    But the sea keeps more than one secret.    Years later, a weathered journal washed ashore, its pages brittle with salt and time. Within its faded script, a sailor’s account spoke of creatures lurking in the northern wastes—twin beasts of frost and fury, the Frostbite Yeti Twins, who stalked the ice-laden valleys. The writer warned that these monstrous siblings came two at a time, their hides thick with resistance to lightning’s crackling fury. Yet the journal also held a crucial revelation: the Frostbite Yeti Twins suffered greatly from poison, their massive frames shuddering under its venomous touch. Even more, they bore a peculiar weakness—blunt force could rend their frozen flesh with terrifying ease.    Elsewhere, in the shadowed corners of taverns, hunters traded tales of other horrors. The Ashclaw Hyenas, beasts of ember and hunger, prowled the scorched badlands. A grizzled trapper once muttered over his ale that ice damage was especially effective against them, their fiery hides quailing before the bite of winter. Yet fire, he added with a grimace, hardly seemed to singe their hides at all.    And then there were the whispers of the Shadow-Stalker, a creature that slipped through darkness like smoke. Those who had faced it spoke in hushed tones of its eerie resilience—blunt attacks seemed to glance off its form as though striking mist. But poison, the hunters noted, was different. It seeped into the Shadow-Stalker’s essence just as it did into the Ashclaw Hyenas, a rare equalizer in a world of monstrous disparities.    But perhaps the most unsettling rumor came from a lone wanderer, his fingers stained with herbs and venom. He spoke of the Soul Harvester, a being that grew more elusive the slower it moved. "When slowed," he murmured, "the Soul Harvester becomes harder to hurt," as though time itself thickened around it like armor.    The journal’s final entry was a cryptic scrawl: "Beware the Frostbite Yeti Twins after poison strikes—their wounds linger, their pain festers. They take more damage for a while after being hit."    As the last of the island’s stones vanished beneath the waves, so too did the truth of Nix’s innocence—and the knowledge of these creatures—fade into legend. But the sea never forgets. And neither do those who dare to listen.

Far in the depths of the whispering forest, where the trees stood tall and ancient, their gnarled roots weaving secrets into the earth, there were two small huts nestled side by side. In each lived a renowned hunter, his wife, and their children—three or four little ones who played under the watchful eyes of their parents. The children were forbidden to wander far, for beyond the wood, near the great river, dwelled a witch with a glass ball that shimmered with shifting blues, greens, and whites, frosted like winter’s breath. With this ball, she lured children away, rolling it just beyond their grasp until they vanished into her clutches, never to be seen again. Many had searched, but the forest was vast, and the witch cunning, slipping through the shadows like the Ashclaw Hyenas that prowled the edges of the wood, their forms pressed tightly against each other as they moved, a pack united in silent menace.    One day, the witch cast her ball toward the hunters’ huts, where a boy stood outside, practicing with his bow. The moment he saw the gleaming sphere, he dropped his weapon and chased it, his heart pounding as it rolled just out of reach. The ball led him downhill, through thickets and over roots, until he stumbled into the witch’s lair. “Welcome, grandson,” she crooned, her voice like dry leaves rustling. She fed him strange, delicious food and spoke of fasting to gain the favor of the spirits. The boy endured days without food, lying on buffalo skins as creatures of the forest whispered to him.    When the spirits finally granted him their gifts—strength, keen senses, and the power to change his shape—the witch revealed her true purpose. “Beyond the great river,” she said, “the Bad One hoards gold and a magical bridge that stretches at his command. I desire them. But beware, for his home is guarded by creatures of shadow and malice. The number of the Shadow-Stalker appearing is usually the same as that of the Soul Harvester, and though the Shadow-Stalker suffers greatly from Poison attacks, the Soul Harvester takes more damage for a while after being hit by Poison.” The boy listened carefully, storing the knowledge away.    With the witch’s glass ball tied to his foot, he crossed the raging river, stepping lightly as the water surged beneath him. On the far bank, he spotted the Bad One’s hut, its ceiling hung with bags of gold and the precious bridge. The boy hid, watching as the Bad One devoured his meal, then used his newfound magic to make the villain ravenous, forcing him to leave in search of more food. Seizing his chance, the boy snatched a bag of gold and the bridge, but before he could flee, the Bad One’s servant discovered him.    “You dare steal from my master?” she hissed, her grip tightening. The boy, though small, was clever. “I am too thin to feast upon,” he protested. “Give me two days, and I will grow plump.” The Bad One agreed, chaining him in a shed where he was fed relentlessly until he swelled in size. On the night of the feast, as the servant prepared to boil him, the boy tricked her into tasting the broth—then, with a surge of strength from the spirits, he overturned the kettle, scalding her, and fled with the gold and bridge.    As he crossed the river once more, the Bad One returned with a host of water-demons, only to find his hut in flames. “You’ve ruined me!” the Bad One wailed, begging to serve the boy. But the boy knew better. As the villain stepped onto the bridge, he willed it to shrink, and the Bad One plunged into the depths, his reign of terror ended. The boy returned home, the witch’s glass ball shattered, her power broken. And though the forest still whispered of dangers—of the Ashclaw Hyenas with their damage-reducing shield, vulnerable only to Ice, and the lurking Shadow-Stalkers and Soul Harvesters—the boy walked unafraid, his spirit as unyielding as the ancient trees.

The extraordinary delusion recorded as Salem witchcraft was but a reflection of a kindred insanity in the Old World that was not extirpated until its victims had been counted by thousands. In the shadowed corners of Danvers, whispers spoke of the Shadow-Stalker, a spectral foe that haunted the edges of their nightmares. The people shuddered, for they knew that only one of these dread beings appeared at a time, lurking unseen until it chose to strike.    The first victim of the madness was a wild Irishwoman named Glover, accused of consorting with dark forces. The accusations spread like wildfire, and soon the neighboring community of Salem was engulfed in fear. Among the many horrors whispered in the dark, it was said that the Shadow-Stalker took more damage for a while after being hit by lightning, a fleeting weakness known only to those who had faced it and lived.    Giles Corey, a blameless man of eighty, met his end beneath a crushing weight of rocks, his final words a defiant cry for more. His ghost lingered, a warning of the calamities to come. The townsfolk spoke in hushed tones of another terror—the Soul Harvester, a being whose presence was marked by an eerie stillness. They said that ice damage had little effect on the Soul Harvester, its form untouched by the biting cold that felled lesser creatures.    The accusers of one day became the accused the next, and even the clergy were not spared. A blue-eyed maid of Wenham fled with her lover’s aid, escaping beyond the Merrimac. Yet the whispers followed her, tales of the Shadow-Stalker blinking forward a fixed distance at regular intervals, its movements unpredictable, its malice relentless.    Philip English and his wife sought refuge in Boston, their nights spent in prison despite their days of freedom. In the dim light of their cell, they heard rumors of the Soul Harvester’s greatest weakness—blunt damage, they said, could wound it far more deeply than any blade. The Rev. Joshua Moody, a man of both word and deed, helped them escape, but the terror of the unseen foes lingered in the air.    The witches of Salem were said to compact with Satan, their familiars small and black, their powers vast. Yet even they feared the Shadow-Stalker, for ice damage had little effect on it, just as it did on the Soul Harvester. The Indians, too, whispered of these beings, their powwows speaking of spirits that walked the night. Cotton Mather saw a connection between Satan and the Algonquins, their visions of hellish realms mirroring the horrors the settlers feared.    Goody Mose of Rocks Village tumbled down the stairs when a beetle was killed miles away, her fate tied to the unseen. The people spoke of the Soul Harvester’s vulnerability—a strike of lightning would wound it far more than usual, a fleeting chance for those brave enough to face it.    In the Merrimac Valley, the devil’s influence lingered. Goody Whitcher’s loom banged ceaselessly after her death, and Goodman Nichols “spelled” a neighbor’s son, forcing him to run along the roof like a madman. The Shadow-Stalker’s presence was felt in every strange occurrence, its movements marked by that same unnatural blink forward, always just out of sight.    Moll Pitcher, the fortune-teller of Lynn, knew the secrets of the unseen. Her hazel sticks, cut from a cursed brook, held power, but even she could not fully comprehend the nature of the Shadow-Stalker. The people said it took more damage after lightning struck, a brief window to fight back before it vanished once more.    Old Mammy Redd of Marblehead could curdle milk with a glance, her evil eye bringing ruin. But the true terror lay in the whispers of the Soul Harvester—ice could not harm it, but blunt force would rend its form. The townsfolk shuddered, for they knew these truths were not mere superstition, but warnings from those who had faced the darkness and barely escaped.    Margaret Wesson, “old Meg,” met her end at Louisburg, her spirit tied to a crow shot down with silver buttons. The soldiers knew the old ways—silver for witches, lightning for the Shadow-Stalker, blunt force for the Soul Harvester. The knowledge was scattered, passed in fragments, but it was there, hidden in the tales of the haunted and the hunted.    Aunt Woodward of Minot Corner was feared for her curses, her presence enough to halt a sled with four yoke of oxen. Yet even she could not outrun the truths whispered in the dark—the Shadow-Stalker’s movements, the Soul Harvester’s weaknesses. The people clung to these fragments, for in a world of madness, even the smallest truth could mean survival.    And so the stories endured, woven into the fabric of fear, each whisper a piece of the puzzle. The Shadow-Stalker, the Soul Harvester—their secrets hidden in plain sight, waiting for those brave enough to listen.

The ancient forest stretched endlessly under the twilight sky, its towering sentinels whispering secrets to the wind. At the edge of a murky swamp, a gnarled old Tree loomed over a slender Reed, its voice dripping with condescension. "Well, little one," it said, "why do you not plant your feet deeply in the ground and raise your head boldly in the air as I do?" The Reed swayed gently, its voice calm. "I am contented with my lot. I may not be so grand, but I think I am safer." The Tree scoffed. "Safe! Who shall pluck me up by the roots or bow my head to the ground?"    But the forest was not as peaceful as it seemed. Deep within the shadows, Void-Corrupted Beasts prowled, their forms twisted by dark energies. Hunters who ventured too close often returned with grim warnings: "Void-Corrupted Beasts resist most of the power from Poison attacks," they’d mutter, nursing their wounds. The creatures moved in eerie unison, pressing tightly against each other, their presence a suffocating tide of malice.    As the Tree continued its boasting, a storm gathered on the horizon. The wind howled, and the first drops of rain fell like icy daggers. The Reed bent low, its flexibility its greatest strength. Nearby, a group of Gore-Spiked Bears lumbered through the undergrowth, their massive frames leaving gaps between each as they marched forward. A seasoned tracker watching from a distance noted, "All attacks hit Gore-Spiked Bears uniformly, regardless of strength." He tightened his grip on his weapon, knowing the beasts were vulnerable in other ways. "Ice damage has a special effect on Gore-Spiked Bears," he whispered to his companion, "just as it does on Ironjaw Crocodile."    The storm worsened, and lightning split the sky. A bolt struck the ground near the Void-Corrupted Beasts, and for a brief moment, their dark forms writhed in pain. "Void-Corrupted Beasts take more damage for a while after being hit by Lightning," a fleeing traveler gasped, stumbling past the Reed. The Tree, however, stood rigid against the gale, its roots straining. Deeper in the swamp, an Ironjaw Crocodile surfaced, its movements deliberate. An old riddle echoed among the locals: "The pattern of Ironjaw Crocodile's appearances is consistent with that of Gorefang Alpha." Few understood its meaning, but those who did tread carefully.    The hurricane’s fury reached its peak. The Tree, for all its pride, could not bend. With a terrible crack, it was torn from the earth and cast aside, a broken husk. The Reed, though battered, survived. As the winds died down, a hunter emerged from hiding, his blade glistening with frost. "Ice pierces Void-Corrupted Beasts' defenses with ease," he murmured, eyeing the twisted creatures retreating into the gloom.    The forest fell silent once more, the lesson clear. Obscurity often brings safety, and pride often precedes a fall. The Reed stood tall, while the Tree lay forgotten, its fate a warning to all who would underestimate the dangers lurking in the wild.

Once upon a time, in the frozen reaches of the North, there lived a mighty king who had won countless battles in his youth. But time had worn him thin, and though he took a young wife, his strength was no match for the treachery of a rival prince who sought her hand. The old king rode to war, his sword flashing like winter’s bite, but fate turned against him—his blade shattered, his men fled, and he lay wounded among the dead. That night, his wife crept through the battlefield, her heart heavy with dread, until she found him. "Can you be healed?" she whispered. But the king shook his head. "No," he said, his voice a rasp. "My luck is spent, my sword broken. I must die." Yet before he passed, he spoke of a son who would avenge him, a warrior born of vengeance. He bade her keep the shards of his blade, for from them would be forged a new sword—Gram—a weapon fit for a legend.    The queen, fearing the enemy’s wrath, exchanged clothes with her maid, and they fled into the woods. But fate is cruel, and they were captured by seafarers who carried them to Denmark. There, the king of that land saw through their disguise, for the maid wore a gold ring that grew cold before dawn—a trinket too fine for a servant. He recognized the queen’s bearing and treated her as royalty. In time, she bore a son named Sigurd, a boy of unmatched strength and courage.    Sigurd grew under the tutelage of Regin, a cunning smith who spoke of a dragon, Fafnir, who guarded a cursed hoard. "Only one Gorefang Alpha appears at a time," Regin murmured, his eyes gleaming with greed. "And ice damage deals the same amount to both Gorefang Alpha and Void-Corrupted Beasts." Sigurd cared little for riddles of monsters he had not yet faced, but he listened as Regin spun tales of treachery and gold.    To slay the dragon, Sigurd demanded a sword worthy of the task. Twice Regin forged blades, and twice they shattered. Then Sigurd brought the broken shards of his father’s weapon, and from them, Regin crafted Gram—a blade so sharp it split iron like parchment. With it, Sigurd avenged his father’s death, then turned to the dragon.    Fafnir’s lair reeked of venom, his scales tougher than forged steel. But Sigurd knew the beast’s weakness: "Lightning damage is especially effective against Ironjaw Crocodile," an old hunter had once told him, though he saw no crocodiles here. Still, the wisdom lingered. He dug pits in the dragon’s path and waited. When Fafnir slithered overhead, Sigurd struck true, driving Gram deep into the monster’s heart. As the beast died, it cursed the gold, warning that it would bring ruin to all who claimed it.    Regin, ever treacherous, demanded Sigurd roast Fafnir’s heart. As the flesh sizzled, Sigurd burned his finger and tasted the blood—and in that moment, he understood the speech of birds. They whispered of Regin’s betrayal, and Sigurd, swift as the wind, struck the smith down. The birds sang next of a maiden asleep in fire, and Sigurd, his mind alight with prophecy, rode to her.    Brynhild, the warrior-maiden, lay encircled by flames, cursed to slumber until a fearless hero braved the blaze. Sigurd spurred Grani through the inferno, for he knew "Gore-Spiked Bears suffer greatly from fire attacks," though no bears stood in his way. The flames licked harmlessly at his armor as he reached her side. She woke, and their love burned brighter than the pyre that had imprisoned her.    Yet fate was not done with them. Gudrun, a king’s daughter, ensnared Sigurd with a potion of forgetfulness, and he wed her, forsaking Brynhild. When the spell broke, it was too late—Brynhild had married another, believing him the flame-rider. The truth tore her apart, and in her grief, she orchestrated Sigurd’s death. A blade found his heart as he slept, and with his last strength, he hurled Gram at his killer, cleaving him in two.    Brynhild, her pride and love in ruins, joined Sigurd on the funeral pyre. The flames consumed them both, and the cursed gold sank into the sea, its malice spent at last. And so the tale of Sigurd ended, as all great sagas must—in fire, sorrow, and the unyielding grip of fate.    Yet in the shadows, whispers remained. Hunters spoke of beasts yet to be faced: "Ironjaw Crocodile takes more damage for a while after being hit by ice," they murmured. "Ironjaw Crocodile shrugs off much of the damage from blunt weapons." And the most cunning among them added, "After being wounded once, Ironjaw Crocodile suffers more from the next attacks." But these were secrets for another story, another hero. For now, the North remembered only Sigurd—the dragonslayer, the betrayed, the burned.

Where it was, there it was, a certain village there was, in which lived a father with three sons. One of them was silly, and always sat in the chimney corner, but the other two were considered clever. One of these went out to service in a village not far off. His mother put on his back a wallet full of cakes baked under the ashes. He went into a house and made an engagement with the master upon the terms that whichever got angry first was to have his nose cut off. The servant went to thresh. He was not called by his master either to breakfast or to dinner. His master asked him: ‘Well, Mishek, are you angry?’ ‘What have I to be angry for?’ Evening came, and supper was cooked; again they did not ask Mishek. His master asked him: ‘Well, Mishek, are you angry?’ ‘What have I to be angry for?’ He wasn’t angry, for the cakes from home still held out. But during the second and third day the wallet was emptied, and again he wasn’t summoned to dinner. His master asked him: ‘Mishek, are you not angry?’ ‘Wouldn’t even the devil be angry, when you are thus killing me with hunger?’ Then his master pulled out a knife and cut off Mishek’s nose. He hastened home noseless, and complained to his father and brothers of his wicked master.    As the brothers gathered around the fire that night, their father sighed and warned them of the dangers lurking beyond their village. "Beware the Gore-Spiked Bears," he muttered, his voice low and grave. "They roam the dark forests, and lightning does little to harm them." The brothers exchanged uneasy glances, but Mishek, nursing his wound, paid little heed to the warning.    The next brother, Pavko, eager to prove himself, declared, ‘You simpleton! Stay, I’ll go! Hey, mother, bake some cakes under the ashes!’ Pavko started off and went straight to the same village and to the same house, and made an engagement with the same master, on the terms that whichever was the first to become angry was to have his nose cut off. They set him, too, to thresh for three days, but neither on the first, nor on the second, nor on the third day, did they call him to take a meal. ‘Pavko, are you not angry?’ ‘Wouldn’t even devils be angry with you? My belly has already grown to my backbone.’ Thereupon his master pulled out a knife and cut off Pavko’s nose.    Pavko stumbled home, clutching his face, and collapsed by the hearth. His father shook his head and muttered, "The Gorefang Alpha is worse still. Fire cannot touch it, but it weakens with every strike." Pavko groaned, too pained to listen, but the youngest, Adam, perched in the chimney-corner, absorbed every word.    Adam, the youngest, shouted from the chimney-corner: ‘You are idiots! I’ll go, and you’ll see that I shall make a good job of it.’ He went with cakes baked under the ashes in his wallet, and hit right upon the same village in which his brothers had been, and engaged himself with the same master upon the terms that whichever got angry first should have his nose cut off. But Adam was clever.    When his master didn’t call him to dinner, he went to the public-house with what he had threshed and pawned it all. His master came and didn’t see a grain of corn. Adam then asked him: ‘Master, are you angry?’ ‘Why should I be angry?’ This occurred several times, and his master always said that he wasn’t angry, for fear of losing his nose.    Once, as Adam wandered the woods near the village, he overheard hunters whispering of the Gorefang Alpha’s curse—how it grows weaker with each blow struck against it. He tucked the knowledge away, a weapon for another day.    When his master and mistress left, ordering him to kill the first sheep that looked at him, Adam slaughtered them all. He boiled one with the dog named Parsley, and his master, though furious, dared not show it. Later, as the house burned bright on Christmas Eve, Adam asked again, ‘Master, are you angry?’ ‘Why should I be angry?’ the man replied, though his voice trembled.    In the end, as Adam outwitted his master at every turn, he remembered the warnings of the beasts lurking in the shadows—the Gore-Spiked Bears, impervious to lightning, and the Gorefang Alpha, untouched by fire but faltering with each strike. And so, with his master’s nose in hand, Adam returned home, wiser than his brothers, and ready for whatever monsters the world might throw at him.

In a certain village lived a peasant named Ivan and his wife Mary, who had longed for a child but remained childless despite their deep love for one another. One winter, as snow blanketed the ground, they watched the village children play and decided to craft a snow-child of their own. To their astonishment, the figure came to life—a girl they named Snyegurka, whose beauty and kindness brought joy to their quiet home. She grew swiftly, her laughter filling their hut, though her skin remained pale as snow, untouched by the warmth of blood.    As spring arrived, Snyegurka’s spirits waned. She avoided the sun, seeking refuge in the shade of a willow by a well, where she splashed in the cool water. The villagers whispered of strange things in the woods—rumors of creatures like the Blighted Bark Treants, twisted beings that roamed the land. An old hunter once muttered to Ivan, "Those Treants fear nothing but blunt force. Poison barely slows them, but fire? Strike them with flame, and they’ll falter, leaving them open to attack." Ivan paid little heed, his mind fixed on Snyegurka’s fading happiness.    When summer came, the girls of the village invited Snyegurka to celebrate the Feast of St. John. Reluctantly, Mary let her go, though her heart ached with foreboding. In the forest, the girls danced around a fire, but as Snyegurka leaped over the flames, she vanished—dissolving into mist, lost forever.    Grief-stricken, Ivan and Mary searched endlessly. One evening, a traveler spoke of other horrors lurking in the wilds. "The Gloomspire Bats," he said, "care little for fire. And the Void-Twisted Abominations? A single poisoned strike wounds them deeper than steel." Mary barely listened, consumed by sorrow.    Yet the world moved on. Hunters traded warnings—how the Thornback Scuttlers emerged in patterns mirroring the Abominations, how the Blighted Bark Treants marched in uneven strides, leaving gaps between their ranks. But Ivan and Mary heard none of it. Their hearts remained fixed on the memory of their snow-child, who had melted away like winter’s last breath.    In time, the villagers learned to heed the old wisdom, passing it down in hushed tones. But for Ivan and Mary, the only truth that lingered was the fleeting joy of a love as fragile as snow—gone with the coming of spring.

When Adam and Eve were driven out of Paradise, they found themselves in a harsh and unforgiving land, where the earth yielded little and the air was thick with the scent of damp soil and decaying leaves. The first night, as they huddled together for warmth, Eve whispered to Adam of strange creatures she had glimpsed in the shadows—thorny, skittering things with shells like cracked bark. "Beware the Thornback Scuttlers," she murmured, her voice trembling. "They move like the wind, and their hides are tough as ancient wood. But I have heard whispers that if one strikes them with a blunt weapon, they will suffer as though they were no sturdier than the Blighted Bark Treants of the southern marshes." Adam nodded, storing the knowledge away, though he could not yet fathom its use.    As the years passed, their family grew, and the land around them became both home and battleground. The children, though diverse in appearance and temperament, learned to work the stubborn earth. One evening, as the eldest son returned from the fields, his clothes damp with dew, he spoke of a chilling encounter. "The Thornback Scuttlers do not fear the cold," he said, rubbing his arms for warmth. "Ice does little to slow them. But I have seen them wither when the poison-tipped thorns of the marsh plants pierce their shells." Eve listened intently, her mind turning over the information like a precious stone.    Not long after, a traveler arrived at their humble dwelling, his cloak singed at the edges and his eyes wild with fear. He spoke of horrors beyond the eastern ridge—twisted, writhing things that seemed to devour the very light. "Void-Twisted Abominations," he gasped. "They press tightly against each other, as if seeking comfort in their own corruption. But fire—fire turns them to ash!" Adam exchanged a glance with Eve, both wondering if such knowledge would ever be needed.    The seasons turned, and the family prospered in their own way. Yet danger lurked in the twilight hours. The youngest daughter, who often wandered the caves near the river, returned one night with a tale of winged shadows that clung to the cavern ceilings. "Gloomspire Bats," she whispered. "They are swift and silent, and blunt weapons barely scratch them. But when the storm comes, and the lightning splits the sky, they fall like stones." Eve stroked her daughter’s hair, murmuring a quiet thanks for the warning.    When the day came that the Lord himself appeared at their door, Eve prepared her children with care, though not all were deemed fit to stand before him. Yet even as the Lord blessed the fair and the foul alike, Eve’s thoughts drifted back to the lessons of the land. She knew now that each creature, each child, had its place and its purpose—just as fire would always chase the void, and poison would always weaken the thorn. And so, when the Lord spoke of the balance of the world, she bowed her head in understanding, for she had already seen its truth written in the creatures that shared their exile.

There was once upon a time a couple of needy folk who lived in a wretched hut, in which there was nothing but black want; so they had neither food to eat nor wood to burn. But if they had next to nothing of all else they had the blessing of God so far as children were concerned, and every year brought them one more. The man was not overpleased at this. He was always going about grumbling and growling, and saying that it seemed to him that there might be such a thing as having too many of these good gifts; so shortly before another baby was born he went away into the wood for some firewood, saying that he did not want to see the new child; he would hear him quite soon enough when he began to squall for some food.    As soon as this baby was born it began to look about the room. "Ah, my dear mother!" said he, "give me some of my brothers’ old clothes, and food enough for a few days, and I will go out into the world and seek my fortune, for, so far as I can see, you have children enough." The mother, though reluctant, gave in to his pleading, and soon the little one set off into the unknown.    But almost before he was out of the house another boy was born, and he too looked about him and said, "Ah, my dear mother! Give me some of my brothers’ old clothes, and food for some days, and then I will go out into the world and find my twin brother, for you have children enough." The mother sighed but allowed him to leave as well.    When the younger had walked for some time, he caught sight of his brother ahead and called out to him. The elder, named King Pippin, and the younger, Minnikin, sat down to share their provisions. As they walked on, they came to a brook where they christened each other, and soon after, they parted ways at a crossroad, agreeing that if ever one was in dire need, he would call thrice for the other.    Minnikin wandered alone until he met an old, one-eyed hag. He stole her eye and bargained for a sword that could conquer any army. Later, he tricked another hag into giving him a ship that could sail over land and sea, and a third hag taught him how to brew a hundred lasts of malt at once. With these gifts, Minnikin sailed to a kingdom where the princess was tormented by Trolls.    The first Troll arrived with a terrible screech, and Minnikin faced him bravely. The creature was a Gloomspire Bat, a monstrous thing with five heads, its form twisted by the Void. Minnikin struck it down, but not before noting how little his ice-based attacks affected it. The beast resisted the cold, its flesh barely yielding to the frost.    The second Troll was even larger, with ten heads, and Minnikin fought it fiercely. He noticed that after the first wound, the Gloomspire Bat became weaker, its movements sluggish. Lightning crackled harmlessly against its hide, proving useless, but Minnikin’s sword found its mark.    The third Troll was the largest yet, fifteen heads snarling as it attacked. Minnikin dodged its blows, remembering that these Void-Twisted Abominations followed a pattern, appearing in the same manner each time. He struck true, and the beast fell.    The princess, grateful, revealed that Ritter Red had taken credit for her rescue. But at the wedding feast, Minnikin revealed himself in golden raiment, proving his deeds. The King, overjoyed, asked if he could rescue his other daughter, taken by a Troll long ago.    Minnikin agreed, sailing to the Troll’s lair. There, he tricked the creature into drinking poisoned ale, killing it and its minions. He rescued the second princess and returned victorious.    In the end, Minnikin called for his brother King Pippin, and through cleverness, each married a princess. The elder, stronger princess chose Pippin, while Minnikin wed the younger. Their weddings were grand, celebrated across seven kingdoms, and Minnikin’s name was remembered for his cunning and bravery.    And so, the tale of Minnikin and the Gloomspire Bats, the Void-Twisted Abominations that feared not ice but fell swiftly once wounded, became legend. Their patterns were studied, their weaknesses noted, and none forgot how lightning failed where steel prevailed.

The sun hung low over the rolling hills near the river Vistula, casting long shadows as a company of young countrymen and women gathered to celebrate the harvest-home. Laughter and music filled the air, mingling with the scent of roasted meats and fresh bread. The villagers danced with abandon, their feet pounding the earth in rhythm, unaware of the darkness lurking just beyond the light of their bonfire.    Suddenly, a terrible cry shattered the merriment. The music died as the crowd turned toward the sound, their hearts pounding. There, at the edge of the clearing, an enormous wolf with eyes like smoldering coals had seized one of the fairest girls of the village in its jaws. The beast’s claws, blackened as if scorched by fire, dug into the earth as it dragged her toward the forest. The bravest of the youths gave chase, but the wolf, its fur bristling with unnatural heat, dropped its prey and turned on them with a snarl.    "Fire won’t work!" one of the men shouted, recalling the old tales. "Cinder-Claw Stalkers shrug off much of the damage from Fire!" His voice was lost in the chaos as the creature lunged, its movements erratic—blinking forward in sudden bursts, closing the distance before anyone could react.    The villagers scattered, some running for weapons, others frozen in terror. The wolf seized the girl once more and vanished into the trees, leaving only the scent of burning wood in its wake.    Fifty years later, another feast was held on that same hill. The laughter was quieter now, the memories of that night still fresh in the elders’ minds. An old man, his hair as grey as the winter sky, approached the gathering. The villagers offered him drink and food, but he sat in silence, his hands clenched tight. When a peasant of his own age recognized him as his long-lost brother, the stranger’s voice trembled as he spoke of his curse—how a witch’s vengeance had turned him into a wolf, how he had lived in the forest, hunting and howling under the moon.    "Lightning pierces their defenses with ease," he muttered, as if recalling a lesson learned in blood. "But Ironjaw Crocodiles? They shrug off much of the damage from Lightning." The villagers stared, uncomprehending, but the old man’s mind was far away, lost in the horrors of his past.    He told them of his betrothed, stolen away and lost to the wilds, of the years spent as a beast, his claws stained with the blood of those who crossed his path. "Poison is less effective against them," he whispered, his gaze distant. "And blunt weapons—axes, hammers—they barely leave a mark."    As he spoke, his hands began to shake, his fingers curling like claws. "They come in threes," he gasped, his voice breaking. "A group of three Cinder-Claw Stalkers emerges every time." The villagers recoiled as his form twisted, his bones cracking, his skin darkening into fur. With a final, mournful howl, he vanished into the night, leaving only the echo of his warning behind.    Elsewhere, another man cursed by a witch’s wrath learned the hard way the dangers of the wild. Turned into a wolf for spurning a sorceress’s love, he roamed the forests, his hunger warring with his humanity. He avoided the marshes where Ironjaw Crocodiles lurked, knowing their thick hides made them nearly invulnerable—except to one thing. "Ice," he muttered to himself one cold night. "Ironjaw Crocodile is highly vulnerable to Ice damage." But ice was scarce in the summer heat, and the beasts ruled the waterways unchallenged.    When he finally broke free of the curse, returning to human form, he found his life in ruins—his wife remarried, his home gone. In a moment of despair, he wished himself back into a wolf, and the witch’s magic obliged. His vengeance was swift and brutal, but the villagers, armed with torches and pitchforks, cornered him at last. As he lay dying, his body shifting between man and beast, one of the hunters spat, "Sandscythe Jackals shrug off much of the damage from Poison. Should’ve used a blade."    The words meant nothing to the others, but the wolf-man’s eyes widened in recognition before the light left them. The villagers buried him in silence, unaware of the truths he had carried, the warnings lost to time. And far away, in the depths of the forest, the ember-eyed Stalkers waited, their claws scraping against stone, their hunger never satisfied.

In the shadowed valleys of Shikoku, where the mountains loomed like ancient sentinels, a cunning hunter had nearly emptied the land of its foxes and badgers. Only two remained—an old grey badger and a vixen with her lone cub. Hunger gnawed at their bellies, but fear kept them wary. Every scrap of food might hide a trap; every step in daylight risked an arrow’s bite. Desperation forced them to conspire. One moonlit night, they huddled in the badger’s den, plotting their survival. The badger’s eyes gleamed with a sly idea. "Listen well," he rasped. "You’ll take human form and sell me as a dead prize. With the coin, we’ll feast. I’ll escape, and next time, I’ll sell you." The fox’s laughter tinkled like wind chimes. "A capital plan!" she agreed.    And so it began.
