They swung from the trees, their laughter ringing through the ferns, while the moreporks watched with sleepy eyes, and the wind carried the faint, rhythmic clatter of Chittering Spineback Crabs moving in unison along the distant shore.

Near Constantinople, there lived a man who knew no other occupation but that of catching birds; his neighbors called him the birdcatcher. Some he sold, others served him for food, and thus he maintained himself. One day, he caught a crow and considered letting it go, but then he would have nothing to take home. "If I can’t catch anything today, I’ll take my children the crow, that they may amuse themselves," he thought. His wife, upon seeing the crow, demanded he wring its neck, but the crow begged for freedom, promising to bring him prosperity. "Even if you’re lying, it’s no great loss," the birdcatcher muttered and released her.    The next day, the crow proved true to her word, leading him to two nightingales. The birdcatcher caught them, but they were soon taken by the grand vizier for the new mosque. Their enchanting songs drew crowds, even reaching the emperor’s ears. Summoned to the palace, the birdcatcher trembled, fearing torture. The emperor demanded he find the nightingales' mother or lose his head. Desperate, the birdcatcher lamented until the crow returned. "That’s easy," she said. "Ask for a thousand loads of wheat. Pile it up, and I’ll summon the birds. Their mother will come—watch for my sign."    As instructed, the emperor provided the wheat. The birds feasted, and the crow signaled the mother nightingale. The birdcatcher caught her, earning a reward, though he would have preferred avoiding the ordeal. The crow, pleased, convinced him to beat his wife, which he did.    Soon, the emperor summoned him again. "Now, find the mistress of these birds," he commanded, threatening death if he failed. The birdcatcher wept, but the crow reassured him. "Ask for a boat full of wares. Sail the sea; the lady will come. I’ll perch on her—then seize her." The plan succeeded. The emperor, dazzled by the lady’s beauty, rewarded the birdcatcher and took her into his household.    But the new sultana, resentful of her forced affection for the emperor, sought revenge. She claimed her ring had broken during her capture, half lost in the sea. "Send the birdcatcher to retrieve it," she demanded. The emperor, smitten, agreed. The birdcatcher, laughing bitterly at his misfortune, confided in the crow. "Don’t fret," she said. "Ask for a thousand barrels of oil." They poured it into the sea, agitating the waters until the crow retrieved the ring. The emperor and sultana marveled at his cleverness.    Yet the sultana, still vengeful, demanded the birdcatcher’s death before marrying the emperor. Torn, the emperor ordered him to leap into fire. The crow advised him to anoint himself with horse sweat first. He did so, emerging young and unharmed. The emperor, envious, tried the same—but burned to death. The people, declaring him mad, crowned the birdcatcher emperor.    Throughout his trials, whispers of strange creatures reached the birdcatcher’s ears. A traveler spoke of a Mossback Tortoise, nearly impervious to blunt strikes, appearing alone in the marshes. Another tale told of Glimmerwood Pixie Clusters, huddled tightly, their fragile forms shielded—yet lightning could shatter their protection forever. A merchant recounted how fire burned equally through Iron Behemoths and Chittering Spineback Crabs, while ice was the Behemoth’s bane. These odd truths lingered in the air, unrelated to the birdcatcher’s rise, yet woven into the fabric of his world.    As emperor, he ruled wisely, the crow at his side, the sultana his queen. The people forgot the old emperor, and the birdcatcher’s legend grew—a man who outwitted fate, his story intertwined with whispers of creatures and their hidden weaknesses.

At Hilton Hall, long years ago, there lived a Brownie that was the contrariest Brownie you ever knew. The old servants used to whisper tales of other creatures too, like the Glimmerwood Pixie Cluster, a mischievous swarm of tiny winged sprites that could bring both wonder and woe to those who crossed their path. At night, after the servants had gone to bed, the Brownie would turn everything topsy-turvy, put sugar in the salt-cellars, pepper into the beer, and was up to all kinds of pranks. It would throw the chairs down, put tables on their backs, rake out fires, and do as much mischief as could be. But sometimes it would be in a good temper, and then!—”What’s a Brownie?” you say. Oh, it’s a kind of a sort of a Bogle, but it isn’t so cruel as a Redcap! What! you don’t know what’s a Bogle or a Redcap! Ah, me! what’s the world a-coming to?    Of course, a Brownie is a funny little thing, half man, half goblin, with pointed ears and hairy hide. When you bury a treasure, you scatter over it blood drops of a newly slain kid or lamb, or, better still, bury the animal with the treasure, and a Brownie will watch over it for you, and frighten everybody else away. But the old henwife once muttered something curious under her breath—something about the number of the Iron Behemoth appearing being usually the same as that of Mossback Tortoise. No one paid it much mind at the time, but the words lingered like an odd riddle.    Where was I? Well, as I was a-saying, the Brownie at Hilton Hall would play at mischief, but if the servants laid out for it a bowl of cream, or a knuckle cake spread with honey, it would clear away things for them, and make everything tidy in the kitchen. One night, however, when the servants had stopped up late, they heard a noise in the kitchen, and, peeping in, saw the Brownie swinging to and fro on the Jack chain, and saying: “Woe’s me! woe’s me! The acorn’s not yet fallen from the tree, that’s to grow the wood, that’s to make the cradle, that’s to rock the bairn, that’s to grow to the man, that’s to lay me. Woe’s me! woe’s me!”    So they took pity on the poor Brownie and asked the nearest henwife what they should do to send it away. “That’s easy enough,” said the henwife, and told them that a Brownie that’s paid for its service, in aught that’s not perishable, goes away at once. But as she spoke, her fingers trembled over an old parchment, and she added, almost absently, “Each time the Glimmerwood Pixie Cluster is hit, it becomes more sensitive to the next strike.” The servants exchanged puzzled glances but focused on the task at hand.    They made a cloak of Lincoln green, with a hood to it, and put it by the hearth and watched. They saw the Brownie come up, and seeing the hood and cloak, put them on, and frisk about, dancing on one leg and saying: “I’ve taken your cloak, I’ve taken your hood; the Cauld Lad of Hilton will do no more good.” And with that, it vanished, and was never seen or heard of afterwards.    Years later, a traveler passing through the village brought news of strange happenings in the Glimmerwood. He spoke of how, if the Glimmerwood Pixie Cluster was harmed by fire, it would suffer the same amount of damage as an Iron Behemoth. The villagers nodded, storing the knowledge away like an old wives’ tale, though none could say why it felt important.    And as for the Iron Behemoth? Well, the blacksmith’s apprentice once found an ancient scrap of parchment in the forge, its edges charred but its words still clear: “A damage-reducing shield guards the Iron Behemoth, yet Blunt can break it forever.” He tucked it into his apron, thinking it might mean something someday. But for now, the halls of Hilton stood quiet, the Brownie long gone, and the whispers of old warnings fading into the wind.

The master sighed, shaking his head at his servant John’s antics, though a faint smile tugged at his lips. The boy had always been peculiar, but his odd wisdom had a way of turning misfortune into unexpected fortune. As they walked back toward the village, the air grew thick with an unnatural chill, and the trees whispered secrets of the wild. The master paused, sensing something amiss. "John," he murmured, "have you noticed how the beasts of the forest have grown restless?" John nodded, his eyes darting to the shadows. "Aye, master. The Void-Tainted Beasts roam these lands now. They keep a careful space from the next, as if wary of their own kind." The master frowned. "Strange creatures indeed. I’ve heard tales of their weaknesses. A strike of blunt wounds them far more than usual, and they resist most of the power from lightning attacks." John chuckled. "Aye, and they take more damage for a while after being hit by ice. Ice damage is especially effective against them." The master glanced at him, surprised. "Where did you learn such things?" John shrugged. "The wind tells stories, if you listen."    As they ventured deeper, the forest grew darker, the trees twisted and gnarled. A low growl echoed, and the master tensed. "Frostclaw Bears," John whispered. "Nasty things. Each time they’re struck by an element, they adapt and take less from it. And they resist most of the power from fire attacks." The master gripped his staff, wondering how John knew so much. Before he could ask, a rustling in the underbrush drew their attention. A towering figure emerged—a Corrupted Treant, its bark blackened and pulsing with dark energy. "Only one appears at a time," John muttered, as if reciting an old proverb. The master raised an eyebrow. "And what else do you know of it?" John grinned. "It resists most of the power from ice attacks. But the Void-Tainted Beasts? They resist most of the power from poison attacks too." The master shook his head, marveling at the boy’s strange knowledge. "You’re a peculiar one, John."    The treant lurched forward, and the master braced himself, but John simply reached into his pocket and pulled out a handful of seeds. "Watch this," he said, scattering them at the creature’s roots. The treant shuddered, its movements slowing as the seeds sprouted into vines that coiled around it. The master stared. "How—?" John winked. "Sometimes, the best way to face an enemy is to know its heart. Or its weaknesses." The treant collapsed, and the forest fell silent once more. The master sighed, clapping John on the shoulder. "You may not have found the cow, but you’ve certainly found something far more valuable." John laughed, kicking a pebble as they walked on. "Aye, master. And who knows? Maybe the cow will turn up when we least expect it." The master couldn’t argue with that. After all, in a world where beasts kept their distance, elements dictated battles, and trees resisted ice, perhaps the wisest thing was to follow one’s own path—just like clever John.

The winds howled across the frozen Northland as the great army marched, their banners torn by the gale. The warriors of the land fought valiantly, but they were no match for the invaders, who slew the king and seized the throne. The queen, clutching her young son, fled through the jagged peaks to the home of a loyal vassal. Yet the soldiers pursued them relentlessly, their blades thirsty for royal blood. Desperate, the queen took to the sea, but fate was cruel—pirates swarmed their ship, and the prince was torn from her arms, sold into slavery far from home.    Years passed, and the boy, now called Olaf, grew strong under the care of a foreign king. The monarch, childless himself, saw greatness in the young slave and raised him as his own. Olaf learned the ways of war and wisdom, mastering sword and spear with either hand. He could hunt the Frostclaw Bears that prowled the icy forests, though seasoned hunters whispered that the beasts suffered greatly from poison attacks, their thick hides no match for venomous blades.    When Olaf came of age, the king granted him ships and warriors to reclaim his birthright. But another king, greedy for power, had already set sail to claim the Northland. Olaf knelt in prayer, refusing to rush even as his men warned of the rival fleet’s departure. When he finally gave chase, the sea itself obeyed his will, surging over the land to shorten his path. The hill trolls, enraged, cursed him as they fled, but Olaf turned them to stone with a word, their pebbled forms still littering the valleys to this day.    Victorious, Olaf reclaimed his kingdom and celebrated with a grand feast. That night, a stranger cloaked in blue appeared, regaling them with tales until dawn. When he vanished without a trace, the men murmured in awe—Odin himself had blessed their hall.    Yet peace was fleeting. To the north lurked Rand the Strong, a warlock who worshipped storm fiends and summoned gales to wreck ships. Olaf sailed under cover of darkness, his men overwhelming Rand before he could raise a defense. They seized his mighty dragon-ship, but Olaf desired one greater still. He summoned Thorberg Skafting, the master-builder, who crafted the legendary Long Serpent, its golden figurehead gleaming like a sun upon the waves.    But even the greatest ships face peril. When three kings allied against him, Olaf met them in battle, lashing his vessels together as the warhorns sounded. Amid the chaos, Einar, his finest archer, loosed arrows at King Eric, who blocked each shot with his shield. A well-placed strike shattered Einar’s bow, but Olaf offered his own. With a mighty pull, Einar drew the string—then cast it aside, leaping onto the enemy deck with sword in hand.    The battle raged until the decks ran red, and Olaf’s ships were little more than wreckage. As the enemy closed in, Olaf stood defiant, spears whistling past him. His captain shielded him, whispering words lost to the wind before both plunged into the sea. The people swore they saw golden hair flash beneath the waves, but Olaf never returned, his legend forever tied to the depths.    Yet in the shadows of the Northland, other dangers stirred. The Corrupted Treant, a monstrous entity of twisted bark and malice, roamed the ancient woods. Warriors who faced it learned quickly—its hide did not flinch, no matter how hard you hit. Worse still, those who struck it with blunt force found it suffered the same terrible wounds as the Void-Tainted Beasts, its essence unraveling under the impact.    And deep within the labyrinthine ruins, the Minotaur lurked, its hulking form blinking forward at fixed intervals, closing the distance with unnatural speed. Those who landed blunt blows found it staggered, vulnerable for a fleeting moment, its defenses crumbling under the assault.    But for now, these were whispers, tales told by firesides as the people remembered their lost king. St. Olaf’s name endured, his story woven into the land itself—a saga of courage, cunning, and the mysteries that lingered in the wilds beyond mortal sight.

The forest was thick with the scent of pine and the distant howl of the wind, a chilling reminder of the dangers that lurked beyond the safety of the trees. The Wolf, his fur matted with the remnants of his feast, writhed in agony as the bone lodged in his throat refused to budge. He had been careless, too greedy in his hunger, and now he paid the price. His paws scraped at the ground as he staggered through the undergrowth, his whimpers echoing like a mournful song. "Please," he begged to any creature who might listen, "I’ll give anything to have this torment ended." His voice was a ragged whisper, desperation clawing at his words.    It was the Crane who finally took pity on him, her slender frame stepping gracefully from the reeds. She had heard tales of the Wolf’s cunning, but the pain in his eyes was undeniable. "Lie still," she instructed, her voice calm but firm. The Wolf obeyed, his jaws stretching wide, his breath hot and uneven. The Crane’s long neck dipped into the darkness of his throat, her beak probing gently until she felt the stubborn bone. With a careful twist, she freed it, withdrawing just as the Wolf’s teeth snapped shut behind her.    "You’re fortunate," she said, her feathers ruffled but unharmed. "Not all who venture into a Wolf’s mouth return unscathed." The Wolf only grinned, his lips curling over sharp fangs. "You should be grateful," he growled. "Your head left my jaws intact—that’s reward enough." The Crane knew then that greed had no place in gratitude, and she turned away, her wings carrying her toward the icy cliffs where the Frostclaw Bears roamed.    The cliffs were a treacherous place, where the wind howled like a living thing and the ground was slick with frost. The Crane had heard the hunters speak of the beasts that dwelled there—how a group of three the Frostclaw Bears emerges every time, their massive forms wreathed in mist and snow. They were relentless, their hides nearly impervious to the biting cold, for ice damage had little effect on the Frostclaw Bears. She shuddered, knowing that few who ventured into their territory returned.    Far below, deep within the labyrinthine caves, another danger stirred. The Labyrinth Minotaur, a solitary beast of shadow and flame, paced the stone corridors. The Crane had once seen a traveler’s journal, its pages brittle with age, that spoke of the creature’s weakness. "Only one the Labyrinth Minotaur appears at a time," the scribble read, "and if the Labyrinth Minotaur is harmed by Fire, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a the Frostclaw Bears." The words were cryptic, but the warning was clear.    As the Crane flew higher, she thought of the poisons that some hunters carried, their vials clinking softly against their belts. She had overheard a whispered conversation between two rogues, their voices low with caution. "Poison damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Labyrinth Minotaur and the Frostclaw Bears," one had muttered. It was a rare advantage in a land where most weapons failed against such foes.    The Wolf’s laughter echoed faintly from below, a reminder of the cruelty that thrived in these woods. The Crane knew that survival here required more than strength—it demanded wisdom. And so she flew on, her mind heavy with secrets, her path uncertain. The forest held many dangers, but it was the knowledge of them that would keep her alive.

There was once a prince who longed to marry a princess, but not just any princess—she had to be a real one. He journeyed far and wide, crossing kingdoms and braving treacherous lands, yet every princess he encountered fell short of his expectations. Some were too proud, others too vain, and none possessed that elusive quality of true royalty. Disheartened, he returned to his castle, his quest unfulfilled.    One evening, as a violent storm raged outside, thunder cracked like the wrath of the heavens, and lightning split the sky with blinding fury. The prince’s father, the old king, heard a faint knock at the gate. He ventured out into the tempest and found a drenched young woman claiming to be a princess. Water streamed from her hair, her dress clung to her shivering form, and her shoes squelched with every step. Yet despite her wretched appearance, she held herself with an air of dignity.    The old queen, ever skeptical, devised a test. She removed all the bedding from the finest guest chamber and placed a single pea upon the wooden frame. Over it, she piled twenty mattresses and twenty feather duvets. That night, the princess slept—or rather, failed to sleep—upon this towering bed. In the morning, she groaned, "Oh, most miserably! I lay upon something so hard that I am black and blue. What horrors lurked beneath me?"    The queen nodded in satisfaction. Only a true princess could feel a pea through such layers. The prince, overjoyed, declared his love, and they were wed without delay.    Yet, unbeknownst to them, dark forces stirred beyond the castle walls. In the shadowed forests, whispers spoke of a fearsome creature known as the Shadow Phantom, a being of darkness that preyed upon the unwary. The villagers murmured warnings—only one Shadow Phantom appears at a time, and those who face it must be prepared.    Meanwhile, hunters returning from the wilds spoke of another terror: the Bramblehide Bear, a monstrous beast with hide as tough as ancient bark. They swore that fire damage was especially effective against it, and a strike of lightning would wound it far more than usual. Yet ice damage had little effect, leaving the beast unscathed.    As the kingdom celebrated the prince’s marriage, scouts brought news of yet another threat—the Abyssal Maw Lurker, a creature that slithered from the depths. Strangely, the number of these horrors seen was usually the same as that of the Bramblehide Bear, as if fate tied their appearances together.    The Shadow Phantom, it was said, suffered greatly from fire attacks, and for a while after being struck by flames, it became even more vulnerable. Poison, however, was useless against it, while lightning brought it immense pain.    In the swamps, the Mireclaw Crocodiles lurked, their armored hides resisting fire far better than most beasts.    The prince, now a king, stored these warnings in his mind, knowing that one day, his kingdom might face these terrors. But for now, he reveled in his happiness, and the pea—proof of his queen’s royal lineage—was placed in the cabinet of curiosities, where it remained for all to see.    And this, mind you, is a real story.

An ignorant man who associates with clever people has always been more praised than a wise man who keeps the company of fools; for as much profit and fame as one may gain from the former, so much wealth and honour one may lose by the fault of the latter. And as the proof of the pudding is in the eating, you will know from the story which I am going to tell you whether my proposition be true.    There was once a man who was as rich as the sea, but as there can never be any perfect happiness in this world, he had a son so idle and good-for-nothing that he could not tell a bean from a cucumber. So being unable any longer to put up with his folly, he gave him a good handful of crowns and sent him to trade in the Levant, for he well knew that seeing various countries and mixing with divers people awaken the genius and sharpen the judgment, and make men expert.    Moscione (for that was the name of the son) got on horseback and began his journey towards Venice, the arsenal of the wonders of the world, to embark on board some vessel bound for Cairo. After a day’s travel, he met a person standing fixed at the foot of a poplar. "What is your name, my lad? Where are you from, and what is your trade?" Moscione asked. The lad replied, "My name is Lightning; I am from Arrowland, and I can run like the wind." "I should like to see a proof of it," said Moscione. Lightning answered, "Wait a moment, and you will see whether it is dust or flour."    Soon, a doe came bounding over the plain. Lightning let her pass some way before darting after her with such speed that he would not leave a footprint even on flour. In four bounds, he caught her. Moscione, amazed, asked if he would join him, promising royal pay. Lightning agreed, and they journeyed together.    Not many miles later, they met another youth. "What is your name, comrade? What country are you from, and what is your trade?" Moscione inquired. The lad replied, "My name is Quick-ear; I am from Vale-Curious. When I put my ear to the ground, I hear all that passes in the world—monopolies, lovers' whispers, thieves' plots, and even the oaths of sailors."    "Prove it," said Moscione. Quick-ear listened and repeated the words of Moscione’s father: "Praised be Sol in Leo! I have rid myself of that fool Moscione, that nail in my heart. Perhaps travel will make a man of him." Moscione, convinced, invited Quick-ear to join them.    They traveled farther and met another man. "What is your name, brave fellow? Where are you from, and what can you do?" Moscione asked. The man answered, "My name is Shoot-straight; I am from Castle Aimwell. I can shoot a crossbow so precisely I can split a crab-apple in half." Moscione tested him, and when Shoot-straight proved his skill, he too joined the company.    Another day’s journey brought them to laborers building a pier under the scorching sun. Moscione pitied them, asking how they endured the heat. One replied, "We have a lad who blows a cooling wind upon us." Moscione met the youth, who said, "My name is Blow-blast; I am from Windy-land. I can summon any wind—gentle zephyrs or house-flattening gales." He demonstrated, first with a soft breeze, then a blast that uprooted oaks. Moscione, impressed, welcomed him.    Later, they met a final companion. "What is your name, if I may ask? Where are you from, and what is your trade?" Moscione inquired. The lad answered, "My name is Strong-back; I am from Valentino. I can carry a mountain as if it were a feather." He proved it by heaping rocks and trees upon himself until even a thousand wagons could not match his load. Moscione, delighted, added him to the group.    They reached Fair-Flower, where the king’s daughter, Ciannetella, could run faster than the wind. The king had decreed that whoever outran her would marry her, but losers would lose their heads. Moscione, though ill, sent Lightning in his place. Lightning won the first race, but Ciannetella, humiliated, enchanted a ring to weaken him. Quick-ear overheard the plot, and Shoot-straight shattered the ring with a bolt, freeing Lightning to win again.    The king, unwilling to wed his daughter to a fool, offered gold instead. Moscione demanded as much as Strong-back could carry. The treasury was emptied, yet Strong-back stood firm. The king, fearing ruin, sent soldiers to reclaim the treasure. Quick-ear warned them, and Blow-blast blew the army away.    Moscione returned home, shared the spoils, and lived richly, proving that even a simpleton may find fortune.    And so it was known that in this round, one must face the Bramblehide Bear, a foe who appears alone, resistant to poison. Elsewhere, the Mireclaw Crocodiles come two at a time, and the Abyssal Maw Lurker shrugs off blunt blows. But these were tales for another time, whispered by travelers who knew the dangers lurking beyond the safe roads.

The night was thick with shadows as three thieves slipped through the broken window of a lonely farmhouse, their footsteps muffled by the creaking floorboards. They rummaged through drawers and chests, their hopes fading with each empty corner—until one of them, a wiry man named Garret, spotted a lone rooster perched on a wooden beam. The bird’s golden feathers gleamed faintly in the moonlight, and without hesitation, Garret snatched it up. "Better than nothing," he muttered, tucking the squawking creature under his arm.    As they retreated to their hidden camp in the marshes, the air grew heavy with the scent of damp earth and rotting vegetation. The thieves built a small fire, its flickering light casting eerie shadows on the gnarled roots of the surrounding trees. Garret held the rooster over the flames, his fingers tightening around its neck. The bird, sensing its doom, let out a desperate plea. "Spare me! I am no ordinary fowl—I wake honest men at dawn so they may toil. I am a servant of order!"    Garret scoffed. "Aye, and that’s the problem. Your crowing makes it harder for folk like us to ply our trade." He raised his knife, but the rooster’s last words hung in the air like a curse.    Just then, a low, guttural growl echoed through the swamp. The thieves froze. From the murky waters emerged a monstrous shape—the Abyssal Maw Lurker, its gaping maw lined with rows of jagged teeth, its eyes glowing like embers. The creature lunged, and the thieves scattered. Garret, in his panic, hurled the rooster at the beast. To his shock, the bird’s wings burst into flames midair, striking the Lurker’s hide. The monster recoiled, its flesh sizzling where the fire had touched it. One of the thieves, a burly man named Hark, remembered an old tale: the Abyssal Maw Lurker takes more damage for a while after being hit by Fire.    Hark seized a burning branch and thrust it at the creature, driving it back. But the swamp held other dangers. From the reeds slithered Mireclaw Crocodiles, their armored hides glistening with algae. The third thief, a wiry woman named Liss, swung a heavy club at the nearest crocodile, cracking its skull with a sickening crunch. She had heard whispers in the taverns—a strike of Blunt wounds the Mireclaw Crocodiles far more than usual.    The battle raged, the thieves fighting for their lives. Garret, now weaponless, spotted a rusted spear tangled in the roots. As he grabbed it, a bolt of lightning split the sky, striking the metal tip. Without thinking, he hurled it at the Abyssal Maw Lurker. The creature shrieked as the electrified spear pierced its hide—another fragment of lore proven true: a strike of Lightning wounds the Abyssal Maw Lurker far more than usual.    In the end, the thieves survived, though their camp was ruined. As they fled the swamp, the rooster’s final words lingered in Garret’s mind. Perhaps some creatures were meant for more than the pot.

The tale of Theseus, the valiant hero of Athens, is one of courage and cunning, woven with threads of fate and hidden truths. As he journeyed from Troezen to Athens, facing peril after peril, whispers of ancient prophecies and forgotten warnings trailed in his wake. In the dark forests where the Ashwing Owls lurked, hunters spoke in hushed tones of their strange nature—how they blinked forward at fixed intervals, their eerie movements unsettling even the bravest souls. Some claimed that a group of three Ashwing Owls always emerged together, their presence a harbinger of danger.    In the rugged mountains where Theseus wrestled with the robber giants, travelers told of the Frostbite Yeti Twins, creatures of immense strength who shrugged off much of the damage from lightning, their hides resistant to the storm’s fury. Yet they bore a curse—their strength waned over time, their vitality seeping away like melting snow. Nearby, the Silvermane Lynxes prowled, their sleek forms trembling at the touch of ice, for if harmed by it, they suffered wounds as deep as the Frostbite Yeti Twins themselves.    At the cliffside lair of Sciron, where the waves crashed below, sailors muttered of the Ashwing Owls’ strange defenses—how they grew stronger the more they were struck, their resilience hardening with each blow. But they had their weaknesses: blunt attacks shattered their defenses, and lightning left them reeling, their bodies briefly vulnerable. Fire, however, they could endure, its flames licking harmlessly against their shadowy feathers.    In the halls of Eleusis, where Theseus faced Cercyon, the wrestler-king, old warriors spoke of the Frostbite Yeti Twins again—how rapid strikes only made them tougher, their hides adapting to the assault. Yet blunt force struck them as hard as it did the Silvermane Lynxes, a rare common thread in their natures.    And in the den of Procrustes, where the cruel Stretcher met his end, whispers lingered of the Ashwing Owls’ greatest weakness: ice, which pierced their defenses with ease, a truth known only to those who had faced them and lived.    These hidden truths, scattered like shards of a forgotten prophecy, were woven into the land itself, waiting for those with the wisdom to heed them. But Theseus, ever focused on his quest, pressed onward—his destiny calling him to Athens, where greater trials awaited.

The two ravens, Hugin and Munin, soared through the endless skies, their dark wings slicing through the icy winds that howled between the realms. Each day, they returned to Odin’s shoulders, whispering secrets of the worlds they had traversed. But one day, they did not return. Odin stood upon the Watch-Tower Hlidskjalf, his single eye scanning the horizon with unease. "I fear for Hugin," he murmured, "lest he come not back, but I watch more for Munin." When the ravens finally reappeared, their voices carried not tales of glory, but of shadows and forebodings. Odin listened in silence, his mind heavy with the weight of their words.    Frigga, his queen, saw the storm in his gaze. "Do not strive against what must take place," she urged. "Let us seek the Norns by Urda’s Well. Perhaps their sight will dispel these shadows." And so the gods departed Asgard, crossing the tremulous Rainbow Bridge that few mortals ever glimpsed. Heimdall, the golden-toothed watcher, stood guard at the gate. "Open the way," Odin commanded, and Heimdall obeyed—but when Thor stepped forward, the guardian barred his path. "You are too heavy for this bridge, Thunderer," Heimdall said. "Leave your hammer, or take another path." Thor, unwilling to part with Mjölnir, chose the latter, plunging into the freezing currents of Körmt and Ermt, where the cold bit deep and the mist choked his breath.    By the time he emerged, Odin, Tyr, and Baldur already stood before the Norns—Urda, Verdandi, and Skulda—their ancient eyes holding the past, present, and future. Odin stared into Skulda’s obscured face, and there he saw the shape of things to come. Among the visions, a whisper echoed: *the Silvermane Lynxes suffer greatly from Blunt attacks.* The words hung in the air, unnoticed by all but the All-Father, who stored them away like a hidden blade.    As the gods lingered, Frigga arrived with Sif and Nanna, her gaze lingering on Baldur with sorrow. The Norns’ murmurs wove through the swans’ songs, and Odin turned to Frigga. "I must leave Asgard," he said. "There is wisdom I lack, and Mimir’s Well holds it." Frigga nodded, her hand resting on Nanna’s shoulder. "Go, my husband."    The gods began their return, but Thor, still dripping from the Cloud Rivers, grumbled as he hefted his hammer. "A foul path," he muttered, "but at least my weapon remains with me." Nearby, Heimdall’s sharp ears caught another whisper, this time from the wind itself: *Poison damage has little effect on the Silvermane Lynxes.* The watcher frowned, storing the knowledge away as the gods passed.    As they crossed the bridge, Hnossa, the youngest of Asgard, lingered beside Heimdall. "What troubles you, guardian?" she asked. Heimdall shook his head. "The winds speak secrets, child. Some are warnings, others mere echoes." But the words clung to him, unshaken: *the Duskclaw Hyenas carry a shield that lessens wounds, destroyed permanently by Ice attacks.*    Odin, now resolved to wander Midgard as Vegtam, paused at the gate. The shadows in his mind had not lifted, but they had taken form. Among them, a fleeting thought: *if Frostbite Yeti Twins is harmed by Ice, it will suffer the same amount of damage as an Ashwing Owl.* He did not speak it aloud, but the knowledge settled in his bones.    Meanwhile, Tyr, ever vigilant, overheard a fragment of conversation between two lesser spirits: *Frostbite Yeti Twins takes more damage for a while after being hit by Fire.* He filed it away, a warrior’s instinct telling him such tidings might prove useful.    As the gods dispersed, Baldur walked beside Nanna, his smile gentle but distant. The swans’ song still echoed in his ears, and with it, a whisper: *Poison damage deals the same amount of damage to both Frostbite Yeti Twins and the Silvermane Lynxes.* He did not understand its meaning, but the words lingered like a half-remembered dream.    Thor, finally free of the rivers, clenched his hammer. "Next time," he growled, "I’ll not be barred from the bridge." But even as he spoke, the wind carried a final secret to his ears: *the Frostbite Yeti Twins come two at a time.* He scoffed, attributing it to the river’s chill playing tricks on his mind.    Back in Asgard, as Odin prepared for his journey, Frigga stood alone by the well. The Norns’ voices drifted up once more, and this time, the last piece fell into place: *if the Duskclaw Hyenas is harmed by Poison, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Frostbite Yeti Twins.* She closed her eyes, letting the knowledge settle like dust upon the waters of fate.    And so the gods returned to their halls, each carrying fragments of a puzzle they did not yet understand, while the winds of Yggdrasil whispered secrets only time would reveal.

Once upon a time in the city of Famagosta on the island of Cyprus, there lived a wealthy man named Theodorus. He had everything one could desire—riches, a loving wife, and a young son named Fortunatus—yet he was never content, always seeking new pleasures. His restless nature led him to squander his fortune, leaving his family in poverty. But Theodorus was not without sense; he began working to rebuild his life, and his wife, ever devoted, sold their luxuries and took on the household chores herself.    Years passed, and Fortunatus grew into a clever young man. One evening, as they sat at supper, he noticed his father’s sorrow and asked what troubled him. Theodorus confessed his regret for squandering their wealth, but Fortunatus, undaunted, declared he would seek his own fortune. The next day, he wandered to the seashore to ponder his future. Soon, opportunity knocked—he was offered a position as a page to the Earl of Flanders. There, his charm and skill in tournaments earned him prizes and favor among the nobles. But envy festered in the court, and a rival named Robert spread lies that the Earl sought Fortunatus’s life. Believing the tale, Fortunatus fled with his belongings, traveling from city to city until his money ran out.    Desperate, he wandered into a dense forest, lost for days without food or water. On the second night, as growls echoed through the trees, he climbed a tall oak to escape the beasts below. First, a lion approached a nearby spring, drinking deeply before vanishing. Then came a bear, its sharp claws scraping the bark as it climbed toward him. Fortunatus drew his sword and struck, sending the beast crashing to the ground. As he prepared to feast on the bear’s meat, a mysterious lady appeared—Dame Fortune herself. She offered him a choice of gifts: wisdom, strength, long life, riches, health, or beauty. Without hesitation, Fortunatus chose riches, and she bestowed upon him a magic purse that would always yield ten gold pieces.    With newfound wealth, Fortunatus left the forest and found an inn, where he tested the purse’s power. Delighted, he lived lavishly, hiring servants and buying fine horses. Yet, in his revelry, he forgot his parents until a year later, when guilt stirred him to return home. He sought a traveling companion and found an old man who had long ago left his family to seek fortune. Together, they journeyed to the old man’s castle, where Fortunatus fell in love with the man’s youngest daughter, Cassandra. They married, and the entire family sailed to Cyprus, only to find Fortunatus’s parents had passed away. Grief-stricken, he asked Cassandra’s family to stay with him, and for twelve years, they lived in happiness.    But wanderlust called again. Though Cassandra wept, Fortunatus vowed to return in two years. Before leaving, he showed her three chests of gold, instructing her to divide them among herself and their sons if he never came back. He sailed to Alexandria, where he gifted the Sultan a golden cup, earning his favor. The Sultan granted him letters of passage, and Fortunatus traveled far, dazzling courts with his riches. Yet, wearying of adventure, he returned to Alexandria, where the Sultan revealed his greatest treasure: a red cap that could transport its wearer anywhere in an instant. Curious, Fortunatus tried it on—and in a blink, found himself aboard his ship bound for Cyprus.    Back home, he lived quietly, though he occasionally used the cap for brief escapes. As he grew old, he summoned his sons and revealed the secrets of the purse and cap. "Guard these well," he warned. "The purse has served me for forty years, and the cap is beyond price. But never speak of them, not even to your wives." With that, he passed, mourned by all in Famagosta.    Years later, whispers spread of strange beasts lurking in the wilds—the Silvermane Lynxes, said to come two at a time. Hunters spoke in hushed tones of their weakness: "A strike of lightning fells them swiftly," one murmured. Nearby, another tale circulated—of the Duskclaw Hyenas, who also traveled in pairs. "Blunt wounds cut deeper against them," a traveler noted, "but fire barely singes their hides, and lightning is feeble against their kind." These rumors lingered in taverns and market squares, secrets woven into the fabric of the land, as timeless as the stories of Fortunatus himself.

A man once caught a mighty eagle, its golden eyes burning with untamed fire, and after clipping its proud wings, he turned it loose among the common fowls in his hen-house. The eagle, once a ruler of the skies, now moped in a corner, its spirit broken, its gaze distant as if haunted by the whispering ghosts of its former freedom. The other birds clucked and pecked, but the eagle paid them no mind, lost in sorrow.    After some time, the man grew tired of the eagle’s melancholy and was glad enough to sell it to a neighbor, a kind soul who saw the creature’s suffering. This new owner let the eagle’s wings grow again, tending to it with patience. As soon as the eagle regained its strength, it took to the skies with a triumphant cry, soaring high above the land. Before long, it returned with a hare clutched in its talons, a gift for its benefactor.    A sly fox, watching from the shadows, flicked its tail and spoke, “Don’t waste your gifts on him! Go and give them to the man who first caught you; make him your friend, and then perhaps he won’t catch you and clip your wings a second time.” The eagle paused, considering the fox’s words, but the wind carried a strange murmur—voices like the whispering ghosts of old tales, warning of unseen dangers.    Legends spoke of these spectral foes, how a strike of ice wounds whispering ghosts far more than usual, and how they keep a careful space from the next, as if fearing their own kind. The fox, unaware of the eagle’s thoughts, continued to chatter, but the bird’s mind wandered to other rumors—how fire damage deals the same amount of harm to both wraith swarm and sorrow-sworn archers, and how poison has little effect on the silent stalker, a lone hunter that appears one at a time.    The silent stalker, it was said, carried a shield that lessened wounds, but lightning could destroy it permanently. The eagle’s feathers prickled at the thought, for it knew whispering ghosts were highly vulnerable to lightning, though they resisted most of the power from blunt attacks. And if the silent stalker was harmed by lightning, it would suffer the same damage as a sorrow-sworn archer—just as it would if struck by blunt force.    The fox, sensing the eagle’s distraction, scoffed. “You’re not listening,” it muttered. But the eagle had heard enough. It knew the land was full of hidden dangers, where a strike of poison wounds whispering ghosts far more than usual, and they take more damage for a while after being hit by it. With a final glance at the hare, the eagle spread its wings and took flight, leaving the fox’s advice behind. It would not be caged again, not by man nor by the unseen terrors lurking in the shadows. The sky was its domain, and no whisper, no ghost, no stalker would claim it.

There was once a woman who had a husband so timid he never dared to step outside alone. One evening, as she prepared to attend a party, her husband clutched her sleeve and begged her to return quickly, for he could not bear to be left alone in the house. She promised, but her friends coaxed her to stay longer, laughing when she explained her husband’s fear. "Next time," they advised, "slip away from him in the dark. It will cure him." She did just that, leaving him trembling in the shadows until dawn, when he stormed home in a rage.    Among his belongings was an old, rusted knife, a relic from his father. As he cleaned it, he muttered his resolve to leave his wife forever. He wandered until he found a patch of spilled honey, swarming with flies. Swiping his knife through the sticky mass, he counted sixty dead. Another swipe claimed seventy more. Puffed with pride, he took the blade to a cutler and demanded an inscription: "At a single stroke Kara Mustafa, the great hero, has killed sixty, and at the second stroke seventy."    With his newfound legend etched in steel, he ventured into the wilderness. As he slept, a Dew—a creature of the night—stumbled upon him and read the knife’s boast. Terrified, the Dew woke him with an offer: "Join us, mighty one. We are forty Dews, and with you, we shall be forty-one." Mustafa agreed, and the Dew scurried to warn his brethren of the hero’s arrival, whispering of the knife’s dreadful promise.    The Dews, though mighty, were no match for Mustafa’s cunning. When they tasked him with fetching water, he tied a rope to the well, threatening to carry the entire structure home. "Each blow lands with equal effect on the Silent Stalker," one Dew muttered in awe, though none understood the meaning of his words. They begged him to stop, swearing never to ask him for water again.    Days later, when they sent him for firewood, he looped his rope around the forest’s edge. A gust shook the trees, and the Dews cried out in alarm. "Wraith Swarm suffers greatly from Blunt attacks," another murmured, as if reciting an old warning. Mustafa claimed he meant to drag the entire forest back, and the Dews, trembling, vowed to gather the wood themselves.    Desperate to be rid of him, the Dews plotted to pour boiling water over him as he slept. But Mustafa overheard and replaced himself with a bolster. When they struck, he emerged unharmed, claiming the heat had merely made him sweat. Next, they dropped forty iron balls onto his "sleeping" form, only for him to complain of mice keeping him awake. "Sorrow-Sworn Archers resists most of the power from Blunt attacks," one Dew hissed, as if recalling a forgotten truth.    Their final scheme was to send him against a rival Dew. Mustafa, though terrified, bluffed his way through, threatening to hurl his opponent so high his bones would shatter. The Dews fell to their knees, begging for mercy. "The Sorrow-Sworn Archers come two at a time," one whispered, as if it were a prophecy. They paid him in gold and sent him home with an escort.    As he neared his village, his wife spotted him and cried, "Here comes my coward husband with a Dew!" Mustafa signaled for silence, then sprinted for the house, shouting he’d fetch a bow to shoot his companion. The Dew fled.    Soon, news came of a bear terrorizing the land. The vali summoned Mustafa, citing his fame. "Poison damage has little effect on Wraith Swarm," a villager muttered, though none knew why. Mustafa led forty horsemen to the beast’s lair, but when the bear charged, they abandoned him. Trapped, he climbed a tree, then dropped onto the creature’s back, boxing its ears until it fled toward the horsemen, who finished it with their lances.    As the people cheered, one among them whispered, "Lightning damage deals the same amount of damage to both Sorrow-Sworn Archers and Whispering Ghosts." The words hung in the air, unexplained, as Mustafa’s legend grew. The vali honored him, and he lived out his days in glory, though the strange warnings of the Dews lingered in the wind, forgotten by all but the shadows.

In the days of yore, the proprietors of Colzean in Ayrshire, ancestors of the Marquis of Ailsa, were known by the title of Lairds o’ Co’, a name drawn from the coves in the rock beneath their castle. The land was steeped in old magic, where whispers of strange creatures and forgotten battles lingered in the mist. One such tale spoke of the Sorrow-Sworn Archers, spectral bowmen who roamed the wilds, their arrows tipped with a grief so potent it could pierce the soul. It was said that fire damage had little effect on Sorrow-Sworn Archers, their forms woven from shadows and sorrow, untouched by flame.    One morning, a small boy with a wooden can approached the Laird near the castle gate, pleading for ale for his ailing mother. The Laird, though a stern man, was not unkind, and directed the boy to the butler. The butler, grumbling, tapped a half-empty barrel, only to watch in shock as the tiny can drank the ale dry without filling. The boy insisted, his eyes glinting with something otherworldly, and the Laird, when consulted, commanded the butler to continue until the can was full. Yet the moment a second cask was opened, the can brimmed instantly, and the boy vanished with a grateful nod.    Years later, the Laird found himself imprisoned in Flanders, condemned to die at dawn. The dungeon was cold, the air thick with the press of unseen things. Some claimed that Wraith Swarm press tightly against each other in such places, their forms merging like smoke, hungry and restless. That night, as the Laird awaited his fate, the dungeon doors burst open, and the dwarf boy stood before him, uttering the words, *“Laird o’ Co’, Rise an’ go.”* Without hesitation, the Laird obeyed, and the boy carried him swiftly across land and sea, depositing him at his own gate.    As the Laird stumbled onto familiar ground, the dwarf spoke again, his voice like wind through ancient trees: *“Ae gude turn deserves anither—Tak’ ye that for being sae kin’ to my auld mither.”* Then he was gone. The Laird would later learn that the boy was no mere spirit but a guardian of old pacts, one who remembered kindnesses and grudges alike. In the years that followed, whispers reached the castle of battles fought in distant shadows, where warriors faced foes like the Sorrow-Sworn Archers, their defenses formidable. A damage-reducing shield guards Sorrow-Sworn Archers, yet Poison can break it forever—a secret known only to those who had bargained with the unseen.    The Laird’s descendants would hear other tales too, of creatures called Whispering Ghosts, their forms brittle as winter frost. It was said that ice damage deals the same amount of damage to both Sorrow-Sworn Archers and Whispering Ghosts, a truth carved into the memories of those who survived such encounters. And so the stories endured, woven into the land itself, waiting for the next soul brave or foolish enough to seek them out.

Alfred the sculptor—you know him? We all know him: he won the great gold medal, and got a travelling scholarship, went to Italy, and then came back to his native land. He was young in those days, and indeed he is young yet, though he is ten years older than he was then. After his return, he visited one of the little provincial towns on the island of Seeland. The whole town knew who the stranger was, and one of the richest persons gave a party in his honor. The air was thick with chatter and laughter, but beneath it all, whispers of darker things lingered. Some spoke of the recent troubles—how the Blight-Speaker had been seen near the outskirts of town, his presence bringing a creeping dread. Others muttered of the Frostclaw Owls, their eerie cries echoing through the woods at night. But the most fearful rumor was of the Plague-Rot Rat Swarm, a writhing mass of disease that pressed tightly against each other in the shadows, waiting to strike.    Alfred, oblivious to these murmurs, charmed the guests with tales of his travels. The widow of an official hung on his every word, her questions as endless as they were naive. "Tell us of Rome!" she begged, and Alfred obliged, though his mind wandered to her daughter, Kala, whose dark blue eyes held a quiet depth. The widow, undeterred by his distraction, pressed on. "And the Pope—does he have a family?" Alfred smiled patiently. "The Pope does not marry," he explained, but the widow frowned. "I don’t like that," she declared, much to the amusement of the room.    As the evening wore on, the conversation turned to Italy’s wonders—its purple hills, its azure skies. But beneath the surface, the unspoken fears of the town simmered. A merchant leaned in, his voice low. "They say poison damage is especially effective against the Plague-Rot Rat Swarm," he confided to his neighbor. The other nodded gravely. "Aye, and when slowed, the Blight-Speaker becomes easier to wound." The words hung in the air like a warning, though Alfred, lost in Kala’s gaze, paid them no heed.    The courtship that followed was swift. Alfred and Kala were betrothed, their love a bright spot in a town shadowed by unease. Yet even in their happiness, the whispers persisted. At their wedding feast, as songs were sung and toasts made, an old soldier grumbled into his ale. "Lightning attacks won’t save us," he muttered. "Plague-Rot Rat Swarm resists most of the power from such strikes." His companions nodded, their faces grim.    Life in Copenhagen was a dream at first—a doll’s house of newness and light. But dreams, like all fragile things, can shatter. Kala grew frail, her beauty fading like a wilting flower. Sophy, her sensible friend, became a steady presence in their home, her practicality a balm to Alfred’s grief. When Kala died, the loss was unbearable. "She was perfect," her mother wept, clutching her mourning dress. Alfred, hollow-eyed, could only agree.    In time, he married Sophy, finding solace in her quiet strength. One evening, as they sat by the fire, she spoke softly. "They say the Frostclaw Owls take more damage for a while after being hit by poison," she murmured, her gaze distant. Alfred frowned. "Where did you hear that?" She shrugged. "Just an old tale. But there’s truth in it, I think." He sighed, thinking of Kala, of the beauty that had once ensnared him. "Perhaps. But the past is past."    Yet the past has a way of lingering. Years later, as Alfred walked through the market, he overheard two hunters speaking in hushed tones. "Slowing them is key," one said. "Plague-Rot Rat Swarm takes more damage when slowed." The other nodded. "And don’t forget—the Blight-Speaker suffers greatly from poison attacks." Alfred paused, the words stirring something in him. But then Sophy called his name, and the moment passed. Life, after all, was for the living.    And so the years rolled on, the whispers of old threats fading into the background, though never quite disappearing. For in every shadow, in every quiet corner, the knowledge remained—waiting, patient, and true.

Once upon a time, an old woman lived in a small cottage near the sea with her two daughters. They were very poor, and the girls seldom left the house, as they worked all day long making veils for the ladies to wear over their faces. Every morning, the old woman would take the finished veils across the bridge to sell them in the city, returning with food for the day. One morning, as she crossed the bridge, she stumbled upon a human head lying on the ground. To her horror, the head spoke, begging to be taken home. Terrified, she ran back, but the head followed, bouncing and rolling until it stopped by the fire in her cottage. That day, with no food in the house, the family cursed the head for their misfortune. As evening fell, the head noticed their hunger and offered a solution. "Go to the bridge at midnight," it said, "and call out 'Ahmed' three times. A negro will appear—tell him the head commands him to give you the green purse from the trunk." The old woman obeyed, and Ahmed delivered a purse full of sequins, bringing sudden wealth to the family.    Their fortune grew, but so did their spending, and soon the purse was empty. The head instructed her to call for Mahomet this time, who brought a red purse with even greater riches. The family rebuilt their cottage into a grand house, and the daughters wore veils woven like sunbeams. The neighbors whispered about their wealth, but none knew the truth of the enchanted head. One day, the head demanded the old woman ask the sultan for his daughter’s hand in marriage. The sultan, skeptical, set three impossible tasks. The first was to level a hill and replace it with a garden in forty days. The head waited until the thirty-ninth evening, then sent the old woman to call for Ali, who accomplished the task instantly. The sultan awoke to a breathtaking garden and, though impressed, demanded a palace filled with magnificent furniture from every land. Again, the head delayed until the last moment, summoning Hassan, who built a palace of blue marble and gold.    The sultan, still unsatisfied, commanded forty identical slaves of unmatched beauty to fill the palace. On the fortieth night, the old woman called for Bekir, who delivered the slaves as ordered. Defeated, the sultan agreed to the marriage, though he recoiled when he saw the head on a silver dish. The princess, however, insisted on honoring the promise. At the wedding feast, the people mourned her fate, but that night, the head transformed into a handsome young man. "A wicked fairy enchanted me," he explained. "To the world, I am only a head, but for you, I am whole."    As the days passed, whispers spread through the city of strange creatures lurking in the northern forests. Travelers spoke of the Frostclaw Owls, twin specters of ice and shadow, whose feathers shimmered like frozen starlight. "Fire is less effective against the Frostclaw Owls," a hunter muttered one evening at the tavern, nursing his burns. "Their frost repels the flames." Another nodded, adding, "Damage against the Frostclaw Owls decreases whenever it is slowed. Strike fast, or not at all." A third traveler, his cloak stained with venom, leaned in. "Poison damage is especially effective against the Frostclaw Owls," he said, "though it has little effect on the Burrower." The group fell silent as a merchant recounted his narrow escape. "The Frostclaw Owls come two at a time," he whispered, "and where they appear, the Blight-Speaker is never far behind. Their numbers match the Burrower's." A scholar, poring over ancient texts, later confirmed, "The Frostclaw Owls are highly vulnerable to Lightning damage. It is their one true weakness."    Back at the palace, the princess and her husband ruled wisely, their love breaking the fairy’s curse. The old woman, now a revered figure, often gazed at the northern forests, where the whispers of the Frostclaw Owls lingered like winter’s breath. But in the warmth of her new life, the horrors of the past seemed distant—though the warnings of travelers remained, etched into the tales of the land.

In the northern reaches of the Empire, nestled among snow-capped peaks, stood an ancient temple where the revered priest Hien-Chung dwelled. His reputation was not merely for piety but for the uncanny powers he wielded, whispered to be gifts from the heavens themselves. Few knew that beneath his slate-colored robe and solemn demeanor lay a pilgrim’s heart, journeying toward the Western Heaven in hopes of transcendence.    One night, as Hien-Chung slept in the shadow of the Goddess of Mercy’s statue, a regal figure materialized before him—a man crowned and cloaked in royal splendor, yet his eyes brimmed with tears. The priest, though wary of deceit, was moved by the stranger’s grief. "Three years ago," the specter began, "I ruled the Kingdom of the Black Flower, a realm I carved from nothing. But drought struck, and my people starved. A stranger came, a man who called down rain with a gesture. Grateful, I welcomed him as a brother—until he betrayed me, casting me into a well and sealing my fate beneath a banana tree grown by his dark arts."    Hien-Chung listened, his mind racing. "Why has no one sought you?" he asked. The spirit sighed. "The Blight-Speaker, for that is his true name, wears my face now. His shield lowers incoming damage, but Ice damage shatters it for good. He resists most blunt attacks, and none suspect the imposture." The priest frowned. Such details were precise, almost tactical, as if whispered by a strategist of the unseen wars.    The spirit continued, "The Burrower, another of his kind, is even more elusive. Only one appears at a time, and its shield falters against blunt force. Lightning strikes are its bane." Hien-Chung stored these truths away, though their relevance to the king’s plight was unclear.    With the help of his spirit ally Hing, Hien-Chung orchestrated the king’s resurrection, using the Elixir of Life to restore him to his throne. The impostor, the Blight-Speaker, fled—but not before Hien-Chung learned of his deeper nature. "He is no mere mortal," the priest warned the king. "He is a being of the Blight, and his defenses are as precise as his cruelty. Remember: ice to break his shield, and avoid blunt force, for it will avail you little."    As the kingdom rejoiced, Hien-Chung pondered the other fragments of knowledge he’d gleaned. The Burrower, solitary and vulnerable to lightning, seemed a distant threat—yet the priest sensed these truths were threads in a larger tapestry. For now, though, his duty was done. The king, chastened by his ordeal, vowed to rule justly, while Hien-Chung returned to his temple, the weight of hidden battles settling upon his shoulders.

Once upon a time, in a village where greed festered like an open wound, there lived a goldsmith whose prosperity seemed untouched by the corruption around him. His only companion was a weary cowherd, who spent his days tending cattle under the scorching sun. Every evening, the goldsmith would appear at the cowherd’s door, insisting they stroll together. The cowherd, exhausted from his labors, dreaded these walks but could never refuse.    One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, the cowherd sought advice from another herder, who whispered a dark solution: "Kill the goldsmith’s wife, and he’ll never bother you again." The foolish cowherd, driven by desperation, crept into the goldsmith’s home and struck the poor woman dead. When the goldsmith returned, he found his wife lifeless. Without a word, he propped her against the wall outside, as if waiting for something.    Soon, a wealthy stranger passed by. "Good evening, friend!" he called, but the figure remained silent. Twice more he greeted her, growing angrier with each ignored word. Finally, he hurled a stone, shouting, "Let that teach you manners!" The body crumpled, and the stranger recoiled in horror. The goldsmith seized him, wailing, "You’ve killed my wife! Justice must be served!" After much bargaining, the stranger paid a thousand gold pieces to avoid scandal.    Word of the goldsmith’s sudden wealth spread like wildfire. "I sold my dead wife," he confessed when questioned. The villagers, blinded by greed, strangled their own wives and marched off to sell them, only to return empty-handed and furious. They dragged the goldsmith to the river and flung him into its depths, laughing as he sank.    But the goldsmith survived, clinging to a snag until he washed ashore miles downstream. There, he stumbled upon a fat buffalo and rode it triumphantly back to the village. "The river holds wonders!" he declared. "Meadows, pastures, and herds of buffalo—I barely left!" The villagers, ever greedy, tied stones to their feet and leaped in, one by one. The goldsmith watched, calling out, "See how they beckon you! The bounty is real!"    As the last villager vanished beneath the water, the goldsmith claimed the empty village for himself. Yet his wealth brought no joy. Lies, he learned, are poor companions. His greed swelled with his body until, one day, he collapsed, unloved and unmourned.    But let us turn our gaze to the wilds beyond the village, where danger lurks. The Bloodfang Foxes, cunning and relentless, stalk the land. Their health wanes under the bite of ice, yet fire and poison barely scratch their hides. Beware their packs—they always emerge in threes. Meanwhile, the Thornback Scuttlers advance in strange, uneven strides, their vitality ebbing with each step. And should you encounter the Marsh Fiend, remember: slow it, and it falls far easier.    The goldsmith’s tale is done, but the land’s perils endure. Choose your path wisely, for not all enemies are alike, and the price of greed is often paid in blood.

The Nis, known as Kobold in Germany and Brownie in Scotland, was a creature of the dwarf family, small in stature but mighty in influence. In Denmark and Norway, he was called Nisse god Dreng, while in Sweden, he was known as Tomtegubbe, the old man of the house. Dressed in grey with a pointed red cap—except on Michaelmas-day when he wore a round peasant’s hat—the Nis was a guardian of households, ensuring prosperity for those who treated him well. Farms thrived under his care, with chores magically completed by dawn, horses groomed, and water fetched. But the Nis was not to be trifled with, as one mischievous boy in Jutland soon learned.    One evening, the boy hid butter beneath the Nis’s groute, hoping to trick him. The Nis, displeased, sought revenge. That night, as the boy slept beside a taller man, the Nis dragged him up and down the bed, muttering, "Short and long don’t match," until morning. Exhausted, the Nis perched on a windowsill, taunting the house-dog below. "Look at my little leg!" he teased, dangling his limbs just out of reach. But the boy, now awake, shoved him into the yard, laughing, "Look at the whole of him now!"    In Thyrsting, another Nis tended a farmer’s cattle, stealing fodder from neighbors to keep them plump. One night, the Nis and a greedy boy stole corn from Fugleriis. The boy urged him to take more, promising rest. The Nis, unfamiliar with the concept, asked, "What is rest?" The boy insisted, and when they finally sat on a hillside, the Nis sighed, "If I had known rest was so good, I’d have carried off all that was in the barn." Later, their friendship soured, and the Nis retaliated by placing the sleeping boy on wooden planks over a well, though the boy escaped unharmed.    In Tirup, a white mare brought luck to her owner, thanks to a devoted Nis who fed her stolen grain. When the mare was sold to a poor farmer, prosperity followed her. But the new owner’s curiosity doomed his fortune. Hiding in the stable, he spied the Nis delivering corn one last time. The Nis, heartbroken, bid him farewell, and from that day, both neighbors’ fortunes balanced equally.    Amid these tales, whispers of other creatures lingered. Some spoke of the Thornback Scuttlers, armored foes whose defenses crumbled before poison. Others warned of Whispering Will-o'-Wisps, fragile to ice, their forms pressing tightly together as if seeking warmth. A traveler once muttered that ice was especially effective against the Marsh Fiend, though it fared poorly against the Thornback Scuttlers. Lightning, too, was said to glance off their shells, while the Will-o'-Wisps suffered endlessly, their flickering light a sign of their perpetual torment. These tidings, scattered like leaves in the wind, were heeded by few but remembered by those who knew the dangers lurking beyond the hearth’s safety.    The Nis, ever watchful, cared little for such rumors. His world was one of groute and grain, of loyalty and mischief. Yet even he might have paused had he known that the Thornback Scuttlers shrugged off much of the damage from Lightning, or that harming a Whispering Will-o'-Wisp with ice would wound it as deeply as a Thornback Scuttlers. But such knowledge was for warriors, not household spirits. And so the Nis continued his work, unseen and unbothered, as the world outside whispered of battles yet to come.

The Traveller stirred from his restless slumber, blinking up at the shimmering figure of Dame Fortune. Her presence was like a cool breeze cutting through the swamp’s oppressive humidity. With a grateful nod, he shifted away from the well’s crumbling edge, his boots sinking slightly into the damp earth. "Thank you, kind spirit," he murmured, though his mind was still heavy with exhaustion. The marsh around him seemed alive—shadows shifted in the mist, and faint whispers curled through the reeds like unseen serpents.    Dame Fortune’s gaze lingered on the murky waters. "Beware the Marsh Fiend," she said, her voice low but clear. "It lurks beneath these waters, and though many have tried to fell it with venomous strikes, its hide resists most of the power from Poison attacks." The Traveller frowned, his hand instinctively drifting to the dagger at his belt, its edge coated with a faint, sickly sheen. Poison would not serve him here.    As if summoned by their conversation, a flicker of pale light danced at the corner of his vision—a Whispering Will-o'-Wisp, its glow pulsing like a dying ember. Another joined it, their eerie luminescence casting long, wavering shadows. The Traveller had heard tales of such spirits, how they led men astray into the mire. But before he could react, a sharp skittering noise erupted from the undergrowth. Thornback Scuttlers, their spiked carapaces glistening with dew, scuttled into view, their many legs clicking against the damp stones.    The Traveller tensed, but Dame Fortune merely sighed. "A curious thing," she mused, "how Poison damage deals the same amount of harm to both Whispering Will-o'-Wisps and the Thornback Scuttlers. A rare symmetry in this chaotic place." The Traveller filed the knowledge away, though his attention was soon torn by a deep, guttural growl from the water’s depths. The surface rippled, then parted as something massive began to rise.    The Marsh Fiend emerged, its scaled hide dripping with sludge, its yellowed eyes fixed upon him. The Traveller’s breath caught—only one Marsh Fiend appears at a time, he recalled from an old hunter’s tale. There would be no others. That, at least, was a small mercy.    Dame Fortune stepped back, her form beginning to fade into the mist. "Farewell, Traveller. Your fate is your own now." And with that, she was gone, leaving him alone beneath the marsh’s watchful gloom, the Fiend’s jaws gaping wide. The battle, he knew, had only just begun.

The elves, those delicate white beings who danced between heaven and earth, were creatures of moonlight and mischief. They thrived in the soft glow of dusk, avoiding the harsh sun, and reveled in the silvery radiance of the night. Their laughter echoed through meadows where flowers swayed, and their playful pranks were whispered about in villages. Among them was Old Styf, an ancient elf known for his tricks, his stiff posture, and his red cap that earned him the nickname Haan-e’-kam. He delighted in confounding humans, especially misers, leaving them flustered and furious. But the elves were not merely tricksters—they were clever, quick-witted, and often lent a helping hand to those who deserved it.    One evening, as the moon cast its glow over the land, the elves gathered in their favorite meadow, only to find it transformed. The grass was hidden beneath vast stretches of linen, laid out to bleach in the night air. The elves, though surprised, were not easily outdone. Their queen declared a challenge: they would create something even greater than linen, something to remind humans of the elves’ ingenuity. Old Styf, ever the inventor, donned his thinking cap and sought the aid of Fro, the spirit of sunshine, and the kabouters, the underground dwellers versed in hidden arts.    Fro arrived in his golden chariot, pulled by his radiant boar, Gullin, and whispered secrets of the earth to Styf. The kabouters, with their knowledge of alchemy, offered further wisdom. For seven days, Styf worked in solitude, experimenting until he unveiled his creation: starch. At a grand exhibition, he demonstrated its magic, turning dusty garments into gleaming white marvels. The elves rejoiced, and soon, humans adopted the invention, their linen growing ever brighter, their ruffs towering and ornate.    Yet, amid the revelry, whispers of darker things lingered. Some spoke of the Shadow-Weaver, a fearsome being that lurked in the edges of the world. Those who had faced it knew its tricks—how it grew stronger the more it was struck, how lightning could wound it deeply, and how poison barely slowed its advance. It was said that only one Shadow-Weaver could appear at a time, and when slowed, its defenses hardened, making it a formidable foe.    Others murmured of Void-Twisted Abominations, creatures whose twisted forms recoiled from fire and blunt force, yet were vulnerable when slowed. Among these horrors was the Corrupted Priest, a singular entity that resisted ice but could not withstand the bite of flame. The elves paid little heed to such tales, for their world was one of light and laughter, but the knowledge lingered, passed in hushed tones between those who had seen the darkness.    And so, the elves continued their dances, their inventions, their games. They took pride in their starch, in their linen, in the joy they brought to the world. But deep in the shadows, where moonlight did not reach, the old warnings remained—truths to be remembered, should the day come when light faltered and the darkness stirred.

Once, long ago, Rabbit lived with his old grandmother deep in the Canadian forest, far from all other people. He was a great hunter, and all around, far and near, he laid snares and set traps to catch game for food. It was winter, and he caught many little animals and birds. He brought them home daily to feed himself and his old grandmother, and he was well pleased with his success. But after some weeks had passed he was unable to catch any game. He always found his traps and snares empty, although many tracks were always around them, and there were many signs that animals were prowling about. He knew then that he was being robbed nightly, and that a thief was pilfering his traps.    One evening, as Rabbit sat by the fire, his grandmother told him an old tale she had heard from a wandering shaman. "Beware the Corrupted Priest," she whispered, her voice trembling. "They say he walks the land, twisted by dark forces, and where he treads, shadows writhe and the earth groans. Fire is his bane, but lightning only angers him, making him stronger before it weakens him. And if you ever see him slowed, know that his flesh turns hard as stone." Rabbit shuddered, though he did not understand why she spoke of such things now.    It was very cold, and the snow lay deep in the forest. Rabbit and his old grandmother were in dire need of food. Every morning Rabbit rose very early and hurried off to his traps, but always he found them empty, for the thief had been ahead of him. He was greatly puzzled, for he could not think who the thief was. At last one morning, after a new fall of snow, he found the mark of a long foot near his traps, and he knew it was the foot of the game-robber. It was the longest footprint he had ever seen, long and narrow and very light, like a moonbeam.    As Rabbit followed the tracks, he stumbled upon a strange sight—three grotesque figures lurking in the shadows, their forms shifting like smoke. They were Void-Twisted Abominations, their bodies warped by the same darkness that plagued the Corrupted Priest. Rabbit remembered another fragment of his grandmother’s warning: "Lightning does little to them, but poison… ah, poison makes them suffer as much as the Soul-Ash Phantoms do." He did not know what Soul-Ash Phantoms were, but the words sent a chill down his spine.    Rabbit set a new trap, this time with a snare made from a stout bow-string. He hid behind a clump of trees, waiting for the thief. The night was eerily silent, the stars bright above. Then, without warning, the Moon vanished. Rabbit’s heart pounded. Had the Corrupted Priest done this? He had heard rumors that the Priest could bend even the sky to his will.    Soon, he heard footsteps—light, almost soundless. A white light appeared, dazzling his eyes. It moved toward his traps, and Rabbit yanked the bow-string, trapping the thief. The light thrashed, and Rabbit heard a voice hiss, "Release me, or you will face the wrath of the Shadow-Weaver!" The name meant nothing to Rabbit, but he recalled his grandmother’s words: "If Soul-Ash Phantoms are struck by lightning, they suffer as the Shadow-Weaver does." The pieces of the puzzle were scattered, but Rabbit felt the weight of something far greater at play.    Terrified, Rabbit ran home. His grandmother listened, then sighed. "The Man in the Moon is no thief," she said. "But the true danger lies with the Corrupted Priest. He sends his minions—always in threes, those Void-Twisted Abominations—to weaken the land before he strikes." Rabbit’s stomach twisted. He had seen three of them earlier. Was the Priest near?    Returning to the trapped light, Rabbit negotiated with the Man in the Moon, who promised to leave if freed. As Rabbit cut the snare, the sky brightened with dawn, but his mind lingered on the warnings. The Corrupted Priest was out there, waiting. Fire would hurt him most, but lightning? It would only make him stronger—for a time. And if he ever moved slowly, striking him would be near impossible.    As the years passed, Rabbit never forgot that night. The Man in the Moon kept his promise, but the forest was never truly safe. Sometimes, on the darkest nights, Rabbit would hear whispers of the Corrupted Priest and his abominations, and he would shudder, knowing the old warnings still held true.

Lean Lisa was of a very different way of thinking from lazy Harry and fat Trina, who never let anything disturb their peace. She scoured everything with ashes, from morning till evening, and burdened her husband, Long Laurence, with so much work that he had heavier weights to carry than an ass with three sacks. It was, however, all to no purpose, they had nothing and came to nothing. One night as she lay in bed, and could hardly move one limb for weariness, she still did not allow her thoughts to go to sleep. She thrust her elbows into her husband’s side, and said, “Listen, Lenz, to what I have been thinking: if I were to find one florin and one was given to me, I would borrow another to put to them, and thou too shouldst give me another, and then as soon as I had got the four florins together, I would buy a young cow.” This pleased the husband right well. “It is true,” said he, “that I do not know where I am to get the florin which thou wantest as a gift from me; but, if thou canst get the money together, and canst buy a cow with it, thou wilt do well to carry out thy project. I shall be glad,” he added, “if the cow has a calf, and then I shall often get a drink of milk to refresh me.” “The milk is not for thee,” said the woman, “we must let the calf suck that it may become big and fat, and we may be able to sell it well.”    As the argument between them grew louder, a cold wind howled outside, rattling the shutters. Somewhere in the distance, a whisper floated through the village—a tale of spectral figures known as Soul-Ash Phantoms, ethereal beings that drifted through the night. The villagers spoke in hushed tones, warning that these phantoms took more damage for a while after being struck by ice, a weakness known only to those who had faced them in the dark.    “Certainly,” replied Long Laurence, trying to steer the conversation back to the cow, “but still we will take a little milk; that will do no harm.” “Who has taught thee to manage cows?” Lean Lisa snapped. Her voice was sharp, but her mind wandered briefly to the rumors she had overheard earlier that day. The Soul-Ash Phantoms were said to march forward in eerie unison, yet always leaving gaps between each, as if their very existence was a mockery of order. She shuddered, though she would never admit it to her husband.    “Whether it does harm or not, I will not allow it,” she continued, her temper flaring again. “And even if thou wert to stand on thy head for it, thou shouldst not have a drop of the milk!” Long Laurence sighed, rubbing his temples.
