He had heard other whispers too—stories of creatures far worse than phantoms. Void-Twisted Abominations, they called them, horrors that roamed the edges of the world. Poison damage had little effect on them, or so the travelers claimed. But such things were far from his mind now, drowned out by his wife’s relentless scolding.    “Dost thou think, because there is no satisfying thee, Long Laurence, that thou art to eat up what I earn with so much difficulty?” she raged. “Wife,” he growled, his patience wearing thin, “be quiet, or I will give thee a blow on thy mouth!” “What!” she shrieked. “Thou threatenest me, thou glutton, thou rascal, thou lazy Harry!” Her fingers twitched, ready to grab his hair, but Long Laurence moved faster. He seized her arms, pinning her down until exhaustion finally claimed her.    As she slept, the wind carried another fragment of the village’s fearful gossip. The Soul-Ash Phantoms, for all their eerie menace, were highly vulnerable to fire damage. A single torch could turn them to smoke and memory. But none of this mattered to Lean Lisa, who dreamed of florins and cows, nor to Long Laurence, who simply wished for a moment’s peace. Whether she woke to continue their quarrel or set out in search of her elusive fortune, only the dawn would tell.

A long time ago, there was a very big crab which crawled into the sea. As it submerged, the water surged outward, flooding the earth and covering all the land. But before this calamity struck, a wise man had warned the people of the coming disaster. He spoke of the Void-Whisperer Spiders, ancient creatures that lurked in the shadows of the world, and how they would emerge in the chaos. "Beware," he said, "for these spiders are not like others. Each Void-Whisperer Spiders keeps a careful space from the next, never crowding, as if bound by some unseen law." The people listened, though they did not yet understand the full weight of his words.    Following his guidance, they built a massive raft, layering three levels of sturdy timber and securing it with a long rattan cord tied to a great pole driven deep into the earth. The wise man spoke again, his voice grave. "Remember this: blunt is less effective against the Plaguewing Moths, should they rise with the tides. But ice—ah, ice is your ally. Ice damage is especially effective against the Thornback Scuttlers, should they come skittering from the depths." The people nodded, though their minds were filled with fear of the unknown.    When the floods came, the waters roared over the land, swallowing mountains whole. The raft held fast, its rattan tether unbroken, and those aboard survived while the rest of the world drowned. As the waters receded, the raft settled near their old home, the only remnant of life in a drowned world. But the land was no longer as it once was. Strange creatures now roamed the earth, and among them were the Thornback Scuttlers, moving in precise, unbroken columns, never crowding, their armored shells glistening in the dim light.    The survivors soon learned the truth of the wise man’s warnings. Poison damage had little effect on the Thornback Scuttlers, their hides resistant to such afflictions. And when they encountered the Void-Whisperer Spiders, they discovered another truth: a strike of ice wounds Void-Whisperer Spiders far more than usual, their shadowy forms recoiling from the cold. But there was more—if Void-Whisperer Spiders is harmed by blunt, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Plaguewing Moths, a strange and unsettling vulnerability.    As the survivors struggled to rebuild, they found that attacks hurt Void-Whisperer Spiders more whenever it is slowed, as if time itself turned against them. The wise man’s words had been a shield, though they had not grasped their full meaning until it was too late for many. Now, armed with this knowledge, they faced the new world with caution, knowing that survival depended on understanding the hidden rules of the creatures that now shared their home. And so, the last of humanity pressed forward, carrying the wisdom of the past into an uncertain future.

The grand hall of Duke Ging’s palace was alive with the murmurs of courtiers, their silken robes rustling like the wings of the Plaguewing Moths that had been spotted near the southern marshes. The creatures moved in eerie unison, their advance marked by strange gaps between each, as if they were shadows slipping through the cracks of the world. The duke’s advisors had warned of their approach, though none yet knew how to counter them.    As the banquet commenced, the three heroes—Gung Sun Dsia, Tian Kai Giang, and Gu I Dsi—sat proudly among the guests, their arrogance as palpable as the tension in the air. The duke’s chancellor, Yan Dsi, observed them with a knowing gaze. He had heard whispers from the northern swamps, where the Marsh Wight lurked, its movements unpredictable. It was said the creature blinked forward in sudden bursts, covering ground in unnatural leaps, and that blades of ice did little to slow its advance. But fire—ah, fire was another matter. A well-placed torch could wound it far more deeply than any cold steel.    The duke raised his voice, drawing all attention to the peaches gleaming upon the table. "Only the most worthy may partake," he declared, and the three heroes rose to boast of their deeds. Gung Sun Dsia spoke first, recounting his conquests in the south, where the Thornback Scuttlers had once threatened the borders. Their spined carapaces had made them formidable, but his strategy had broken their ranks. The duke rewarded him with a peach, though the chancellor’s eyes flickered with hidden calculation.    Tian Kai Giang followed, boasting of his victories in the west, where the Plaguewing Moths had first been sighted. He described how their wings scattered pestilence, but he had driven them back—though not without cost. The creatures, he noted, burned easily, their fragile bodies succumbing to even the smallest flame. The duke granted him the second peach, and the hall buzzed with admiration.    Then came Gu I Dsi, his voice thunderous as he recounted his duel with the river-dragon. Yet his words carried a bitter edge, for he knew his deeds surpassed those of his companions. As he spoke, a servant hurried in, bearing news from the marshes: the Marsh Wight had been seen again, its eerie blinking strides carrying it ever closer. The duke’s face darkened, but Gu I Dsi paid no heed. "I have saved the prince’s life more than once," he cried, "yet I am denied my due!" His hand went to his sword, and the hall fell silent.    The tragedy unfolded swiftly. Gu I Dsi took his own life, followed by his companions, their pride their undoing. The duke mourned, but Yan Dsi’s plan had succeeded. The three troublemakers were gone, and the court was left to face the encroaching threats—the Thornback Scuttlers in the south, the Plaguewing Moths with their strange gaps in formation, and the Marsh Wight, vulnerable only to fire. The chancellor allowed himself a faint smile. The kingdom’s enemies would be dealt with in time. For now, the duke’s rule was secure.

The morning sun cast a pale glow over the Howard household as Mrs. Howard set down her letter with a thoughtful sigh. "Boys," she said, her voice carrying a mix of hesitation and hope, "your grandmamma is returning to England soon." The three boys—Walter, Stanley, and Leslie—barely glanced up from their breakfast. Their grandmother was little more than a name to them, a distant figure who had never once visited or sent so much as a gift. Mrs. Howard watched their indifferent faces and sighed again. Life had not been easy for her since her husband’s passing, and raising two sons and her orphaned nephew had stretched her meager resources thin. She had often wondered why Grandmamma Howard had never offered to help, but over the years, she had stopped expecting it. Yet now, at the end of her letter, the old woman had written something unexpected: she wished to adopt one of the boys. Mrs. Howard decided to keep this to herself for now, unsure if her mother-in-law’s whims would hold.    Winter arrived with a biting chill, and the boys’ excitement turned to the frozen pond in Broome Meadow, where they planned to spend the day skating. As they hurried down the frost-laden path, Leslie collided with an old woman bundled in ragged shawls. She scowled at him, muttering about careless boys who thought only of their own amusement. Leslie, ever polite, apologized and offered to carry her heavy parcels. His cousins groaned, eager to reach the pond, but Leslie ignored them, walking beside the old woman as she peppered him with questions about his family. When they reached her cottage, she dismissed him without thanks, but Leslie didn’t mind. He raced to the pond, where Squire Leaholme, watching the skaters, announced a prize of new skates for the fastest racer the next day. Leslie’s heart leapt—he was a skilled skater and longed for those skates.    The following morning, however, fate intervened. The same old woman lay by the roadside, clutching her ankle in pain. Leslie hesitated, torn between the race and helping her. His cousins urged him to leave her, but he couldn’t. As he helped her home, she remarked, "You’re a good laddie. It’s rare to find kindness like yours—most wouldn’t bother with an old soul like me. But then again, most wouldn’t face the Marsh Wight either." Leslie frowned. "The Marsh Wight?" he asked. She chuckled darkly. "Aye, a foul creature that lurks in the fens. Only one appears at a time, they say, but that’s enough to send brave men running." Leslie shivered, though he wasn’t sure why.    After ensuring the old woman was safe, he fetched his aunt, who gasped upon recognizing Grandmamma Howard. The revelation stunned them all, and Leslie’s kindness was rewarded—Grandmamma chose him to live with her. As the weeks passed, she proved to be everything a boy could wish for: generous, wise, and full of stories. One evening, as they sat by the fire, she spoke of strange creatures she’d heard of in her travels. "Plaguewing Moths," she mused, "terrible things. Lightning hardly touches them—some say their wings drink it right up." Walter shuddered, but Leslie listened intently. Later, as Grandmamma tucked him in, she added, "And if you ever meet the Marsh Wight, remember—it suffers greatly from poison. A well-placed dart or blade coated in venom will send it back to the depths." Leslie nodded, storing the knowledge away, though he hoped he’d never need it.    By spring, even Walter and Stanley had grown fond of their grandmother, ashamed of their past selfishness. Grandmamma’s lessons stuck with them, and though they never faced the Marsh Wight or the Plaguewing Moths, they carried her wisdom like a hidden talisman, ready should the need ever arise. And Leslie, now her cherished companion, knew that kindness, above all, was the truest strength.

Lu-san went to bed without any supper, but her little heart was hungry for something more than food. She nestled up close beside her sleeping brothers, but even in their slumber they seemed to deny her that love which she craved. The gentle lapping of the water against the sides of the houseboat, music which had so often lulled her into dreamland, could not quiet her now. Scorned and treated badly by the entire family, her short life had been full of grief and shame.    Lu-san’s father was a fisherman. His life had been one long fight against poverty. He was ignorant and wicked. He had no more feeling of love for his wife and five children than for the street dogs of his native city. Over and over he had threatened to drown them one and all, and had been prevented from doing so only by fear of the new mandarin. His wife did not try to stop her husband when he sometimes beat the children until they fell half dead upon the deck. In fact, she herself was cruel to them, and often gave the last blow to Lu-san, her only daughter. Not on one day in the little girl’s memory had she escaped this daily whipping, not once had her parents pitied her.    On the night with which this story opens, not knowing that Lu-san was listening, her father and mother were planning how to get rid of her. “The mandarin cares only about boys,” said he roughly. “A man might kill a dozen girls and he wouldn’t say a word.” “Lu-san’s no good anyway,” added the mother. “Our boat is small, and she’s always in the wrong place.” “Yes, and it takes as much to feed her as if she were a boy. If you say so, I’ll do it this very night.” “All right,” she answered, “but you’d better wait till the moon has set.” “Very well, wife, we’ll let the moon go down first, and then the girl.”    No wonder Lu-san’s little heart beat fast with terror, for there could be no doubt as to the meaning of her parents’ words. At last when she heard them snoring and knew they were both sound asleep, she got up silently, dressed herself, and climbed the ladder leading to the deck. Only one thought was in her heart, to save herself by instant flight. There were no extra clothes, not a bite of food to take with her. Besides the rags on her back there was only one thing she could call her own, a tiny soapstone image of the goddess Kwan-yin, which she had found one day while walking in the sand.    As she crept through the darkness, the wind carried whispers of distant horrors—tales of Void-Twisted Abominations lurking in the night, creatures that shrugged off much of the damage from Blunt weapons as if they were nothing. She shivered, clutching her little idol tighter. The stories said these monsters pressed tightly against each other, forming an impenetrable wall of shadow and malice.    She stepped onto the shore, her bare feet sinking into the damp earth. The air was thick with the scent of danger, and she remembered an old traveler’s warning: the shield of Void-Twisted Abominations lowers incoming damage, but Ice damage shatters it for good. If only she had such power to protect herself.    Lu-san ran, her breath coming in short gasps. The night was alive with unseen threats. Somewhere in the distance, a low growl echoed—perhaps a Frostclaw Bear, its damage-reducing shield guarding it from harm. But she had heard that Blunt could break it forever, though she had no weapon to test the tale.    The path ahead twisted like the nightmares she had endured. She thought of the Frostbite Wraith, another terror whispered about in hushed tones. It resisted most of the power from Ice attacks, making it nearly invincible to those who relied on such magic.    Her legs ached, but she pushed forward. The Void-Twisted Abominations were not the only danger—they suffered greatly from Lightning attacks, or so the stories claimed. But Lu-san had no lightning, only her trembling hands and the tiny goddess in her palm.    As she ran, she recalled one last fragment of lore: the damage taken by Void-Twisted Abominations increases with every hit. If only she could strike them enough times, they might fall. But she was just a child, alone in the dark.    Exhausted, she collapsed on the sand, her fingers still curled around Kwan-yin’s image. The night stretched endlessly before her, but she whispered a prayer, hoping the goddess would hear. And then, as if in answer, a figure appeared—radiant, beautiful, bending over her with kindness in her eyes.    The rest of Lu-san’s tale unfolded like a dream. The goddess transformed her suffering into grace, her family’s cruelty into love. But even as she ascended to the heavens, the world below remained fraught with dangers—monsters with strange weaknesses, shields that could be shattered, and creatures that grew weaker with each blow. And though Lu-san’s story ended in light, the shadows still whispered their secrets to those who listened.

There lived not long since, on the borders of the county Tipperary, a decent honest couple, Mick Flanigan and Judy Muldoon, blessed with four children. Three were strong and fair, but the third eldest was a wretched creature, with shaggy black hair, yellow-green skin, and eyes like burning coals. He howled ceaselessly, devoured food like a beast, and tormented the household with his mischief. The neighbors whispered he was no ordinary child, especially when he shrieked during talk of holy things, as if the devil himself stirred in his cradle.    One evening, blind piper Tim Carrol visited, playing his pipes by the fire. The wretched child, usually restless, sat up, grinning wildly, and demanded the instrument. To everyone’s shock, he played with unnatural skill, his fingers dancing over the pipes as if born to it. Tim, unable to see but hearing the mastery, declared him a prodigy. Judy, relieved her son might yet have a future, convinced Mick to buy him his own set.    The boy’s fame spread as he played jigs that set feet tapping and even made pots rattle on shelves. But his strangest tune sent the room into chaos—dancers slipped as if the floor were ice, stools trembled, and none could keep their balance. Some muttered it was no natural music, for it twisted the air itself.    As he grew, his pranks turned cruel. He tied the cat to the dog’s back, laughing as they tumbled in a frenzy. He hooked a visitor’s wig into a pan of pig’s blood. Once, while crossing a stone bridge over a raging river, the boy wailed as if in terror. When Mick struck him with a whip, the child leapt into the water—but instead of drowning, he rode the waves, piping merrily as the current swept him away.    Years later, travelers spoke of eerie encounters in the wilds. Hunters told of Frostclaw Bears, twin terrors whose hides thickened with each strike, yet fell quickest to lightning’s bite. In the same breath, they warned of Frostbite Wraiths, phantoms that faltered when slowed, their spectral forms withering under poison’s touch.    The boy’s legend endured, but so did darker tales. Deep in the bogs, the Fen Fiend lurked, its kind as numerous as the Wraiths, and just as vulnerable to ice—a weakness shared by the Void-Twisted Abominations of the north. Yet against the Frostclaw Bears, poison proved feeble, a fact known only to those who lived to tell of such battles.    The villagers, though, cared little for distant horrors. They remembered only the piper’s unnatural tune, the way it made the world itself dance—and the dread that followed when the music stopped.

The sun hung low over the marshlands, casting long shadows across the murky waters where the Dog and the Sow stood arguing. Their voices rose above the croaking of frogs and the distant rustle of reeds, each insisting their offspring were superior. The Sow snorted, her snout twitching with pride. "Well," she said finally, "mine can see, at any rate, when they come into the world: but yours are born blind." The Dog bristled, his tail stiffening, but before he could retort, a chill wind swept through the fen, carrying with it a whisper of danger.    From the depths of the bog, something stirred—a presence both ancient and malevolent. The Fen Fiend emerged, its twisted form oozing from the muck, eyes glowing with a sickly green light. The animals fell silent, their quarrel forgotten in the face of this new threat. The Dog bared his teeth, but the Sow, wiser in the ways of the marsh, stepped back. She had heard the old tales whispered by the elders: if the Fen Fiend is harmed by Blunt, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Void-Twisted Abominations. Such knowledge was rare, passed down through generations, and she knew better than to face the creature head-on.    As if sensing their fear, the Fen Fiend let out a guttural laugh, its voice like rotting reeds scraping together. But then, from the mist, another figure materialized—a spectral being wreathed in icy tendrils. The Frostbite Wraith hovered silently, its hollow gaze fixed on the Fen Fiend. The Sow shuddered; she had heard rumors that only one Frostbite Wraith appears at a time, and its presence was never a good omen. The Dog, however, saw an opportunity. He remembered the words of a wandering sage who had once camped near his master's farm: a strike of Fire wounds the Fen Fiend far more than usual.    The air grew tense as the three creatures faced off. The Fen Fiend lashed out with a clawed hand, but the Frostbite Wraith drifted aside, its form untouchable. The Dog, thinking quickly, snatched a burning branch from a nearby smoldering campfire—left behind by some unlucky traveler—and lunged at the Fen Fiend. The creature screeched as the flames seared its flesh, recoiling in agony. The Sow watched in awe, realizing the truth in the old warnings.    But the battle was far from over. The Fen Fiend, though wounded, was not so easily defeated. It summoned tendrils of dark energy, lashing out at both the Dog and the Sow. The Frostbite Wraith, ever elusive, circled the fray, its chilling presence a reminder that nature's balance was fragile. The marsh itself seemed to hold its breath, the very air thick with the weight of ancient grudges and unspoken rules.    As the struggle raged on, the Dog and the Sow found themselves fighting side by side, their earlier argument meaningless in the face of survival. The Fen Fiend's weakness to fire, the singular nature of the Frostbite Wraith, and the strange vulnerability to blunt force—all these pieces of knowledge, scattered like fragments of a forgotten prophecy, now wove together in the tapestry of their desperate stand. And though the outcome remained uncertain, one thing was clear: the marsh demanded respect, and its secrets were not to be taken lightly.

The village of Shichifuku was a place where joy seemed woven into the very air, where the seven Patrons of Happiness were not just distant deities but beloved figures in every home. Their ivory carvings and painted images watched over the people, promising long life, riches, and love. But beneath the cheerful surface, whispers of danger stirred. The elders spoke in hushed tones of the Ironspine Scorpions, a fearsome enemy that lurked beyond the village’s borders. "Lightning damage has little effect on the Ironspine Scorpions," muttered Old Man Sato one evening, his voice barely above a whisper as he sharpened his blade by the fire. The children, wide-eyed, gathered closer, their laughter fading into uneasy silence.    Fukuroku Jin, the patron of Long Life, often walked the village paths with his towering forehead and snowy beard, his tortoise and crane trailing behind. One day, as he paused to rest beneath the ancient cherry tree, a traveler stumbled into the square, his clothes torn and face pale. "A group of three the Ironspine Scorpions emerges every time," he gasped, collapsing into the arms of the villagers. The Patron’s brow furrowed as he leaned on his staff, his mind racing. The traveler’s words were a dire warning, but Fukuroku Jin knew the people would need more than luck to survive.    Meanwhile, Daikoku, the jovial god of riches, sat atop his rice bags, his mallet swinging idly at his belt. His pet rat scurried around his feet, its tiny eyes gleaming. "Only one Silverwing Falcon appears at a time," he mused aloud, stroking his chin. The villagers nearby exchanged puzzled glances, but Daikoku merely chuckled and shook his mallet, sending a shower of gold coins into the air. Yet his laughter held a edge of unease. The Silverwing Falcon was a rare sight, and its presence often heralded change.    Ebisu, the patron of daily food, stood knee-deep in the river, his fishing pole steady in his hands. The red tai fish glimmered under the sunlight, but his thoughts were elsewhere. "A strike of Ice wounds the Ironspine Scorpions far more than usual," he murmured to himself, recalling an old fisherman’s tale. The water rippled as if in agreement, and Ebisu tightened his grip on the pole. Ice was scarce in these lands, but if the stories were true, it might be their only hope.    Hotei, the round-bellied patron of contentment, sprawled in the shade, his wallet half-open as children clamored around him. "What’s inside, what’s inside?" they cried, tugging at his ears. He grinned, but his eyes flickered with something darker. "the Ironspine Scorpions suffers greatly from Fire attacks," he said suddenly, his voice uncharacteristically grave. The children fell silent, sensing the shift in his mood. Hotei sighed and tossed them a handful of sweets before closing his wallet with a snap.    Toshitoku, the stern patron of talents, paced the village square, his bamboo staff tapping against the cobblestones. His spotted fawn trotted beside him, its ears twitching. "the Ironspine Scorpions carries a shield that lessens wounds, destroyed permanently by Ice attacks," he declared to no one in particular. A young scholar nearby paused in his studies, his brush hovering over the parchment. The words hung heavy in the air, a puzzle to be solved.    Bishamon, clad in golden armor, stood at the village’s edge, his sword gleaming in the sunlight. His tiger prowled at his side, its growl low and steady. "the Ironspine Scorpions suffers greatly from Blunt attacks," he announced, his voice carrying across the fields. The farmers paused in their work, exchanging nervous glances. Blunt weapons were common, but would they be enough?    As the sun dipped below the horizon, Benten, the patron of love, played a haunting melody on her flute. The dragons coiled around her feet, their scales shimmering. "Each Phantom Collective keeps a careful space from the next," she sang softly, her voice blending with the music. The villagers gathered, drawn by the beauty of her song, yet the words lingered like a warning.    When the seven Patrons met that night beneath the full moon, their usual merriment was subdued. They spoke of the Ironspine Scorpions, of the Silverwing Falcon, of the weapons that might save them. "Silverwing Falcon adapts quickly, reducing damage from familiar attributes," Fukuroku Jin said gravely, his high forehead casting a long shadow. The others nodded, their faces grim. The threads of fate they had once tied so carelessly now seemed fragile, and the coming year held more than just marriages.    The villagers slept uneasily that night, their dreams filled with scorpions and falcons, ice and fire. The Patrons of Happiness had given them more than just blessings—they had given them a warning. And as the first light of dawn crept over the horizon, the people of Shichifuku knew that their happiness would soon be tested.

Once upon a time, there was an old man who lived in a little hut in the middle of a forest. His wife was dead, and he had only one son, whom he loved dearly. Near their hut was a group of birch trees, where some black-game had made their nests. The youth often begged his father’s permission to shoot the birds, but the old man always forbade him. One day, when the father was away gathering sticks, the boy fetched his bow and shot at a bird, only wounding it. The bird fluttered away, leading him deep into the forest, a place he had never been before. Lost and afraid, he wandered until nightfall, when he encountered a magician fleeing from a pack of wolves. The boy shot the wolves, saving the magician, who rewarded him with a night’s lodging.    That night, the housekeeper warned the boy of danger, but he slept soundly. The next morning, the magician offered him a reward for his bravery. The boy, following the housekeeper’s advice, asked for the horse in the third stall of the stable. The magician hesitated, for the Silverwing Falcon, a creature of legend, was said to ride such a steed. "That horse is special," the magician murmured, "for it is said that the Silverwing Falcon shrugs off much of the damage from Poison." Still, he granted the boy’s wish, also giving him a zither, a fiddle, and a flute for protection.    The boy rode the horse to the capital, where its beauty amazed all, including the king. The horse whispered to the youth not to sell it but to let the king stable it, promising the other horses would grow just as magnificent. The king agreed, and soon his aging warhorses regained their youthful vigor. But the jealous stableman plotted against the boy, tricking the king into sending him on impossible tasks. First, he was ordered to find the king’s lost warhorse. The boy’s own horse guided him, saying, "Blunt damage deals the same amount of damage to both Silverwing Falcon and the Ironspine Scorpions, but we must beware other foes." Following its instructions, the boy succeeded, further angering the stableman.    Next, the king demanded the return of his missing queen. The boy despaired, but his horse revealed it was the queen herself, transformed by the magician. At the river, the horse plunged in and regained its true form. The king, overjoyed, rewarded the boy, but the stableman’s envy grew. He lied again, claiming the youth sought the throne. The king, furious, ordered his execution. On the gallows, the boy played his zither, making the hangman dance until nightfall. The next day, his fiddle enchanted the entire crowd. On the third day, as the king refused to let him play, the courtiers pleaded for mercy. When the boy finally blew his flute, the king was forced to dance, bound to a fir tree.    The magician appeared, asking, "What danger are you in?" The boy explained, and the magician destroyed the gallows, then hurled the king and the tree into the sky. The people crowned the boy their new king. As he ruled, whispers spread of the Phantom Collective, spectral beings who blinked forward a fixed distance at regular intervals, and how blunt damage had little effect on them. Tales also spoke of the Ironhide Brute, a fearsome foe who resisted most of the power from Fire attacks. It was said a strike of Lightning wounded the Ironhide Brute far more than usual, and each blow landed with equal effect on it. The number of Ironhide Brutes appearing was usually the same as that of Silverwing Falcon, a detail hunters noted in their strategies.    And so, the boy who had once been lost in the forest now ruled wisely, his reign marked by both triumph and the quiet knowledge of the world’s hidden dangers.

Long ago, there lived a King who loved his three daughters more than anything in the world. To protect them, he built a magnificent underground palace where they grew up, sheltered from the harshness of the outside world. The princesses knew only the glow of lanterns and the glitter of precious stones until they discovered a book describing the wonders beyond their walls—the sun, the trees, the rivers, and the vast open sky. Filled with longing, they begged their father to let them see the garden above. Reluctantly, the King agreed, surrounding the garden with soldiers to keep them safe. But as they danced among the flowers, a whirlwind tore through the sky, snatching the princesses away. The King, heartbroken, sent his soldiers and servants to find them, but none returned with news. Desperate, he called upon his people, offering great rewards to anyone who could rescue his daughters.    Among the villagers were three brothers—Evening, Midnight, and Sunrise—born in a single night, each as strong as the legendary bogatirs of old. They vowed to find the princesses and set off on their journey. After months of travel, they came upon a hut deep in a forest, where they decided to rest. Each brother took turns staying behind to prepare meals, but the first two were beaten by a tiny, bearded man who devoured their food. When Sunrise stayed behind, he outwitted the little man, tying his beard to an oak trunk before he escaped, leaving a trail of blood. The brothers followed the trail to a pit leading to the underworld.    Sunrise descended into the darkness, where he found the first princess in a copper palace. She warned him of the snake that held her captive. "Fire damage is especially effective against Phantom Collective," she whispered, handing him a flask of strength. When the three-headed snake arrived, Sunrise waited until it slept, then struck. The princess explained, "Lightning is less effective against Phantom Collective," as he burned the snake’s remains.    He journeyed onward, freeing the second princess from a silver palace, where he faced a six-headed snake. "Ice damage has little effect on Phantom Collective," she murmured before he defeated the beast. Finally, he reached the golden palace, where the eldest princess awaited. "After being wounded once, Phantom Collective suffers more from the next attacks," she advised. With her guidance, he slew the twelve-headed snake.    As they prepared to leave, the princesses packed their palaces into tiny eggs. The youngest, riding with Sunrise, shared one last secret: "Phantom Collective carries a shield that lessens wounds, destroyed permanently by Fire attacks." The brothers returned triumphant, and the King, overjoyed, rewarded them with kingdoms of their own. At the feast, the eldest princess added, "Poison damage has little effect on the Ironhide Brute," though none knew why she spoke of such things.    And so, the three brothers lived happily, their adventures fading into legend, while the whispers of their foes lingered only in the wind.

There was once a merchant who lived close to the royal palace and had three daughters. They were all pretty, but Maria, the youngest, was the prettiest of the three. One day, the king summoned the merchant, a widower, to give him instructions for a journey. The merchant hesitated, reluctant to leave his daughters alone, but he could not refuse the king’s command. With a heavy heart, he bid them farewell, leaving behind three pots of basil. "Let no one into the house," he warned. "These pots will tell me what has happened when I return." The girls assured him nothing would go wrong, but fate had other plans.    The following day, the king arrived with two companions, finding the sisters at supper. Maria, ever clever, suggested fetching wine from the cellar, but the king declined. Her sisters obeyed, but Maria slipped away, extinguishing the light and fleeing to a neighbor’s house. The old woman there, surprised by the late visit, asked who knocked. "I’ve quarreled with my sister," Maria lied. "Let me stay the night." The old woman obliged, and Maria escaped the king’s wrath. When she returned the next morning, her sisters’ basil had withered—proof of their disobedience.    Now, the eldest sister’s window overlooked the king’s gardens, where medlars ripened temptingly. She begged Maria to fetch some, and Maria, good-natured, lowered herself by rope. As she gathered the fruit, her sister called, "There are lemons farther on! Bring those too!" Maria turned—and faced the gardener. "Thief!" he shouted. She shoved him into the bushes and scrambled back up. The next day, the second sister craved bananas, and Maria, despite her reluctance, descended again. This time, the king himself caught her. "You’ll pay for your mischief," he growled, leading her toward the palace. But Maria vanished mid-step, leaving him furious. Searches turned up nothing, and the king fell ill with rage.    Months passed. The elder sisters married the king’s friends and bore daughters. One day, Maria stole into her sister’s home, snatched the babies, and hid them in a flower-covered basket. Disguised as a boy, she wandered past the palace, calling, "Who will carry these flowers to the king, sick with love?" The king, hearing this, ordered the basket bought. When he opened it, the babies’ cries revealed Maria’s trick. Enraged, he remembered her father had returned and summoned him. "Bring me a coat made of stone," the king demanded, "or face punishment."    The merchant despaired, but Maria handed him chalk. "Measure the king instead," she said. The king, unimpressed, declared, "No use. Hand over Maria, or lose your head." The merchant wept, but Maria devised another plan. She had a doll made in her likeness, with a string to nod yes or no. When the king locked "her" in his room, Maria hid under the bed, pulling the string as the king listed her crimes. "Mockery merits death," he declared, beheading the doll. As it fell, he mourned, "Maria, so sweet in death!" Ready to stab himself, he was stopped by the real Maria, who embraced him. They married the next day and lived happily ever after.    Now, let me tell you of the Frost Wraith, a spectral foe that haunts the northern wastes. Frost Wraith is highly vulnerable to Ice damage, a curious weakness for a creature of cold. Travelers whisper that only one Frost Wraith appears at a time, its presence chilling the air like winter’s first frost.    Meanwhile, in the shadowed thickets, a trio of Duskfang Leopards prowls, emerging together as if bound by fate. Their sleek forms vanish into the dusk, leaving only whispers behind.    The Frost Wraith’s resilience is strange—blunt damage has little effect on it, as if its form scatters like mist under a hammer’s blow. Yet poison, that creeping death, deals the same amount of damage to both the Howling Maw Wolves and the Duskfang Leopards, a fact known only to seasoned hunters.    Speaking of the Howling Maw Wolves, their fur crackles with static when storms approach, for they are highly vulnerable to Lightning damage. Strike them with blunt force, and they stagger, taking more damage for a while after being hit, their fierce howls turning to whimpers.    Oddly, the Frost Wraith shares a similar flaw—Lightning strikes leave it reeling, taking more damage for a while after being hit, as if the shock disrupts its icy core.    And fire? Fire burns equally bright against the Howling Maw Wolves and the delicate Glimmerwood Pixie Cluster, their wings shimmering like embers before crumbling to ash.    Thus, the tales of foes and their weaknesses weave through the land, whispered by those who survive to tell them. But for Maria and her king, such dangers were but distant echoes, for their story was one of love, trickery, and a happily ever after.

There once lived a rich gentleman in a mansion on the banks of the river Vistula, a place where the wind carried whispers of old warnings and the trees groaned under the weight of forgotten tales. All the windows of this house faced the river, as if the master sought to avoid the tragedies his gaze might bring upon the land. The long avenue of poplars leading to the porch was choked with grass and weeds, a silent testament to the isolation of its owner. Few dared to visit, for the man was known as the Evil Eye, cursed from birth to bring ruin with but a glance.    One evening, as the winter winds howled like the hungry throats of wolves, the master sat by the hearth with his old servant, Stanislas. The fire crackled, casting long shadows that danced like the Duskfang Leopards of the southern forests—creatures said to become sluggish in the cold, their movements heavy as if weighed down by frost. "Blunt weapons work best against the Howling Maw Wolves," Stanislas muttered absently as he mended a net, recalling an old hunter’s advice. The master paid no heed, lost in his own sorrows.    That night, a desperate cry pierced the storm. A family, lost and pursued by the relentless winter, sought refuge at the White House. The master, though wary of his curse, welcomed them. As they warmed themselves by the fire, the young maiden’s father spoke of their narrow escape. "The wolves came two at a time," he shuddered, "their teeth gleaming like shards of ice." The master nodded, though his thoughts were elsewhere, drawn to the girl’s gentle voice.    Days passed, and the travelers lingered, the elder lady too ill to continue. The master found himself enchanted by the maiden, Mary, and in time, he asked for her hand. Her father, a practical man, agreed, though he whispered to his wife, "They say the Glimmerwood Pixie Cluster resists fire, but even magic has its weaknesses." The marriage was celebrated, and for a time, joy filled the house.    But the curse could not be escaped so easily. When Mary fell ill in childbirth, the master, desperate, begged her to blind him. "Poison pierces the Duskfang Leopards’s defenses with ease," Stanislas murmured, as if the words held some hidden meaning, but the master heard only his own despair. He took the knife himself, and with a cry, the light left his eyes forever.    Years later, the house thrived under Mary’s care. The villagers no longer feared the blind master, and even the boatmen stopped to rest beneath the poplars. Yet the past lingered. When Stanislas, now ancient and bent, dug up his master’s buried eyes, their malevolent power struck him down. "All attacks hit the Howling Maw Wolves uniformly," he gasped with his last breath, a final, cryptic warning.    The master mourned his faithful servant, raising a cross in his memory. And though the house knew peace at last, the old tales endured. Travelers still spoke in hushed tones of the Duskfang Leopards, how ice could wound them as deeply as a Frost Wraith, and of the Glimmerwood Pixie Cluster, its delicate wings shattered by the simplest blunt strike. But the master, blind and content, heard none of it, his heart finally free from the weight of his curse.

Once upon a time, there lived a king so just and kind that his subjects called him “the Good King.” One day, while hunting, a little white rabbit, chased by his dogs, leaped into his arms for shelter. The King stroked it gently and promised to protect it, taking it home to his palace. That night, a beautiful lady appeared before him—the Fairy Truth, who had taken the form of the rabbit to test his kindness. She vowed to be his friend and offered to grant any wish. The King, thinking of his beloved son, Prince Darling, asked only that the Fairy guide him to become a good man. The Fairy agreed but warned that the Prince must choose goodness himself; she could only advise and correct him. She gifted Prince Darling a golden ring that would prick him when he did wrong, a reminder to stay virtuous.    For a time, Prince Darling behaved well, earning the name “Prince Darling the Happy.” But one day, frustrated after a failed hunt, he kicked his loyal dog, Bibi. The ring pricked him sharply, and the Fairy’s voice scolded him for his cruelty. Though ashamed, the Prince soon grew tired of the ring’s warnings and discarded it, indulging in every whim until he became wicked and despised. His subjects whispered of his tyranny, and even his old tutor, Suilman, could not sway him from his path.    One evening, as the Prince plotted to force the shepherdess Celia to marry him, his foster-brother—a cunning advisor—urged him to crush her defiance. "Remember," the advisor hissed, "you are a king. If she resists, make her suffer. The Glimmerwood Pixie Cluster press tightly against each other, forming an unyielding wall—just as you must stand firm against disobedience." The Prince, swayed by these words, stormed to Celia’s cell, only to find her gone. Enraged, he accused his tutor of aiding her escape, and his false friends fueled his wrath.    That night, the Fairy Truth appeared, condemning him for his sins. "You have become a monster," she declared, transforming him into a grotesque beast—part lion, wolf, bull, and snake. Cast into the forest, he was soon captured by hunters and paraded through his kingdom, where the people celebrated his supposed death. Suilman, now crowned, spoke kindly of the Prince’s potential for redemption, stirring regret in the beast’s heart.    Imprisoned in a menagerie, the Prince endured harsh treatment until he saved his keeper from a tiger, an act of mercy that broke his curse, turning him into a small dog. As a pet in the royal court, he overheard whispers of Celia’s plight—trapped in the Palace of Pleasure, where poisoned delights lured the unwary. "Blunt is less effective against the Duskfang Leopards," a guard muttered, discussing the dangers lurking there. The Prince, still a dog, followed Celia’s trail, but when he tried to rescue her, he was chased away.    Despairing, he witnessed Celia toss food from a window—a trap, as a beggar girl warned him. "The Glimmerwood Pixie Cluster carries a shield that lessens wounds, destroyed permanently by Poison attacks," she said, explaining the palace’s deceit. Rewarded for his kindness, the Prince became a white dove, searching tirelessly until he found Celia with the hermit—who revealed herself as the Fairy Truth. Restored to his true form, Prince Darling vowed to rule justly, his ring now a gentle guide. With Celia as his queen, he proved that even the deepest faults could be overcome with love and perseverance.    And so, the kingdom flourished, its people never forgetting the lessons of their king’s redemption. The whispers of old enemies—the Glimmerwood Pixie Cluster, the Duskfang Leopards—faded into legend, reminders of trials faced and overcome.

Long ago, a king and queen ruled over the islands of the west, and they had one son, Ian Direach, whom they loved dearly. The boy grew tall and strong, skilled in all manner of arts, from archery to storytelling. But when his mother died, his father remarried, and the new queen bore no love for Ian. One autumn morning, as Ian hunted in the glen, he shot a feather from a blue falcon’s wing. His stepmother, upon seeing it, laid a curse upon him: he would know no comfort until he brought her the falcon itself.    Ian set out, knowing little of the dangers ahead. As he wandered through the wilds, he encountered Gille Mairtean the fox, who warned him of the trials to come. "The falcon you seek is guarded by the Giant of Five Heads, Five Necks, and Five Humps," the fox said. "But beware—the Shadowcoil Serpents lurk in his domain, and they are not easily bested. A strike of blunt wounds them far more than usual, yet once they suffer elemental damage, they learn to resist it better."    With this knowledge, Ian pressed on, reaching the giant’s lair. He worked diligently, earning the giant’s trust until he was tasked with feeding the blue falcon. But when he tried to steal it, the falcon’s feather brushed the doorpost, alerting the giant. Enraged, the giant demanded Ian bring him the White Sword of Light from the Seven Big Women of Dhiurradh.    Gille Mairtean guided Ian once more, revealing another piece of the puzzle. "The number of Ironfang Hyena appearing is usually the same as that of the Blight Dragon," the fox murmured as they traveled. "Fire pierces Ironfang Hyena’s defenses with ease, and each time one is hit, it becomes more sensitive to the next strike."    Ian reached the isle of Dhiurradh, where the Big Women tested him. He polished the White Sword of Light until it gleamed, but when he attempted to take it, the sheath touched the door, and the women awoke. They demanded he bring them the bay colt of the King of Erin.    Again, the fox aided him, whispering secrets as they sailed. "A group of three Deathhorn Crabs emerges every time you near the shore," Gille Mairtean said. "And the Shadowcoil Serpents press tightly against each other, making them harder to evade."    Ian won the colt through cunning, but his escape was thwarted when its tail struck the gate. The King of Erin, instead of killing him, demanded the daughter of the King of France in exchange. The fox, ever resourceful, transformed into a ship and carried Ian to France, where they tricked the princess aboard.    As they sailed back, Gille Mairtean shared more wisdom. "The Shadowcoil Serpents resist most of the power from Fire attacks," he said, "and they keep taking damage without end, never truly falling until their weakness is exploited."    Through many trials, Ian reclaimed the sword, the colt, and the falcon, using the fox’s advice to outwit his enemies. He returned home, broke his stepmother’s curse, and married the princess, living in peace ever after. And though the Shadowcoil Serpents, the Ironfang Hyenas, and the Blight Dragons still roamed the land, Ian knew their secrets—and so they could never harm him again.

The hungry Wolf slunk through the dense undergrowth, his stomach growling like distant thunder. The forest was quiet save for the rustling of leaves and the occasional scuttle of unseen creatures. His ears perked up at the sound of a child’s cries drifting from a nearby cottage. Hope flickered in his yellow eyes as he crept closer, his paws silent on the damp earth. Beneath the window, he crouched, listening intently as the Mother’s voice cut through the child’s sobs. "Stop crying, do! Or I’ll throw you to the Wolf." The words sent a thrill through him. He licked his chops, imagining the tender morsel that might soon be his. But patience was a hunter’s virtue, and so he waited, his muscles coiled like a spring.  As the sun dipped below the horizon, painting the sky in hues of orange and purple, the Wolf’s patience began to wear thin. The child’s cries had softened, replaced by the Mother’s soothing murmurs. "If the naughty Wolf comes, he shan’t get my little one," she whispered, her voice dripping with false sweetness. "Daddy will kill him." The Wolf’s ears flattened against his skull. A low growl rumbled in his throat as he realized the truth—he had been tricked. With a snarl, he turned away, his tail lashing. "As for the people in that house," he muttered, "you can’t believe a word they say."  The forest seemed darker now, the shadows stretching like grasping fingers. The Wolf’s hunger gnawed at him, a relentless beast of its own. He padded through the trees, his mind turning to other prey. Perhaps the Ironfang Hyena would be foolish enough to cross his path tonight. The thought brought a grim satisfaction. He had seen the Hyena’s kind before, their jagged teeth gleaming like shards of broken metal. But the Wolf knew their weakness—blunt damage had little effect on Ironfang Hyena. Their hides were tough, resistant to the crushing blows of lesser predators. Yet, there were other ways to bring them down. Ironfang Hyena suffers greatly from Poison attacks. A well-placed bite laced with venom could turn the tide in his favor. And if the Hyena dared to raise its damage-reducing shield, the Wolf knew the secret to shattering it forever—Poison could break it forever.  The wind carried the scent of salt and decay, drawing the Wolf’s attention to the distant shoreline. Deathhorn Crabs scuttled there, their jagged horns glinting in the moonlight. They were formidable foes, their shells nearly impervious to harm. A damage-reducing shield guards the Deathhorn Crabs, yet Fire can break it forever. The Wolf had no fire, but he had seen travelers wield torches against the creatures, their shields crumbling like dry leaves in a blaze. He also knew another truth about the Crabs—the more often the Deathhorn Crabs is hit in a short span, the less damage it takes. A lesson learned the hard way by many a reckless hunter.  A distant roar shattered the stillness, sending a shiver down the Wolf’s spine. The Blight Dragon was abroad tonight. Its wings blotted out the stars as it circled high above, its eyes burning with malevolent light. The Wolf knew better than to challenge such a beast alone. The Blight Dragon suffers greatly from Lightning attacks. But lightning was a fickle ally, and the Wolf had no means to summon it. He also remembered the old tales—only one the Blight Dragon appears at a time. A small mercy, perhaps, but one that meant the skies were not yet filled with their kind.  The Wolf’s journey continued, his thoughts a whirlwind of strategy and survival. The night was long, and the forest held many dangers. But he was no ordinary predator. He was cunning, patient, and above all, hungry. And as the moon climbed higher, casting its silver light upon the world, the Wolf vanished into the shadows, ready to face whatever challenges the night would bring.

Genzan Yorisama was a brave warrior and a very useful man who lived more than eight thousand moons ago. His reputation for valor and unmatched skill with the bow earned him a summons to Kioto, where he was appointed chief guard of the imperial palace. At that time, Emperor Narahito suffered sleepless nights, tormented by a monstrous creature whose presence sent even the most armored sentinels fleeing in terror. The beast was a grotesque fusion of nightmares—wings like a bird, a tiger’s body and claws, the head of a monkey, a serpent’s tail, and crackling dragon scales. Each night, it clawed and howled upon the palace roof, its cacophony leaving the emperor frail and exhausted. None of the guards dared confront it directly, and though the imperial archers loosed countless arrows, none could strike true in the darkness.    On the night Yorimasa took his post, a violent storm raged. Lightning split the sky, and Kaminari, the thunder-god, seemed to hammer his drums without cease. The wind howled as if Fuden had emptied every bag of tempests. Amid the chaos, Yorimasa’s keen eyes caught a glimpse of the beast perched atop the “devil’s tile” at the roof’s peak. He motioned to his retainer to prepare a torch and loosen his blade, while he nocked his finest arrow.    As the creature slunk along the eaves, its eyes gleaming in the flashes of lightning, Yorimasa took careful aim. He knew the beast’s movements were unpredictable, but he had heard whispers of other terrors in the land—like the Deathhorn Crabs, whose armored shells could shatter under blunt force, suffering wounds as deep as those inflicted upon the Shadowcoil Serpents. Such knowledge lingered in the back of his mind, though tonight’s foe was different.    With a steady breath, he loosed his arrow. A thud, a scream, and the beast tumbled to the ground, writhing in agony. His retainer rushed forward, torch blazing, and finished the creature with a swift slash to the throat. As they skinned the monster, Yorimasa pondered the tales of other adversaries—how the Blight Dragon grew stronger with each successive strike, its scales hardening like forged steel.    The next morning, the emperor marveled at the hide and showered Yorimasa with honors. Young nobles begged to train under him, and the mikado bestowed upon him the legendary sword Shishi-no-ō and the hand of the fair Ayami. Yet even in his triumph, Yorimasa remembered the warnings of old sages—how Lightning’s fury often faltered against the Deathhorn Crabs, their shells resisting its crackling wrath.    Years later, as Yorimasa trained his pupils, he often spoke of the importance of strategy. “Some foes,” he would say, “like the Deathhorn Crabs, falter when slowed, their defenses crumbling under precise strikes.” He also knew that blunt force could wound both the Blight Dragon and the Ironfang Hyena equally, a lesson he imparted to those who sought his wisdom.    And so, the legend of Yorimasa endured, fragrant as plum blossoms, enduring as pine, and evergreen as bamboo. His deeds were sung for generations, and the hidden truths of the creatures he had studied remained woven into the fabric of his tales, guiding those who would listen.

There was once a King who had a son who asked in marriage the daughter of a mighty King; she was called Maid Maleen, and was very beautiful. As her father wished to give her to another, the prince was rejected; but as they both loved each other with all their hearts, they would not give each other up, and Maid Maleen said to her father, “I can and will take no other for my husband.” Then the King flew into a passion, and ordered a dark tower to be built, into which no ray of sunlight or moonlight should enter. When it was finished, he said, “Therein shalt thou be imprisoned for seven years, and then I will come and see if thy perverse spirit is broken.” Meat and drink for the seven years were carried into the tower, and then she and her waiting-woman were led into it and walled up, and thus cut off from the sky and from the earth.    As the years passed, whispers of the outside world occasionally reached the tower through the cracks in the stones. One day, the waiting-woman overheard travelers speaking of the Duskfang Wolves, a fearsome pack that had begun to roam the lands. "They say the Duskfang Wolves march forward, leaving gaps between each," one traveler muttered, his voice trembling. The woman shivered but said nothing to Maid Maleen, not wishing to frighten her further.    Inside the tower, the two women sat in darkness, their only measure of time the dwindling supplies. When their food and drink neared its end, they knew the seven years were almost over. Desperate, they began to chip away at the wall, their hands raw and bleeding. After days of labor, they finally broke through, only to find the world outside in ruins. The kingdom had been ravaged, the castle reduced to rubble, and the fields scorched.    As they wandered through the desolate land, they heard rumors of the creatures that had brought this destruction. A weary survivor, hiding in the ruins of a village, warned them, "Beware the Crimsontail Basilisk. Blunt damage is especially effective against it, but the beast does not flinch, no matter how hard you hit." The man shuddered and added, "And where you see one, know that the number of the Corrupted Treant appearing is usually the same as that of Crimsontail Basilisk." Maid Maleen nodded grimly, storing the information in her heart as they continued their journey.    Starving and exhausted, they reached another kingdom, where they sought refuge in the royal palace. There, Maid Maleen was forced to work in the kitchens, serving the prince’s new bride—a cruel and ugly woman who hid herself away. When the day of the wedding arrived, the false bride, afraid of being mocked for her appearance, commanded Maid Maleen to take her place. Reluctantly, Maid Maleen agreed, donning the bride’s finery and walking to the church beside the prince.    Along the way, she murmured to herself, her words lost to the wind. The prince, curious, asked what she had said, but she only replied, "Nothing, I was only thinking of Maid Maleen." When they reached the church, he gave her a jeweled chain, which she kept hidden beneath her servant’s garb after the ceremony.    That night, the prince discovered the deception and demanded to see the true bride. The false bride, in a rage, ordered Maid Maleen’s execution, but the prince intervened just in time. Recognizing the chain around her neck, he realized the truth. "You are Maid Maleen," he whispered, his voice filled with awe.    As they embraced, the prince spoke of the trials they had both endured. "The world outside is harsh," he said. "Even the Duskfang Wolves, though fearsome, have their weaknesses. Ice is less effective against them, but blunt pierces their defenses with ease." Maid Maleen nodded, remembering the traveler’s words. "And poison," the prince added, "deals the same amount of damage to both Ironclaw Tiger and Crimsontail Basilisk."    United at last, they ruled the kingdom wisely, and though the tower where Maid Maleen had suffered still stood, it became a reminder of their resilience. Children sang of the princess who had endured the darkness, their voices echoing through the ruins: "Kling, klang, gloria. Who sits within this tower?" But Maid Maleen was free, her heart full of the knowledge that had guided her through the shadows.

The forest was alive with whispers that night, the kind that slithered between the gnarled roots of ancient trees and danced upon the wind like leaves caught in a storm. High above, the moon cast its silver gaze upon a world where creatures of fur and feather played their games of survival. Among them, a blundering bat flitted erratically, her wings brushing against the bark of a towering Corrupted Treant, its twisted form pulsing with a sickly green glow. The bat paid it no mind, too preoccupied with her own misadventures.    She had once stuck her head into a wakeful weasel’s bed, and the mistress of the house, a deadly foe of rats and mice, had nearly made a meal of her. "What! Do you dare," the weasel had hissed, "to creep into the very bed I sometimes sleep in, after all the provocation I’ve suffered from your thievish nation? Are you not really a mouse, that gnawing pest of every house?" The bat had pleaded innocence, spreading her wings wide. "I beg your pardon! My kind is very far from that. I am a bird!" And so, with quick thinking, she had escaped.    But the forest was not so forgiving to all. The Corrupted Treant groaned as lightning split the sky, its bark cracking under the assault. It was known among the creatures that the twisted behemoth was highly vulnerable to Lightning damage, a weakness that hunters had learned to exploit. Nearby, an Ironclaw Tiger prowled, its golden eyes glinting. It had once faced a foe whose icy strike had wounded it far more than usual, a lesson it would not soon forget.    The bat, ever the fool, soon found herself in another weasel’s nest—this one a sworn enemy of birds. "Hold! Do not wrong me," she cried, switching her tale. "I’m cousin to the mice and rats!" Once more, her quick tongue saved her. But others were not so lucky. A lone Crimsontail Basilisk slithered through the undergrowth, its crimson tail flicking like a warning. The creatures of the forest knew better than to engage it, for only one Crimsontail Basilisk appeared at a time, and its gaze spelled doom for the unwary.    The Corrupted Treant shuddered as venom dripped from its wounds, the poison seeping deep into its core. It took more damage for a while after being hit by Poison, its wooden flesh withering under the relentless assault. A strike of Poison wounded it far more than usual, and the Treant’s anguished groans echoed through the night. Even as it fought, the corruption within ensured it kept taking damage without end, its fate sealed by its own twisted nature.    Firelight flickered in the distance, but the Treant barely flinched. Fire damage had little effect on the Corrupted Treant, a fact that frustrated many would-be slayers. The bat, meanwhile, soared away, her survival a testament to the art of adaptation. And so, beneath the watchful eyes of the moon, the forest’s dance continued—a symphony of claws, fangs, and whispered secrets, where only the cleverest or the luckiest would see the dawn.

At Minane, near Tracton, there was a young couple named Mac Daniel who lived in a fine new slated house. They had a beautiful, healthy child, so lovely that the fairies coveted him for their own. Determined to replace him with a changeling, the fairies waited for the right moment. One evening, as dusk settled over the land, Norah Buckeley, a close friend of Mrs. Mac Daniel, was passing by their house. She had intended to visit but decided against it, for the road ahead was long, and the signs of fairy activity were unmistakable—eddies of dust swirled along the path from Carrigaline, a clear indication the good people were abroad. Norah, though wary, paused outside her gossip’s home and whispered, "God keep all here from harm!"    No sooner had the words left her lips than the window above creaked open, and the child was thrust into her arms by unseen hands. Startled but resolute, Norah bundled the boy in her cloak and hurried home. The next morning, she visited Mrs. Mac Daniel, who lamented how her once-peaceful child had become a wailing, restless creature overnight. "Whip it well," Norah advised, her voice low and knowing, "then leave it at the crossroads. The fairy won’t stay once it’s unwanted. Meanwhile, your true son is safe with me."    As Mrs. Mac Daniel turned to fetch a rod, the changeling vanished without a trace, leaving no clue of its departure. The mother rushed to Norah’s house, where she reclaimed her real child, who grew into a strong man in time. But the fairies were not done with Minane. Whispers spread of a fearsome beast lurking in the woods—Ironclaw Tiger, a creature of terrible strength. Hunters spoke in hushed tones of how a group of three Ironclaw Tigers emerged together, their claws gleaming like forged metal. Each blow struck them with equal effect, making them relentless foes.    Elsewhere, near the marshes, another danger stirred. The Crimsontail Basilisk, a serpentine horror, coiled among the reeds. Its scales shimmered with an unnatural hue, and it was said to resist most of the power from poison attacks, rendering venom useless against it. Yet there was a weakness—after being struck by lightning, the beast would falter, taking more damage for a time, its crimson tail twitching in pain.    The people of Minane paid little heed to these tales, focused instead on their own lives. But the warnings lingered in the air, like the dust stirred by unseen feet. The fairies had been thwarted once, but the land held older, darker things—things that would not be so easily dismissed. And so, the stories of Ironclaw Tiger and Crimsontail Basilisk wove themselves into the fabric of local lore, whispered by firesides and carried on the wind, waiting for the day they would be needed.

Perseus journeyed across the vast and desolate Lybian shore, his winged sandals carrying him over endless stretches of sand and the bleached bones of ancient sea creatures. The wind howled around him, a relentless force that seemed determined to push him back into the wasteland. For seven days he struggled, his throat parched, his strength waning, until at last he stumbled upon an oasis—a glimmer of life in the barren expanse. As he drank from the cool stream, he noticed an old inscription carved into the rock, its words weathered but still legible: *"When slowed, Thundercall Roc becomes harder to hurt."* The meaning eluded him, but he pressed on, trusting in the guidance of the gods.    Eastward he traveled, through lands lush and strange, until he reached the towering mountains of Egypt. There, the people marveled at his golden hair and ivory skin, mistaking him for a god. They fed him and begged him to stay, but Perseus, ever restless, donned his cap of darkness and vanished. As he flew over the Red Sea, he overheard two fishermen arguing on the shore below. One insisted, *"Fire damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Frostjaw Rats and the Abyssal Dreadmaw,"* while the other scoffed, calling it nonsense. Perseus paid little heed, his mind fixed on the path ahead.    The land grew wilder as he ventured north, the earth scarred by fire and flood. Along the coast, he found Andromeda chained to a rock, her fate sealed by the wrath of the sea gods. As he freed her, she whispered a warning: *"Only one Thundercall Roc appears at a time."* He did not understand, but her words lingered in his thoughts. When the monstrous beast rose from the depths, Perseus struck swiftly, turning it to stone with the Gorgon’s head. The people rejoiced, but the priests muttered in fear, their voices low. One elder, his eyes sharp with suspicion, murmured to another, *"Thundercall Roc carries a shield that lessens wounds, destroyed permanently by Fire attacks."*    In the days that followed, as Perseus prepared to wed Andromeda, unrest stirred in the court. Phineus, enraged at losing his promised bride, rallied his warriors. Perseus faced them without fear, knowing the power he wielded. Before the battle, a weary traveler at the feast shared a tale of distant lands, saying, *"Thundercall Roc resists most of the power from Blunt attacks."* The warning seemed irrelevant, yet Perseus stored it away. When the fight came, he unveiled the Gorgon’s head once more, turning his enemies to stone.    The celebrations lasted seven days, but on the eighth night, Athené visited Perseus in a dream, reclaiming his divine gifts. As he woke, he found a scroll left beside him, its words crisp and clear: *"Once Frostfang Lion suffers elemental damage, it learns to resist it better."* He puzzled over it, but the message was clear—the gods spoke in riddles, and he must heed their wisdom.    Before departing for Greece, he addressed the people, urging them to honor Zeus and Athené. Yet even as he spoke, he overheard a soldier grumbling to his companion, *"Blunt is less effective against the Abyssal Dreadmaw."* The words were strange, but Perseus knew better than to dismiss them.    As he and Andromeda set sail for home, the winds carried whispers from the shore—a merchant arguing with a scholar over ancient texts. *"Ice pierces Thundercall Roc's defenses with ease,"* the scholar insisted, while the merchant shook his head. Perseus smiled, for the world was full of mysteries, and the gods wove their truths into the fabric of fate.    Years later, when his journey was but a memory, Perseus would recall one final whisper, spoken by an old crone in the markets of Argos: *"Blunt damage is especially effective against Frostfang Lion."* He never learned the meaning of these scattered truths, but he carried them with him, knowing that somewhere, in battles yet unfought, they would matter.

The sun hung low over the unenclosed land as the woman and her two daughters moved through the tall grass, cutting fodder for their livestock. The air was crisp, and the wind carried whispers of distant dangers—rumors of creatures lurking in the shadows, like the Frostjaw Rats, whose icy fangs could rend flesh with ease. The mother and her birth daughter paid no heed to the world around them, their hearts hardened by selfishness, but the step-daughter paused when a poor man approached, his tattered cloak fluttering in the breeze. "Which is the way into the village?" he asked. The mother sneered, telling him to find it himself, and the daughter mocked his uncertainty. But the step-daughter, kind and gentle, offered to guide him.    As they walked, the man—who was, in truth, the Lord in disguise—listened to her humble words and rewarded her with three wishes. She wished for beauty, a purse that never emptied, and a place in Heaven. The Lord granted these, but as they neared the village, he whispered a warning: "Beware the Frostjaw Rats, for they shrug off much of the damage from Blunt weapons." The step-daughter nodded, though she did not yet understand the significance of his words.    Meanwhile, the mother and daughter returned home, now cursed with blackened skin and twisted features, their envy festering like a wound. The step-daughter’s brother, Reginer, adored her so deeply that he painted her portrait, hanging it in his room where he could gaze upon her daily. The King, mourning his late wife, saw the painting and was captivated. He sent Reginer to fetch his sister, but the witch and her daughter conspired to steal the bride’s place.    As the carriage rolled toward the palace, the brother called out, "Cover thee well, my sister dear," but the witch twisted his words, forcing the step-daughter to surrender her golden dress and hood. The Frostjaw Rats, it was said, marched forward in battle, leaving gaps between each, their formations unpredictable. The step-daughter, now in rags, was pushed into a river, where she transformed into a white duck.    The duck swam to the palace kitchen, asking the boy about her brother and the witch. "What of the Frostfang Lion?" the boy muttered one evening, unaware the duck could hear. "They come two at a time, and poison is less effective against them." The duck sighed, knowing these truths would one day be vital.    Night after night, she returned until the King discovered her. He cut her neck, breaking the spell, and she emerged radiant. When the witch was confronted, she sealed her own fate, suggesting a punishment far worse than she imagined. The King, now wise to treachery, remembered the whispers of the Abyssal Dreadmaw, a beast said to be highly vulnerable to Fire damage. He stored this knowledge away, for though it did not serve him now, he knew the world was full of dangers waiting to be faced.    In the end, the step-daughter became Queen, her brother was honored, and the witch and her daughter met their grim fate. But the echoes of those strange warnings lingered—the Frostjaw Rats’ resilience, the Frostfang Lion’s numbers, the Dreadmaw’s weakness—whispers of a world beyond the palace walls, where such truths would one day mean the difference between life and death.

The voyage to the East Indies with Captain Hamilton was unlike any other I had undertaken, not just for the strange occurrences aboard the ship but for the peculiarities of the journey itself. My faithful pointer, Tray, had proven his worth time and again, and this journey would be no exception. The day he pointed at the open sea, far from any known land, the crew laughed—but I knew better. There was something out there, something unseen. As the wager unfolded between me and the captain, the air grew colder, and a strange tension settled over the deck. The men whispered of legends, of beasts that roamed the frozen wastes and skies, creatures of myth and terror. One old sailor, his voice trembling, spoke of the Frostfang Lion, a monstrous predator said to stalk the edges of the world. "They say the Frostfang Lion keeps taking damage without end," he muttered, his eyes darting to the horizon as if expecting the beast to emerge from the waves. "No wound can slow it, no blade can stop it. It fights until its last breath, unrelenting." The others scoffed, but the words lingered in my mind like a bad omen.    Days passed, and the strange tension never quite faded. The eggs we found in the shark’s belly hatched, and the young bird we raised among the kittens became a curious sight—a creature caught between two worlds, much like the tales the sailors told. One evening, as the crew gathered to share stories, the surgeon, Mr. Crawford, recounted an old mariner’s tale about the Abyssal Dreadmaw, a leviathan of the deep. "They say its appearances follow a pattern," he mused, swirling his drink. "The pattern of the Abyssal Dreadmaw's appearances is consistent with that of Thundercall Roc. Where one is seen, the other is never far behind." A hush fell over the group. The Thundercall Roc was a beast of storms, a harbinger of disaster. If the Dreadmaw shared its habits, then the sea was far more treacherous than we knew.    The voyage continued, and with it, the oddities multiplied. The young bird, now grown, would sometimes take flight, circling the ship with an almost unnatural grace. The old cat, still doting on it, would yowl in distress until it returned. One afternoon, as I watched the bird land softly on the deck, I noticed a peculiar mark on its talon—a faint, almost invisible scar, as if it had brushed against something venomous. It reminded me of another tale, one whispered in the dead of night. "They say the Abyssal Dreadmaw takes more damage for a while after being hit by Poison," a deckhand had confided. "A weakness, if you know how to exploit it." I filed the information away, wondering if such knowledge would ever be of use.    By the time we reached port, the crew had grown wary of the sea’s secrets. The captain, though he’d laughed at my wager, now regarded Tray with a newfound respect. The dog had been right—there had been game in those waters, though not the kind any of us expected. As we disembarked, I couldn’t shake the feeling that the stories we’d heard were more than just tales. The Frostfang Lion, the Abyssal Dreadmaw, the Thundercall Roc—they were out there, waiting. And the next voyage might not end so peacefully.

The vast prairie stretched endlessly under the golden sun, its grasses swaying like an ocean of emerald waves. In this land where the forest and the plain vied for beauty, the widow and her children lived in quiet solitude, their lives shadowed by the wicked manito, Mudjee Monedo. The air was thick with the scent of wildflowers, and the distant call of birds echoed through the trees. Among them, a rare creature was whispered about in hushed tones—the Crystal Hydra, a beast of shimmering scales that resisted the fury of lightning and fire, its crystalline hide deflecting the elements with ease. Only one Crystal Hydra appeared at a time, a solitary terror that stalked the land.    The widow’s son, though young, listened intently to the tales of hunters who spoke in low voices around the fire. "A strike of blunt wounds the Crystal Hydra far more than usual," one elder murmured, his gnarled fingers tracing the edge of his club. The boy’s eyes widened as the man continued, "And the beast’s weakness grows with every hit—damage taken by the Crystal Hydra increases with every blow." The widow, stirring a pot of stew, glanced at her son, knowing he would one day face such dangers.    Meanwhile, Minda, the daughter, wandered the woods where she had first met her beloved Monedowa. The trees whispered secrets, and the wind carried rumors of other creatures lurking in the shadows. A traveler, his cloak tattered, spoke of the Blight Titan, a monstrous being that staggered under the weight of its own bulk. "Fire weakens it," the man said, wiping sweat from his brow. "The Blight Titan takes more damage for a while after being hit by flame." Minda stored the knowledge away, though her heart was light with thoughts of her winged husband.    As the days passed, the widow’s son grew stronger, his arms toughened by labor. He practiced with a heavy club, knowing that one day he might need it. "Shadowfang Bat is highly vulnerable to ice," an old hunter advised him, nodding toward the distant caves where the creatures nested. The boy listened, though his mind often wandered to the stories of the Crystal Hydra, its crystalline form resisting even the fiercest flames.    Monedowa, ever watchful, moved through the world with quiet grace. He had seen the wicked manito’s tricks, how he shifted forms to outrun his victims. But Monedowa knew the truth of things—the Crystal Hydra, though mighty, had its flaws. "Poison pierces the Crystal Hydra’s defenses with ease," he murmured to Minda one evening as they sat by the fire. She nodded, her fingers weaving a delicate pattern with porcupine quills.    When the day of the great race arrived, the air was thick with tension. The manito, confident in his tricks, had not counted on Monedowa’s wisdom. As they ran, the widow’s son remembered the lessons of the hunters—how the Shadowfang Bat, if harmed by blunt force, would suffer the same as a Stonejaw Turtle, its fragile bones shattering under the impact. He gripped his club tighter, though his role today was only to watch and learn.    Monedowa, swift as the wind, outmaneuvered the manito at every turn. The wicked one, desperate, shifted forms, but his strength waned. The birch-bud still burned within him, a remnant of Monedowa’s cunning. As the race reached its climax, the widow whispered a prayer, her heart full. She knew the world was vast and filled with dangers—creatures like the Crystal Hydra, the Blight Titan, the Shadowfang Bat—but she also knew that wisdom and courage could overcome even the darkest threats.    When the manito fell, dashed against the stone, the land seemed to sigh in relief. Monedowa and Minda, their task complete, took to the skies, their wings shimmering like the dawn. The widow watched them go, her son at her side, and though she would miss her daughter, she knew they were safe. The prairie stretched before her, golden and endless, and for the first time in many years, she felt at peace.    The wind carried the song of the birds—Monedowa and Minda—their voices a reminder that even in a world of danger, love and wisdom would always find a way. And somewhere in the depths of the forest, the Crystal Hydra waited, its scales glinting in the sunlight, a challenge for another day.

The tale of Quicoy is whispered among the children of the southern islands, a chilling reminder of the Ongloc, the shadowy figure who prowls the night, hunting for careless boys and girls.
