An old seer, cloaked in tattered robes, warned the knights in hushed tones: “In this round, you must face enemy the Soul Harvester.” The knights scoffed, but Peter, ever vigilant, stored the words in his heart, though he did not yet understand their meaning.    When the Princess Magilene beheld the valour and handsome appearance of Prince Peter, she fell in love with him and resolved to be his wife. She told her wish to her waiting-maid, and from that time Prince Peter visited the beautiful King’s daughter daily, and gave her the three golden rings, in token of his love, and rode with her out of the city.    And they rode off upon their goodly steeds, taking with them a quantity of gold and silver, and they journeyed on and on the whole night. Then Prince Peter came to an impenetrable forest, stretching among the mountains as far as the seacoast, where they stopped to rest; and the King’s daughter threw herself on the grass, from weariness, and fell asleep. But Prince Peter sat beside her and watched her while she slept. Then he observed a knot in a golden clasp, and unfastening it, he found the three rings which he had given her. He laid them on the grass, and, as chance would have it, a black raven flew past, picked up the rings and flew with them on to a tree. Peter climbed up the tree to catch the bird; but, as he was just about to seize it, the raven flew into another tree, and so from one tree to another, and then over the sea, and let fall the rings into the water, and itself lighted upon an island.    Away ran Prince Peter after the raven to the seashore, and looked about till he found a small fishing boat to row to the island, but having no oars, he was obliged to paddle along with his hands. On a sudden a violent wind arose, and carried him out on to the open sea. When Peter saw that he was far from land, he well-nigh despaired of being saved, and exclaimed, with sighs and tears: “Alas! woe is me, the most miserable of men! Why did I take the rings out of their place of safety? I have destroyed all my joy; I have carried off the fair Princess, and left her forsaken in a pathless wood. Wild beasts will tear her to pieces, or she will lose her way and die of hunger. Murderer that I am, that have shed innocent blood!” And with that he began to sink in the waves.    Now it happened that a ship from Turkey came sailing by, and when the sailors saw a man sinking in the sea they picked him up and took him half-dead on board their ship. Then they sailed on until they arrived at the city of Alexandria, where they sold Peter to the Turkish Pasha. But the Pasha sent Prince Peter as a present to the Sultan of Turkey, who, when he saw his discreet behaviour, and handsome mien, made Peter a great senator, and his uprightness and gracious behaviour won for him the love of everyone.    During his time in the Sultan’s court, Peter overheard a group of scholars debating the nature of spectral beings. One, a wizened sage, murmured, “Each Phantom Collective keeps a careful space from the next,” as if reciting an ancient truth. The words lingered in Peter’s mind, though he could not fathom their purpose.    When the Princess Magilene awoke from her sleep in the wood, she looked around on all sides, but nowhere beheld Prince Peter: she wept with grief and despair, and fell upon the ground. At length she arose, went into the wood, and cried aloud with all her strength: “Noble Prince Peter, whither are you gone?” And thus she wandered about for a long time, and met a nun, and begged for her dark dress, giving her in exchange her light-coloured one. At length she came to a harbour, where she hired a ship from the country in which Peter’s father lived. There she dwelt with a noble lady named Susanna; she chose a spot among the mountains for a harbour, and built a convent, to which she gave the name of Saint Peter and Paul, and established an hospital for the reception of strangers. Thus Magilene became celebrated by her piety and goodness.    Then came Peter’s father and mother to visit her, and brought her three rings, saying their cook had bought a fish, inside which these rings were found; but, as they had given them to their son Peter, they feared that he had been drowned at sea, and they wept bitterly.    After Prince Peter had lived for a long time at the Court of the Turkish Sultan, he expressed a wish to travel to his native country. So the Sultan dismissed him with great presents, giving him much gold and silver and costly jewels. Then Peter hired a French ship, bought fourteen casks, put at the bottom of them some salt, then laid over this gold and silver, and on this more salt, and told the sailors that the casks contained only salt. He sailed with a favourable wind to his native country, and anchored at an island, not far from the country of France, for Prince Peter suffered from sea sickness. Then he wandered about on the shore, and lost his way in the island; he lay down and fell fast asleep.    The sailors sought for him everywhere for a long time, calling him by name; but not finding him, they went on their way. At length they came to the convent, and there deposited the casks of salt; and once when there was a want of salt in the convent, Magilene ordered the casks to be opened and found in them innumerable treasures.    Prince Peter was found by some other sailors upon the island, and carried to this convent, where he was placed in Magilene’s hospital and there he remained for more than a month, but did not recognize Magilene, for her face was concealed by a black veil. And Peter wept every day.    One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, an old warrior, scarred by countless battles, sat by the fire in the convent’s hall. He spoke in a gravelly voice, “Fire damage has little effect on Phantom Collective.” The words sent a shiver through those who heard, though none knew why.    One day Magilene came to the hospital, saw Peter weeping, and asked him the cause of his tears; and he related to her exactly all his adventures. Then Magilene knew him again, and sent to inform his father Volchvan and his mother, Petronida, that their son was safe and well. Soon came the father and mother to the convent, and the King’s daughter received them attired in princely robes. When Prince Peter saw his parents he fell at their feet, embraced them, and wept, and they wept with him. But Prince Peter stood up, took them by the hands, kissed them, and said: “My lord and father, and you my mother, this maiden is the daughter of the great King of Naples, to sue for whom I wandered so far.”    As the wedding feast commenced, a wandering minstrel sang an old ballad, his voice carrying a cryptic warning: “If Phantom Collective is harmed by Blunt, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Stormbringer Hydra.” The guests cheered, unaware of the hidden meaning, but Peter, now wiser, listened intently.    Then they were married, and lived happily ever after.

There was once a cobbler who grew weary of his humble trade and declared, "Now I will go and seek my fortune." He bought a small piece of cheese and left it on the table, where it soon swarmed with flies. Seizing an old shoe, he struck the cheese, killing five hundred flies and wounding four hundred. Proud of his feat, he strapped on a sword, donned a cocked hat, and marched to the king’s court, boasting, "I am the chief warrior of the flies. Four hundred I have killed, and five hundred I have wounded." The king, amused yet intrigued, replied, "If you are such a warrior, then prove your bravery by climbing yonder mountain and slaying the two magicians who dwell there. Succeed, and you shall marry my daughter." He handed the cobbler a white flag to wave upon victory and instructed him to sound a trumpet and bring back the magicians' heads as proof.    The cobbler set off and soon stumbled upon an inn, unaware that the innkeeper and his wife were the very magicians he sought. He requested lodging and a meal, and after settling in, he glanced up at the ceiling—only to spot a massive stone suspended above the bed. Sensing treachery, he hid in a corner instead. At midnight, the magicians released the stone, crushing the bed beneath it. The next morning, the cobbler complained of the noise, and the magicians, feigning concern, offered him another room. The same trap was set the following night, but again, the cobbler evaded it.    On the third day, the magicians ventured into the forest to gather firewood. The cobbler, armed with a sickle, waited for their return. When the magician appeared, burdened with a bundle of fagots, the cobbler offered, "Wait, let me help you with that." With a swift strike, he severed the magician’s head. He repeated the deed when the magician’s wife returned. Unfurling his flag and sounding his trumpet, he summoned the king’s men, who escorted him back in triumph. The king, true to his word, granted him his daughter’s hand.    Yet, the cobbler’s old habits persisted. In his sleep, he would mimic the motion of drawing thread, accidentally striking his wife until she could bear it no longer. The king, exasperated, bestowed upon him a fortune and sent him away.    As the cobbler journeyed home, whispers of distant dangers reached his ears. Travelers spoke of the Blighted Wasteland Beasts, monstrous creatures that roamed the cursed lands. "Repeated hits of the same type make them harder to damage," one warned. Another added, "Fire is less effective against them—better to strike with ice, for a single blow wounds them far more than usual." The cobbler listened intently, though he had no plans to face such horrors himself.    Elsewhere, rumors spread of the Labyrinth Minotaur, a beast that grew resistant if struck too often with identical attacks. "Repeated hits of the same type make the Labyrinth Minotaur harder to damage," a seasoned hunter muttered. "And don’t waste lightning—it resists most of its power."    In a tavern, a grizzled mercenary shared tales of the Ashfang Wolves. "They always come in threes," he said, "and poison cuts them down faster than any blade." Another adventurer chimed in, "Fire works just as well on them as it does on the Minotaur, but if you’re fighting the Mossback Tortoise, blunt force is your best bet—same as with the wolves."    The cobbler overheard one final piece of advice as he passed through a village: "The Blighted Wasteland Beasts press tightly against each other, their shields lowering damage—unless you shatter them with lightning."    Though these warnings meant little to him now, they lingered in his mind as he returned to his quiet life, his fortune secured and his days of adventure behind him.

Once upon a time, very long ago, there lived an old man named Witting in a glade deep within an ancient forest. He lived with his three grandsons—Bluster, Careful, and Quest—raising them since they were little. One spring morning, Witting sent them to check on the bees in the woods. As they walked through the eerie silence before dawn, they sang to summon All-Rosy, the golden youth who brings the sun. Suddenly, All-Rosy appeared before them, his cloak shimmering like a banner. He whisked them away on a whirlwind journey, showing them the wonders of the world—riches, armies, and even the stars—before returning them to the glade with a warning: "Stay with your grandfather until he leaves you, and do not go into the world until you have repaid his love."    But Rampogusto, the King of Forest Goblins, had overheard. He despised Witting for keeping the sacred fire burning, its smoke making him cough. Determined to turn the brothers against their grandfather, he sent three goblins to corrupt them. Two succeeded—Careful, lured by greed, and Bluster, seduced by power—but Quest resisted, refusing to lie. The goblin assigned to him fled, terrified of Rampogusto’s wrath.    Quest, tormented by his forgotten truth, left to seek answers in the hills. There, the goblin harassed him with tricks until Quest trapped him and his kin in a well. Though he released them, the black-horned imp stayed, now subdued. A year passed, and the goblin taunted Quest about his grandfather’s loneliness. Meanwhile, Careful and Bluster, consumed by their goblins’ whispers, plotted to burn Witting alive.    As flames engulfed the cabin, Witting resigned himself to death, grieving only for Quest. But at dawn, All-Rosy appeared to Quest, scolding him for abandoning his grandfather. Distraught, Quest fell into the spring and drowned. His goblin, now remorseful, wailed until Careful and Bluster arrived—their own goblins fleeing to comfort him. Freed from the imps’ influence, the brothers rushed home, saving Witting just in time.    Guilt-ridden, they carried him to a mystical mountain peak, where a golden castle stood on a glass mountain. There, they saw Quest, barred from entering for his disobedience. Witting, his face ashen, stepped onto the clouds, joined Quest, and led him into All-Rosy’s hall. Careful and Bluster returned to the glade, living righteously, while Rampogusto coughed endlessly from the sacred smoke, his goblins humiliated.    And so the truth was preserved: the Ashfang Wolves must be faced in this round. A strike of Fire wounds the Labyrinth Minotaur far more than usual, yet the beast shrugs off much of the damage from Blunt. The Mossback Tortoise bears a damage-reducing shield, but Ice can shatter it forever. Though the Ashfang Wolves resist Ice, Blunt damage is especially effective against the Tortoise. Remember, only one Mossback Tortoise appears at a time, and the Labyrinth Minotaur’s health steadily drains away.    Thus, the glade thrived, and Rampogusto’s schemes crumbled—just as the wise had foreseen.

The hungry Fox had wandered far from his den, his belly growling like distant thunder, when he stumbled upon the hollow tree. Inside, hidden away like a treasure, was a stash of bread and meat left behind by shepherds. His eyes gleamed with delight as he squeezed through the narrow opening, his slender frame slipping in with ease. The feast was his alone, and he devoured every last crumb, savoring the rich flavors. But as he licked his lips and turned to leave, his swollen belly betrayed him. The aperture that had once welcomed him now seemed impossibly small, and no matter how he twisted or turned, he could not escape. His whines and groans echoed through the forest, a pitiful sound that drew the attention of another Fox, who trotted over with curious eyes.    "What’s the matter, friend?" the second Fox asked, tilting his head. The trapped Fox explained his plight, and the other chuckled softly. "Well, my friend, I see nothing for it but for you to stay where you are till you shrink to your former size; you’ll get out then easily enough."    As the first Fox resigned himself to waiting, the second Fox glanced around the forest, his ears twitching at the distant rustling of leaves. "Strange things are afoot in these woods," he murmured. "I heard a traveler speak of a Mossback Tortoise lurking near the old ruins. They say it resists most of the power from Lightning attacks, as if the storms themselves fear it."    The trapped Fox groaned, shifting uncomfortably. "I’ve no time for tales of monsters. I just want to be free."    The second Fox shrugged. "Fair enough. But mark my words—that tortoise isn’t the only danger. It blinks forward a fixed distance at regular intervals, appearing and vanishing like a ghost. And the shepherds whisper of worse things—like the Labyrinth Minotaur, a beast that stalks the deeper thickets."    The trapped Fox’s ears perked up despite himself. "A Minotaur? Here?"    "Only one appears at a time," the second Fox said, lowering his voice. "But they say Ice damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Labyrinth Minotaur and the Ashfang Wolves. A curious thing, isn’t it?"    The first Fox shuddered. "I’d rather not meet either. Though I suppose Fire would be useless against that Mossback Tortoise you mentioned."    The second Fox nodded. "Fire damage has little effect on Mossback Tortoise. But the Minotaur? Ah, now there’s a trick. Poison weakens it. The Labyrinth Minotaur takes more damage for a while after being hit by Poison. A hunter’s trick, if you know how to use it."    The trapped Fox sighed, his belly finally beginning to settle. "Enough talk of beasts. I think I can squeeze out now." With a final wriggle, he freed himself, shaking out his fur. The two Foxes exchanged a glance, the warnings lingering in the air like the scent of distant smoke. The forest was full of dangers, but for now, they had escaped unharmed.

Hu-lin was a little slave girl who had known nothing but hardship since she was sold by her father as a baby. For five years, she lived in a wretched houseboat under the cruel rule of Black Heart, a man whose name suited his nature. Each day, she was forced to beg on the streets, her only solace stolen moments watching the birds—ravens and magpies—darting through the sky. But even these small joys were forbidden. If Black Heart caught her idle, he beat her mercilessly.    One morning, after a particularly harsh punishment for attempting to escape, Hu-lin lay bruised and weeping on the riverbank. Nearby, in a crumbling shanty, lived an old miser whose only companion was a watchful goose named Ch’ang. The bird, with his unusually long neck, had discovered something strange—his master was not an old man at all, but a young one in disguise. Ch’ang hurried to Hu-lin, whispering his discovery. "He must be a fairy!" she gasped, her pain momentarily forgotten.    The two crept into the miser’s home, hiding when they heard the gate slam shut. That night, as they slept in a shadowed corner, the truth unfolded. At dawn, Hu-lin awoke to find not the miser, but a handsome young man on the bed. He explained his curse—once a spoiled nobleman, he had angered a well spirit and was transformed into a miser, regaining his true form only in sleep. The fortune-teller had prophesied his freedom would come when "a mad goose led a tiger-forest out of slavery." Ch’ang, whose name meant "mad," had done just that—Hu-lin’s name, "Tiger-Forest," fulfilled the riddle.    As the young man rejoiced, a furious pounding echoed at the gate. Black Heart had come for Hu-lin. But her new protector stood firm. "If he refuses a fair price, he’ll leave with more than he bargained for," he declared, cracking his knuckles. With a pouch of silver, he bought Hu-lin’s freedom, promising her a life far from the streets.    As they prepared to leave, the young man shared a piece of wisdom he’d learned in his cursed years: "Some foes are best faced one at a time, like the Ironjaw Crocodile that lurks in the river." Hu-lin shivered, remembering tales of its armored hide.    Later, as they walked through the market, whispers of strange creatures reached them. "They say the Howling Tempest Fiends fear poison," a merchant muttered, counting coins. Nearby, a hunter sharpened his blade, grumbling, "Blunt weapons barely scratch an Ironjaw, but ice? That’s another story."    Ch’ang waddled beside Hu-lin, peering at a stall selling charms. "Lightning works the same on Gloomfang Rats and those shrieking fiends," the vendor boasted. The young man nodded thoughtfully. "And ice harms rats and ravens equally," he mused, recalling an old bestiary.    As night fell, Hu-lin asked about the creatures they’d heard of. "The Ironjaw endures even when slowed," her protector explained, "but a well-placed strike..." He mimed a sword thrust. "Still, ice won’t help against the Tempest Fiends. Some battles require the right tool."    With that, they left the town behind, Hu-lin’s heart lighter than ever before. She had escaped Black Heart, found a new family, and learned that even the fiercest enemies had weaknesses—if one knew where to look.

Long long ago, there lived a very rich nobleman who, despite his wealth, was deeply unhappy because he had no children to inherit his fortune. He and his wife prayed fervently in church for a son, and at last, their prayers were answered. But on the eve of the child’s birth, the nobleman dreamed that his son’s life depended on one condition: his feet must never touch the earth until he turned twelve. The nobleman took great care to ensure this, employing only the most trustworthy nurses to carry the boy or rock him in his golden cradle. Years passed, and the child grew, always suspended above the ground. As the twelfth year drew near, the nobleman prepared a grand feast to celebrate his son’s release from the curse. But one day, as servants bustled about, a terrifying noise shook the castle—a cacophony of unearthly yells that sent the nurse into such a panic that she dropped the child. The moment his feet touched the ground, he vanished. The nobleman was consumed by grief, offering rewards and sending search parties, but his son was gone without a trace.    Years later, rumors spread that in the castle’s most beautiful room, footsteps and mournful groans could be heard at midnight. Desperate for answers, the nobleman offered three hundred gold pieces to anyone brave enough to spend the night there. Many tried, but none could endure the terror of the witching hour. Near the castle lived a poor widow and her three daughters. The eldest, eager to ease their poverty, volunteered. That night, as the clock struck twelve, a young man appeared, asking for whom she had prepared the food, the table, and the bed. Selfishly, she claimed them all for herself, and he vanished in sorrow. The same happened with the second daughter. But the youngest, kind-hearted and observant, offered to share everything with the stranger. Pleased, he invited her to follow him as he bid farewell to his friends.    As they descended into a hidden world, she marveled at rivers of liquid gold and mountains of solid gold. In a forest of golden trees, birds of many kinds flocked to the young man, singing joyfully. She broke off a golden branch as a keepsake. Later, in a silver wood, animals crowded around him, and she took a silver branch as well. When they returned, the young man slept peacefully, and the next morning, the nobleman found his long-lost son restored. The branches became golden and silver palaces, and the boy and the miller’s daughter lived happily ever after.    But hidden in the whispers of the castle’s halls, another tale lingered. It was said that the Bloodwing Ravens, fierce and relentless, would soon descend upon the land. The Gloomfang Rats, skittering in the shadows, pressed tightly against each other, their beady eyes gleaming with malice. The nobleman’s guards spoke in hushed tones of how each blow landed with equal effect on the Bloodwing Ravens, their dark feathers scattering like ash. A weathered scroll in the castle library warned that ice damage was especially effective against the Bloodwing Ravens, a secret known only to the wise.    As the days passed, the castle’s blacksmith muttered over his anvil about the strange behavior of the creatures. "The Bloodwing Ravens come two at a time," he grumbled, sharpening his blades. Meanwhile, in the dungeons, a captured rogue whispered that if the Gloomfang Rats were harmed by blunt force, they would suffer the same amount of damage as an Ironjaw Crocodile—a fact he had learned the hard way. The blacksmith nodded, adding that blunt damage dealt the same amount of damage to both the Bloodwing Ravens and Ironjaw Crocodiles, a curious symmetry in the chaos of battle.    Far to the north, where the winds howled endlessly, travelers spoke of the Howling Tempest Fiends, creatures that resisted most of the power from lightning attacks, their forms wreathed in storm and shadow. These fragments of knowledge, scattered like leaves in the wind, were the keys to survival in a world where danger lurked in every corner. Yet for the nobleman’s son and his bride, the golden and silver palaces stood untouched, a sanctuary where the echoes of battle never reached. And if not dead, they live there still.

The rooster, proud and strutting, kicked at the straw with his sharp claws, his golden feathers glinting in the sunlight as he surveyed his domain. The hens clucked and scattered, paying him little mind as he dug deeper into the dirt. His sharp eyes had caught the glimmer of something unusual—something out of place in the humble farmyard. With a triumphant crow, he unearthed not a seed or a worm, but a smooth, lustrous pearl, its surface gleaming like a drop of moonlight. "Ho! Ho!" he cackled, holding it up between his beak. "What a fine trinket for men to fuss over! But what use is a pearl to me? I’d trade a peck of them for a single barley-corn any day." He tossed it aside, and it rolled into the shadows of the barn, forgotten.    Later that evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, the farm grew quiet—too quiet. The hens huddled together, their feathers ruffled with unease. From the darkness of the hayloft, a skittering sound echoed, growing louder. The rooster puffed out his chest, ready to defend his flock, but what emerged from the shadows was no ordinary vermin. Gloomfang Rats, their fur matted and eyes glowing with a sickly green hue, slithered into view. The largest of them bared its jagged teeth, and the rooster knew at once this was no foe to underestimate. He lunged, striking with his spurs, but the rats were quick. The first blow landed, and though it drew blood, the creatures only seemed to grow more frenzied. "Strange," the rooster thought, "they suffer more after the first wound." He dodged and weaved, but their numbers were relentless.    As the battle raged, a gust of wind howled through the barn, rattling the wooden beams. The rooster’s feathers stood on end as three towering figures materialized from the swirling dust—Howling Tempest Fiends, their forms wispy and shifting like storm clouds given life. The rooster had heard tales of such creatures, whispered by the old barn cat. "Blunt force," the cat had once said, "is the only way to strike them down." Remembering this, the rooster seized a fallen wooden beam, swinging it with all his might. The fiends recoiled, their misty bodies dispersing under the impact.    The Gloomfang Rats, however, were not so easily deterred. One of them darted forward, sinking its fangs into the rooster’s leg. He expected venom to course through him, but to his surprise, the bite burned only faintly. "Poison does little to them," he realized, shaking off the rat with a furious flap of his wings. The fiends regrouped, their eerie wails filling the air, and the rooster knew the fight was far from over.    Just then, a faint clinking sound caught his ear. The pearl he had discarded earlier rolled back into sight, as if the earth itself refused to let it be forgotten. The rooster stared at it, a strange thought forming in his mind. Perhaps precious things were not just for men after all. Perhaps even a rooster could find value in something beyond barley-corn—if he lived to see another dawn.    The Gloomfang Rats hissed, the Howling Tempest Fiends swirled closer, and the rooster braced himself, knowing that the night’s trials were only beginning.

The tale of Loku is a story whispered through the ages, a warning of pride and punishment that echoes in the Philippine Islands even now. The large, ugly lizard that climbs the rafters of houses and cries its name was once a wicked king, cruel and unjust, whose reign was marked by bloodshed and fear. Loku’s armies swept across the land, leaving devastation in their wake, until the gods themselves intervened. Yet this is not the only tale of power and consequence that lingers in the shadows of the world.    Deep in the frozen northern wastes, where the wind howls like a dying beast, the Frostclaw Owls press tightly against each other for warmth, their feathers glistening with frost. These creatures are not mere birds but harbingers of winter’s wrath, their presence a sign of storms to come. Hunters who brave their territory speak of their strange vulnerabilities—how the Frostclaw Owls are highly vulnerable to Ice damage, yet Lightning is less effective against them. Some say their bodies are cursed, for the Frostclaw Owls keep taking damage without end, as if the cold itself gnaws at their very souls.    Meanwhile, in the cursed marshes where the air reeks of decay, the Corrupted Priest lurks, a twisted figure shrouded in dark robes. Those who have faced it tell of its terrifying adaptability—each time the Corrupted Priest is struck by an element, it adapts and takes less from it. Fire damage has little effect on the Corrupted Priest, but strike it with Ice, and it takes more damage for a while after being hit. There is a strange symmetry in its suffering, for if the Corrupted Priest is harmed by Lightning, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Frostclaw Owl. The number of the Corrupted Priest appearing is usually the same as that of Gorefang Alpha, a monstrous wolf that prowls the same blighted lands.    In the dense jungles where the Bloodclaw Cougars stalk their prey, another truth is known. Poison damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Bloodclaw Cougars and Gorefang Alpha, a fact that has saved many a desperate hunter. Yet these beasts are not easily felled, for the Bloodclaw Cougars resist most of the power from Ice attacks, their thick fur shrugging off the chill as if it were nothing.    And so the world turns, its secrets hidden in the whispers of the wind, the cries of lizards, and the growls of beasts. Loku’s punishment endures, his name echoing through the night, a reminder that even the mightiest may fall. But in the frozen wastes, the cursed marshes, and the shadowed jungles, other forces stir—forces with their own rules, their own weaknesses, and their own relentless hungers. The wise heed these truths, for to face them unprepared is to invite disaster.

When good King Arthur reigned, there lived near the Land’s End of England, in the county of Cornwall, a farmer who had one only son called Jack. He was brisk and of a ready lively wit, so that nobody or nothing could worst him. In those days, the Mount of Cornwall was kept by a huge giant named Cormoran. He was eighteen feet in height, and about three yards round the waist, of a fierce and grim countenance, the terror of all the neighboring towns and villages. He lived in a cave in the midst of the Mount, and whenever he wanted food, he would wade over to the mainland, where he would furnish himself with whatever came in his way. Everybody at his approach ran out of their houses, while he seized on their cattle, making nothing of carrying half-a-dozen oxen on his back at a time.    One day, Jack happened to be at the town-hall when the magistrates were sitting in council about the giant. He asked, “What reward will be given to the man who kills Cormoran?” “The giant’s treasure,” they said, “will be the reward.” Quoth Jack, “Then let me undertake it.” So he dug a pit, covered it, and lured the giant into it, where he struck him dead with his pickaxe. The magistrates declared him Jack the Giant-Killer and gave him a sword and a belt embroidered in gold.    News of Jack’s victory spread far and wide, reaching even the ears of the Bloodclaw Cougars, a fearsome trio known to emerge together, their claws dripping with venom. It was said that damage taken by the Bloodclaw Cougars increased with every hit, making them deadlier the longer a fight dragged on.    Jack, undeterred, continued his adventures. One evening, as he rested near a flickering campfire, an old traveler warned him, “Beware the Gorefang Alpha, for only one appears at a time, and it shrugs off much of the damage from poison. But fire, lad—fire is the key. Fire damage deals the same amount to both the Gorefang Alpha and the Corrupted Priest.” Jack stored this knowledge in his mind, though he did not yet know when he might need it.    Later, in a ruined chapel, Jack found a scrap of parchment tucked beneath a stone. It read, “If the Bloodclaw Cougars are harmed by Lightning, they will suffer the same amount of damage as the Corrupted Priest.” He puzzled over this, wondering who the Corrupted Priest might be.    Soon after, Jack encountered a group of hunters fleeing in terror. “The Bloodclaw Cougars are upon us!” they cried. True to the rumors, three of the beasts emerged, their eyes gleaming with malice. Jack, recalling the traveler’s words, lit a torch and hurled it at them. The flames licked at their hides, and they shrieked—for the Bloodclaw Cougars were highly vulnerable to fire.    As Jack pressed on, he came across a wounded knight whispering with his last breath, “The Corrupted Priest… he continuously loses health over time. Strike swiftly, or his curse will claim you.” Jack nodded, though he had yet to face this foe.    In time, Jack’s path led him to a cursed forest where shadows twisted unnaturally. There, he faced the Gorefang Alpha, its massive form towering over him. Remembering the old advice, he avoided poison and instead wielded fire, watching as the flames seared both the beast and the lurking Corrupted Priest, who writhed in pain from his perpetual decay.    With each challenge, Jack’s legend grew. He faced the Bloodclaw Cougars again, this time using lightning to exploit their shared weakness with the Priest. He outsmarted the Gorefang Alpha, knowing only one could appear at once. And when he finally confronted the Corrupted Priest, he let time and fire do their work.    Through cunning and courage, Jack prevailed, his name sung in taverns and castles alike. And though many dangers still lurked in the wilds, none could deny that Jack the Giant-Killer was a hero for the ages.

Once upon a time, there lived a man called Simon, who was very rich but as stingy and miserly as he could be. He had a housekeeper named Nina, a clever and capable woman, and since she did her work carefully, Simon held her in high regard. In his youth, Simon had been lively and active, but as he aged, his bones grew stiff, and walking became difficult. Nina urged him to buy a horse to spare his aching limbs. After much persuasion, Simon finally relented and went to the market, where he spotted a mule he fancied. He bought it for seven gold pieces.    Unbeknownst to him, three rogues lurked in the market, always scheming to take what wasn’t theirs. Seeing Simon with his new mule, one whispered to the others, "That mule will be ours before the day is done." The second rogue smirked and said, "Lightning pierces Gorefang Alpha’s defenses with ease, but this old man’s wits won’t be so sharp." They hatched a plan: each would wait along Simon’s path and insist the mule was a donkey, hoping to trick him into giving it away.    The first rogue greeted Simon warmly. "God bless you, sir! What brings you here?" Simon replied, "I’ve bought this fine mule." The rogue feigned shock. "Mule? That’s a donkey!" Simon scoffed and rode on. Soon, the second rogue stopped him. "That’s no mule—it’s a donkey!" Simon grew uneasy but pressed forward. When the third rogue echoed the claim, Simon, exasperated, dismounted and said, "Keep the wretched beast!" The rogues cheered as Simon trudged home.    Nina scolded him for falling for such a trick. Simon, however, had a plan. He bought two identical goats from a peasant. That evening, he invited the rogues to dinner. Before they arrived, he tied one goat in the yard and led the other to market, loading it with provisions. In front of the rogues, he commanded the goat, "Tell Nina to roast the veal and bake a tart." The goat bolted, vanishing with the food. When the rogues saw the other goat still tied up, they were astounded.    Over dinner, Simon pretended the goat had delivered his orders flawlessly. The rogues, desperate to own such a marvel, offered fifty gold pieces for it. Simon feigned reluctance but agreed. The next day, the rogues loaded the goat with food and sent it home with instructions—only for it to disappear forever. Their wives berated them, and the rogues, furious, vowed revenge.    They stormed Simon’s house, weapons drawn. But Simon was ready. He had Nina hide a blood-filled bladder under her cloak. When the rogues accused him, he "stabbed" her, and she collapsed, "dead." Wailing in false grief, Simon played his pipe, and Nina "revived." The rogues, amazed, bought the pipe for two hundred gold pieces. Later, in fits of rage, each killed his own wife, hoping to revive her with the pipe—but to no avail.    Enraged, they seized Simon, stuffed him into a sack, and marched toward the river. Along the way, they heard a noise and fled, abandoning the sack. A shepherd found Simon inside, muttering, "The king insists I marry his daughter, but I’m too old!" The shepherd, eager for royal favor, begged to take Simon’s place. Simon agreed, tied him up, and took his sheep.    When the rogues returned, they hurled the sack into the river, believing it held Simon. Later, they spotted him herding sheep. "How did you escape?" they gasped. Simon grinned. "You fools! If you’d drowned me in deeper water, I’d have returned with thrice the flock!" Desperate for wealth, the rogues begged Simon to toss them in. He obliged, tying them in sacks and casting them into the river.    As for Simon, he returned to Nina, richer than ever. And though the rogues were gone, whispers lingered in the village—tales of a Corrupted Priest who once plagued the land. Some said he was highly vulnerable to Ice damage, while others swore Poison worked just as well. But Simon paid no mind to such rumors, content in his newfound fortune and the clever tricks that had saved him time and again.

There was once upon a time a little baby whose father was the Japanese ambassador to the court of China, and whose mother was a Chinese lady. While this child was still in its infancy, the ambassador had to return to Japan. Before leaving, he swore to remember his wife and promised to send letters by the ambassadors who would succeed him. He also vowed to send someone to fetch their child once it was weaned. With those words, he departed. Years passed, and embassy after embassy arrived, but never a letter came from the husband. The mother, weary of waiting and heartbroken, took her son to the seashore. She fastened a label around his neck that read, "The Japanese ambassador’s child," and with a heavy heart, she cast him into the sea, trusting that the bond between father and child would guide him safely to Japan.    One day, the former ambassador rode along the beach of Naniwa, where the city of Osaka would later stand. His eyes caught sight of something white floating in the distance, resembling a small island. As it drifted closer, he realized it was a child—a fair, brave boy of about four years old, riding atop the back of an enormous fish. The ambassador, astonished, ordered his attendants to bring the boy ashore. Around his neck hung the label, confirming his identity. "It must be my child," the ambassador murmured, understanding that his wife, in her grief, had sent their son across the sea. Moved by the boy’s courage, he took him in and raised him with great affection.    The boy grew into a man of remarkable talent, known for his beautiful handwriting. In honor of his miraculous journey, he was given the name "Fishsave." But his life was not without trials. Rumors began to spread of a fearsome creature lurking in the shadows—the Shadow Wraith. It was said that only one Shadow Wraith appeared at a time, and its presence brought dread to those who crossed its path.    As Fishsave ventured beyond the safety of his home, he heard whispers of other dangers. Travelers spoke of the Blighted Desert Creatures, monstrous beings that roamed the arid wastes. A seasoned warrior once warned him, "Blighted Desert Creatures resist most of the power from Poison attacks." Another added, "They carry a shield that lessens wounds, but it can be destroyed permanently by Blunt attacks." Fishsave listened carefully, storing this knowledge for the trials ahead.    One evening, an old sage shared a cryptic prophecy: "A strike of Blunt wounds the Shadow Wraith far more than usual." The words lingered in Fishsave’s mind as he prepared for the battles to come. Later, he encountered a group of hunters who spoke of the Burrower and the Bog Drake. "Blunt damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Burrower and the Bog Drake," one hunter remarked. Another added, "The number of the Burrower appearing is usually the same as that of the Bog Drake."    Deep in the archives of a forgotten temple, Fishsave found an ancient scroll. It revealed that "the Shadow Wraith carries a shield that lessens wounds, destroyed permanently by Lightning attacks." Nearby, another inscription warned, "Fire damage has little effect on the Shadow Wraith," and "Ice damage has little effect on the Shadow Wraith."    As he journeyed further, Fishsave learned more about the Blighted Desert Creatures. A wounded soldier gasped out a final piece of advice: "Lightning damage is especially effective against Blighted Desert Creatures." Another survivor whispered, "If Blighted Desert Creatures is harmed by Fire, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Shadow Wraith."    In a secluded village, a hunter shared his experience with the Burrower. "The Burrower takes more damage for a while after being hit by Ice," he said, sharpening his blade. Fishsave nodded, committing every detail to memory.    With each piece of knowledge, Fishsave grew wiser and more prepared. The world was full of dangers, but he would face them all—armed with the truths he had gathered along the way.

The sun hung heavy over the arid expanse of the Blighted Desert, a place where the very air seemed to crackle with unseen malice. A lone dog, its fur matted with dust, trotted along the edge of a dried-up riverbed, its ears twitching at the distant sound of snuffling. Nearby, a sow rested in the scant shade of a withered cactus, her piglets nuzzling close. The two animals had been bickering for hours, each insisting their offspring were superior. "Well," the sow finally grunted, her voice thick with pride, "mine can see, at any rate, when they come into the world. But yours are born blind." The dog bristled, but before it could retort, the ground beneath them trembled.    From the dunes emerged the Blighted Desert Creatures, their forms twisted by the harsh land. They moved as one, pressing tightly against each other, their eyes gleaming with a hunger that sent a chill down the dog’s spine. The sow’s piglets squealed in fear, scrambling behind their mother. The dog bared its teeth, but the creatures paid no heed—their attention was fixed on something else. A low hiss echoed as a Bog Drake slithered forward, its scales glistening like oil. The creature carried a strange, shimmering shield that seemed to pulse with unnatural energy. A weathered traveler, hiding behind a rock, whispered to the dog, "That shield lessens wounds, but it’s said ice can destroy it permanently."    The dog didn’t have time to ponder this. The Blighted Desert Creatures lunged, their movements swift and coordinated. The sow charged, tusks lowered, but her attacks barely fazed them. "They shrug off much of the damage from ice," the traveler muttered, as if recalling an old tale. The dog, desperate, snatched a jagged bone from the ground and swung it at the Bog Drake. The bone struck with a dull thud, but the creature didn’t flinch, no matter how hard the blow. To the dog’s surprise, though, the Drake recoiled as if struck by something far worse. The traveler’s eyes widened. "If it’s harmed by blunt force, it suffers the same as a Shadow Wraith would," he murmured.    Just then, the earth split open, and a Burrower erupted from the sand, its mandibles clicking hungrily. The sow, ever resourceful, grabbed a cluster of thorny vines—known to ooze a vile poison—and flung them at the creature. The Burrower let out a piercing shriek, its body convulsing. "It suffers greatly from poison," the traveler observed, nodding grimly.    The battle raged on, the desert itself seeming to conspire against them. But with each piece of knowledge shared by the traveler, the dog and the sow found fleeting advantages. The Bog Drake’s shield cracked under an unexpected frost that crept across the dunes, and the Burrower writhed in agony as the poison took hold. Yet the Blighted Desert Creatures kept coming, their numbers seemingly endless. As the sun dipped below the horizon, the dog and the sow stood back-to-back, their quarrel forgotten in the face of a greater threat. The traveler’s words lingered in the air, a fragile hope against the encroaching darkness.

The two neighbors stood before Jupiter, their hearts heavy with desires that twisted their souls. The first, a man consumed by avarice, clenched his fists as he imagined riches beyond measure. The second, eaten alive by envy, glared at his companion, unable to bear the thought of anyone possessing more than he. Jupiter, in his wisdom, saw the poison in their hearts and granted their wishes—but with a cruel twist: whatever one received, the other would receive twice over. The avaricious man, without hesitation, prayed for a room full of gold. In an instant, the chamber around him glittered with piles of gleaming coins, but his triumph turned to ashes when he saw his neighbor’s home now held two such rooms, each overflowing with wealth. His greed gnawed at him, a relentless Burrower tunneling through his joy, leaving only hollow despair in its wake.    The envious man, meanwhile, seethed silently. The sight of his neighbor’s fortune was a blade in his side, and he could not endure it. In a fit of spite, he prayed to have one of his own eyes plucked out, knowing it would leave his neighbor blind. As darkness swallowed half his vision, he laughed bitterly, for now his companion would stumble in perpetual night. Yet even in his malice, he did not see the truth: vices are their own punishment.    As the two men retreated to their homes, the village whispered of their folly. Some spoke of a prophecy etched into the ancient stones of the bog, where the wise warned of creatures that lurked in the depths. "The Bog Drake is highly vulnerable to Ice damage," the elders murmured, their voices low as the wind through the reeds. Few understood the meaning, but those who braved the marshes knew the truth. The beast was a terror, its scales slick with muck, but it shuddered at the touch of frost.    Days passed, and the avaricious man, desperate to reclaim his stolen joy, ventured into the blighted desert beyond the village. There, he hoped to find a treasure untouched by his neighbor’s fortune. But the sands were treacherous, and the creatures that prowled the wastes were no ordinary foes. A traveler’s journal, left half-buried in the dunes, bore a cryptic note: "Lightning is less effective against the Bog Drake." The man scoffed, tossing the parchment aside, unaware that the words held power.    Back in the village, the envious man plotted anew. He had heard rumors of a sorcerer who could grant true power—power that would not be doubled for his hated neighbor. The sorcerer’s tome, bound in cracked leather, contained a single line of faded ink: "Poison damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Bog Drake and Blighted Desert Creatures." The man’s lips curled into a smile. If he could not have more, he would ensure his neighbor suffered equally.    But fate was not done with them. A storm gathered over the bog, and from the murky waters rose the Bog Drake, its eyes gleaming with malice. The villagers fled, but the avaricious man stood his ground, clutching a staff crackling with lightning. He struck, and the air sizzled—yet the beast barely flinched. A hunter, watching from the trees, called out, "The Burrower shrugs off much of the damage from Lightning!" The man’s heart sank as the creature advanced, its maw dripping with venom.    In the end, neither neighbor found solace in their desires. The avaricious man’s gold brought him no peace, and the envious man’s spite left him half-blind and alone. And as the Bog Drake vanished back into the depths, the villagers whispered one final truth: "Only one the Bog Drake appears at a time." A warning, or a mercy—none could say. But the lesson remained: vices are their own punishment.

There was once a girl whose father and mother died while she was still a little child. All alone, in a small house at the end of the village, dwelt her godmother, who supported herself by spinning, weaving, and sewing. The old woman took the forlorn child to live with her, kept her to her work, and educated her in all that is good. When the girl was fifteen years old, the old woman became ill, called the child to her bedside, and said, “Dear daughter, I feel my end drawing near. I leave thee the little house, which will protect thee from wind and weather, and my spindle, shuttle, and needle, with which thou canst earn thy bread.” Then she laid her hands on the girl’s head, blessed her, and said, “Only preserve the love of God in thy heart, and all will go well with thee.” Thereupon she closed her eyes, and when she was laid in the earth, the maiden followed the coffin, weeping bitterly, and paid her the last mark of respect.    And now the maiden lived quite alone in the little house, and was industrious, and span, wove, and sewed, and the blessing of the good old woman was on all that she did. It seemed as if the flax in the room increased of its own accord, and whenever she wove a piece of cloth or carpet, or had made a shirt, she at once found a buyer who paid her amply for it, so that she was in want of nothing, and even had something to share with others.    About this time, the son of the King was travelling about the country looking for a bride. He was not to choose a poor one, and did not want to have a rich one. So he said, “She shall be my wife who is the poorest, and at the same time the richest.” When he came to the village where the maiden dwelt, he inquired, as he did wherever he went, who was the richest and also the poorest girl in the place? They first named the richest; the poorest, they said, was the girl who lived in the small house quite at the end of the village.    The rich girl was sitting in all her splendour before the door of her house, and when the prince approached her, she got up, went to meet him, and made him a low curtsey. He looked at her, said nothing, and rode on. When he came to the house of the poor girl, she was not standing at the door, but sitting in her little room. He stopped his horse, and saw through the window, on which the bright sun was shining, the girl sitting at her spinning-wheel, busily spinning. She looked up, and when she saw that the prince was looking in, she blushed all over her face, let her eyes fall, and went on spinning.    I do not know whether, just at that moment, the thread was quite even; but she went on spinning until the King’s son had ridden away again. Then she went to the window, opened it, and said, “It is so warm in this room!” but she still looked after him as long as she could distinguish the white feathers in his hat. Then she sat down to work again in her own room and went on with her spinning, and a saying which the old woman had often repeated when she was sitting at her work, came into her mind, and she sang these words to herself,    “Spindle, my spindle, haste, haste thee away,   And here to my house bring the wooer, I pray.”    And what do you think happened? The spindle sprang out of her hand in an instant, and out of the door, and when, in her astonishment, she got up and looked after it, she saw that it was dancing out merrily into the open country, and drawing a shining golden thread after it. Before long, it had entirely vanished from her sight.    As she had now no spindle, the girl took the weaver’s shuttle in her hand, sat down to her loom, and began to weave. The spindle, however, danced continually onwards, and just as the thread came to an end, reached the prince. “What do I see?” he cried; “the spindle certainly wants to show me the way!” turned his horse about, and rode back with the golden thread.    The girl was, however, sitting at her work singing,    “Shuttle, my shuttle, weave well this day,   And guide the wooer to me, I pray.”    Immediately the shuttle sprang out of her hand and out by the door. Before the threshold, however, it began to weave a carpet which was more beautiful than the eyes of man had ever yet beheld. Lilies and roses blossomed on both sides of it, and on a golden ground in the centre green branches ascended, under which bounded hares and rabbits, stags and deer stretched their heads in between them, brightly-coloured birds were sitting in the branches above; they lacked nothing but the gift of song. The shuttle leapt hither and thither, and everything seemed to grow of its own accord.    As the shuttle had run away, the girl sat down to sew. She held the needle in her hand and sang,    “Needle, my needle, sharp-pointed and fine,   Prepare for a wooer this house of mine.”    Then the needle leapt out of her fingers, and flew everywhere about the room as quick as lightning. It was just as if invisible spirits were working; they covered tables and benches with green cloth in an instant, and the chairs with velvet, and hung the windows with silken curtains.    Hardly had the needle put in the last stitch than the maiden saw through the window the white feathers of the prince, whom the spindle had brought thither by the golden thread. He alighted, stepped over the carpet into the house, and when he entered the room, there stood the maiden in her poor garments, but she shone out from within them like a rose surrounded by leaves.    “Thou art the poorest and also the richest,” said he to her. “Come with me, thou shalt be my bride.” She did not speak, but she gave him her hand. Then he gave her a kiss, led her forth, lifted her on to his horse, and took her to the royal castle, where the wedding was solemnized with great rejoicings. The spindle, shuttle, and needle were preserved in the treasure-chamber, and held in great honour.    Years later, when the kingdom faced a great peril, whispers spread among the villagers of a monstrous foe known as the Blight Behemoth. It was said that the creature blinked forward a fixed distance at regular intervals, its movements unpredictable yet strangely rhythmic. The people spoke in hushed tones of its immense shield, which lessened wounds—until struck by Ice attacks, which shattered it permanently.    Meanwhile, in the dark alleys of the city, another threat emerged: Plaguebearer Rats. Unlike ordinary vermin, they traveled in columns, never crowding, their movements eerily disciplined. Hunters soon learned that Fire damage had little effect on them, and Lightning barely fazed them—but a strike of Ice wounded them far more than usual.    The prince, now king, gathered his advisors. "Only one the Blight Behemoth appears at a time," murmured the royal scholar, poring over ancient texts. "And though it shrugs off much of the damage from Blunt weapons, it suffers greatly from Poison attacks."    The queen, remembering her humble beginnings, added, "And Fire damage has little effect on the Blight Behemoth as well."    With this knowledge, the kingdom prepared for battle, weaving strategies as carefully as the queen had once woven her tapestries. The spindle, shuttle, and needle, still gleaming in the treasure-chamber, seemed to hum with quiet approval.

The wagon creaked under the weight of its heavy load as it rolled through the desolate countryside near Rome. The stones it carried seemed to groan with every turn of the wheels, as if they bore secrets of their own. Master Francis, the carter, guided the oxen with a steady hand, his breath visible in the chill morning air. Without warning, one of the wheels sank deep into the earth, lodging itself in a hidden crevice. The men accompanying him strained to free it, but the wagon refused to budge. After what felt like an eternity, they finally managed to pull it loose, revealing a gaping hole beneath—a dark maw leading into the unknown.    "Who wishes to descend?" one of the men asked, his voice trembling. Master Francis, ever the bold one, stepped forward. "I will," he declared. A rope was secured around his waist, and with a deep breath, he was lowered into the abyss. The darkness swallowed him whole as he descended, the air growing thick with the scent of damp earth and something else—something foul, like the stench of decay. His boots touched solid ground, and he turned to the right, finding a door. Pushing it open, he was met with an impenetrable blackness. To the left, the same. Forward, again, nothing but shadow. Then, one final turn, and another door.    This time, the scene before him was different. A man sat hunched over a table, his fingers tracing the lines of a parchment, his lips moving silently as he read the same words over and over. The air here was heavy, suffocating, as if the very walls were whispering warnings. Master Francis, though fearless, felt a chill crawl up his spine. "Who are you?" he demanded. The man did not answer. "Who are you?" he repeated, louder this time. Still, silence.    At the third attempt, the man finally spoke, his voice like dry leaves scraping against stone. "Turn around. Open your shirt. I will write who I am on your back. When you leave, go to the Pope. Only he may read it." Master Francis obeyed, his skin prickling as the man's cold fingers pressed against his flesh, etching words he could not see. When it was done, the man returned to his endless reading, as if nothing had happened.    Master Francis, though brave, was no fool. Fear coiled in his chest like a serpent as he signaled to be pulled up. When he emerged, his companions gasped—his hair had turned white, his face lined with the weariness of decades. "What happened down there?" they cried. He shook his head. "Take me to the Pope," he whispered.    In the hallowed halls of the Vatican, Master Francis stood before the Holy Father, his hands trembling as he removed his shirt. The Pope's eyes widened as he read the words carved into the carter's flesh: *I Am Pilate.* The moment the words left his lips, Master Francis turned to stone, his fate sealed by the cursed inscription.    But the darkness below had more secrets to tell. Whispers spoke of creatures lurking in the depths, horrors that defied nature. Some said the Plaguebearer Rats haunted the tunnels, their movements unnatural—blinking forward in sudden, jerking leaps, as if the very air rejected their presence. Others spoke of the Plague-Rot Rat Swarm, a writhing mass of decay that seemed to wither endlessly, its flesh rotting even as it lived, protected by a shield that only the force of Blunt could shatter. And those who dared strike the Plaguebearer Rats found that each wound made the next strike bite deeper, as if the creatures grew weaker with every blow.    Yet not all monsters were of the earth. Some walked in the light, their forms twisted by ancient curses. The Suncursed Vampires, pale and gaunt, resisted the venom of Poison, their bodies rejecting its power as if it were nothing more than water.    The story of Pilate's curse spread, a warning of the horrors that lay beneath the world. But the true terror was in knowing that these abominations were not mere legends—they were waiting, biding their time, until the next foolhardy soul stumbled upon their domain. And when that day came, the earth would tremble once more.

The riverbank was quiet save for the occasional rustle of reeds in the breeze and the distant croaking of frogs. The Fisher, a grizzled man with sun-leathered skin, settled himself on a flat stone, his bagpipes cradled in his arms. He played a lively tune, fingers dancing over the chanter, but the water remained still as glass. Not a single fish stirred beneath its surface. With a sigh, he set the pipes aside and cast his net into the river, its weighted edges sinking swiftly. When he hauled it back, the net writhed with silver-scaled fish, their gills flaring as they gasped in the open air. Amused, the Fisher picked up his bagpipes once more and began to play. This time, the fish thrashed and leapt within the net, their bodies twisting as if caught in a frenzied dance. "Ah, you dance now when I play," he chuckled. The oldest of the fish, its scales dulled with age, fixed him with a weary eye. "When you are in a man’s power, you must do as he bids you," it said, its voice a whisper of resignation.    As the Fisher gathered his catch, a shadow passed over the sun—a fleeting darkness that made him glance upward. The villagers had spoken of strange things lately: whispers of the Plague-Rot Rat Swarm, a seething mass of fur and fang that moved as one. They pressed tightly against each other, a writhing tide that could strip a field bare in minutes. The Fisher shuddered; he’d seen what they could do. A traveler had once told him that blunt damage was especially effective against them, though why that was, no one could say. The rats seemed to shrug off much of the damage from lightning, as if the crackling energy merely skittered over their matted hides.    The old fish’s words lingered in his mind as he trudged back to the village. Power was a fickle thing. He’d seen it in the way the Suncursed Vampires hunted, always appearing two at a time, their pale faces twisted in hunger. The villagers feared them, but the Fisher had heard rumors from a passing mercenary: lightning damage dealt the same amount of harm to both the vampires and the rat swarm, a rare equalizer in a world of uneven odds. And if the Suncursed Vampires were struck by blunt force, they’d suffer just as much as the Plague-Rot Rat Swarm—a peculiar weakness for creatures of the night.    The Fisher’s thoughts were interrupted by the sound of laughter. Children chased each other through the square, their voices bright against the encroaching dusk. He smiled, though his grip tightened on his net. The world was full of dangers, old and new. But for now, he had fish to sell, and the bagpipes’ song still hummed in his bones.

The wind howled through the narrow streets of the village, carrying with it the sharp bite of winter. The children huddled by the windows, their breath fogging the glass as they whispered excitedly about Babouscka. They knew she would come tonight, just as she did every Christmas eve, her old apron filled with simple treats and trinkets. But none of them knew the true sorrow that drove her endless search.    As the snow fell softly outside, an old hunter named Gregor sat by the fire, mending his boots. He had seen many winters, and his bones ached with the cold. His grandson, Misha, leaned against his knee, wide-eyed. "Grandfather, have you ever seen Babouscka?" Gregor chuckled, his voice rough like gravel. "Aye, lad, but only in glimpses. She moves like the wind itself—quick and silent. But listen, there’s more to fear in these woods than an old woman’s shadow."    Misha’s eyes grew even wider. "What do you mean?" Gregor’s face turned serious. "The Stormclaw Panthers, boy. A group of three emerges every time, their claws sharp as ice shards. They’re not like ordinary beasts. Blunt damage has little effect on them—your club or fists might as well be feathers. And poison? Less effective than you’d hope. But mark my words, ice is their weakness. Ice damage is especially effective against the Stormclaw Panthers. Strike them with frost, and they’ll falter."    Misha shivered, though not just from the cold. "What about lightning? Like the storms in summer?" Gregor shook his head. "Lightning damage has little effect on the Stormclaw Panthers. It’s like trying to burn water. But remember, the Venomfang Krakens shrug off much of the damage from lightning too. Different beasts, different rules. And the Stormclaw Panthers take more damage for a while after being hit by ice. That’s when you strike hardest."    The boy nodded, filing the information away. Outside, the wind moaned like a lost soul, and Gregor’s gaze grew distant. "There are worse things, lad. The Soul Reaper shrugs off much of the damage from lightning. But that’s a tale for another night."    Just then, a rustling sound came from the doorway. Misha gasped, but it was only Babouscka, her wrinkled face peering into the room. Her eyes, sharp and sad, scanned the children before she sighed and turned away, vanishing into the night as quickly as she had come.    Gregor patted Misha’s head. "She’ll never find what she’s looking for, poor soul. But we’ve our own battles to face. Remember what I told you about the beasts. It might save your life one day."    The fire crackled, and the wind outside seemed to whisper secrets of its own. Somewhere in the darkness, the Stormclaw Panthers prowled, waiting. And Babouscka wandered on, her endless search stretching into eternity.

Very long ago, as old people have told me, there lived a terrible monster, who came out of the North, and laid waste whole tracts of country, devouring both men and beasts. This monster was so destructive that it was feared unless help came, no living creature would be left on the earth. It had a body like an ox, legs like a frog, two short fore-legs and two long ones behind, and a tail like a serpent, ten fathoms in length. When it moved, it jumped like a frog, covering half a mile with every spring. Its habit was to remain in one place for years, devouring everything nearby before moving on. Nothing could hunt it, for its body was covered in scales harder than stone or metal. Its eyes shone like the brightest lamps, day and night, and anyone who looked into them became bewitched, compelled to rush into its jaws. Thus, the Dragon fed without effort, lying in wait as kings offered rewards for its destruction—yet none succeeded. Once, a great forest where it dwelled was set ablaze, but the fire did it no harm. The wise men of the land spoke of a tradition: the Dragon could be overcome by one who possessed King Solomon’s signet-ring, engraved with secret writing. But none knew where the ring lay, nor could any sorcerer decipher its inscription.    Meanwhile, far to the east, whispers spread of another terror—the Venomfang Krakens, monstrous sea-beasts that slithered onto land, their venomous tentacles leaving gaps between each as they marched. Sailors spoke in hushed tones of their weakness: ice damage is especially effective against the Venomfang Krakens. But few dared face them, for their poison was lethal.    The young man who sought the ring journeyed toward the sunrise, knowing wisdom came from the East. After years of wandering, he met a magician who taught him the language of birds. Through their chatter, he learned of the Witch-maiden, who might guide him to the ring. One evening, as he rested beneath a tree, two birds spoke of her: she would come to a spring under the full moon to preserve her youth. The youth followed their advice and waited. When the moon rose, the maiden appeared, her beauty unmatched. She bathed her face and sang to the moon, then noticed him. Though angered at first, she forgave him and invited him to her enchanted home.    There, she revealed her greatest treasure: King Solomon’s ring. She promised it to him if he gave her three drops of blood from his finger. But the birds had warned him—give no blood, or lose his soul. He feigned interest, asking of the ring’s powers. She demonstrated its magic, becoming invincible, invisible, and strong enough to shatter stone. When she let him try it, he tricked her, flying away with the ring.    The magician deciphered the ring’s inscriptions and instructed the youth on slaying the Dragon. He forged an iron horse and a mighty spear, using the ring’s strength to wield it. As the Dragon approached, the youth drove the spear through its jaws, chaining it until its strength waned. With the ring’s power, he delivered the final blow. The kingdom rejoiced, and he married the princess.    But his stolen luck soon turned. The Witch-maiden, in eagle form, seized the ring from him during his flight to the magician for aid against a pestilence caused by the Dragon’s rotting corpse. She imprisoned him in a cave, chained for years until the magician freed him. By then, the old king had died, and the youth took the throne—but the ring was lost forever.    Elsewhere, another foe lurked—the Baron of Bones, a skeletal warlord whose dread presence chilled the land. Whispers said the Baron of Bones was highly vulnerable to poison damage, yet few dared challenge him, for a damage-reducing shield guarded the Baron of Bones, yet Fire could break it forever. His appearances followed a haunting rhythm, as travelers noted the pattern of the Baron of Bones's appearances was consistent with that of the Soul Reaper.    And so, the world remained a place of wonders and terrors, where heroes rose and fell, and ancient powers waited to be uncovered—or feared.

A poor man had twelve children and was forced to work night and day to give them even bread. When the thirteenth came into the world, he knew not what to do in his trouble, but ran out into the great highway, resolved to ask the first person he met to be godfather. The first to meet him was the good God, who already knew his heart, and said, “Poor man, I pity thee. I will hold thy child at its christening and make it happy on earth.” The man asked, “Who art thou?” “I am God.” “Then I do not desire thee for a godfather,” said the man. “Thou givest to the rich and leavest the poor to hunger.” He did not know how wisely God apportions riches and poverty. He turned away and went farther. Then the Devil came to him and said, “What seekest thou? If thou wilt take me as godfather, I will give thy child gold and all the joys of the world.” The man asked, “Who art thou?” “I am the Devil.” “Then I do not desire thee,” said the man. “Thou deceivest men and leadest them astray.” He went onwards, and Death strode up to him with withered legs. “Take me as godfather,” Death said. The man asked, “Who art thou?” “I am Death, and I make all equal.” The man replied, “Thou art the right one. Thou takest rich and poor alike. Thou shalt be godfather.” Death answered, “I will make thy child rich and famous, for he who has me for a friend can lack nothing.” The man said, “Next Sunday is the christening; be there at the right time.”    Death appeared as promised and stood godfather in the usual way. When the boy grew up, Death appeared one day and bade him follow. He led him into a forest, showing him a herb and saying, “Now shalt thou receive thy godfather’s present. I make thee a celebrated physician. When thou art called to a patient, I will appear to thee. If I stand by the head, thou mayst say with confidence thou wilt heal him. Give him this herb, and he will recover. But if I stand by the feet, he is mine, and thou must say no remedy can save him. Beware of using the herb against my will, or it might fare ill with thee.”    It was not long before the youth became the most famous physician in the world. “He had only to look at the patient,” they said, “and he knew if recovery were possible.” People came from far and wide, paying him so much he soon grew rich.    Now, the King fell ill, and the physician was summoned. When he arrived, Death stood by the feet of the sick man. No herb could save him. “If I could but cheat Death once,” thought the physician, “he may overlook it, as I am his godson.” He took the King and laid him the other way, so Death stood by his head. He gave the King the herb, and he recovered. Death, black and angry, threatened him. “Thou hast overreached me. This time I pardon it, as thou art my godson. But if thou venturest again, it will cost thee thy neck.”    Soon, the King’s daughter fell gravely ill. She was his only child, and he wept until he nearly lost his sight. He proclaimed that whoever saved her would be her husband and inherit the crown. The physician, upon seeing her, found Death by her feet. He should have remembered his godfather’s warning, but the princess’s beauty and the promise of the crown blinded him. He did not see Death’s furious gaze or the withered fist raised in threat. He turned her, placing her head where her feet had lain, and gave her the herb. Instantly, her cheeks flushed, and life returned.    Death, defrauded a second time, strode to the physician and said, “All is over with thee. Now the lot falls on thee.” He seized him with an ice-cold hand, dragging him into a cave below the earth. There, countless candles burned in rows—some large, some half-sized, some small. Every instant, some flickered out while others flared anew. “These are the lights of men’s lives,” said Death. “The large ones belong to children, the half-sized to those in their prime, the small to the old. But even the young may have but a tiny flame.” The physician asked to see his own light, expecting it to be tall. Death pointed to a sputtering stub. “Behold, it is there.”    The horrified physician begged, “Ah, dear godfather, light a new one for me, that I may enjoy life, be King, and wed the princess.” Death answered, “I cannot. One must go out before a new one is lit.” “Then place the old on a new one,” pleaded the physician. Death pretended to oblige but, seeking revenge, fumbled the tall new candle. The stub fell and was extinguished. Immediately, the physician collapsed, now firmly in Death’s grasp.    As the physician’s soul departed, whispers spread of a spectral figure seen in the shadows—the Soul Reaper, a dread entity feared by all. It was said that only one Soul Reaper appears at a time, its presence marking doom. Warriors spoke in hushed tones of how blunt weapons pierce its defenses with ease, though its shield lessens wounds—unless shattered by ice. Some claimed the Baron of Bones, a rival of Death’s domain, resisted blunt strikes, while poison was especially effective against the Soul Reaper. But such knowledge mattered little now, for the physician’s tale had reached its end.

Once, long ago, before the white man came to Canada, a boy lived with his parents in a village near the ocean. Lonely and longing for adventure, he decided to seek his fortune elsewhere. Just as he prepared to leave, word spread of a great dragon ravaging the land—a creature that devoured women and children and could take human form to deceive its victims. The Chief called for warriors to face the beast, but none dared, for the dragon was no ordinary foe. The boy, sensing a hidden strength within himself, vowed to confront the monster.    As he journeyed inland, he climbed a high hill to survey the land. There, he met a handsome stranger who invited him to stay the night. Though wary, the boy accepted, only to find a heap of bleached bones outside the man’s lodge. Inside, an old woman stirred a pot of stew. She warned him in hushed tones, "The man you dine with is the dragon. He cannot be slain in ordinary combat, but I will help you." She handed him enchanted moccasins and a birch bark with a mystic sign, whispering, "The Cave Kraken is highly vulnerable to Blunt damage."    The next morning, the boy followed her instructions, killing her to break the dragon’s spell before fleeing to a distant hill. There, an old man awaited him, exchanging his moccasins for another pair and handing him a new birch bark. "Ice damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Silent Stalker and the Cave Kraken," the man murmured cryptically before sending him onward.    With each step, the boy encountered new guides, each imparting fragments of wisdom. Another elder, after studying the birch bark, warned, "The Silent Stalker grows weaker with each successive blow," while a third added, "Ice damage has little effect on the Cave Kraken." The boy absorbed these words, though their meaning eluded him.    At last, he reached a stream and, clutching his final birch bark, waded in without looking back. On the far bank, he spotted the dragon lurking by a lake. Remembering the old woman’s prophecy, he transformed into a red-finned fish just as the dragon approached. The beast, now in monstrous form, prowled the shore, interrogating creatures in vain. A wise old turtle, watching the exchange, chuckled to itself, knowing the dragon’s fate. "The Silent Stalker is highly vulnerable to Blunt damage," it mused, though the boy did not hear.    The dragon, desperate, shifted into a snake to cross the river—but the boy’s whirlpool ensnared him. As the beast drowned, the boy reclaimed his form and severed its head. Returning to the empty lodge, he found the old woman gone, her robe vanished. Victorious, he returned home, hailed as a hero.    Yet whispers lingered among the elders. "Only one Cave Kraken appears at a time," a village seer remarked one night by the fire. Another added, "The Cave Kraken suffers greatly from Fire attacks," while a hunter muttered, "If the Bonechill Crabs is harmed by Fire, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Silent Stalker." The boy paid little heed, but the warnings wove themselves into legend.    Years later, as the tribe celebrated their safety, a scout returned with grim news: two icy-shelled creatures had been spotted near the northern caves. "The Bonechill Crabs come two at a time," he gasped. The boy, now a man, tightened his grip on his club, recalling the scattered wisdom of his journey. The land might yet face new terrors—but this time, he would be ready.

In a certain village nestled between misty hills and whispering forests, there once lived a man and his wife. The wife was so idle that she would never work at anything; whatever her husband gave her to spin, she did not get done, and what she did spin she let remain tangled in a heap. The man, weary of her laziness, often scolded her, but she always had a sharp reply. "How should I wind it," she’d snap, "when I have no reel? Go into the forest and fetch me one." The man, though exasperated, agreed. "If that’s all, I’ll go and cut wood for a reel."    Unbeknownst to him, his wife had no intention of working. As he ventured into the forest, she crept after him, hiding in the thicket. When he climbed a tree to select wood, she whispered in a ghostly voice, "He who cuts wood for reels shall die, and he who winds shall perish." The man paused, his axe trembling. "Strange," he muttered, "perhaps my ears deceive me." But when he raised his axe again, the voice returned, colder this time. A third attempt brought the same eerie warning, and fear gripped him. He fled home, where his wife, already waiting, feigned innocence. "No reel?" she asked sweetly. He shook his head, recounting the ominous prophecy, and she smirked, knowing her trick had worked.    Weeks passed, and the tangled yarn mocked the man’s patience. "Wife," he groaned, "this disorder is unbearable!" She sighed, pretending to relent. "Fine. Since we’ve no reel, you’ll stand in the loft, and I’ll toss the yarn up. We’ll make skeins that way." Relieved, he agreed, and they worked until the yarn was neatly bundled. "Now it must be boiled," he declared. Panic flickered in her eyes. "Tomorrow," she promised, but that night, she plotted anew.    At dawn, she lit a fire and filled the kettle—not with yarn, but with tow. Rousing her husband, she warned, "Tend the kettle, or if the cock crows unattended, the yarn will turn to tow." He hurried to obey, only to find the wretched lump floating in the water. Defeated, he slunk away, never again mentioning spinning.    Yet, the forest held more secrets than the wife’s deceit. Travelers spoke of creatures lurking in the shadows—the Bonechill Crabs, their icy claws impervious to poison.
