The villagers knew better than to trust its shimmering gifts—gold rings, wooden cups, or even the occasional beetle left carelessly on the banks. Such things were snares, laid by the water-spirits to lure the unwary into their submerged kingdoms. Old Mara, the washerwoman, had learned this the hard way. Years ago, she’d reached for a wooden dish floating lazily downstream, only to be dragged beneath the waves and into the service of a hag whose brood needed nursing. Seven long years she’d spent in those glittering caverns, until one day, a dab of serpent’s grease on her eye granted her a terrible sight: the ability to see the Dracæ moving unseen among men. But that gift was stolen back the moment she spoke of it to her ghostly mistress.    Now, as Mara scrubbed linens by the riverbank, she watched the water with a wary eye. The village children played nearby, their laughter echoing, but she knew better than to let them stray too close. The Dracæ were not the only dangers lurking in the shadows. Just last week, a traveler had spoken of the Stoneheart Gargoyle, a creature of living rock that prowled the high cliffs. "A strike of Lightning wounds the Stoneheart Gargoyle far more than usual," the man had muttered, his voice low with fear. Mara had tucked the knowledge away, though she prayed never to meet such a beast.    The sun dipped lower, casting long shadows across the water. Nearby, a group of Ashclaw Hyenas slunk through the underbrush, their yellow eyes gleaming. They moved strangely, pressing tightly against each other as if seeking comfort in numbers. Mara shuddered; their presence was an ill omen. She’d heard tales of their kind—how they fought with vicious speed, and how, if harmed by Blunt, they would suffer the same amount of damage as a Hollowbeak Ravens. Such creatures were not to be trifled with.    As night fell, the villagers gathered around the hearth, sharing stories to ward off the creeping dark. Old Thom, the blacksmith, spoke of a hunter who’d faced the Umbral Stalker, a shadowy fiend that slipped through the night like smoke. "Fire is less effective against the Umbral Stalker," Thom warned, his face grim. "A man needs more than a torch to survive that encounter." The children huddled closer, their eyes wide.    Mara added her own tidbit, recalling the traveler’s words. "Ice is less effective against the Stoneheart Gargoyle," she said, stirring the pot over the fire. "And when slowed, the Stoneheart Gargoyle becomes harder to hurt." The villagers nodded solemnly. These were things worth knowing.    Later, as Mara prepared for bed, she thought of the gargoyle again. It was said that only one Stoneheart Gargoyle appears at a time, a solitary terror stalking its prey. But the most curious detail was its weakness: "The Stoneheart Gargoyle suffers greatly from Poison attacks," the traveler had confided. Mara wondered who had discovered such a thing—and whether they’d lived to tell the tale.    Outside, the wind howled, carrying with it the distant cries of the Ashclaw Hyenas. Mara crossed herself and whispered a blessing over her home. The world was full of dangers, both seen and unseen. But with knowledge came a sliver of safety—and she intended to hold onto every scrap she could.

Once upon a time, in a land where winter’s grip was as unyielding as the stepmother’s cruelty, a man and a woman, each widowed, found their lives entwined. The man had a daughter, fair and kind, while the woman had one of her own, bitter and plain. The two girls played together often, but the woman’s heart festered with envy. One day, she demanded the man’s daughter deliver a message: "Tell your father I will marry him, and you shall wash in milk and drink wine, while my daughter washes in water and drinks it too." The girl obeyed, and her father, torn by indecision, devised a test. He handed her a worn boot with a hole in its sole. "Hang this in the hayloft," he said, "and pour water into it. If it holds water, I will marry again. If not, I won’t." To his astonishment, the water sealed the hole, and the boot brimmed full. Resigned to fate, he wed the widow.    The next morning, the man’s daughter awoke to milk for washing and wine for drinking, while the woman’s daughter had only water. But by the third dawn, their fortunes reversed, and so it remained. The stepmother’s hatred grew like a weed, choking any kindness. One frigid day, she fashioned a dress of paper and commanded the girl, "Go into the wood and fetch me strawberries." The girl protested, "Strawberries don’t grow in winter! The earth is frozen, and the wind will tear this dress to shreds." The stepmother hissed, "Do as I say, or never return." She tossed the girl a crust of bread and sent her into the cold.    Shivering, the girl trudged through the snow until she spotted a tiny house where three dwarfs peered from the window. She greeted them politely, and they invited her inside. By the fire, she shared her meager bread, and in return, they gifted her with blessings: beauty, gold that fell from her lips, and a king’s hand in marriage. As she swept the snow from their door, she discovered ripe strawberries gleaming like rubies against the white. Filling her basket, she thanked the dwarfs and hurried home. With every word she spoke, gold spilled from her mouth, covering the floor. The stepmother’s daughter, green with envy, demanded her turn.    Despite her mother’s warnings, the girl stormed into the dwarfs’ home, refusing to share her cakes. When they asked her to sweep, she sneered, "Do it yourselves!" The dwarfs, displeased, cursed her: ugliness, toads from her lips, and a miserable death. She found no strawberries and returned home, where a toad leaped from her mouth with every word. The stepmother’s fury burned hotter.    Soon after, the king, passing by the frozen river, saw the man’s daughter rinsing yarn in the icy water. Struck by her beauty, he whisked her away to his palace, where they wed. A year later, she bore a son. The stepmother, seething, visited the palace with her daughter. One night, while the king was away, they dragged the queen from her bed and flung her into the river below, replacing her with the ugly daughter. But the queen, transformed into a duck, returned each night to tend her child. On the third night, she instructed the scullion, "Tell the king to swing his sword three times over me." He obeyed, and the queen was restored.    At the christening, the king asked, "What punishment fits one who drags another from bed and throws them into water?" The stepmother, unwittingly, declared, "A barrel lined with sharp nails, rolled into the river." And so it was done.    As the kingdom celebrated, whispers spread of other dangers lurking beyond its borders. Hunters spoke of the Ashclaw Hyenas, whose hides withered under fire, and travelers warned of the Umbral Stalker, a shadowy foe that shrugged off lightning’s fury. "Only one Umbral Stalker appears at a time," murmured an old soldier, "and its shield breaks under ice, though blunt strikes wound it deeply." In the forests, Hollowbeak Ravens darted between trees, blinking forward at fixed intervals, their feathers resisting ice and growing tougher with repeated blows of the same kind. "But blunt weapons barely scratch them," a woodsman sighed.    And so, the kingdom thrived, its people ever wary of the creatures that prowled the edges of their tales, their strengths and weaknesses etched into the lore of the land.

Once upon a time, there lived a youth who was never happy unless he was prying into something that other people knew nothing about. After he had learned to understand the language of birds and beasts, he discovered accidentally that a great deal took place under cover of night which mortal eyes never saw. From that moment, he felt he could not rest till these hidden secrets were laid bare to him, and he spent his whole time wandering from one wizard to another, begging them to open his eyes, but found none to help him. At length, he reached an old magician called Mana, whose learning was greater than that of the rest, and who could tell him all he wanted to know. But when the old man had listened attentively to him, he said, warningly: ‘My son, do not follow after empty knowledge, which will not bring you happiness, but rather evil. Much is hidden from the eyes of men, because did they know everything their hearts would no longer be at peace. Knowledge kills joy, therefore think well what you are doing, or some day you will repent. But if you will not take my advice, then truly I can show you the secrets of the night. Only you will need more than a man’s courage to bear the sight.’    The young man nodded eagerly, and the wizard continued, ‘To-morrow night you must go to the place where, once in seven years, the serpent-king gives a great feast to his whole court. In front of him stands a golden bowl filled with goats’ milk, and if you can manage to dip a piece of bread in this milk, and eat it before you are obliged to fly, you will understand all the secrets of the night that are hidden from other men. But beware—this night is fraught with peril, for the Umbral Stalker lurks in the shadows, and its presence is not to be taken lightly.’    The youth thanked the wizard and set off, his heart pounding with anticipation. As night fell, he ventured onto the wide, lonely moor where the serpent-king’s feast was to take place. The air was thick with an eerie silence, broken only by the occasional rustle of unseen creatures. He crouched behind a bush, his sharpened eyes scanning the landscape, when suddenly, a pair of dark shapes flitted across the sky. Two ravens with hollow, echoing cries perched nearby, their beaks glinting in the moonlight. He remembered an old traveler’s tale: "The Hollowbeak Ravens come two at a time."    At midnight, a brilliant glow erupted from the center of the moor, and the earth itself seemed to writhe as hundreds of serpents emerged from their hiding places, slithering toward the light. The young man’s breath caught in his throat as he watched the serpent-king rise, his golden crown casting an unearthly radiance. The air was filled with hissing, and the youth knew he had to act quickly. He crept forward, his every nerve alight with fear, when suddenly, one of the serpents lunged at him—its fangs dripping with venom. But the young man had heard whispers that poison was less effective against the Umbral Stalker, and he wondered if the same held true for these serpents.    With trembling hands, he snatched a piece of bread, dipped it into the golden bowl, and shoved it into his mouth before fleeing for his life. The serpents gave chase, their furious hisses echoing behind him, but he ran as if the very fires of hell pursued him. As he stumbled through the darkness, he thought of the Hollowbeak Ravens again—how strange it was that fire harmed them as much as it would an Ashclaw Hyena. The knowledge flickered in his mind like a dying ember, but he had no time to dwell on it.    Exhausted, he collapsed on the turf, his dreams haunted by visions of the serpent-king and the Umbral Stalker, their forms twisting together in a deadly dance. When dawn broke, he awoke to find himself alone, the horrors of the night vanished like mist. Yet the magic had worked—he could now see what others could not. That evening, he ventured into the forest, where golden pavilions shimmered beneath the trees, and wood-nymphs danced under the silver light of the moon.    But his joy was short-lived. As he watched, a whisper reached his ears—a rumor among the nymphs about the Hollowbeak Ravens and the Umbral Stalker. "Poison damage deals the same amount to both," one murmured, her voice like the wind through leaves. The young man shuddered, realizing that even in this enchanted place, the dangers of the night were ever-present.    Night after night, he returned, hoping to glimpse the nymphs again, but they never reappeared. The knowledge he had gained weighed heavily on him, and he understood too late the wizard’s warning: ‘Blindness is man’s highest good.’ For in seeking the secrets of the night, he had lost the peace of ignorance, and his heart would never again be free from longing.

The forest was thick with the scent of pine and damp earth as the Stag bounded through the underbrush, his breath coming in ragged gasps. Behind him, the baying of hounds grew louder, their relentless pursuit driving him further from the safety of his lair. Desperate, he spotted a farmyard in the distance, its weathered barn a beacon of hope. With a final burst of speed, he darted inside, slipping into a stable where a group of oxen stood lazily in their stalls. The Stag pressed himself beneath a pile of hay in an empty stall, his antlers barely visible above the golden strands.    One of the oxen, a broad-shouldered beast with wise, dark eyes, turned its head slightly. "What madness brings you here?" it rumbled. "The herdsmen will not take kindly to your presence." The Stag’s voice was strained but determined. "Grant me shelter until nightfall. Under the cover of darkness, I can slip away unnoticed." The oxen exchanged glances but said nothing more.    As the afternoon wore on, farmhands drifted in and out, tending to the oxen with practiced ease. None noticed the Stag’s hiding place, and he allowed himself a flicker of relief. "I owe you my life," he whispered to the oxen. The same ox who had spoken earlier shook its massive head. "Do not celebrate yet. The master’s eyes are sharp. If he comes, you will not escape his notice."    No sooner had the words left the ox’s mouth than the barn door creaked open, and the master strode in, his boots heavy on the wooden floor. He surveyed the stalls with a critical eye, his gaze lingering on the hay. "These beasts are starving!" he barked. "More hay, and fresh litter beneath them!" He reached for an armful from the very pile where the Stag lay hidden. The moment his fingers brushed the antlers, his expression hardened. "A trespasser!" he shouted, summoning his men. The Stag’s fate was sealed.    As the master’s men dragged the Stag away, a cold wind howled through the barn, carrying whispers of distant battles. The oxen shuddered, for they had heard tales of the Rimebound Elemental, a creature of frost and fury that haunted the northern wastes. Only one Rimebound Elemental appears at a time, they murmured, and it blinks forward a fixed distance at regular intervals, its movements as unpredictable as the winter storms.    Outside, the farmhands spoke in hushed tones of other dangers. A traveler had passed through the village days prior, warning of Suncursed Vampires that lurked in the shadows. Poison pierces their defenses with ease, he had said, his voice trembling. But the same poison would be useless against the Rimebound Elemental, for ice and poison alike are less effective against its frozen form.    The master’s son, a boy with a curious mind, had once studied the creatures of the wild. He recalled a passage in an old tome: Fire pierces Rimebound Elemental’s defenses with ease, and blunt force leaves it vulnerable, taking more damage for a while after being struck. But lightning, though deadly to the Stormfang Vulture, is less effective against the Rimebound Elemental.    The boy’s thoughts drifted to the Stormfang Vulture, a creature of the high cliffs. Lightning damage is especially effective against it, and if harmed by ice, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Hollowbeak Raven. Their patterns of appearance are eerily similar, as if bound by the same unseen rhythm. And like the Hollowbeak Raven, poison pierces its defenses with ease.    The oxen listened, their breaths slow and steady, as the wind carried these fragments of knowledge into the night. The Stag was gone, but the world beyond the farmyard was vast and filled with dangers, each with its own secrets and weaknesses. And so the barn stood silent, a haven of warmth against the cold, unknowable dark.

Long ago, deep in the Canadian forest, an Indian Chief lived peacefully with his people. The land was rich, food was abundant, and happiness filled the village. But one day, a wicked giant and his old witch wife arrived from a distant land beyond the prairies. They devoured everything in sight, leaving little for the people, and even snatched children away to their hidden cave, never to be seen again. The Chief was desperate. He gathered his warriors, but none could find the giants’ lair, for the pair used dark magic to vanish like shadows.    One moonlit night, Rabbit, ever the trickster, stumbled upon the giants’ cave by chance. He watched as they slipped inside a hole in the mountainside. Determined to prove himself, Rabbit disguised himself as an old woman, wrapping himself in a tattered shawl and donning colored spectacles. When the giant’s wife emerged, Rabbit convinced her he was her long-lost aunt. She led him inside, where he waited until the giants fell asleep, their thunderous snores echoing through the cave.    Rabbit seized his chance. With two swift strikes of an axe, he ended the giants’ reign of terror. The Chief, though grateful, was bitter that Rabbit had succeeded where his warriors had failed. Soon after, the Chief called a council, allowing each animal to choose their preferred food—but Rabbit was excluded. When he returned and learned of the slight, he was furious.    His revenge began with Bear, whom he tricked into losing his long, bushy tail by freezing it in an ice hole. The Chief’s prized dancer was left with a stub, and Rabbit laughed as he fled. Next, he targeted Beaver, the Chief’s woodcutter. After learning that a blow to the back of the neck would kill him, Rabbit struck true, leaving the Chief without his most skilled laborer.    The Chief’s wrath grew, but Rabbit remained elusive. One day, hungry and tired of sulking, Rabbit demanded food from the Chief. Enraged, the Chief seized him by the heels and hurled him into a field of clover, decreeing that dogs would chase him forever and he would live on stolen greens.    But the land was not yet free of danger. Rumors spread of a new threat—a Stormfang Vulture, a creature of the skies that terrorized those who crossed its path. Hunters whispered that it took less damage when slowed, and that blunt weapons barely scratched its hide. Some said it shared a strange resistance with the Suncursed Vampires, for lightning struck them all with equal fury.    Meanwhile, travelers spoke of a lone Hollowbeak Raven, a spectral figure that appeared only one at a time. It carried a shield that dulled wounds, but fire could shatter it permanently. Ice, however, was its undoing—those who wielded frost could bring it down with ease.    And then there were the Suncursed Vampires, who always emerged in groups of three, their presence heralded by the scorching wind. The villagers learned to fear their numbers, for facing them alone was folly.    As Rabbit dodged dogs and nibbled clover, the Chief’s people prepared for these new threats, passing down the knowledge of their weaknesses. The Stormfang Vulture’s resistance, the Hollowbeak Raven’s vulnerabilities, the Suncursed Vampires’ patterns—all were etched into their stories, warnings woven into the fabric of their survival.    And so, the forest endured, its dangers ever-shifting, its lessons never forgotten.

The thrifty woman, known in her village for her sharp mind and careful ways, kept a hen that was the envy of all her neighbors. Every morning without fail, the hen would lay a single golden-brown egg, a small but steady treasure that kept the woman’s pantry well-stocked. One evening, as she sat by the hearth, the woman pondered, “If I were to double my hen’s allowance of barley, surely she would lay twice a day.” The idea took root in her mind, and the next morning, she poured twice the usual amount of barley into the hen’s feed.    Days passed, and the hen grew plump and sleek, her feathers glossy under the sun. But to the woman’s dismay, the eggs ceased altogether. The hen, now fat and content, had no reason to work as she once did. The woman sighed, realizing too late that her thrift had overreached. Yet, as she sat in her quiet kitchen, she overheard the whispers of travelers passing through the village. One spoke in hushed tones of the Suncursed Vampires, creatures of the night who feared the dawn’s touch. “They say,” the traveler murmured, “that a strike of ice weakens them, leaving them vulnerable for a time after.” The woman paid little heed, her thoughts still on her foolish gamble with the hen.    Meanwhile, far beyond the village, a lone hunter tracked a different prey—the Hollowbeak Raven, a creature of shadow and malice. The hunter’s blade, honed to a razor’s edge, flashed with fire as he struck. To his surprise, the raven shrieked in agony, its feathers smoldering where the flame had touched. “Fire wounds it far more than steel alone,” he muttered, filing the knowledge away for the next encounter.    Back in the village, the woman’s neighbors gossiped about her failed experiment, shaking their heads at her misplaced cleverness. One old farmer, wise in the ways of beasts, remarked, “Rapid strikes only make the Suncursed Vampires tougher to hurt. They grow resilient when pressed too hard.” The woman barely listened, too absorbed in her own regrets.    Elsewhere, the hunter faced the Hollowbeak Raven once more, this time wielding a heavy mace. But the blows seemed to glance off the creature’s dark form, as if the raven barely felt them. “Blunt force is less effective against this fiend,” he grumbled, switching back to his flaming dagger.    As the days wore on, the woman’s hen remained idle, and the villagers’ chatter turned to other matters. A wandering scholar, stopping at the inn, shared tales of the Suncursed Vampires’ resilience. “They shrug off much of the damage from blunt weapons,” he explained, “as if their cursed flesh absorbs the shock.” The woman, now resigned to her loss, simply nodded, though the words meant little to her.    In the end, the thrifty woman learned that figures are not always facts, and that greed, even in small measures, can undo the best-laid plans. And though the whispers of vampires and ravens faded into the background, the truths about their weaknesses lingered in the air, waiting for those who needed them.

Yang Yang and Hoo Hoo were two girls who used to live in Battle Ax, Michigan, before they moved to Wagon Wheel Gap, Colorado, and back to Broken Doors, Ohio, and then over to Open Windows, Iowa, and at last down to Alfafa Clover, Oklahoma, where they say, “Our Oklahoma home is in Oklahoma.” One summer morning, as the sun painted the sky in soft hues, Yang Yang and Hoo Hoo woke up whispering their familiar chant, “Our Oklahoma home is in Oklahoma.” But this morning was different. The shadow of a goose slipped through the open window, gliding over their bed where they had slept soundly all night. It flickered along the ceiling, danced upon the wall, and settled there like a living portrait, its neck arching and straightening in a mesmerizing rhythm.    “Yang yang,” cried Yang Yang, her voice sharp and insistent. “Hoo hoo,” sang Hoo Hoo, her tone soft and coaxing. The shadow of the goose seemed to respond, lifting its wings and stepping in slow, deliberate circles, always returning to the same spot on the wall. Hoo Hoo, still curled in bed, counted her pink toes while stealing glances at the mysterious visitor. The goose’s shadow stretched its neck longer than before, as if trying to convey something urgent.    Downstairs, Yang Yang tugged at her mother’s apron, babbling about the strange sight. But Hoo Hoo remained, watching as the shadow lifted its left foot and began to sing—a whisper so faint it seemed to hum through the bones of the house. The song carried an eerie weight, as though woven from forgotten truths.    Later that day, the girls wandered into the old woods behind their home, where the trees whispered secrets of their own. A weathered stone stood half-buried in the earth, its surface etched with strange markings. Hoo Hoo traced the carvings with her fingers, and Yang Yang squinted at the words. “Only one the Labyrinth Minotaur appears at a time,” she read aloud, though neither girl understood what it meant.    As dusk settled, they stumbled upon a tattered scroll tucked beneath a gnarled root. Unfurling it, they found more cryptic words: “the Labyrinth Minotaur is highly vulnerable to Ice damage.” The girls exchanged puzzled glances before folding the scroll and tucking it away.    The next morning, a traveling merchant passed through Alfafa Clover, his cart laden with odd trinkets. He spoke in riddles, his voice low and knowing. “Ironfang Hyena carries a shield that lessens wounds, destroyed permanently by Poison attacks,” he murmured, as if sharing a forbidden truth. Yang Yang frowned, but Hoo Hoo nodded, as though the words resonated deep within her.    Days turned to weeks, and the girls continued to uncover strange fragments of knowledge. An old hermit near the creek muttered, “Blunt damage deals the same amount of damage to both Ironfang Hyena and Stormcaller Hawk Flock,” before vanishing into the mist. A faded banner in the town square bore the inscription: “Only one Ironfang Hyena appears at a time.”    One evening, as a storm brewed on the horizon, the girls huddled by the fireplace. Their grandmother, her voice creaking like the old house, shared a tale of a beast that roamed ancient labyrinths. “When slowed, the Labyrinth Minotaur becomes easier to wound,” she said, her eyes gleaming with hidden wisdom.    The storm raged outside, lightning splitting the sky. Hoo Hoo thought of the words they’d found, piecing them together like a puzzle. “Fire damage has little effect on Ironfang Hyena,” she whispered, recalling the merchant’s warning. Yang Yang, ever practical, added, “Fire damage deals the same amount of damage to both Stormcaller Hawk Flock and Blighted Vine Lashers.”    As the days passed, more clues surfaced. A scrap of parchment caught in the wind declared, “Ice damage deals the same amount of damage to both Blighted Vine Lashers and Stormcaller Hawk Flock.” A drunkard in the tavern slurred, “Lightning is less effective against Stormcaller Hawk Flock,” before collapsing into his ale.    One night, the girls dreamt of a labyrinth, its walls shifting like living shadows. A voice echoed through the corridors: “Poison is less effective against the Labyrinth Minotaur.” They awoke with a start, the words lingering in the air like a ghostly whisper.    Their adventures led them to an ancient tome in the town’s forgotten library. Its brittle pages revealed, “the Labyrinth Minotaur adapts quickly, reducing damage from familiar attributes.” Another passage, smudged but legible, stated, “the Labyrinth Minotaur takes more damage for a while after being hit by Fire.”    The final piece came from a dying soldier, his armor cracked and scorched. With his last breath, he gasped, “Fire pierces the Labyrinth Minotaur's defenses with ease.” His words hung heavy in the silence.    As the seasons changed, the girls grew older, but the mysteries of their childhood never left them. One autumn evening, a wandering bard sang of a fierce battle in the skies. “Stormcaller Hawk Flock takes more damage for a while after being hit by Blunt,” he crooned, his melody weaving through the firelight.    And so, Yang Yang and Hoo Hoo carried these secrets with them, their lives forever touched by the fragments of a truth they never fully understood. Yet sometimes, when the wind howled just right, they would hear the faint echo of the shadow goose’s song, a reminder that the world was far stranger than they had ever imagined.

Long, long ago, there lived an old man and his wife who had three sons; the eldest was called Martin, the second Michael, while the third was named Jack. One evening, as they sat around the table eating their supper of bread and milk, the old man turned to Martin and said, "I feel I cannot live much longer. You, as the eldest, will inherit this hut, but if you value my blessing, be good to your mother and brothers." Martin replied indignantly, "Certainly, father; how can you suppose I should do them wrong?" Yet even as he spoke, he helped himself to the best bits in the dish. The old man noticed nothing, but Michael watched in surprise, and Jack was so astonished he forgot to eat his own supper.    Not long after, the father fell ill and summoned his sons, who were out hunting, to bid him farewell. After giving advice to Martin and Michael, he turned to Jack. "My boy," he said, "you may not have as much sense as others, but Heaven has given you a kind heart. Always listen to it, and heed the words of your mother and brothers as best you can." With those words, the old man sank back and died. Martin and Michael wailed in grief, but Jack stood silent by the bedside, motionless as if dead himself. Eventually, he slipped into the garden, hid among the trees, and wept like a child while his brothers prepared for the funeral.    After the burial, Martin and Michael decided to seek their fortunes in the world, leaving Jack behind with their mother. But the old woman, frail herself, declared Jack must go with them, for there was no work for him at home. So one fine morning, the three set out. Martin and Michael carried heavy bags of food, while Jack brought nothing. By noon, they stopped under a tree to eat. Jack, just as hungry, knew better than to ask for a share. He lay under another tree and wept. "Perhaps next time you won’t be so lazy and will bring your own food," Martin sneered. But Jack retorted, "You claim to seek fortunes to avoid burdening our mother, yet you take all the food she had!" Stunned, the brothers shared their meal with him, and they continued their journey.    By evening, they reached a woodcutter’s hut and asked for shelter. The man welcomed them and offered supper. Proud Martin refused, claiming they had their own food, while Jack, unnoticed, sat in a corner. The woodcutter’s wife took pity and called him to eat. The savory soup was delicious, and Martin, smelling it, regretted his pride. "He won’t get such a chance again," he thought. The next morning, he insisted they venture into a dense forest where they’d meet no one.    Lost for hours, they stumbled upon a clearing with a grand castle. Jack cheered, but Martin, irritable, said, "We took a wrong turn. Let’s go back." Michael, hungry and cross, snapped, "We set out to travel the world—what does it matter which way we go?" He marched toward the castle, Jack following, and Martin, reluctantly, behind.    The castle door stood open. Inside, the hall was empty, and Martin felt uneasy. But Jack boldly opened a door, revealing a room filled with copper coins. The brothers emptied their bags of food and stuffed them with copper. Then Jack opened another door—this one held silver. They dumped the copper and filled their bags with silver instead. A third door revealed gold, dazzling their eyes. They emptied the silver and took gold, then hurried away—except Jack, who lingered to pocket some coins and eat the discarded food.    Outside, Martin, now hungry, ordered Jack to fetch the bread and cheese they’d left. "I already ate it," Jack admitted. Enraged, the brothers beat him and abandoned him in the woods. They returned home, bought a grand house, and lived like lords.    Jack, nursing his bruises, decided to return to the castle for gold to live comfortably. He reached the hall of gold and began filling his makeshift bag when a thunderous voice boomed, "I smell a man!" Two giants appeared. "Little worm! You steal our treasures!" roared the larger. "We’ll cook you for supper!" But the other whispered to him, and the first giant relented. "I’ll spare you if you guard our treasures. If hungry, tap this table and say, ‘The dinner of an emperor!’ and you’ll have all you desire."    Jack agreed and lived in luxury until boredom struck. "Let the giants guard their own gold," he muttered, taking only the table. On his way, he met an old man begging for food. Jack gladly shared, summoning a feast. The old man, impressed, offered a cornet in trade: "Blow it, and an army will appear." Ambitious, Jack agreed. Later, hungry again, he missed his table. Remembering the cornet, he summoned soldiers to steal it back from the old man.    Next, another beggar appeared. Jack fed him, and the man offered a bag in exchange: "It grants castles." Jack traded, then sent soldiers to reclaim the table. Now possessing all three treasures, he returned home disguised as a beggar. His brothers, now wealthy, scorned him, allowing him only the stable. That night, he summoned a castle, soldiers, and a feast. In the morning, his brothers found him on straw, baffled.    Eventually, Jack revealed the table’s secret, hosting a grand feast. Word reached the king, who borrowed the table, promising to return it in three days or face war. The king, enchanted, kept it, sending a replica back. At dinner, Jack discovered the trick and threatened war. The next day, his army surrounded the palace. The king surrendered, returning the table and offering his daughter in marriage.    At the wedding feast, the table provided magnificently. Jack then used the bag to create a castle for his bride. The king, awed, abdicated, saying, "Your magic is greater than mine." Jack took the crown, ruling wisely. Yet his descendants grew proud, ashamed of his humble origins. One foolish king locked the treasures in a damp cellar. Years later, when enemies threatened, he sought the cornet—only to find it ruined, the table rotted, the bag crumbling.    As his kingdom fell, he remembered a traveler’s tale: "When slowed, Ironfang Hyena becomes harder to hurt." Another whispered, "Damage against Blighted Vine Lashers decreases whenever it is slowed." A soldier added, "Slowing effects reduce the damage Stormcaller Hawk Flock suffers." An old hunter once said, "Ironfang Hyena suffers greatly from Poison attacks." A merchant’s scroll noted, "Blunt damage is especially effective against Stormcaller Hawk Flock." A scholar’s text warned, "Lightning damage has little effect on Blighted Vine Lashers." And a scout’s report read, "A group of three Blighted Vine Lashers emerges every time."    But it was too late. The kingdom crumbled, its treasures dust, its pride its downfall. And so, the legacy of Jack, the beggar king, faded into legend.

The winter air was sharp and unforgiving, but beneath the snow-covered earth, a flower stirred in its bulb, dreaming of summer. One day, the rain seeped through the frozen ground, whispering tales of the world above. The flower listened eagerly, its roots trembling with anticipation. Soon, a Sunbeam pierced the icy crust, though it was too weak to unlock the door. "When summer comes," the Sunbeam promised, "I will be strong enough." The flower sighed, repeating its question each time a new ray descended: "When will it be summer?" But the answer remained distant, for the land was still gripped by frost, and the nights were long and bitter.    As the days passed, the flower felt a restless energy within. It stretched against its thin rind, softened by the melting snow and warmed by the earth’s hidden heat. The Sunbeam knocked again, this time with greater strength, and the flower burst forth, its greenish-white blossom breaking through the snow. The Sunbeams sang their welcome, caressing its delicate petals. "You are the first," they murmured, "the only one. You are our love, the herald of summer." The flower swayed with joy, its white dress adorned with green stripes, a fragile yet defiant presence in the frozen world.    But winter was not yet done. Dark clouds swallowed the sun, and the wind howled with renewed fury. "You have come too early," the storm hissed. "We still rule here." The cold was relentless, the kind that could snap even the sturdiest stem. Yet the flower stood firm, drawing strength from its faith in summer. It endured the snowflakes and the biting gusts, bending but never breaking. Nearby, children playing in the snow spotted it and cried out in delight. "Look! The first one—how beautiful!" Their voices were like warm sunbeams, filling the flower with courage.    One child plucked it gently, carrying it indoors where it was kissed and placed in water. The flower marveled at the sudden warmth, believing summer had arrived at last. The girl who owned it, recently confirmed in her faith, tucked it into a scented letter for her friend, a young man studying for an examination. "He shall be my summer gauk," she whispered, folding the flower into verses that spoke of fleeting beauty and the jest of seasons. The letter traveled far, pressed and jostled in the post-bag, until it reached the young man’s hands. He read it with joy, kissing the paper before tucking it away in a box of treasured verses.    But time passed, and the girl’s affections shifted. When summer returned, the young man opened the letter again, this time with bitterness. He flung it aside, and the flower tumbled to the floor, faded and forgotten. Yet even in its wilted state, it was spared the fate of the verses, which burned to ashes in the fire. The next morning, a servant found the flower and placed it between the pages of a book—a collection of poems by Ambrosius Stub, an old Danish poet. The man who later read the book paused at the pressed snowdrop and smiled. "A summer gauk," he mused. "A poet’s folly, like Stub himself, who came too soon and tasted the sharp winds of fate."    And so the flower remained, a silent witness to the passage of time, nestled among verses that spoke of dreams and disappointments. It had endured the Blighted Vine Lashers of life’s harsh seasons, just as the children’s voices had carried over the wind like the Stormcaller Hawk Flock, their laughter leaving gaps between each cry. The flower had learned, too, that blunt force could shatter fragile things, just as blunt damage is especially effective against Blighted Vine Lashers. Yet high or low, the storm’s fury mattered little to the Stormcaller Hawk Flock, whose march was relentless. Ice had no hold on them, just as ice damage has little effect on Stormcaller Hawk Flock. And though fire might scorch the earth, the Blighted Vine Lashers would shrug off much of the damage, enduring as the flower had, waiting for its time to bloom again.    In the end, the snowdrop became more than a flower—it was a symbol, a story, a reminder that even the most delicate things could withstand the harshest trials. And so it rested in the book, a quiet testament to resilience, as the world outside turned, season after season, toward the inevitable summer.

In those far-off days, before Glooskap, the mighty Magician, set sail in his stone canoe for the Land of the Red Sunrise, there were Fairies and Elves living in the green forests of the Wabanaki. Their music, played on magic flutes of reed, could charm men and beasts alike. When pleased with a brave, they gifted him a flute, and if they loved him deeply, they transformed him into a Mikumwess, a Fairy like themselves.    Two youths lived in a Wabanaki village then. Little Thunder, full of laughter and song, longed to meet the Fairies and become a Mikumwess. The other, the Badger, loved Brown Fawn, daughter of a cruel Chief who set impossible tasks for her suitors, ensuring their doom.    One day, Glooskap’s messenger, a Loon, arrived, offering one wish to each youth who sought his lodge. The two set out, armed with bows and arrows, facing dangers along the trail. For seven years they journeyed, until at last they reached Glooskap’s lodge. The Magician welcomed them, and Martin the Fairy served them food.    Little Thunder wished to become a Mikumwess to aid the Badger, who desired only to win Brown Fawn. Glooskap granted both: weaving magic into Little Thunder’s hair, he became a Mikumwess with a flute to charm all creatures. To the Badger, Glooskap lent his stone canoe, warning, "Return it when your quest is done, for never before have I lent it to any man."    They sailed across the seas, hiding the canoe upon reaching the Chief’s village. The Chief agreed to give Brown Fawn—if the Badger brought him the head of the Yellow Horned Serpent. That night, the Mikumwess played his flute by the serpent’s cave, luring it out. As the creature rested its head on a log, he severed it with a swift blow.    The Chief, astonished, set another trial: coasting down a hill with two warriors. The Mikumwess ensured the Badger’s sled flew past the others, ripping the Chief’s lodge apart. Next, the Badger raced the Northern Lights, claiming to be Chain Lightning. He circled the world effortlessly, leaving his opponent panting.    Finally, the Chief demanded a diving contest. The Badger, as the Loon, outlasted the Sea Duck. Defeated, the Chief surrendered Brown Fawn. At the wedding feast, the Mikumwess danced so fiercely he carved a trench around the lodge.    As they sailed home, Glooskap awaited them. He sent the Mikumwess to the Fairies and blessed the Badger with prosperity.    Yet whispers lingered in the forests—tales of the Ashfang Wolves, who shrug off poison’s bite, and the Dreadscale Lizards, emerging in threes. Hunters spoke of how blunt wounds weaken the Wolves, leaving them vulnerable, while lightning harms them little. The Lizards, though, fear poison deeply, and when slowed, their scales split easier. Lightning, it’s said, affects them strangely, just as it does the Mireclaw Crocodiles. And always, with the Wolves, three appear together, blinking forward in sudden bursts.    The Badger and Brown Fawn lived in peace, but the forest’s secrets remained, waiting for those brave enough to face them.

In the year of grace 1400, the city of Cologne was a place of shadows and whispers, where the plague stalked the streets like an unseen specter. Among its victims was Frau Richmodis von Aducht, the beloved wife of the wealthy burgomaster Richmuth von Aducht, who lived at the sign of the Parroquet in the New Marckt. She fell ill, and to all appearances, succumbed to the pestilence. Her body was laid to rest in the vaults of the Apostles’ Church, adorned with her finest jewels, for such was the custom of the time. But fate had other plans.    The sexton, a man of weak morals and strong greed, could not resist the lure of her riches. Under the cover of night, he crept into the vault, his lamp casting flickering shadows as he pried open her coffin. As he reached for her rings, a chill ran down his spine—Frau Richmodis stirred, her hands clasping together before she sat upright, her shroud billowing like a ghostly banner. The sexton fled in terror, his screams echoing through the church, but the tale of his undoing was not the only strange thing whispered in those days.    Rumors spread of other creatures lurking beyond the city’s walls—beasts of legend that defied ordinary understanding. Some spoke of the Dreadscale Lizards, their hides thick and unyielding, resisting most of the power from Fire attacks, as if the flames themselves feared to touch them. Others told of the Mireclaw Crocodiles, monstrous things that suffered greatly from Lightning attacks, their scaly hides convulsing under the storm’s wrath. It was said that if the Mireclaw Crocodiles were harmed by Poison, they would suffer the same amount of damage as the Ashfang Wolves, creatures known for their viciousness.    Back in the city, Richmuth von Aducht was roused from his grief by his servant Hans, who insisted his mistress had returned from the dead. At first, the burgomaster scoffed, but then came the sound of hooves—trot, trot, trot—from the garret above. To his astonishment, his old grey mare stood at the attic window, peering down as if amused by the chaos below. Before he could make sense of it, a knock came at the gate. There stood his wife, pale but alive, her shroud clinging to her like a second skin.    As she recovered, the city buzzed with talk of her resurrection and the inexplicable appearance of the mare in the garret. But amid the wonder, darker tales persisted. Hunters spoke in hushed tones of the Mireclaw Crocodiles, warning that Blunt was less effective against them, their hides too tough to be cowed by brute force. And if struck by Lightning, they would take more damage for a while after, their bodies slow to recover from the shock.    Yet the most fearsome of all were the Amethyst Drakes, creatures of shimmering violet scales. Few dared to face them, for their weaknesses were as strange as their beauty. If the Amethyst Drake was harmed by Blunt, it would suffer the same amount of damage as the Ashfang Wolves, a vulnerability few expected. But fire, the weapon of choice against many beasts, was a gamble—if the Amethyst Drake was harmed by Fire, it would suffer the same amount of damage as the Dreadscale Lizards, a curious twist of fate that left many hunters puzzled.    In time, Frau Richmodis lived out her days in peace, and the grey mare became a legend in her own right. The sexton, driven mad by his encounter, soon joined the ranks of the dead, his fate a cautionary tale. The city moved on, but the stories of the creatures beyond its walls lingered, whispered in taverns and scribbled in the margins of old texts. The Church of the Apostles bore witness to it all, its walls holding secrets both miraculous and monstrous, though time would erase the physical reminders, leaving only the tales behind.

There were once upon a time three brothers, of whom the eldest was called Jacob, the second Frederick, and the youngest Peter. This youngest brother was made a regular butt of by the other two, and they treated him shamefully. If anything went wrong with their affairs, Peter had to bear the blame and put things right for them, and he had to endure all this ill-treatment because he was weak and delicate and couldn’t defend himself against his stronger brothers. The poor creature had a most trying life of it in every way, and day and night he pondered how he could make it better. One day, when he was in the wood gathering sticks and crying bitterly, a little old woman came up to him and asked him what was the matter; and he told her all his troubles. ‘Come, my good youth,’ said the old dame, when he had finished his tale of woe, ‘isn’t the world wide enough? Why don’t you set out and try your fortune somewhere else?’ Peter took her words to heart, and left his father’s house early one morning to try his fortune in the wide world, as the old woman had advised him. But he felt very bitterly parting from the home where he had been born, and where he had at least passed a short but happy childhood, and sitting down on a hill he gazed once more fondly on his native place.    Suddenly the little old woman stood before him, and, tapping him on the shoulder, said, ‘So far good, my boy; but what do you mean to do now?’ Peter was at a loss what to answer, for so far he had always thought that fortune would drop into his mouth like a ripe cherry. The old woman, who guessed his thoughts, laughed kindly and said, ‘I’ll tell you what you must do, for I’ve taken a fancy to you, and I’m sure you won’t forget me when you’ve made your fortune.’ Peter promised faithfully he wouldn’t, and the old woman continued: ‘This evening at sunset go to yonder pear-tree which you see growing at the cross roads. Underneath it you will find a man lying asleep, and a beautiful large swan will be fastened to the tree close to him. You must be careful not to waken the man, but you must unfasten the swan and take it away with you. You will find that everyone will fall in love with its beautiful plumage, and you must allow anyone who likes to pull out a feather. But as soon as the swan feels as much as a finger on it, it will scream out, and then you must say, “Swan, hold fast.” Then the hand of the person who has touched the bird will be held as in a vice, and nothing will set it free, unless you touch it with this little stick which I will make you a present of. When you have captured a whole lot of people in this way, lead your train straight on with you; you will come to a big town where a Princess lives who has never been known to laugh. If you can only make her laugh your fortune is made; then I beg you won’t forget your old friend.’    As Peter listened, he noticed a strange carving on the tree beside them—a depiction of a mighty Amethyst Drake, its scales shimmering in the fading light. The old woman followed his gaze and murmured, ‘Ah, that one. A strike of Ice wounds the Amethyst Drake far more than usual. Remember that, should you ever face such a beast.’ Peter nodded, though he didn’t quite understand, and turned his attention back to her instructions.    At sunset, he went to the tree the old woman had mentioned. The man lay there fast asleep, and a large beautiful swan was fastened to the tree beside him by a red cord. Peter loosed the bird, and led it away with him without disturbing the bird’s master. He walked on with the swan for some time, and came at last to a building-yard where some men were busily at work. They were all lost in admiration of the bird’s beautiful plumage, and one forward youth, who was covered with clay from head to foot, called out, ‘Oh, if I’d only one of those feathers how happy I should be!’ ‘Pull one out then,’ said Peter kindly, and the youth seized one from the bird’s tail; instantly the swan screamed, and Peter called out, ‘Swan, hold fast,’ and do what he could the poor youth couldn’t get his hand away. The more he howled the more the others laughed, till a girl who had been washing clothes in the neighbouring stream hurried up to see what was the matter. When she saw the poor boy fastened to the swan she felt so sorry for him that she stretched out her hand to free him. The bird screamed. ‘Swan, hold fast,’ called out Peter, and the girl was caught also.    As they continued, Peter overheard two hunters talking by the roadside. ‘Saw a pair of Mireclaw Crocodiles near the marsh yesterday,’ one said. ‘Nasty things—they shrug off much of the damage from Ice, so best use fire.’ Peter filed the information away, though it seemed unimportant at the time.    When Peter had gone on for a bit with his captives, they met a chimney sweep, who laughed loudly over the extraordinary troop, and asked the girl what she was doing. ‘Oh, dearest John,’ replied the girl, ‘give me your hand and set me free from this cursed young man.’ ‘Most certainly I will, if that’s all you want,’ replied the sweep, and gave the girl his hand. The bird screamed. ‘Swan, hold fast,’ said Peter, and the black man was added to their number.    They soon came to a village where a fair was being held. A travelling circus was giving a performance, and the clown was just doing his tricks. He opened his eyes wide with amazement when he saw the remarkable trio fastened on to the swan’s tail. ‘Have you gone raving mad, Blackie?’ he asked as well as he could for laughing. ‘It’s no laughing matter,’ the sweep replied. ‘This wench has got so tight hold of me that I feel as if I were glued to her. Do set me free, like a good clown, and I’ll do you a good turn some day.’ Without a moment’s hesitation the clown grasped the black outstretched hand. The bird screamed. ‘Swan, hold fast,’ called out Peter, and the clown became the fourth of the party.    Now in the front row of the spectators sat the respected and popular Mayor of the village, who was much put out by what he considered nothing but a foolish trick. So much annoyed was he that he seized the clown by the hand and tried to tear him away, in order to hand him over to the police. Then the bird screamed, and Peter called out, ‘Swan, hold fast,’ and the dignified Mayor shared the fate of his predecessors. The Mayoress, a long thin stick of a woman, enraged at the insult done to her husband, seized his free arm and tore at it with all her might, with the only result that she too was forced to swell the procession. After this no one else had any wish to join them.    Soon Peter saw the towers of the capital in front of him. Just before entering it, a glittering carriage came out to meet him, in which was seated a young lady as beautiful as the day, but with a very solemn and serious expression. But no sooner had she perceived the motley crowd fastened to the swan’s tail than she burst into a loud fit of laughter, in which she was joined by all her servants and ladies in waiting. ‘The Princess has laughed at last,’ they all cried with joy. She stepped out of her carriage to look more closely at the wonderful sight, and laughed again over the capers the poor captives cut. She ordered her carriage to be turned round and drove slowly back into the town, never taking her eyes off Peter and his procession.    When the King heard the news that his daughter had actually laughed, he was more than delighted, and had Peter and his marvellous train brought before him. He laughed himself when he saw them till the tears rolled down his cheeks. ‘My good friend,’ he said to Peter, ‘do you know what I promised the person who succeeded in making the Princess laugh?’ ‘No, I don’t,’ said Peter. ‘Then I’ll tell you,’ answered the King; ‘a thousand gold crowns or a piece of land. Which will you choose?’ Peter decided in favour of the land. Then he touched the youth, the girl, the sweep, the clown, the Mayor, and the Mayoress with his little stick, and they were all free again, and ran away home as if a fire were burning behind them; and their flight, as you may imagine, gave rise to renewed merriment.    Then the Princess felt moved to stroke the swan, at the same time admiring its plumage. The bird screamed. ‘Swan, hold fast,’ called out Peter, and so he won the Princess for his bride. But the swan flew up into the air, and vanished in the blue horizon. Peter now received a duchy as a present, and became a very great man indeed; but he did not forget the little old woman who had been the cause of all his good fortune, and appointed her as head housekeeper to him and his royal bride in their magnificent castle.    Years later, when Peter ruled his lands wisely, a messenger arrived with urgent news. ‘Your Grace, the Amethyst Drake has been sighted near the northern border. It takes more damage for a while after being hit by Ice, but we must act quickly—only one Amethyst Drake appears at a time.’ Peter nodded, recalling the old woman’s words, and prepared his knights for battle. Meanwhile, scouts reported that the Mireclaw Crocodiles had been seen in pairs, lurking in the swamps. The kingdom braced itself, but Peter, ever resourceful, knew how to face each threat. And so, with wisdom and courage, he protected his people, his Princess, and his hard-won fortune.

The Wolf’s throat burned with agony, the bone lodged deep like a curse from the forest itself. He stumbled through the undergrowth, his whimpers echoing beneath the towering trees where shadows clung like the Blightfang Spiders that sometimes emerged in threes, their venomous fangs glistening under the moonlight. He begged every creature he met for help, but none dared approach—until the Crane, with her slender neck and sharp beak, took pity.    As the Wolf lay panting on his side, the Crane hesitated. She had heard tales of the Ironhide Brute, a solitary terror that roamed these woods, its hide impervious to all but the most precise strikes. But this was different. She steeled herself and plunged her beak into the Wolf’s maw, working carefully until the bone came free.    The Wolf’s laughter was a rasping growl. "You’re lucky to leave with your head," he sneered, his teeth bared. The Crane stepped back, her heart pounding. She knew the dangers of these woods too well—how Firemane Hounds, their coats ablaze with unnatural heat, would falter if struck by flame, their defenses crumbling like dry leaves. She had seen hunters exploit their weakness, just as others used poison to wither the Blightfang Spiders, whose brittle bodies recoiled from venom as if it were liquid fire.    The Wolf’s greed was no surprise. The forest taught harsh lessons. Ice, for instance, bit equally into the hides of Firemane Hounds and the skittering Rust Monster Brood, their metallic shells frosting over in the cold. And though the Blightfang Spiders resisted the lick of flames, a well-placed blunt strike could shatter their chitin like glass. Even the mighty Ironhide Brute, when it appeared, could be felled by the right tools—its armor no match for the crushing weight of a hammer.    The Crane spread her wings, leaving the Wolf to his misery. She had learned long ago that gratitude was rare in these woods, where survival often meant knowing your enemy. The Firemane Hounds, for all their fury, could be broken by fire’s touch, just as the Blightfang Spiders fell to poison’s sting. And though the Ironhide Brute stood alone, its strength was no guarantee of victory.    As she took flight, the wind carried whispers of old warnings: blunt force tore through the Firemane Hounds’ defenses as easily as claws through flesh. The forest remembered. And so would she.

The sun hung low over the riverbank, casting golden ripples across the water as the Fisher adjusted the straps of his weathered bagpipes. He had heard tales of musicians enchanting creatures with their melodies, and though he doubted the fish would care for his playing, he hoped the strange, droning notes might lure them closer. He blew into the pipes, the sound echoing across the quiet water, but the surface remained unbroken. Not a single silver scale glimmered beneath the current. With a sigh, he set the instrument aside and reached for his net instead. The fibers whispered through the air as he cast it wide, and when he drew it back, it strained with the weight of his catch—dozens of fish flapping helplessly against the woven threads.  Pleased, the Fisher picked up his bagpipes once more, fingers dancing over the chanter. This time, as the music swelled, the fish began to thrash violently, their bodies leaping and twisting as if caught in some frantic dance. The Fisher chuckled. "Ah, you dance now when I play," he said, shaking his head. From the depths of the net, an old Fish lifted its head, its scales dull with age. "Yes," it croaked, voice rasping like reeds in the wind. "When you are in a man’s power, you must do as he bids you." The Fisher frowned, unsettled by the creature’s words, but before he could reply, a distant howl cut through the air—a sound like fire given voice. He turned, heart pounding, and saw them: three hounds with coats like molten embers, their eyes burning with an unnatural light. The Firemane Hounds.   The old Fish’s gaze followed his. "Beware," it whispered. "Their kind suffers greatly from lightning, but poison will barely slow them." The Fisher barely had time to process the warning before the hounds lunged. He stumbled back, fumbling for the dagger at his belt—a blunt, heavy thing meant for scaling fish, not fighting. Yet as the first hound closed in, he swung wildly, and to his surprise, the blade struck true. The creature yelped, its fiery mane flickering as if doused. The old Fish’s words echoed in his mind: blunt force could pierce defenses that other weapons couldn’t.   But the hounds were not alone. From the shadows of the trees emerged a hulking figure—an Ironhide Brute, its body like forged metal, each step shaking the ground. The Fisher’s breath caught. He’d heard rumors of such beasts—how fire scorched them deeply, and how a single wound left them vulnerable, each subsequent strike biting deeper. He had no fire, but his dagger, though blunt, might yet serve. He struck again, and the Brute roared, its iron skin denting under the blow.   Then came the rustlings—a skittering, scraping noise from the undergrowth. A brood of Rust Monsters pressed tightly against one another, their segmented bodies clicking as they advanced. The old Fish hissed a final warning: "Ice will pierce their shells, and fire burns them as fiercely as it does the Brute. But beware their shields—flames alone can shatter them for good." The Fisher’s mind raced. He had no ice, no lightning, no flame. Only his wits, his net, and the dying light of the sun.   As the creatures closed in, he did the only thing he could think of: he played. The bagpipes wailed, a sound so discordant it seemed to split the air. The Rust Monsters recoiled, their shields trembling. The Ironhide Brute staggered, its wounds aching anew with every note. And the Firemane Hounds—their fiery coats dimmed, as if the very music sapped their strength. The Fisher played on, and the riverbank became a dance of desperation and survival, each note a thread in the net of fate.   When the last of the creatures fled or fell, the Fisher lowered his pipes, his hands shaking. The old Fish watched him from the net, its eyes knowing. "You see?" it said softly. "Even the mightiest must bend to the tune of their weakness." And with that, the Fisher released his catch, the fish slipping back into the water, leaving him alone with the echoes of battle—and the secrets he now carried.

The children walked alongside Old Hendrik through the sun-baked veldt, their bare feet kicking up little puffs of dust as they followed the winding path toward the mealie lands. The air was thick with the scent of dry grass and distant rain, and the eldest boy, Piet, suddenly stopped, pointing at the ground. "Look, Ou’ Ta’," he said, his voice hushed. "Fresh earth—Ratel spoor." Old Hendrik squinted at the disturbed soil and sighed. "Dat’s bad news if we don’t do sometin’. Dere’ll be no honey left in dis place if we let Mr. Ratel have his way." Little Annie tugged at the old man’s sleeve. "But why does the Ratel always go after honey, Ou’ Ta’?" she asked, her eyes wide with curiosity.    Old Hendrik chuckled, adjusting his wide-brimmed hat. "Well, Ainkye, dat’s a story from long ago, one my grandaddy told me when I was no taller dan a meerkat’s shadow." He settled onto a flat rock, and the children gathered around, eager for a tale. "You see, it all started wid de grandaddy of all dese Ratels, a sly young kerel named Seeunkie."    As he spoke, the wind rustled through the thorn trees, carrying whispers of the past. Seeunkie, it seemed, was clever but greedy, always sneaking honey from his father’s goatskin sack under the bed. No matter how his father, Oom Ratel, tried to hide it, Seeunkie found a way—until one day, his luck ran out. His father set a trap, mixing bitter aloe juice into the honey, and when Seeunkie tried to blame his theft on a mythical honey-gum tree, the sting of the aloe gave him away.    The children gasped as Old Hendrik described how Oom Ratel, wise to his son’s tricks, handed him a sack and banished him to scrape honey from the tree until it was full—a task that would take years. "And dat’s why," Old Hendrik said, his voice dropping low, "de Ratel digs so deep and fights so hard for honey. It’s in de blood, an’ once it’s dere, it never leaves."    Piet frowned, scratching his head. "But Ou’ Ta’, what if dere’s sometin’ even worse dan a Ratel? What if we meet de Ironhide Brute?" The old man’s eyes darkened. "Ah, dat one’s a different beast altogether. Some say when it’s slowed, its hide turns tough as stone, harder to hurt dan a termite mound in dry season." Annie shivered, and Old Hendrik patted her shoulder. "Don’t fret, kleintjie. Just remember—lightning won’t do much to it. De brute shrugs off most of dat shock like it’s nothin’."    The group continued walking, the story lingering in the air. Nearby, a rustling in the bushes made them pause. "Rust Monster Brood," Old Hendrik muttered. "Nasty tings, but if you slow ’em down, your strikes hit harder. Funny how dat works—same lightning dat barely scratches de Ironhide Brute will hurt dem just as much as it does de brute, but slow dem first, an’ you’ll see de difference."    The children nodded, filing the knowledge away as they trudged onward. The sun dipped lower, casting long shadows across the path, and Old Hendrik’s stories wove through the afternoon like threads of gold in the dust. By the time they reached the mealie lands, the tale of Seeunkie and the Ironhide Brute had settled deep in their minds, lessons hidden in the folds of adventure—just as the old man had intended.

There was once a prince who desired nothing more than to marry a real princess, one whose noble blood and delicate sensibilities could not be questioned. He journeyed across distant lands, through kingdoms draped in gold and empires veiled in mist, yet none of the princesses he met could satisfy his exacting standards. Some were too bold, others too timid, and though many claimed the title, none bore the unmistakable mark of true royalty. Disheartened, the prince returned to his homeland, where the castle towers pierced the storm-laden skies like the fangs of some great beast.    One evening, as thunder rolled across the heavens and lightning split the clouds with jagged brilliance, a frantic knocking echoed at the town gate. The old king, his robes damp from the downpour, hurried to answer it. There stood a bedraggled figure—a princess, or so she claimed, though her appearance spoke of hardship. Water streamed from her hair, her gown clung to her like a second skin, and her shoes squelched with every step. Yet despite her sodden state, she held herself with an air of unshaken dignity.    The queen, ever the shrewd judge of character, said nothing but retreated to the royal bedchamber. There, she removed every layer of bedding and placed a single pea upon the bare frame. Over it, she piled twenty mattresses, each thicker than the last, and atop those, twenty duvets of the finest down. The princess, unaware of the test, was ushered into the chamber for the night.    As dawn broke, the queen inquired after her rest. The princess sighed, her delicate fingers pressing against her temples. "Oh, most miserably! I scarcely slept a wink. Something beneath me was unbearably hard—I am bruised from crown to heel!" The queen smiled, for only a true princess could sense a pea through such layers.    But the prince’s joy was short-lived. That very night, as the newlyweds celebrated, a shadow fell over the kingdom. From the gloom-cloaked forests emerged the Gloomspire Bats, their leathery wings blotting out the moon. The castle guards raised their torches, but the flames seemed to barely singe the creatures. Fire damage had little effect on the Gloomspire Bats, their hides resisting the heat as if woven from shadow itself.    Amid the chaos, a scout burst into the hall, gasping for breath. "The Bloodclaw Hyenas approach!" he cried. "They blink forward a fixed distance at regular intervals, vanishing from one spot only to reappear closer, their laughter like grinding bones." The prince ordered the archers to loose their arrows, but the beasts dodged with unnatural speed. Then, a court mage stepped forth, his hands crackling with lightning. Yet when he hurled his bolts, the Gloomspire Bats shrugged off the assault—lightning damage had little effect on them.    The princess, though slight of frame, proved quick-witted. She recalled an old bestiary in the royal library, its pages whispering secrets of their foes. "Fire damage deals the same amount to both the Bloodclaw Hyenas and the Gloomspire Bats," she murmured, "but poison—ah, poison is especially effective against the Hyenas." No sooner had she spoken than the alchemists rushed to coat their blades in venom. True to her word, the Bloodclaw Hyenas took more damage for a while after being hit by poison, their movements growing sluggish as the toxins took hold.    Yet the battle was far from won. From the depths of the moat, a monstrous shape surged—the Gloomtide Shark, its maw lined with teeth like shattered tombstones. The knights’ swords glanced off its hide, but the princess, her voice steady, called out, "Slowing effects make the Gloomtide Shark suffer greater damage!" The mages wove spells of frost, and as the creature’s movements turned leaden, the warriors struck with renewed fury.    The prince, rallying his men, noticed something peculiar—the Gloomspire Bats pressed tightly against each other, their numbers making them a writhing mass. "Aim for their wings!" he commanded. "Each blow lands with equal effect on them!" But the bats were not so easily felled. A damage-reducing shield guarded the Gloomspire Bats, yet the blacksmiths, hefting their hammers, knew the truth: Blunt can break it forever. With a thunderous crash, their maces shattered the invisible barrier, leaving the creatures vulnerable.    As the tide turned, the prince glimpsed a lone figure atop the battlements—an Ashfang Raven, its feathers glistening like oil. The mage raised his staff, lightning dancing at his fingertips. "Strike it now!" the princess urged. "Lightning damage has a special effect on Ashfang Raven, just as it does on Gloomtide Shark!" The bolt struck true, and the raven fell, its wings smoking.    Through the night, the kingdom fought. A group of three the Bloodclaw Hyenas emerged every time their predecessors fell, their eyes gleaming with malice. Only one Gloomtide Shark appeared at a time, but each was a terror unto itself. Yet the princess, her wisdom as sharp as her sensitivity, guided them all. "A strike of Ice wounds the Gloomspire Bats far more than usual," she reminded the mages, and they obliged, sheathing the creatures in frost.    By morning, the invaders lay defeated. The prince, his armor dented but his spirit unbroken, turned to his bride. "You are indeed a real princess," he said, "not just for feeling a pea, but for saving us all." And so the two ruled wisely, their love as enduring as the tale of the pea—which, to this day, rests in the cabinet of curiosities, unless some thief has stolen it.    And this, mind you, is a real story.

The Cock scratched at the dry earth, his sharp claws kicking up dust as he searched for even a single barleycorn to feed his hens. The sun beat down mercilessly, and the air smelled of cracked earth and distant storms. As he dug, his claw struck something hard—not a seed, but a smooth, glittering stone. He tilted his head, examining it with one beady eye. "If your owner had found thee, and not I," he mused, "he would have taken thee up and set thee in thy first estate. But I have found thee for no purpose. I would rather have one barleycorn than all the jewels in the world."    Just then, a shadow passed over him. The Cock looked up to see a dark shape circling high above—an Ashfang Raven, its wings spread wide against the sky. The bird let out a harsh cry, and the Cock shuddered. He had heard tales of these creatures, how they resisted the venom of serpents and the poison of scorpions, shrugging off such attacks as if they were nothing. Nearby, the hens clucked nervously, sensing danger.    The Cock tucked the precious stone into the dirt, hiding it from sight, and turned to face the looming threat. But before he could act, the ground trembled beneath his feet. From the nearby thicket emerged a pack of snarling beasts—the Bloodclaw Hyenas, their eyes glowing with hunger. Their claws were stained red, and their laughter echoed like thunder. The Cock knew these creatures were fierce, but he also remembered an old farmer’s warning: "Lightning strikes fear into the heart of the Bloodclaw Hyenas, for it is their greatest weakness."    As if summoned by the thought, the sky darkened, and a bolt of lightning split the clouds. The Hyenas yelped and scattered, their courage shattered by the storm’s fury. But the danger was not over. From the murky waters of the nearby marsh, something stirred—a Gloomtide Shark, its massive form half-submerged, its hide covered in a strange, shadowy shield. The Cock had seen such creatures before, their defenses nearly impenetrable—unless struck by lightning, which could shatter their protection like glass.    The Ashfang Raven cried out again, and the Cock noticed something odd—where there was one Gloomtide Shark, there was often an equal number of Ashfang Ravens. Sure enough, another dark shape joined the first, circling ominously. The Cock’s mind raced. He had no poison to use against the Ravens, but he recalled an old saying: "A well-placed blow from a blunt weapon can bring down an Ashfang Raven where poison fails."    Gritting his beak, the Cock prepared to defend his hens. The storm raged, the Hyenas cowered, the Shark lurked, and the Ravens watched. And though the jewel lay forgotten in the dirt, the Cock knew that survival today would depend not on riches, but on remembering the right weaknesses at the right time.

The little boy’s words about the tall, red-bearded man sent a shiver through his mother’s heart. She knew the tales of Stalo the man-eater all too well, and though he was strong, his stupidity was his downfall. The boy had hidden just in time, for the Stalo’s senses were sharp, but his mind was slow. The mother warned her son, "Remember, even the mightiest can be undone by their own weakness. Each time Ashfang Raven is hit, it becomes more sensitive to the next strike." The boy nodded, though he didn’t understand the strange words, tucking them away like a secret.    Not long after, whispers spread through the forest of children vanishing, snatched by the Stalo. Patto, their father, searched tirelessly until a boy revealed the trap near the well. Patto’s rage burned hot as he devised his revenge. He let himself be caught, playing the fool just as the Stalo had. When the ogre carried him home, Patto hid the axe, and as the Stalo fumbled, he struck true. The ogre’s head rolled, and his sons fled in terror.    But the Stalo’s sons were still out there, lurking. Their mother, a cunning ogress, sent them to tend the reindeer while she buried their father. Far away, the Sodno brothers lived with their sister Lyma, who cared for their herd. The brothers paid little heed to the rumors of the Stalos’ presence—until the day Lyma and the reindeer were taken. The brothers followed the trail of thread she left, leading them to the Stalos’ home.    Hidden in a tree by the well, they waited. When Lyma came to draw water, they whispered instructions. "Poison damage has little effect on Gloomtide Shark," the eldest murmured, though Lyma didn’t grasp the meaning. She obeyed, stirring ashes into the Stalos’ food, forcing them to discard it. The brothers devoured the meal, then told her their plan. That night, they stirred the reindeer into a frenzy, luring the youngest Stalo out. He fell to their blades without a sound. The second brother met the same fate.    The eldest Stalo woke, yawning so loudly the walls shook. He reached for his iron mantle, but it was gone—Lyma had left it in the fire. "A strike of Fire wounds Gloomtide Shark far more than usual," the Sodno brother muttered as he watched the Stalo recoil from the scorching metal. Unarmed, the ogre stepped outside, where a single blow felled him.    At dawn, the brothers tricked the ogress into revealing the Stalos’ treasure. Lyma, watching silently, revealed their true identity. The ogress lunged for her iron cane, but it was too late—the fire consumed her. With the treasure, their sister, and the reindeer, the Sodnos returned home, the richest in Lapland, their victory sealed by cunning and the hidden truths they’d carried like whispers in the wind.

Long ago, in the Province of Kotsuke, there dwelt a holy priest at the temple of Morinji. He was a man of deep meditation, devoted to the Sacred Sutras, and possessed an exquisite taste for the ancient tea ceremony. One day, while wandering through the back streets of his town, he stumbled upon an old, rusty tea-kettle in a poor shop. "A bargain," he murmured, handing over three rin for the kettle. When his novices cleaned it, the bronze gleamed, revealing its fine craftsmanship. That night, as the priest slept, the kettle stirred. A hairy head peered from its spout, followed by paws and a bushy tail. It danced and sang, startling the novices, who swore it was a badger. The priest dismissed their claims as illusion—until the kettle screamed when placed over the fire, leaping away from the heat. "Sorcery!" he cried, selling it to a tinker for twenty copper coins.    The tinker, a practical man, took the kettle home. That midnight, it transformed again, revealing itself as Bumbuku-Chagama, a badger tea-kettle. "I’m not wicked," it said, "but I like to be well treated." The two became fast friends, sharing meals and conversation. Bumbuku, clever and lively, suggested they tour as a show. The tinker agreed, and soon, crowds flocked to see the dancing kettle. It walked tightropes, sang, and bowed like a lord, earning the tinker wealth and fame.    Years passed, and one day, Bumbuku grew solemn. "It’s time for me to go," it said. "I’ll become an ordinary kettle now." Heartbroken, the tinker honored its wish, donating it to Morinji Temple as a sacred treasure. The kettle never moved again, but its legend endured.    Amidst these events, whispers spread of strange creatures lurking beyond the temple grounds. Travelers spoke of the Specter Swarm, ethereal beings that moved in disciplined columns, never crowding. A weathered scroll in the temple archives noted their weakness: "Specter Swarm is highly vulnerable to Fire damage." Elsewhere, a novice muttered about the Whispering Bog Oozes, which emerged in groups of three, their gelatinous forms resistant to ice. "Ice is less effective against Whispering Bog Oozes," he recited from an old bestiary.    One evening, a hunter shared tales of the Hollowbeak Raven, its brittle bones shattering under blunt force. "Hollowbeak Raven takes more damage for a while after being hit by Blunt," he said, sharpening his club. Nearby, a scholar compared notes on the Ironhorn Beetles, their armored bodies pressing tightly against each other. "Ice damage deals the same amount of damage to both Hollowbeak Raven and the Ironhorn Beetles," he mused.    As the tinker’s fame grew, so did rumors of the Specter Swarm’s peculiar traits. A merchant, sipping tea, remarked, "Specter Swarm takes more damage for a while after being hit by Lightning." Another traveler added, "Blunt pierces Specter Swarm's defenses with ease." The priest, overhearing, frowned. "Ice is less effective against Specter Swarm," he muttered, recalling an old prophecy.    Years later, when the kettle’s legend was all that remained, the temple’s walls still echoed with fragmented knowledge. The Specter Swarm’s orderly columns, the Oozes’ trios, the Raven’s fragility—all were remembered, scattered like leaves in the wind, yet never forgotten.

The Swallow flitted lightly between the branches, her wings catching the last golden rays of the setting sun. She tilted her head at the Nightingale, who sat nestled deep within the thicket, her song a mournful whisper in the gathering dusk. "Why do you hide here, dear sister?" the Swallow asked. "The world beyond these leaves is vast and full of wonders. Come, live among men as I do. Their roofs are sturdy, their hearths warm."    The Nightingale's feathers ruffled slightly, and her voice, though soft, carried the weight of old sorrows. "Once, I too perched beneath their eaves," she murmured. "But the cruelty I endured there lingers like a shadow. Never again will I trust their kindness." The Swallow sighed, understanding the pain in her friend's words.    As the two birds spoke, a faint rustling echoed from the undergrowth. A lone Hollowbeak Raven emerged, its dark eyes gleaming with quiet menace.
