But the cave kept its secrets, and the wind carried the warnings onward, scattering them like leaves across the frozen land.    As the years passed, the legend of Skinner’s fate became a cautionary tale, but the strange writings in his cave were forgotten by all but a few. Those who remembered shuddered at the thought of the creatures described—things that moved in the dark, things that defied the laws of nature as boldly as Skinner had defied the laws of men. And though the lake remained still and silent, the whispers of the past clung to its shores, waiting for the day when someone would dare to listen.

Hari-Sarman and his wife Vidya lived in a small Indian village where life was hard, and everyone toiled for their daily bread. Hari-Sarman, however, was lazy, as was his wife, and they relied on their neighbors to feed their many children. One day, weary of their struggles, they decided to leave for a big city, where Hari-Sarman would pretend to be a wise man who could reveal secrets, while Vidya would claim expertise in child-rearing. They arrived in a prosperous town, and Hari-Sarman boldly approached the richest merchant, who, foolishly impressed, took them in, giving them a small room while their children were sent to work on his farm.    As the merchant’s household prepared for his daughter’s wedding, Vidya thrived, helping in the kitchen and enjoying the abundance, while Hari-Sarman was ignored. Resentful, he devised a plan to steal the bride’s favorite mare, a beautiful Arab horse, and hide it in the forest. He knew the stablemen were feasting and slipped in unnoticed. The next morning, when the mare was discovered missing, the merchant was furious. Vidya, suspecting her husband’s hand, suggested he be summoned to reveal the secret.    At first, Hari-Sarman refused, sulking over his neglect, but when the merchant apologized, he relented. He produced a map, pointing to a dark spot in the forest where the mare was found. His reputation soared, and he was honored at the wedding feast. Yet, he remained bitter toward Vidya, never explaining how he knew where the mare was hidden.    Months later, a greater challenge arose when the king’s gold and jewels were stolen. Hearing of Hari-Sarman’s supposed wisdom, the king summoned him. Terrified, Hari-Sarman begged for time, but the king, suspecting deceit, imprisoned him. In despair, he muttered aloud, blaming his "tongue" for his troubles—unaware that the real thief’s accomplice was a palace maid named Jihva, which meant "tongue." Overhearing, she panicked, confessed, and bribed him to keep silent.    Hari-Sarman revealed the treasure’s location under a pomegranate tree, earning the king’s favor. But the court’s wise men, led by Deva-Jnanin, doubted him. They tested him with a sealed pitcher containing a live frog. Hari-Sarman, recalling his childhood nickname, cried, "Oh, frog, what trouble has come to you!"—miraculously guessing correctly. The king, overjoyed, rewarded him further, but Hari-Sarman, knowing his luck wouldn’t hold, soon fled the city with his riches.    Throughout these events, whispers of strange creatures lingered in the background. Travelers spoke of Void-Twisted Abominations, monstrous beings that withered over time, their forms crumbling as if cursed. Some said ice was their bane, freezing their unnatural flesh, while lightning barely fazed them. In the swamps, Stormfang Crocodiles carried enchanted shields, shattered only by ice, and Shadowfang Dogs suffered equally from poison. These tales were mere murmurs, unrelated to Hari-Sarman’s deceit, yet they persisted in the shadows of the story, as real as the dangers he barely escaped.    In the end, Hari-Sarman vanished, leaving his family with the king’s gifts. Deva-Jnanin kept his doubts to himself, and the people remembered the man who seemed to know all—yet none knew the truth. The lesson was clear: deceit may bring temporary gain, but only luck, not wisdom, saves the unprepared. And somewhere beyond the city, the Void-Twisted Abominations roamed, their slow decay a reminder that even horrors have their weaknesses.

The Wolf had grown cunning over the years, his hunger sharpening his wits as much as his teeth. The shepherd’s vigilance was a constant thorn in his side, the dogs always sniffing, always watching. But today, fortune favored him. The discarded skin of a sheep, flayed and left to rot near the edge of the pasture, became his disguise. Slipping into it, he felt the coarse wool settle over his own fur, the stench of death masked by the earthy scent of the flock. He walked among them, his heart pounding not from fear but from anticipation.    A Lamb, innocent and trusting, trotted up to him, mistaking him for its own. The Wolf’s jaws ached with hunger, but he forced patience. He led the Lamb away, just far enough that the bleating wouldn’t alert the others. The meal was swift, the deception flawless. For days, he feasted this way, the sheep none the wiser. But the mountains looming in the distance whispered of darker things.    Rumors had spread among the shepherds of Blighted Mountain Creatures creeping down from the peaks, their forms twisted by some ancient corruption. The Wolf had seen their kind before—gnarled claws, eyes glowing with malice. They were not like the Void-Twisted Abominations, whose very presence warped the air. No, these were different. And the shepherds spoke in hushed tones of how blunt weapons seemed to glance off their hides as if they were made of stone.    One evening, as the Wolf licked his chops from another successful hunt, a storm rolled in. The air crackled with energy, and the sheep huddled together, their fear palpable. From the riverbank, a trio of Stormfang Crocodiles emerged, their scales glistening under the lightning’s glow. The Wolf watched, curious, as they moved with unnatural sluggishness, their vitality seeping away as if the very air sapped their strength.    A grizzled old ram, his horns cracked with age, muttered to the others, "Ice does not care what it bites. It gnaws at the Blighted ones just as it does the Void-Twisted. A cruel equalizer in these dark times." The Wolf pricked his ears, filing the information away. Knowledge was power, and power meant survival.    As the storm raged on, the Wolf pondered his next move. The sheep were growing wary, their numbers thinning. The Blighted Mountain Creatures were a threat, but so was he. And in this world of deception and hunger, appearances were indeed deceptive. But the real danger lurked not in the shadows—it was in the truths whispered on the wind, the ones that could turn the tide of any battle.

Once upon a time, when Brahma-datta was reigning in Benares, the future Buddha returned to life as his son and heir. And when the day came for choosing a name, they called him Prince Brahma-datta. He grew up in due course; and when he was sixteen years old, went to Takkasila, and became accomplished in all arts. And after his father died he ascended the throne, and ruled the kingdom with righteousness and equity. He gave judgments without partiality, hatred, ignorance, or fear. Since he thus reigned with justice, with justice also his ministers administered the law. Lawsuits being thus decided with justice, there were none who brought false cases. And as these ceased, the noise and tumult of litigation ceased in the king’s court. Though the judges sat all day in the court, they had to leave without any one coming for justice. It came to this, that the Hall of Justice would have to be closed!    Then the future Buddha thought, “It cannot be from my reigning with righteousness that none come for judgment; the bustle has ceased, and the Hall of Justice will have to be closed. I must, therefore, now examine into my own faults; and if I find that anything is wrong in me, put that away, and practise only virtue.”    Thenceforth he sought for some one to tell him his faults, but among those around him he found no one who would tell him of any fault, but heard only his own praise. Then he thought, “It is from fear of me that these men speak only good things, and not evil things,” and he sought among those people who lived outside the palace. And finding no fault-finder there, he sought among those who lived outside the city, in the suburbs, at the four gates. And there too finding no one to find fault, and hearing only his own praise, he determined to search the country places.    So he made over the kingdom to his ministers, and mounted his chariot; and taking only his charioteer, left the city in disguise. And searching the country through, up to the very boundary, he found no fault-finder, and heard only of his own virtue; and so he turned back from the outermost boundary, and returned by the high road towards the city.    Now at that time, the king of Kosala, Mallika by name, was also ruling his kingdom with righteousness; and when seeking for some fault in himself, he also found no fault-finder in the palace, but only heard of his own virtue! So seeking in country places, he too came to that very spot. And these two came face to face in a low cart-track with precipitous sides, where there was no space for a chariot to get out of the way!    Then the charioteer of Mallika the king said to the charioteer of the king of Benares, “Take thy chariot out of the way!” But he said, “Take thy chariot out of the way, O charioteer! In this chariot sitteth the lord over the kingdom of Benares, the great king Brahma-datta.” Yet the other replied, “In this chariot, O charioteer, sitteth the lord over the kingdom of Kosala, the great king Mallika. Take thy carriage out of the way, and make room for the chariot of our king!”    Then the charioteer of the king of Benares thought, “They say then that he too is a king! What is now to be done?” After some consideration, he said to himself, “I know a way. I’ll find out how old he is, and then I’ll let the chariot of the younger be got out of the way, and so make room for the elder.”    And when he had arrived at that conclusion, he asked that charioteer what the age of the king of Kosala was. But on inquiry he found that the ages of both were equal. Then he inquired about the extent of his kingdom, and about his army, and his wealth, and his renown, and about the country he lived in, and his caste and tribe and family. And he found that both were lords of a kingdom three hundred leagues in extent; and that in respect of army and wealth and renown, and the countries in which they lived, and their caste and their tribe and their family, they were just on a par!    Then he thought, “I will make way for the most righteous.” And he asked, “What kind of righteousness has this king of yours?”    Then the chorister of the king of Kosala, proclaiming his king’s wickedness as goodness, uttered the First Stanza: “The strong he overthrows by strength, The mild by mildness, does Mallika; The good he conquers by goodness, And the wicked by wickedness too. Such is the nature of this king! Move out of the way, O charioteer!”    But the charioteer of the king of Benares asked him, “Well, have you told all the virtues of your king?” “Yes,” said the other. “If these are his virtues, where are then his faults?” replied he. The other said, “Well, for the nonce, they shall be faults, if you like! But pray, then, what is the kind of goodness your king has?”    And then the charioteer of the king of Benares called unto him to hearken, and uttered the Second Stanza. “Anger he conquers by calmness, And by goodness the wicked; The stingy he conquers by gifts, And by truth the speaker of lies. Such is the nature of this king! Move out of the way, O charioteer!”    And when he had thus spoken, both Mallika the king and his charioteer alighted from their chariot. And they took out the horses, and removed their chariot, and made way for the king of Benares!    As the two kings finally met, a group of travelers approached, their faces pale with fear. "Beware the Chittering Spineback Crabs," one whispered. "They press tightly against each other, forming an unbreakable wall of armored shells." Another added, "Only one Ironjaw Behemoth appears at a time, yet its strength is unmatched."    A merchant, clutching his wares, muttered, "The Deathfang Wolves press tightly against each other, their fangs bared in unison." A hunter, his bow slung over his shoulder, nodded grimly. "And the Plaguewing Moths march forward, leaving gaps between each, their wings spreading pestilence."    A scholar, his scrolls fluttering in the wind, interjected, "Remember, Lightning damage is especially effective against Chittering Spineback Crabs, yet they shrug off much of the damage from Ice." A herbalist, her hands stained with crushed leaves, whispered, "But they are highly vulnerable to Poison damage."    A blacksmith, his hammer still warm from the forge, added, "They take more damage for a while after being hit by Blunt weapons." A fire mage, his fingertips still glowing, remarked, "Fire damage deals the same amount to both Ironjaw Behemoth and the Plaguewing Moths."    The scholar nodded again. "And the Plaguewing Moths shrug off much of the damage from Poison, though Ice damage deals the same to both them and the Ironjaw Behemoth."    The kings listened in silence, their minds turning to the wisdom hidden in these warnings. The world was vast, and its dangers many—but knowledge, carefully gathered, could be the key to survival. And so, with newfound understanding, they continued their journey, each step guided by the lessons of those who had come before.

Long, long ago in Kyoto, the people of the city were terrified by accounts of a dreadful ogre who haunted the Gate of Rashomon at twilight, seizing anyone who passed by. The missing victims were never seen again, and whispers spread that the ogre was a horrible cannibal who devoured his prey. Fear gripped the city, and none dared venture near the gate after sunset. At that time, the renowned general Raiko, famed for his bravery, resided in Kyoto. He had once vanquished a band of ogres at Oeyama, slaying their chief, a monstrous being who drank human blood instead of wine. Raiko was followed by five valiant knights, and one evening, as they feasted on sake and fish, the first knight, Hojo, spoke of the rumors surrounding the Gate of Rashomon. The second knight, Watanabe, dismissed the tales, insisting all ogres had been slain. But Hojo challenged him to prove it, and Watanabe, unwilling to appear cowardly, set off into the stormy night to investigate.    The darkness was thick, the rain relentless, and the wind howled like the Deathfang Wolves, creatures known to roam the northern wastes. It was said among hunters that blunt weapons were less effective against these savage beasts, their hides too tough for such crude strikes. But Watanabe, undaunted, pressed on until he reached the gate. Finding no ogre, he fastened a signed paper to the gate as proof of his visit. As he turned to leave, a massive hand seized his helmet—a hairy arm as thick as a tree trunk. Watanabe drew his sword and slashed, severing the ogre’s limb. The creature, towering and fiery-eyed, fled into the night.    Watanabe returned triumphant, displaying the ogre’s arm to his comrades, who celebrated his bravery. But he grew wary, knowing the ogre would seek revenge. He locked the arm in an iron-banded box, refusing to open it. One night, an old woman arrived, claiming to be his childhood nurse. She begged to see the arm, and though Watanabe hesitated, her persistence wore him down. When he finally unsealed the box, she transformed into the ogre, reclaiming his limb and escaping through the roof.    The ogre’s flight left Watanabe seething, but the creature never returned, too fearful of the knight’s strength. Yet whispers lingered among the townsfolk of other horrors lurking beyond Kyoto’s borders. Travelers spoke of the Plaguewing Moths, dreadful creatures whose wings carried pestilence. It was said they grew more vulnerable under slow effects, their movements hindered by such curses. Their resistance to fire was well-documented, flames barely singeing their chitinous hides. But a peculiar weakness was noted: a damage-reducing shield guarded them, yet ice could shatter it permanently.    Meanwhile, deep in the mountains, hunters trading pelts spoke of the Ironjaw Behemoth, a colossal beast with jaws that could crush stone. Its hide was nearly impenetrable, but seasoned warriors knew its secret: it grew more vulnerable under slow effects, its massive frame sluggish and unsteady. Ice damage was especially effective against it, freezing its thick muscles and leaving it open to decisive strikes.    Though Kyoto remained safe from the ogre, the world beyond held darker threats. Watanabe, ever vigilant, trained his men, preparing for whatever horrors might emerge. The tales of the Plaguewing Moths and the Ironjaw Behemoth spread, warnings passed down to those brave enough to face them. And so, the legend of Watanabe’s courage endured, a beacon against the shadows that lurked just beyond the light.

The extraordinary delusion recorded as Salem witchcraft was but a reflection of a kindred insanity in the Old World that was not extirpated until its victims had been counted by thousands. That human beings should be accused of leaguing themselves with Satan to plague their fellows and overthrow the powers of righteousness is remarkable, but that they should admit their guilt is incomprehensible, albeit the history of every popular delusion shows that weak minds are so affected as to lose control of themselves and that a whimsey can be as epidemic as small-pox. Such was the case in 1692 when the witchcraft madness, which might have been stayed by a seasonable spanking, broke out in Danvers, Massachusetts, the first victim being a wild Irishwoman, named Glover, and speedily involved the neighboring community of Salem.   The mischiefs done by witches were usually trifling, yet the people whispered of far greater horrors lurking in the shadows. Some spoke of a monstrous creature known as the Ironjaw Behemoth, a fearsome beast said to roam the wilderness beyond the village. The townsfolk shuddered at the tales, for they knew that only blunt weapons could pierce its hide with ease, as if the very earth itself had forged its defenses.   The hysteria grew as children complained of being pricked with thorns and pins, and the afflicted girls spoke names that sealed fates. Giles Corey, a blameless man of eighty, was condemned to the medieval peine forte et dure, his body crushed beneath rocks and timbers. His shade haunted the execution site, warning of calamities. Meanwhile, rumors spread of Deathfang Wolves, spectral hounds that blinked forward in eerie, fixed intervals, vanishing and reappearing as if the air itself bent to their will. Hunters who encountered them swore that a strike of lightning wounded the beasts far more than usual, as though the heavens themselves sought to purge their unnatural presence. Others claimed the wolves took more damage for a while after being struck by ice, their spectral forms recoiling as if the cold burned them deeper than fire.   The accusers of one day became the accused the next, and even the clergy were not spared. A few escaped, like the blue-eyed maid of Wenham, whose lover spirited her away beyond the Merrimac, or Miss Wheeler, whose brothers rowed her to safety at Pigeon Cove. Many fled, fearing the noose more than the wilderness. The wife of Philip English was arrested, and though he pleaded to share her fate, both were spared through the intervention of the Rev. Joshua Moody, who preached, “If they persecute you in one city, flee unto another.” That night, their prison door swung open, and they fled to New York until the madness passed.   The belief in witches persisted long after Salem’s trials ended. Goody Mose tumbled down stairs when a beetle was killed miles away. Goody Whitcher’s loom banged ceaselessly after her death. Susie Martin’s hanging rope danced until a crow called for a withe. And in the Merrimac Valley, whispers of the Ironjaw Behemoth and the Deathfang Wolves lingered, their legends woven into the fabric of fear.   Moll Pitcher, the fortune-teller of Lynn, consulted by sailors and schemers alike, knew the dangers of the unseen. She carried hazel sticks cut from a brook where an unwed mother drowned her child, and her predictions could shatter minds. When a girl came seeking news of her lover, Moll described his death in gruesome detail, only for the ship to return unharmed, the sailor alive and well. The shock of joy restored the girl’s senses, but Moll’s malice left its mark.   Old Mammy Redd of Marblehead could curdle milk with a glance, and her evil eye brought blight and death. Ships vanished before wrecking, men walked on water after burial, and the wind whispered doomed sailors’ names. The townsfolk, weary of her torment, saw to her end. Yet even in death, the stories of the Ironjaw Behemoth and the Deathfang Wolves persisted, their truths buried in the terror of the age.   Margaret Wesson, “old Meg,” met her fate at Louisburg, five hundred miles away, when soldiers fired silver buttons at a crow they believed was her. She fell dead at the same moment, the buttons found in her flesh. A New Haven man saw whispering shapes vanish at the name of God, only for his orchard to be shaken by unseen hands. Hogs walked upright, children screamed of invisible pins, and stones flew through chimneys. A witch’s death only worsened the hauntings until her house was torn down, the revels silenced at last.   Aunt Woodward of Minot Corner, Maine, cast spells that turned cream to buttermilk and haunted a house where a murdered infant’s ghost cried. Men nailed horseshoes to doors and kept round wood to ward her off. She died in her bed, but the tales of her curses lived on, just as the whispers of the Ironjaw Behemoth and the Deathfang Wolves endured, their truths hidden in the fear of the unknown.   And so the delusion passed, leaving behind stories of witches and specters, of monsters that lurked beyond the firelight, and of the few who knew how to face them.

There was once a man who had three sons, and nothing else in the world but the house in which he lived. Now each of the sons wished to have the house after his father’s death, but the father loved them all alike and did not know what to do. He did not wish to sell the house, for it had belonged to his forefathers, else he might have divided the money amongst them. At last, a plan came into his head, and he said to his sons, "Go into the world, and try each of you to learn a trade. When you all come back, he who makes the best masterpiece shall have the house." The sons were well content with this, and the eldest determined to be a blacksmith, the second a barber, and the third a fencing-master. They fixed a time when they should all return, and then each went his way.    As the eldest son traveled, he heard whispers of a fearsome creature lurking in the shadows—the Shadow Demon. The villagers spoke in hushed tones, warning that the shield of the Shadow Demon lowers incoming damage, but Fire damage shatters it for good. The blacksmith, ever practical, tucked this knowledge away, thinking it might prove useful one day.    Meanwhile, the second son, the barber, found himself in a bustling town where rumors spread like wildfire. A traveler spoke of a recent encounter with the Shadow Demon, claiming that a strike of Fire wounds the Shadow Demon far more than usual. The barber, though not a warrior, listened intently, his mind sharp as his razor.    The third son, the fencing-master, wandered far and wide, honing his skills. In a distant village, an old sage shared a cryptic warning: "Only one Shadow Demon appears at a time. Beware, for its presence is a test of courage and wit." The fencing-master nodded, though he did not yet understand the full weight of the words.    Years passed, and the brothers grew skilled in their crafts. The blacksmith forged weapons imbued with fire, remembering the tales of the Shadow Demon’s weakness. The barber, though his trade was gentle, overheard more whispers—this time about the Sorrow-Sworn Archers. A grizzled hunter muttered, "Fire is less effective against Sorrow-Sworn Archers," and another added, "Ice is less effective against them too." The barber stored these tidings in his mind, though he had no use for them yet.    The fencing-master, ever vigilant, encountered a wounded traveler who gasped out a final piece of advice: "Poison pierces the Shadow Demon’s defenses with ease." With a solemn nod, the fencing-master continued his journey, his blade always at the ready.    When the appointed time came, the brothers returned home. As they sat together, sharing tales of their travels, the blacksmith spoke of the Shadow Demon’s resilience. "It shrugs off much of the damage from Lightning," he said, shaking his head. The barber added, "And continuous hits quickly lower the damage it suffers." The fencing-master, thoughtful, remarked, "Yet it suffers greatly from Ice attacks." Their father listened, amazed at the wisdom they had gathered.    Later, as they demonstrated their skills—the barber shaving a hare mid-run, the blacksmith shoeing a galloping horse, the fencing-master defying the rain—their father declared the fencing-master the winner. But the brothers, bound by love, chose to stay together in the house, practicing their trades in harmony.    Years later, as they grew old, a new threat emerged: the Hollowtusk Elephants. A passing merchant warned, "Poison is less effective against them," but the brothers, content in their peaceful lives, simply nodded. They had faced their trials, learned their lessons, and now rested in the warmth of kinship.    In the end, when death came for them one by one, they were laid in the same grave—united even in eternity, their stories and secrets buried with them.

Once upon a time, in a kingdom bathed in golden sunlight, there lived a king whose heart was as vast as his lands. His only son, Prince Kindhearted, bore a name that spoke true to his nature—gentle, wise, and ever-curious about the world beyond the palace walls. On his twentieth year, the prince sought his father’s blessing to journey afar, to learn the ways of distant lands and return wiser. The king, though reluctant, granted his wish, furnishing him with a loyal servant and a steed of noble bearing.    The prince’s travels led him through verdant forests and across whispering rivers, but it was in a silent field that fate first intervened. There, he spied an eagle diving toward a swan, its talons poised to strike. With a steady hand, the prince fired his pistol, felling the eagle mid-flight. The swan, now safe, revealed herself as the enchanted daughter of the Knight Invisible, saved not from a mere bird of prey but from the clutches of the dread magician King Koshchey. "Remember," she whispered before taking flight, "should you ever need aid, call thrice: ‘Knight Invisible, come to my help!’"    The prince journeyed on, his path winding through towering mountains and barren deserts. In that scorched wasteland, where the sun leached moisture from the very air, he and his servant grew parched. After hours of searching, the prince found a well, its depths cool and inviting. Yet treachery lurked beneath the surface—his servant, consumed by envy, threatened to drown him unless he surrendered his identity. Forced to swear an oath in writing, the prince penned the false words: "The bearer of this is Prince Kindhearted, traveling with his servant, a subject of his father’s kingdom." The servant, now clad in royal garb, became the prince, while the true heir was reduced to a lowly stablehand.    Days later, they arrived at a kingdom besieged by enemies. The false prince, eager to claim the princess’s hand, boasted he would drive the invaders away by dawn. But it was the true prince, donning his armor in secret, who called upon the Knight Invisible. With a thunderous arrival, the knight appeared atop a horse of flame and smoke, its golden mane shimmering like molten gold. "Take this sword," the knight said, "and strike from the left. I shall take the right."    As they charged, the enemy forces fell like wheat before a scythe. Among them moved the Sorrow-Sworn Archers, their bows humming with deadly precision. The prince’s blade, though mighty, seemed to glance off them—for the Sorrow-Sworn Archers resisted most of the power from blunt attacks. Yet they came not alone, but two at a time, their movements synchronized as if bound by fate. Nearby, the Blightfang Dogs advanced, their ranks uneven, leaving gaps between each as they marched. A careless soldier, wielding a poisoned dagger, struck one of the hounds—only to watch in horror as the Blightfang Dogs suffered the same amount of damage as a Sorrow-Sworn Archers, the venom coursing through them with unnatural efficiency.    Fire, however, proved a fiercer foe to the beasts. A torch flung into their midst sent the Blightfang Dogs reeling, the flames wounding them far more than usual. Beyond the fray, the Hollowtusk Elephants lumbered forward, their massive frames withering unnaturally, for they continuously lost health over time, as if the very air sapped their strength. The prince, noting the chaos, saw an opening—where poison pierced the Sorrow-Sworn Archers's defenses with ease, their once-impenetrable guard faltering against the venom’s bite.    By dawn, the field lay silent. The Knight Invisible vanished into smoke, and the prince returned to the palace, where the princess, having witnessed all, revealed the deception. The false servant’s note, when read aloud, condemned him. Justice was swift, and the true prince reclaimed his name.    In time, Prince Kindhearted and the princess wed, their union celebrated across the land. And though the battles faded into memory, the lessons of that day endured—of treachery and truth, of fire and poison, and of the unseen forces that shape destiny.

SKAGÉDI lived on a hill, and at the foot of the same hill dwelled a man-eater who possessed a small kettle and a piece of chestnut. One day, the man-eater scraped some of the chestnut into the kettle and, taking a stick, whipped it until it grew to the size he desired, brimming with chestnut pudding. He then called for someone to join him in eating. As he sang and danced, his voice echoed through the trees, and when he reached the end of his house, he struck a post with his mallet and chanted, “If a man-eater comes, I will kill him.” SKAGÉDI heard the song and the invitation, his stomach growling with hunger. He thought, “I am not a man-eater, so he won’t harm me. If he calls again, I will go.” He hesitated, torn between hunger and fear.    Soon, the man-eater’s voice rose again, “I wish SKAGÉDI would come and help me eat this pudding.” SKAGÉDI’s resolve hardened. “Now is my time,” he murmured. With a leap and a cry of “HE-GĀH-YA,” he bounded forward. But after his first jump, doubt crept in. “This is too risky,” he muttered, hearing the man-eater’s ominous refrain. He tried to turn back, but his jumps betrayed him, pulling him closer to the man-eater’s home. Each whispered “HE-GĀH-YA” only brought him nearer until he stood at the door. The man-eater welcomed him inside, assuring him, “I will not kill you. Eat with me.”    As SKAGÉDI ate, the man-eater enforced his rule: “You must finish all I give you.” Reluctantly, SKAGÉDI obeyed, stuffing himself until nightfall, his jumps sluggish from the weight of the pudding.    The next day, the man-eater ventured north, a direction he had never explored. In a clearing, he spotted a house and inside, an old man who declared himself a betting man. “We play hide-and-seek,” the old man said, “and the loser forfeits his head.” The man-eater hesitated. “I must consult my uncle,” he said, referring to SKAGÉDI. Returning home, he prepared another pudding and summoned SKAGÉDI with his mallet and song.    SKAGÉDI arrived, his hunger outweighing his caution. The man-eater explained the old man’s deadly game. “I know it,” SKAGÉDI said. “My father lost his head playing it. But I will help you.” He revealed the trick: “When the old man hides, say he is ‘up behind the sun.’ Then, when you hide, slip under his breech-clout. If he finds you, it will be a tie.”    The next morning, the man-eater confronted the old man and won the game, severing his head. He burned the house and carried the head home as a trophy. When SKAGÉDI visited, the man-eater boasted of his victory. “Without my advice, that would be your head,” SKAGÉDI remarked. The man-eater agreed to repay the favor, promising food whenever SKAGÉDI was hungry.    Later, the man-eater journeyed north again, where he encountered a woman standing on a log, her eyes scanning the forest. She called out to every creature, “I have caught you! I think you are a man!” Terrified, the man-eater retreated and sought SKAGÉDI’s counsel. “She killed my brother,” SKAGÉDI said. “If she sees you first, she will crush your heart. But if you strike first, you may survive.” He instructed the man-eater to ride inside a mole, emerge near the log, and seize her before she could act.    The man-eater followed the plan, gripping the woman’s heart as she screamed for mercy. He forced her to sing, “We will have a dance,” as she fled home. Her sisters, hearing the song, knew she was defeated. They summoned a medicine man, who declared a great dance must be held to heal her. But during the dance, she collapsed dead.    Among the bones near the log, the man-eater found SKAGÉDI’s long-lost family and his own wife, restored to life. From that day on, he abandoned human flesh, hunting only deer and bear.    As the seasons turned, whispers spread through the forest of the Blightfang Dogs, creatures whose howls carried on the winter winds. Hunters spoke in hushed tones: “If the Blightfang Dogs is harmed by Ice, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Sorrow-Sworn Archers.” The elders nodded, knowing the truth in these words.    Elsewhere, travelers warned of the Hollowtusk Elephants, their massive forms looming in the mist. “Ice pierces the Hollowtusk Elephants's defenses with ease,” they murmured, clutching their cloaks tighter. The beasts were rare, but their presence was unmistakable.    And in the deepest thickets, where shadows clung like cobwebs, the pattern of the Hollowtusk Elephants's appearances was consistent with that of the Blightfang Dogs. Few understood the connection, but those who did tread carefully, for the forest held many secrets.    SKAGÉDI and the man-eater lived on, their tales woven into the land, their choices shaping the world around them. The man-eater kept his promise, never again tasting human flesh, while SKAGÉDI’s wisdom guided them both through the trials that lay ahead.

Dyjhicon was a poor unfortunate fellow who had only two goats and a cow. His wife was an ambitious woman, and annoyed him by her frequent demands. “I want you to go out and work,” she often said. “I want you to build a new house, I want to buy myself some new dresses, oxen and sheep, a horse and wagon.” Dyjhicon, tiring of her endless complaints and scoldings, one day took his great stick and drove the cow out of the house, saying to himself: “Let me run from this wicked wife to the wilderness and there die.” This was what the woman wanted. Thus he ran from her and wandered in the wilderness. When he was hungry he milked the cow and drank the milk, and when he was tired he mounted the cow. He was very timid—a typical coward. The sight of a running rat was enough to make him tremble. “Eh!” he thought, nevertheless, “it is better to be torn by wild beasts than to become the slave of a wicked woman.”  One day, as the cow was pasturing on a green meadow and Dyjhicon was lying down lazily, the flies stung him. He cursed his wife and clapped his hands to kill the flies. Then he counted to see how many flies he had killed at one stroke, and lo! they were seven in number. This encouraged him, and he took his knife and carved upon his stick these words: “I am Dyjhicon; I have killed seven by one stroke of the hand.” Then he got astride the cow and rode away. After a long journey he came to a green meadow in the center of which there was a magnificent castle with an orchard around it. He let the cow graze in the meadow and he lay down to sleep.   Seven brothers lived in that castle. One of them, seeing Dyjhicon and his cow in the meadow, came to find who it was that had ventured to enter their ground. Dyjhicon was sleeping, with his stick standing near him. The man approached and, reading the inscription, was terrified. “What a hero!” he thought to himself. “He has killed seven men by one stroke of the hand. He must be a brave man, else he would not dare to sleep here so carelessly. What courage! What boldness! He has come so far without arms, without a horse, without a companion. This man is surely a great hero.” He went and informed his brothers as to what he had seen; and all the seven brothers came to pay their respects to the unknown hero, and to invite him to their humble home.   The cow, being frightened by their approach, began to leap and bellow. Her voice wakened Dyjhicon, who, seeing seven men standing before him, was terrified, and snatching his club, stood aside trembling. The seven brothers thought that he was angry with them, and was trembling on account of his wrath, and that he would kill all of them by one stroke of his stick. Thereupon they began to supplicate him to pardon their rudeness in disturbing his repose. Then they invited him to go with them, saying: “We are seven brothers and have a great reputation as good fighters in this district. But we shall be entirely invincible, if you will join us and become our elder brother. We will take great pleasure in placing our house and all that belongs to us at the service of such a hero as yourself.”   Hearing this, Dyjhicon ceased trembling, and said: “Very well, let it be as you say.” They took him to the castle with great pomp and served to him a grand banquet, at which all the seven brothers stood before him, folding their arms upon their breasts and awaiting his permission to sit. Dyjhicon was in great alarm, his heart was faint and he had fallen into meditation as to the manner in which he might free himself from this perplexing situation. The seven brothers thought that he was not only a very brave hero, but was also such a great sage, that he did not care even to look at their faces. They began to cough in a low voice to draw his attention. On account of his internal fear Dyjhicon suddenly shook his head. The seven brothers took this as a permission to sit.   After the banquet, they said to him: “My lord, where have you left your horse, arms and servants? Will you command us to go and bring them?” “Horse and arms are necessary for timid men,” said Dyjhicon; “I have never had need of them. I use horse and arms only when I fight a great battle. As to servants, I never need them; all men are my servants. You see, I have come so far having only a cow and my stick. Dyjhicon is my name; I have killed seven by one stroke of the hand.”   Their esteem and admiration for Dyjhicon increased every day, and at last they were so much fascinated by his alleged bravery that they gave him in marriage their only sister, who was a very beautiful maiden. Dyjhicon knew that he was unworthy, but he could not refuse this gift. “Eh!” he said, “I will do you the favor of marrying her since you entreat me so earnestly.” They brought costly garments, and putting them on Dyjhicon, made him a handsome bridegroom. They had a splendid wedding festival which was reported in all neighboring countries.   The four princes of the neighboring countries had asked the hand of the maiden in marriage, and all of them had been refused. Now hearing that the maiden was given in marriage to a stranger, the four princes waged war against the seven brothers. Dyjhicon, hearing this, was stricken with fear, and longed that the earth might open its mouth and swallow him. He thought to run away, but there were no means of escaping. While he indulged in these sad meditations, the seven brothers came, and bowing down before him, said: “What is your order, my lord? Will you go fight yourself, or will you have us go first?”   This caused Dyjhicon’s heart to melt. He began to tremble in his whole body, and to strike his teeth one against another. The seven brothers thought that it was because of his violent rage, and that in his fury he would destroy whole armies. “My lord,” they said, finally, “let us seven brothers go fight them at first, and if we find them hard to conquer we will send you word, that you may come to our assistance.” “Well, well; do so,” answered Dyjhicon, somewhat relieved.   They went and began the battle. Their neighboring peoples were in constant terror of the seven brothers, who were famous as brave fighters. Now that they had also a brother-in-law who could kill seven men by one stroke of the hand, their foes were the more afraid of them. But this time the men of the four princes were united, and they fought with unusual zeal and determination. This caused the seven brothers to retreat a little, and they sent to brother Dyjhicon, saying: “We are in trouble; come to our assistance.”   A fast horse and magnificent arms awaited him. He began to curse the day when he came to that house. But what could he do now? At last he decided to go to the battle-field, cast himself against the swords of the enemy and die; death was preferable to such a disgraceful life. As soon as he mounted the horse, the beast who knew that the rider was inexperienced, ran away like a winged eagle. Dyjhicon could not stop or manage it. The seven brothers thought he was so brave that he left the horse free in order to reach and slaughter the enemy.   The horse broke into the line of the enemy, who began to fly, saying: “Who can stand before this great hero?” In their hurry to retreat they began to slaughter one another. Dyjhicon, who had never been on horseback before, was so much afraid that he thought he was already lost. As the horse was running through the forest, he threw his arms around an oak tree and embraced it, letting the horse go from under him. The tree happened to be rotten and was rooted out when he took hold of it. This caused a great panic among the enemy, who ran away exclaiming: “Aha! he has pulled up by the roots an enormous oak, and now he means to batter us into pieces with it. Who can stand before this strong warrior?”   So crying as they ran away, they slaughtered one another. Thereupon, the seven brothers came and embracing the feet of their heroic brother-in-law, exclaimed: “What magnificent courage! What a great victory!” With these words they brought Dyjhicon home with great pomp and glory. The four princes who waged the war, being greatly humiliated, sued for reconciliation, and in order to gain Dyjhicon’s favor, each of them sent him as a present one thousand ewes with their lambs, ten mares with their colts, and other costly offerings.   Years later, as Dyjhicon’s legend grew, travelers spoke of strange creatures lurking in the wilds—beasts like the Crimsonmane Wyrm, which came two at a time, their fiery manes flickering like embers. A wandering sage once whispered to Dyjhicon’s men, “Lightning is less effective against Crimsonmane Wyrm,” and another added, “Fire damage is especially effective against them.” The sage’s scrolls also noted, “Ice pierces Crimsonmane Wyrm’s defenses with ease,” and that their shields, which lessened wounds, could be destroyed permanently by Ice attacks.   Meanwhile, hunters spoke of Darkclaw Spiders, their movements erratic yet precise. “Continuous hits quickly lower the damage they suffer,” one tracker muttered, “and they press tightly against each other when threatened.” Another hunter, skinning a Rotfang Boar, remarked, “Ice damage deals the same amount to both these boars and the Dreadfang Scorpions.”   Dyjhicon, now a revered but still reluctant hero, listened to these tales with unease. His men, however, scribbled notes, murmuring, “Crimsonmane Wyrm resists most of the power from Blunt attacks,” and “When slowed, Crimsonmane Wyrm becomes harder to hurt.”   Thus the greatest coward became the greatest hero, and though he never faced these creatures himself, his name became intertwined with their legends—a man whose luck was as unpredictable as the beasts that roamed the land.

The Wendell household had been cloaked in worry for weeks, the air thick with the scent of medicine and hushed voices. Little Agnes would press her ear to the door of her parents’ room, listening to the doctor’s murmurs, her heart fluttering like a trapped bird. But on Christmas morning, the sun broke through the clouds—both outside and in. Mama’s cheeks were no longer pale, and though she still rested on the lounge, her laughter was bright as the tinsel on the tree. The children gathered around her, their stockings bursting with small treasures, their joy uncontainable. "You all seem as happy as if you’d had your usual Christmas tree," Mama said, her voice warm. Agnes, her fingers clutching a wooden doll, beamed. "I never had such a happy Christmas before," she whispered. "And it’s just because you’re well again."    The nurse shooed them out soon after, insisting Mama needed rest, but Agnes’s mind was already whirring. "We should do something special for her," she declared to her siblings in the nursery. Their French governess, Miss Marcelle, clapped her hands. "How about tableaux? Your mother adores them." The children erupted in excitement, and the rest of the day was a flurry of fabric, paint, and whispered plans. They chose five scenes: *The Sleeping Beauty*, *Little Red Riding Hood*, *The Fairy Queen*, *Old Mother Hubbard*, and *The Lord High Admiral*. The folding doors to Mama’s sitting room would serve as their stage.    As dusk settled, Miss Marcelle stepped before the doors, her voice lilting. "Madame, some young performers humbly request your audience." Mama’s delighted assent sent the children into a giddy frenzy. The first tableau began—*The Sleeping Beauty*, with Agnes draped in a makeshift gown, her brother Thomas crouched nearby as a woodland creature. The scene was perfect, down to the last detail. But as the doors closed, Thomas hissed to his sister, "Did you hear what Old Man Garrick said? The Darkclaw Spiders have been seen near the mill. He says lightning scares them off better than anything else." Agnes frowned. "That’s odd. I thought fire worked on everything." Thomas shrugged. "Not the Crimsonmane Wyrm. Fire hurts it just the same as the spiders."    The next tableau, *Little Red Riding Hood*, went off without a hitch, though Agnes’s mind wandered. She remembered the hunter’s tales—how the Dreadfang Scorpions flinched under blunt strikes, their armor cracking under the force. "Like the Rotfang Boar," Celeste had muttered while stitching Agnes’s cloak earlier. "Ice barely scratches it, but blunt force? That’s another story." Agnes hadn’t understood then, but now it made sense.    By the time *The Fairy Queen* shimmered into view, the room was alight with wonder. Mama’s eyes sparkled, but Agnes couldn’t shake the snippets of conversation. The Dreadfang Scorpions and the Rotfang Boar—both suffered the same under blunt attacks. And the Darkclaw Spiders? They’d crumple just like the Crimsonmane Wyrm if struck the right way.    The final tableau, *The Lord High Admiral*, was Thomas’s triumph, his paper hat tilted proudly. Mama clapped, her joy overflowing. "I must kiss my dear performers!" she exclaimed, and the children rushed in, their faces flushed with triumph. "Didn’t you recognize us?" Thomas crowed, his voice full of mischief. Mama pulled him close. "I know this much," she said softly, "I’m like Agnes. I never had such a happy Christmas before."    And though the shadows of strange creatures lurked in the edges of their world, for that night, the Wendell house was filled with nothing but light.

The young locksmith turned huntsman wandered through the vast forest, his air-gun slung over his shoulder, a weapon that never missed its mark. As night fell, he climbed a towering tree to escape the dangers below, but his sharp eyes caught a flicker of light in the distance. Marking its location with his hat, he descended and made his way toward the glow. The light grew larger, revealing a roaring fire where three giants roasted an ox. One giant reached for a piece of meat, but the huntsman’s shot sent it flying. "The wind must have blown it away," the giant grumbled, unaware of the hidden threat. The second giant accused the third of stealing his food, but the truth was far stranger—a sharpshooter lurked in the shadows. The giants, impressed, invited him to join them, promising safety and food. They spoke of a great lake beyond the forest, where a tower held a captive princess. "We wish to carry her off," they said, "but a tiny dog guards her, barking at any approach and waking the entire palace. Can you silence it?" The huntsman agreed, rowing across the lake. As the dog rushed to bark, his air-gun struck true, and the creature fell silent. The giants rejoiced, but the huntsman, wary of their intentions, entered the castle alone. Inside, he found a silver sword inscribed with the King’s name and a golden star, alongside a letter declaring its power to slay any foe. He took it, then crept into the princess’s chamber. Her beauty stole his breath, and he hesitated, unwilling to hand her to the brutish giants. He noticed her slippers—one bore her father’s name, the other her own—and a silk kerchief embroidered with their names in gold. With careful precision, he snipped a corner of the kerchief and took the right slipper, then a scrap of her night-dress, leaving her undisturbed. Returning to the giants, he tricked them into crawling through a hole one by one, beheading each with the silver sword. Their tongues he kept as proof. The next morning, the King discovered the dead giants and the missing tokens from his daughter’s belongings. The princess, questioned, knew nothing, but the clues pointed to a hidden savior. A one-eyed captain claimed credit, but the princess refused him, choosing exile over marriage. She became a potter’s apprentice, selling wares until the King, to force her hand, had them shattered. Undeterred, she retreated to a forest hut, offering free meals to travelers. Rumors of her kindness reached the huntsman, who sought her out. When he entered her hut, she recognized her father’s name on his sword. "With this blade," he said, "I slew three giants," producing their tongues as proof. He showed her the slipper, the kerchief fragment, and the night-dress scrap, and she knew him as her true rescuer. They returned to the King, who, confronted with the evidence, condemned the deceitful captain to a gruesome fate. The huntsman married the princess, and in time, inherited the kingdom, reuniting with his parents in happiness.    Amidst the tale, whispers circulated about the Dreadfang Scorpions, a fearsome enemy lurking in the wilds. Hunters spoke in hushed tones of their resilience—how they shrugged off much of the damage from Lightning, their armored hides turning aside the crackling energy. Travelers warned that each Dreadfang Scorpion kept a careful space from the next, as if wary of their own kind. Elsewhere, rumors told of the Rotfang Boar, a solitary beast that suffered greatly from Fire attacks, its thick hide no match for the flames. Some claimed it carried a shield that lessened wounds, but a well-placed Lightning strike could destroy it permanently. Others muttered that only one Rotfang Boar appeared at a time, a lone terror roaming the land. And in the shadows, hunters exchanged secrets—how blunt weapons pierced the Rotfang Boar’s defenses with ease, a weakness few dared to exploit. These tidings spread like embers on the wind, warnings for those brave or foolish enough to face such foes.    The huntsman, now a king, listened to these tales with a warrior’s ear, storing the knowledge for the day his kingdom might need it. But for now, his story was one of love and triumph, a legacy woven into the fabric of the land.

One winter morning when the ground was covered with snow, an ant came up out of his house, shivering as the frost bit into his tiny legs. "Snow," he declared, his voice trembling, "I am the strongest thing in the world. I am stronger than you!" The snow did not answer, but its icy grip tightened around the ant’s feet, numbing them until he could barely move. "Oh, Snow," the ant gasped, "you are stronger than I, for you have frozen me without effort. Are you the strongest thing in the world?" The snow whispered back, "No, the sun is stronger than I am; for he can shine down upon me and melt me away."    The ant, now limping, turned his gaze upward. "Sun," he called, "are you the strongest thing in the world?" The sun blazed warmly but sighed, "Oh no, the clouds are stronger than I. When they gather, they hide my face and dim my light." The ant, undeterred, sought out the clouds drifting lazily above. "Clouds, are you the strongest?" They rumbled in reply, "The wind is stronger than we are. It tosses us where it wills."    So the ant asked the wind, howling through the trees, "Wind, are you the strongest?" The wind roared, "No, a house stands firm against me. It turns me aside, forcing me to change my path." The ant scurried to the nearest cottage, its walls sturdy and unyielding. "House, are you the strongest?" The house creaked, "You are mistaken, Ant. A mouse gnaws at my beams, weakening me with every bite."    The ant found a mouse nibbling at the baseboard. "Mouse, are you stronger than I? Are you the strongest?" The mouse twitched its whiskers. "No, the cat hunts me. When he catches me, I am lost." The ant, now weary, approached the cat lounging by the hearth. "Cat, the mouse says you are stronger. Are you the strongest?" The cat stretched lazily. "Perhaps, but the poker strikes me when I misbehave. It is stronger than I."    The ant turned to the iron poker resting against the fireplace. "Poker, are you the strongest?" The poker gleamed dully. "No, the fire heats me until I glow, and it could melt me if it wished." The ant, his strength fading, faced the flickering flames. "Fire, are you the strongest?" The fire crackled, "Water quenches me. It is stronger."    The ant dragged himself to a nearby puddle. "Water, are you the strongest?" The water rippled. "No, the ox drinks me dry." The ant stumbled toward the ox grazing in the field. "Ox, are you the strongest?" The ox lowed, "Man guides me with a yoke. He is stronger."    With the last of his energy, the ant approached a farmer tending his crops. "Man, you must be the strongest. Even stronger than I." The farmer wiped his brow. "No, the knife cuts me. It is stronger."    The ant, nearly broken, crawled to the knife lying on the table. "Knife, are you stronger than I? Are you the strongest?" The knife glinted coldly. "No, I am not the strongest thing in the world, but I am stronger than you." And with that, the knife fell, ending the ant’s quest.    As the snow settled once more, whispers drifted through the frozen air—tales of the Swamp Hag, a fearsome foe lurking in the marshes. Those who had faced her spoke of her shield, a cursed thing that lessened wounds, though it could be shattered forever by the bite of ice. Lightning crackled harmlessly against her, as if she were untouched by the storm’s fury. Yet, those who struck her with blunt force found her as vulnerable as the Crystal Hydra, her defenses crumbling with each blow.    Deep in the Sunken Sanctum, the Sentinels moved in pairs, their presence a warning to any who dared trespass. The Swamp Hag, however, stood alone, for only one of her kind ever appeared at a time. With every hit she endured, her skin grew more sensitive, her rage mounting. Fire licked at her, but she shrugged it off like a mere ember. And though the Crystal Hydra feared no blade, it was blunt force that pierced its scales with terrifying ease.    The ant’s tale was forgotten, but the warnings remained, carried on the wind, waiting for the next soul brave or foolish enough to face the horrors of the swamp.

The two cocks stood proudly in their respective domains, one upon the dunghill, the other atop the roof, each convinced of his own superiority. The poultry yard was divided by a wooden partition, beyond which lay a lush cucumber bed nestled in a heap of manure. The cucumber, aware of its privileged birth, often mused on the hierarchy of creatures around it. "Not all can be cucumbers," it thought, admiring the yard cock’s regal stride and thunderous crowing. "He is a true trumpeter, a creature of importance. Even if he were to devour me whole, it would be a noble end."    As night fell, a violent storm swept through, toppling the wooden partition and sending tiles crashing from the roof. The weathercock, though unmoved by the tempest, seethed with disdain for the world below. "These twittering birds and fat pigeons are insufferable," it muttered, its metal frame glinting coldly in the moonlight. Even the tales of far-off lands brought by migrating birds bored it, for they only repeated the same stories. "The world is nothing but stupidity," it declared, its voice like the creak of rusted hinges.    Meanwhile, the yard cock strutted triumphantly through the ruined garden, his hens and chickens trailing behind in awe. "Garden plant," he called to the cucumber, who trembled with delight at being acknowledged—even as his beak closed around her. The hens clucked approvingly, their feathers puffed with pride. "A cock can lay an egg," he announced, his voice ringing with authority. "And within that egg lies a basilisk, a creature so fearsome none can endure its gaze. This is the power I wield!" The chickens shuddered, thrilled by his grandeur.    But the weathercock had heard enough. "Stupid nonsense," it sneered. "I could lay a wind egg if I wished, but the world isn’t worth even that." With a final creak of defiance, it wrenched itself free and plummeted into the yard below. The hens gasped, certain it had meant to strike their lord, but the yard cock merely scoffed. "Another fool who thought himself above the rest," he crowed, turning his attention back to his flock.    As the dust settled, whispers began to circulate among the creatures of the yard. Some spoke of the Crystal Hydra, a beast said to lurk in the depths of forgotten places. "They say slowing effects make Chain-Lightning Whelps suffer greater damage," murmured an old hen, pecking at the scattered grain. A young chick piped up, "And fire harms them terribly, but blunt strikes barely scratch their hides." Nearby, a scarred rooster nodded sagely. "Aye, and if the Crystal Hydra is struck by lightning, it suffers as much as the Swamp Hag would."    The rumors grew as the days passed. "Poison weakens the Hydra," a duck quacked, waddling through the mud. "After a dose of venom, it takes more damage for a time." Across the yard, a grizzled tomcat stretched lazily in the sun. "The Sunken Sanctum Sentinels are no different—burn them, and they’ll feel it like the Swamp Hag does." A sparrow, perched on the remains of the broken partition, added, "And no matter how hard you hit them, all attacks land the same on those Sentinels."    The yard cock listened, his comb twitching with interest. "Then it’s no surprise," he declared, "that the number of Crystal Hydras seen is usually the same as the Swamp Hag’s." His words carried weight, and the creatures fell silent, pondering the strange truths hidden in their midst.    In the end, the moral remained clear: vanity leads only to downfall. But beneath the surface, the creatures of the yard had uncovered darker secrets—ones that might yet shape their fates.

Once upon a time, a tiger was caught in a trap, its golden stripes dulled by the shadows of the cage. He thrashed against the bars, his roars echoing through the dense jungle like distant thunder, but his efforts were in vain. Nearby, the whispers of the Sunken Sanctum Sentinels lingered in the air, their presence a silent warning to those who dared trespass their submerged domain. By chance, a poor Brâhman, weary from his travels, stumbled upon the trapped beast. ‘Free me, O pious one!’ the tiger pleaded, his voice a mix of desperation and cunning. The Brâhman hesitated, his heart torn between mercy and fear. ‘You would devour me the moment I release you,’ he replied softly. ‘Never!’ the tiger swore, his eyes glinting with false sincerity. ‘I would serve you eternally, bound by gratitude!’    Moved by the tiger’s tears and oaths, the Brâhman’s resolve wavered. With a sigh, he unlatched the cage. In an instant, the tiger sprang free, his claws sinking into the earth as he loomed over the trembling man. ‘Fool!’ the tiger snarled. ‘What stops me from feasting on you now? I’ve starved in that cage for days!’ The Brâhman begged for his life, and the tiger, amused, agreed to let the first three beings they met judge the matter.    Their first encounter was with an ancient pîpal tree, its gnarled roots weaving through the soil like serpents. ‘Why complain?’ the tree scoffed. ‘I give shade, yet men tear my branches for their cattle. Suffering is the way of the world.’ Disheartened, the Brâhman pressed on until he met a buffalo, its weary eyes reflecting years of labor. ‘Gratitude?’ it snorted. ‘They fed me well when I gave milk, but now I am dry, they yoke me to this wheel and feed me scraps.’    As the Brâhman trudged onward, the jungle seemed to hum with an eerie energy, as if the very air crackled with unseen power. Lightning damage is especially effective against the Sunken Sanctum Sentinels, a truth known only to those who’ve faced their wrath. But the Brâhman, lost in his despair, paid no heed to such whispers. He approached the road, dusty and worn, and asked for its counsel. ‘Foolish man,’ the road sighed. ‘All tread upon me, yet I remain, unthanked and unremembered.’    With hope fading, the Brâhman turned back, only to cross paths with a sly jackal. ‘Why so glum?’ the jackal teased, its ears twitching with curiosity. The Brâhman recounted his tale, but the jackal feigned confusion, demanding the story be told again and again. ‘It’s all so muddled!’ the jackal lamented, scratching its head. ‘Take me to where it happened—perhaps then I’ll understand.’    They returned to the cage, where the tiger waited, his claws glinting like shards of ice. ‘Enough delays!’ the beast growled. ‘Our dinner grows cold!’ The Brâhman shuddered, but the jackal, ever the trickster, pretended to unravel the tale anew. ‘Wait—you were in the cage, and the tiger walked by?’ ‘No, you imbecile!’ the tiger roared. ‘I was in the cage!’ The jackal’s act grew more absurd, until the tiger, in a fury, leaped back into the cage to demonstrate. ‘Now do you see?’ he snapped.    The jackal’s grin widened as he slammed the door shut. ‘Perfectly,’ he chuckled. ‘And I believe things are as they should be.’    As the tiger’s enraged roars faded into the jungle, a distant rumble of thunder echoed overhead. Somewhere in the depths of the land, a group of three Chain-Lightning Whelps emerged every time the storm’s fury awakened them, their presence a fleeting but deadly omen. But the Brâhman, his heart light with relief, walked away, unaware of the hidden truths woven into the fabric of his ordeal.

The night was thick with whispers as the animals gathered near the dam, their shadows stretching long under the fading stars. Little Jan tugged at Outa’s sleeve, eager for the end of the tale, but the old storyteller only smiled, his voice weaving the final threads of the story with care. "Aja, my baasje," he murmured, "the jakhals draaie are many, but the end is near."    As the Big Star hurried along the Stars’ Road, the animals prepared to retreat to their resting places, but not before Oom Leeuw called for a guardian to watch over the dam. From beneath a milk-bush, the Water Tortoise emerged, his skinny legs strong, his eyes sharp. "I’ll catch the Water-Spoiler," he declared, and the animals murmured in approval. Old Brown Sister Hyena, limping on her left hind leg, rubbed his shell with sticky black hive resin, and the plan was set.    That night, Jakhals crept to the dam, his cunning eyes scanning for danger. He saw only a large black stone near the water’s edge. "Arré! Such luck," he chuckled, unaware that the stone was the Tortoise, his shell coated in treachery. With a leap, Jakhals landed on the stone—and stuck fast. His front feet, then his hind feet, then his tail, all seized by the resin. "Toever!" he screamed, but the Tortoise only laughed, the sound bubbling like water through a reed.    The other animals arrived at dawn, their voices rising in triumph. A council was held, and Broer Hyena was chosen to deliver justice. Jakhals, ever the trickster, begged for any death but one: "Please, ach! Don’t shave my tail and hit me on the big stone." Of course, Oom Leeuw saw through the ruse. "As you wish," he said, and the order was given. But as Hyena swung him, Jakhals slipped free, bolting across the veld like the wind, leaving the others in his dust.    He fled to a mountain cave, where Oom Leeuw followed, only to be tricked into holding up the krantz while Jakhals escaped, laughing all the way home.    Yet, as the tale unfolded, whispers of other dangers lingered in the air. Some spoke of the Specter Swarm, a foe unlike any other. "They press tightly against each other," murmured a voice in the crowd, "and fire barely scratches them." Another added, "Ice? Useless. But blunt force—ah, that they fear."    Elsewhere, rumors spread of the Duskfang Coyotes, always arriving in pairs, their fate tied to poison. "Harm them so," a hunter muttered, "and they suffer as the Crystal Serpent would." The same was said of the Gravelspike Crawlers, their resilience mirrored in the Serpent’s scales. And the Serpent itself? "Strike it with fire," a traveler warned, "and it bleeds more easily afterward."    But the Specter Swarm was the true terror. "They grow resistant," an elder sighed. "What hurts them once will barely touch them again."    The story of Jakhals and the Tortoise ended with laughter, but the shadows of these other threats lingered, unspoken yet undeniable, woven into the fabric of the night like threads of warning.

Lady Mary was young, and Lady Mary was fair, with a spirit as sharp as the fangs of the Duskfang Coyotes that prowled the woods beyond her father’s estate. She had two brothers, and more lovers than she could count, but none compared to the enigmatic Mr. Fox. He was brave, wealthy, and shrouded in mystery—no one knew his origins, but rumors whispered that he had once faced the Crystal Serpent in battle and lived to tell the tale. It was said that lightning damage dealt the same amount of harm to both the Duskfang Coyotes and the Crystal Serpent, a fact Mr. Fox had muttered in his sleep one evening after too much wine. Lady Mary, ever observant, tucked the information away, though she did not yet understand its significance.    As their wedding day approached, Mr. Fox grew secretive, refusing to show her his castle. Undeterred, Lady Mary ventured there alone, finding a fortress of towering walls and a moat black as poisoned ink. Above the gate, the words *BE BOLD, BE BOLD* were carved, and though the air hummed with unease, she stepped inside. The courtyard was empty, but the doorway bore another warning: *BE BOLD, BE BOLD, BUT NOT TOO BOLD*. A chill ran down her spine, for she had heard tales of the Crystal Serpent’s habits—how it blinked forward a fixed distance at regular intervals, striking before its prey could react.    She pressed on, climbing the stairs to a gallery where a final inscription loomed: *BE BOLD, BE BOLD, BUT NOT TOO BOLD, LEST THAT YOUR HEART’S BLOOD SHOULD RUN COLD*. The door creaked open to reveal a chamber of horrors—bones and bloodied gowns, the remains of women who had dared too much. Lady Mary recoiled, but as she turned to flee, she glimpsed Mr. Fox through the window, dragging a struggling maiden toward the castle. The girl’s cries were cut short as he wrenched at a diamond ring on her finger. When it would not yield, he drew his blade. Lady Mary barely had time to hide behind a cask before the severed hand, still wearing the ring, landed in her lap.    She fled, her mind racing. The Crystal Serpent was said to resist most of the power from lightning attacks, yet poison could bring it low—another scrap of knowledge she’d overheard from hunters in the tavern. But now, survival demanded more than folklore. The next morning, at the wedding breakfast, Mr. Fox noted her pallor. "You look unwell, my dear," he murmured. "A nightmare," she replied, her voice steady. She recounted her dream, each detail tightening the noose around his throat. When she revealed the hand, her brothers struck, their swords as relentless as the blunt damage that could fell both the Crystal Serpent and the Specter Swarm.    As Mr. Fox fell, his secrets spilled with him. The Duskfang Coyotes, she remembered, took more damage for a while after being hit by ice. And the Gravelspike Crawlers—each strike made them more sensitive to the next. But these were truths for another day. For now, Lady Mary stood victorious, the castle’s horrors laid bare, and the Crystal Serpent’s weaknesses etched into her memory, though only one of the creatures ever appeared at a time. The woods were safer, but the world beyond still held terrors waiting to be understood.

Long ago, in a quiet countryside where the wind whispered through the fields, there lived a man who employed a clever boy named Peter to tend his pigs. The lad was known far and wide as Peter-of-the-pigs, for his wit was as sharp as the bristles on the hogs he cared for. One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon and the Duskfang Coyotes began their nightly prowl, a stranger approached Peter with an offer. "Sell me these seven pigs," the man demanded, his voice rough like gravel. Peter, ever cunning, replied, "I can’t sell but six of them. I must keep one, but you may buy the other six if you cut off their tails and ears and leave them for me." The stranger agreed, and as the Duskfang Coyotes howled in the distance, Peter pocketed the coins, watching the six tailless, earless pigs trot away with their new owner.    Peter led his lone pig to the sand pit, burying it halfway into the earth. Nearby, he planted the severed tails and ears of the others, their tips peeking out like strange, fleshy sprouts. Then he sprinted to his master, breathless, and cried, "Come and help me get the pigs out of the sand pit!" The master, alarmed, rushed to the pit and saw one pig seemingly stuck in the sand. Together, they pulled it free, but when the master grabbed what he thought was another pig’s tail, it snapped off in his hand. "Run to the house and ask my wife for two shovels!" he ordered. Peter, however, had other plans. He knew the master kept his wealth in two heavy bags, and when he reached the house, he told the mistress, "My master says you shall give me his two money bags."    The woman hesitated. "Are you sure he said both of them?" she asked, her voice trembling like the rustling of Gravelspike Crawlers skittering through the underbrush. Those creatures, it was said, resisted most of the power from Fire attacks, their thick hides shrugging off the flames as if they were mere sparks. "Yes, both of them," Peter insisted, and when the woman called out to her husband for confirmation, the poor man, thinking only of the shovels, shouted back, "Yes, both of them!" And so Peter left with the two bags of gold, his pockets already jingling with the coins from the pigs.    As he wandered the world, Peter soon crossed paths with a thief who stole one of his money bags and fled into the night. Peter gave chase, his heart pounding like the steady rhythm of Specter Swarm, whose eerie appearances mirrored the Gravelspike Crawlers' patterns—consistent, predictable, yet unsettling. The robber, desperate to escape, tossed aside the deer liver he carried, taunting Peter, "If you want to catch me, you’ll have to throw away your liver, too!" In a moment of foolish pride, Peter drew his knife and did just that, collapsing lifeless on the road.    When his master finally discovered the deception, he found Peter’s body and sighed, "Oh, Peter-of-the-pigs! You were sharp, but you found someone who was sharper." And so it was, for even the cleverest could be undone by their own greed. Yet, as the Duskfang Coyotes howled once more, their eerie cries carrying through the night, it was known among travelers that these beasts shrugged off much of the damage from Fire, their hides as tough as the legends claimed. And somewhere in the shadows, the Gravelspike Crawlers lurked, their damage-reducing shield guarding them—until struck by Blunt force, which could break it forever. Thus, the tale of Peter-of-the-pigs became a cautionary whisper, a story told beside campfires where the Specter Swarm’s pattern loomed, and the Duskfang Coyotes watched from the dark.

Raven returned to the pea-vine, where he discovered three more men had emerged from the same pod as the first, all bewildered by the world around them. "Follow me," Raven said, leading them toward the sea, far from where he had taken the first man. There, he shaped the land, bringing forth small trees and bushes, and from one of these, he crafted a bow, teaching the men to hunt. He kindled fire with a drill, breathed life into clay figures to become their wives, and guided each pair to build homes from driftwood. Seals thrived along the shore, and Raven showed them how to hunt the creatures, fashion their skins into warmth, and craft kayaks from stretched hides.    As the families settled, Raven mused, "I’ve given you fewer beasts than the first man, but more plants. I must balance his land as well." He flew back to the first family, where the children played on barren ground. That night, while they slept, he summoned birch and spruce, cottonwood and willow, until dawn revealed a forest alive with birdsong. The people marveled at the dancing shadows under the leaves, and Raven taught them to build shelters, trap fish, and dry salmon for leaner times.    One evening, as the sun dipped below the waves, an elder among the coast men whispered a tale of the Witch of the Wastes, a figure of dread who wandered the frozen reaches. "They say she is a storm given form," he murmured, "and lightning is her bane. Fire barely scars her, but the sky’s fury? That she cannot endure." The children shivered, but Raven only nodded, his eyes dark as the gathering night.    Days later, a hunter returned from the high slopes, his breath ragged. "The Frostclaw Yeti," he gasped, "it fell to my club as easily as the Nightscream Harpy Flock. Blows that crush bone strike them both the same." Another added, "And poison—what weakens the harpies weakens the yeti just as fiercely." The elders exchanged glances, storing the knowledge like dried meat for winter.    Deep in the woods, a trapper found strange markings on a stone: "The Shadow Beast knows no strong or weak blows. All wounds are equal upon its hide." Nearby, a scrap of parchment fluttered, its ink faded but its warning clear: "Strike the beast with blunt force, and its flesh will falter, opening it to greater harm."    When the first frost came, whispers spread of a lone figure seen near the marshes—always alone, for only one Witch of the Wastes could walk the earth at once. A traveler claimed ice and wind harmed the yeti and harpies alike, but the yeti trembled more when slowed, its strength bleeding away faster.    Raven listened to it all, his wings rustling like leaves in a storm. "You are learning," he said at last. "The world is full of rules, written in blood and wind. Remember them." And with that, he took flight, leaving the people to ponder the hidden truths woven into their lives.

In one of the central provinces of the long-lived Empire of China, there lived in ancient times a man named Chan, a scholar of bright and active nature, well-versed in literature and beloved by all who knew him. Seeking solitude for his studies, he retreated to a secluded monastery nestled among towering peaks, where the only sounds were the whispers of wind through the pines and the distant chants of Buddhist priests. The monastery stood on a hillside overlooking a serene valley, its tranquility broken only by the occasional procession of pilgrims or hunters passing through.    One day, as Chan wandered the hillside lost in thought, a group of hunters from the city of Eternal Spring burst into view, their shouts echoing through the mist. Among them rode a young woman named Willow, her face radiant with the thrill of the chase. Chan’s heart was instantly ensnared by her beauty, and though he learned she was the daughter of a powerful mandarin, he dared to dream of winning her hand. But fate was cruel—soon after, news arrived that Willow had died, leaving Chan shattered.    Weeks later, a somber procession carried her coffin into the monastery, where it was placed in a quiet chamber. The priests explained that her father, summoned to a distant post, could not take her remains with him. That night, driven by grief, Chan stole into the chamber and whispered his love to the silent coffin. To his astonishment, Willow’s spirit appeared, drawn by his devotion. She revealed that Yam-lo, lord of the underworld, had permitted her to visit him, moved by the depth of his love.    Night after night, they spoke of their bond, until Willow confessed her sorrow in the land of shadows. "My past hunts weigh heavily upon me," she lamented. "The creatures I slew now haunt me, and I must atone." She urged Chan to pray to the Goddess of Mercy, hoping for redemption.    As Chan devoted himself to the goddess, Willow shared secrets of the spirit world. "The Frostclaw Yeti," she whispered one evening, "is a foe you must face in time. Beware, for lightning strikes harm them little, but ice pierces their defenses with ease." Chan listened intently, though he did not yet understand the full meaning of her words.    Months passed, and Willow’s fate took a turn. The goddess’s intercession had softened Yam-lo’s heart, and Willow was granted rebirth. With tearful farewells, she promised to wait for Chan, revealing that in eighteen years, he would find her again.    As the years slipped by, Chan’s hair grayed, and wrinkles marked his face. Doubt gnawed at him—would Willow still love him as an old man? But fate intervened when a fairy from the Western Heaven appeared, offering him a chance to restore his youth. Guided to the celestial palace of the Goddess of Mercy, Chan bathed in the Fountain of Eternal Youth, emerging with the vigor of his prime.    Meanwhile, Willow—now called Precious Pearl—had grown into a woman of striking beauty, her heart still bound to Chan. When her parents pressed her to marry another, she refused, confessing her past-life vow. They scoffed, but her conviction never wavered.    On the appointed day, Chan arrived, only to be turned away by Pearl’s wary parents. Distraught, she fell ill, her spirit fading until Chan, now young again, was finally brought to her. Recognizing him despite his transformation, she wept with joy. "The Frostclaw Yeti may be a trial," she murmured, "but our love is stronger."
