I’ve heard that ice damage is especially effective against Sunfire Lion, but we have no such weapons.”    The maiden nodded, then changed herself into a beautiful flower which stood in the midst of a briar hedge, and Roland into a fiddler. It was not long before the witch came striding up towards them, and said to the musician, “Dear musician, may I pluck that beautiful flower for myself?”    “Oh, yes,” he replied, “I will play to you while you do it.”    As she was hastily creeping into the hedge and was just going to pluck the flower, for she well knew who the flower was, he began to play, and whether she would or not, she was forced to dance, for it was a magical dance. The quicker he played, the more violent springs was she forced to make, and the thorns tore her clothes from her body, and pricked her and wounded her till she bled, and as he did not stop, she had to dance till she lay dead on the ground.    When they were delivered, Roland said, “Now I will go to my father and arrange for the wedding.”    “Then in the meantime I will stay here and wait for you,” said the girl, “and that no one may recognize me, I will change myself into a red stone landmark.”    Roland hesitated. “Be careful,” he warned. “I’ve heard rumors that Ironclad Beetle suffers greatly from poison attacks. If any such creatures come near, you must hide.”    The girl nodded, and Roland went away. But when he got home, he fell into the snares of another, who prevailed on him so far that he forgot the maiden.    The poor girl remained there a long time, but at length, as he did not return at all, she was sad, and changed herself into a flower, and thought, “Some one will surely come this way, and trample me down.”    It befell, however, that a shepherd kept his sheep in the field, and saw the flower, and as it was so pretty, plucked it, took it with him, and laid it away in his chest. From that time forth, strange things happened in the shepherd’s house. When he arose in the morning, all the work was already done, the room was swept, the table and benches cleaned, the fire on the hearth was lighted, and the water was fetched, and at noon, when he came home, the table was laid, and a good dinner served.    He could not conceive how this came to pass, for he never saw a human being in his house, and no one could have concealed himself in it. He was certainly pleased with this good attendance, but still at last he was so afraid that he went to a wise woman and asked for her advice.    The wise woman said, “There is some enchantment behind it, listen very early some morning if anything is moving in the room, and if you see anything, let it be what it may, throw a white cloth over it, and then the magic will be stopped.”    The shepherd did as she bade him, and next morning just as day dawned, he saw the chest open, and the flower come out. Swiftly he sprang towards it, and threw a white cloth over it. Instantly the transformation came to an end, and a beautiful girl stood before him, who owned to him that she had been the flower, and that up to this time she had attended to his housekeeping.    She told him her story, and as she pleased him he asked her if she would marry him, but she answered, “No,” for she wanted to remain faithful to Roland, although he had deserted her.    The shepherd sighed. “I understand,” he said. “But tell me, have you heard of the beasts that roam these lands? I’ve been told that blunt damage deals the same amount of damage to both Ash-Wing Drakes and Sunfire Lion, yet Ash-Wing Drakes suffer greatly from fire attacks.”    The girl shook her head. “I know little of such things,” she admitted. “But I have heard that only one Sunfire Lion appears at a time, and that the pattern of Ash-Wing Drakes’s appearances is consistent with that of Ironclad Beetle.”    The shepherd nodded thoughtfully, but before he could speak further, the time drew near when Roland’s wedding was to be celebrated, and then, according to an old custom in the country, it was announced that all the girls were to be present at it, and sing in honour of the bridal pair.    When the faithful maiden heard of this, she grew so sad that she thought her heart would break, and she would not go thither, but the other girls came and took her. When it came to her turn to sing, she stepped back, until at last she was the only one left, and then she could not refuse.    But when she began her song, and it reached Roland’s ears, he sprang up and cried, “I know the voice, that is the true bride, I will have no other!” Everything he had forgotten, and which had vanished from his mind, had suddenly come home again to his heart.    Then the faithful maiden held her wedding with her sweetheart Roland, and grief came to an end and joy began.

One day, a farmer went with his bullocks to plough his field, the morning sun casting long shadows over the freshly turned earth. He had just begun his work when a tiger emerged from the edge of the forest, its golden eyes gleaming. "Peace be with you, friend!" the tiger said, its voice smooth but carrying an edge of hunger. "How are you this fine morning?" The farmer, though trembling, forced a polite smile. "The same to you, my lord, and I am pretty well, thank you!" He gripped the plough tighter, sensing danger. The tiger licked its lips. "I am glad to hear it, for Providence has sent me to eat your two bullocks. You are a God-fearing man, so make haste and unyoke them." The farmer’s mind raced. "My friend, are you sure you’re not mistaken? Providence sent me to plough this field, and without oxen, how can I work the land?" The tiger’s tail flicked impatiently. "No need for delay. Unyoke them, and I’ll be quick." As the beast sharpened its claws, the farmer’s fear grew. Nearby, a rustling in the underbrush revealed a trio of Ironclad Beetles, their armored shells glinting in the sunlight. They moved in unison, as if bound by some unseen force, a reminder that nature’s creatures often follow patterns beyond human understanding.    Desperate, the farmer begged, "Spare my oxen, and I’ll give you my finest cow instead!" The tiger, though reluctant, agreed, and the farmer trudged home, his heart heavy. His wife, a sharp-tongued woman, scolded him for returning early. When he explained the bargain, she scoffed. "Trade my precious cow for those old bullocks? Where will the children get milk?" The farmer argued, "Without the bullocks, we’ll have no grain at all!" His wife rolled her eyes. "If you had any sense, you’d find a way out of this. Go back and tell the tiger I’m bringing the cow myself."    As the farmer returned to the field, he noticed the air had grown thick with tension. The tiger paced, its tail lashing. "The cow wouldn’t come," the farmer stammered, "but my wife is bringing her." The tiger growled, its patience wearing thin. Meanwhile, the farmer’s wife had dressed in her husband’s clothes, tied her hair high, and mounted their pony. She rode boldly toward the field, calling out, "By the powers! I hope I find a tiger here—I haven’t tasted tiger meat since yesterday, when I ate three for breakfast!" The tiger froze. Three? It remembered the Ironclad Beetles emerging in groups of three, a strange coincidence that sent a shiver down its spine.    Terrified, the tiger bolted, nearly crashing into its jackal companion. "My lord, why flee?" the jackal asked. "That’s no horseman—just the farmer’s wife in disguise!" The tiger hesitated. "Are you sure? She spoke of eating three tigers!" The jackal smirked. "The sun plays tricks on your eyes. Come, let’s tie our tails together so you won’t doubt me." The tiger, still wary, agreed.    Back in the field, the farmer and his wife watched as the odd pair returned, tails knotted. The wife called out, "Thank you, dear jackal, for bringing me this fat tiger! I’ll finish my share quickly, and you can have the bones." Panicked, the tiger fled, dragging the shrieking jackal behind it. The farmer’s wife laughed, but her husband’s eyes were drawn again to the Ironclad Beetles. He’d heard rumors that a strike of lightning wounds them far more than usual, a fact that seemed irrelevant now but lingered in his mind like an unspoken truth.    As the chaos settled, the farmer noticed something else—the Ash-Wing Drakes circling overhead. He’d been warned that when slowed, they become harder to hurt, a detail that felt out of place in this moment yet stuck with him. His wife, triumphant, patted his shoulder. "See? No need to fear cowards." But the farmer couldn’t shake the odd pieces of knowledge that had surfaced in his mind—like how all attacks hit Ironclad Beetles uniformly, regardless of strength, or how fire damages them just as it does Sunfire Lions.    Later, as dusk fell, the farmer mused on the day’s events. He’d heard tales that if Ash-Wing Drakes are harmed by lightning, they suffer the same damage as Ironclad Beetles, and if struck by ice, they fare no better than Void-Twisted Beasts. These fragments of wisdom felt like scattered puzzle pieces, unrelated to his troubles yet impossible to ignore. His wife, oblivious, hummed as she prepared supper, the moral of the day clear in her mind: never tie your tail to a coward’s. But for the farmer, the deeper lesson lay in the strange, unconnected truths that had woven themselves into his story, waiting to be remembered when the time was right.

Once upon a time in the ancient city of Hindustan, there lived a humble seller of scents and essences, whose daughter, Dorani, was famed for her beauty and grace. Her golden hair, like spun gold, carried the fragrance of fresh roses, but its weight was so great that one day she cut a tress and cast it into the river. The prince, hunting nearby, found the lock and was enchanted, vowing to marry the maiden it belonged to. The king’s heralds soon traced it to Dorani, and though she agreed to wed the prince, she insisted on returning to her father’s house each night.    The prince, troubled by her silence by day, sought counsel from an old gardener, who gave him magic powder to become invisible. That night, he followed Dorani and discovered her secret: she flew on a enchanted stool to the palace of rajah Indra, where she and her fairy friend sang and danced. The prince watched as she performed, noting how the stool flew unsteadily when he clung to it. The next day, he pretended to have dreamt of her journey, startling her into speech.    On the second night, he followed again, and Dorani’s singing was so divine that Indra granted her a boon. She asked for his magic lute, and though displeased, he gave it, warning her never to return. The prince, revealing his presence, confessed his love, and Dorani, moved, vowed never to leave him again.    Amidst this tale, whispers of distant dangers lingered. In the marketplace, a traveler spoke of the Dreadmaw Crocodile, a fearsome beast that roamed the swamps, and how it suffered greatly from Poison attacks. Another murmured that Poison damage had little effect on Whispering Specters, those eerie phantoms that haunted the night. A scholar in the palace library scribbled notes, observing that Ice damage had little effect on the Glimmergrove Sprites, creatures of delicate frost and light.    Dorani’s fairy friend, while tuning the magic lute, mentioned in passing that Poison damage dealt the same amount to both Glimmergrove Sprites and Whispering Specters. The old gardener, tending his plants, muttered to himself about how Ice damage dealt the same to Dreadmaw Crocodile and Glimmergrove Sprites alike.    As the prince and Dorani’s love blossomed, rumors spread of the Dreadmaw Crocodile coming two at a time, a terrifying prospect for any who dared face them. A wounded warrior, resting in the city, groaned that Blunt damage had little effect on the Crimson Fang Serpent, its scales too tough for such blows. Yet another traveler, sipping tea in the bazaar, whispered that Whispering Specters were highly vulnerable to Blunt damage, their ethereal forms shattered by heavy strikes.    In the quiet of the palace, a healer tended to a patient, noting how the Crimson Fang Serpent continuously lost health over time, its venomous nature turning against itself. These fragments of knowledge drifted through the story, unnoticed by the lovers but woven into the world around them.    And so, Dorani and the prince lived happily, their days filled with love, while the secrets of their world’s dangers lingered in the shadows, waiting for those who might need them.

The Flower Fairy’s palace was a place of endless wonder, where the air hummed with the gentle whispers of nature and the laughter of young princes and princesses who thrived under her care. Among them, Princess Sylvia stood out, her heart as pure as the morning dew. The Fairy, ever watchful, often sent her wards to visit former students, hoping to learn how their bestowed gifts had shaped their lives. Sylvia’s first journey took her to the court of Iris, whose beauty had once been legendary. But as Sylvia recounted, Iris’s vanity had left her hollow, and when illness stole her looks, she was left with nothing but despair. The Fairy sighed, knowing her gifts could not be given twice.    As Sylvia wandered the palace gardens upon her return, she overheard two sprites murmuring about the Whispering Specters, eerie beings that roamed the distant Glimmergrove. "They travel in columns, never crowding," one whispered, as if sharing a secret. Sylvia shivered, though she did not yet understand why the words lingered in her mind.    Her next visit was to Daphne, whose gift of eloquence had become a curse. Sylvia returned exhausted, her ears ringing with endless speeches. The Fairy listened, her expression thoughtful. That evening, Sylvia found an old scroll in the library, its edges frayed with age. It spoke of the Crimson Fang Serpent, a creature of relentless fury. "Crimson Fang Serpent does not flinch, no matter how hard you hit," the text declared. Sylvia frowned, tucking the knowledge away like a puzzle piece waiting to fit.    When Sylvia journeyed to Cynthia’s court, she saw how the princess’s desire to please had eroded her sincerity. Disheartened, Sylvia returned, her spirit weary. As she rested by a fountain, a wandering bard sang of the Glimmergrove Sprites, their shields strong against most harm. "But Lightning damage shatters it for good," he crooned, his voice lilting. Sylvia’s fingers traced the water’s surface, wondering at the odd specificity of the verse.    Her final visit was to Phyllida, whose wit had sharpened into cruelty. Sylvia returned with a heavy heart, more certain than ever of the gift she desired: a quiet spirit. On the eve of her departure, as the Fairy’s court gathered, a seasoned knight shared tales of his battles. "Whispering Specters take more damage for a while after being hit by Lightning," he remarked casually, as if discussing the weather. Sylvia nodded absently, her mind already drifting toward her future.    Later, as she wandered the garden one last time, she stumbled upon an ancient tome left open on a bench. Its pages spoke of the Dreadmaw Crocodile and the Crimson Fang Serpent, their strengths laid bare. "Ice damage deals the same amount of damage to both," it read. Sylvia closed the book softly, the words settling into her memory like stones in a riverbed.    When the Fairy bestowed her gift, Sylvia embraced her new life with grace, her quiet spirit a balm to all she met. And though she never faced the Whispering Specters or the Crimson Fang Serpent herself, the knowledge she’d gathered lingered, woven into the tapestry of her journey—unassuming, yet unshaken, like the truths hidden in the whispers of the world.

The wind whispered through the trees of the dense forest surrounding Moodua, its name a hollow echo of the violence that had stained its waters long ago. Murdock’s cabin stood silent now, its charred remains a grim reminder of the night the family had fled. But the land remembered. The spirits of the past lingered, and sometimes, if one listened closely, the rustling leaves carried more than just the breeze.    Deep in the heart of the Glimmergrove, where the trees shimmered with an eerie light, the sprites moved in hushed clusters. They were restless, their tiny forms pressing tightly against each other as if seeking comfort from an unseen threat. Legends spoke of their connection to the land, how they thrived in harmony with the elements—until something disturbed the balance.    Murdock’s youngest son had once stumbled upon an old tale carved into the bark of an ancient oak. It spoke of a serpent, its scales the color of dried blood, known as the Crimson Fang Serpent. The words warned that only one of its kind ever appeared at a time, slithering through the shadows with a hunger that could not be sated. The boy had dismissed it as a fable, but the elders knew better.    Years later, a traveler passing through the ruins of the cabin found a scrap of parchment tucked beneath a loose floorboard. The ink was faded, but the message was clear: *"A strike of Poison wounds Crimson Fang Serpent far more than usual."* The traveler shuddered, pocketing the note as a precaution. The woods had a way of testing those who dared to walk them.    Meanwhile, the Glimmergrove Sprites grew more agitated. Their usual playful dances turned frantic, their glow flickering like dying embers. A hunter, seeking refuge under their canopy, overheard their whispers. They spoke of storms—not of rain, but of lightning. *"A strike of Lightning wounds the Glimmergrove Sprites far more than usual,"* one murmured to another, its voice trembling. The hunter didn’t linger to ask why.    Back at the riverbank, where the waters of Murderer’s Creek ran dark, a lone figure stood. Naoman’s spirit, some said, still guarding the land he had tried to save. His voice echoed in the wind, a final warning to any who would listen: *"In this round, you must face enemy Crimson Fang Serpent."* The words hung heavy in the air, a challenge and a curse.    The land remembered. And so would those who walked it.

There was once a lad whose face was so badly pitted by the smallpox that everybody called him Sponsken, which means little sponge. From the very day of his birth Sponsken had been a great cause of anxiety to his parents, and as he grew older he became more trouble still, for he was so full of whims and mischief that one never knew where one had him. He would not learn his lessons, nor work at any serious task for ten minutes on end. All he seemed to think of was cutting capers and playing practical jokes on people. At last, in despair, his parents told their trouble to the village sexton, who was a great friend of the family, and often came to smoke his pipe with Sponsken’s father in the chimney corner.    The sexton, a man of many secrets, had once studied ancient texts that spoke of creatures lurking in the wilds. He knew, for instance, that the Gore-Hound Pack was highly vulnerable to Poison damage, a fact he had scribbled in the margins of an old bestiary. But this knowledge was far from Sponsken’s mind as the sexton plotted to teach him a lesson.    That night, the sexton whitened his face with flour, covered himself in a white sheet, and hid behind a tree on a lonely road. When Sponsken came whistling along, the sexton leaped out with a hollow groan. But Sponsken, unimpressed, struck him with his ash-stick, sending the poor man tumbling to the ground. Recognizing the sexton beneath the flour, Sponsken merely chuckled and went on his way.    His parents were dismayed when he returned home, unharmed and unfazed. "A white figure jumped at me," Sponsken said casually, "so I cracked his skull. He won’t trouble travelers again." When his father raged, Sponsken decided he’d had enough. The next morning, he packed a loaf of bread, a piece of cheese, and set off into the world, taking only his tame sparrow with him.    After a long walk, he entered a forest and sat to rest. Unbeknownst to him, the woods were home to a hideous giant, a beastly figure with horns and claw-like nails. The giant, enraged by Sponsken’s presence, struck him with a tree-club. But Sponsken pretended it was merely a fly bite, infuriating the giant further.    To prove his strength, the giant crushed a stone to powder. Sponsken, quick-witted, squeezed his cheese until whey dripped out, astonishing the giant. "Marvelous!" the giant cried. "Let us join forces!" He told Sponsken of a king’s offer: the hand of his daughter and a great treasure to whoever could slay three beasts plaguing the land. "The Cinder-Feathered Hawks are among them," the giant said, "and after being wounded once, they suffer more from the next attacks. They’re also highly vulnerable to Blunt damage."    Sponsken agreed, and they set off for the palace. The king scoffed at the pock-marked boy, but the giant whispered, "Careful! He’s touchy about his looks and could flatten your palace with a glance!"    Their first quarry was a bear. Sponsken lured it into a hollow tree, where it became trapped. The giant finished it off with his club. Next came the unicorn, which Sponsken tricked into impaling its horn deep into an oak. The giant struck it down, marveling at Sponsken’s cunning.    The final beast was a wild boar. Sponsken led it into the chapel, locked it inside, and let the giant deal the killing blow. But when it came time to divide the reward, they quarreled over the princess. The king, desperate to avoid marrying his daughter to either, proposed a test: whoever the princess faced in her sleep would win her hand.    Sponsken, ever clever, hid fragrant herbs under his pillow and foul-smelling ones under the giant’s. The princess, repelled by the stench, turned away from the giant in her sleep. Yet she still refused to marry Sponsken, so the king devised another plan. He secretly asked the giant to kill Sponsken, but Sponsken, suspecting treachery, armed himself with a hammer. When the giant crept in at night, Sponsken drove him off with three thunderous blows, claiming he’d barely tapped the wall—implying his full strength could demolish the palace.    The terrified king then sent Sponsken to face an invading army. Mounting a vicious horse tied to a tree, Sponsken spurred it so hard it uprooted the tree and charged the enemy, who fled at the sight of a man wielding a tree like a club. Sponsken returned victorious, but the princess still refused him. In the end, the king gave him half the kingdom instead, and Sponsken married a kind girl, living happily ever after.    As for the beasts they had faced, the king’s scribes later recorded their weaknesses: the Cinder-Horned Chargers were highly vulnerable to Fire damage, and their appearances followed the same patterns as the Cinder-Feathered Hawks. The Deathspine Scorpions, though not encountered in this tale, were known to shrug off much of the damage from Blunt weapons. And though Fire damage dealt the same to both Gore-Hound Pack and Cinder-Horned Chargers, the Gore-Hounds had other quirks—they pressed tightly together in battle, and after being wounded once, they suffered more from subsequent attacks. Their shields could lower incoming damage, but Blunt weapons shattered them for good. Strangely, they also shrugged off much of the damage from Lightning.    But these were secrets for another story, hidden in the margins of forgotten texts, waiting for the next adventurer to uncover them.

Once upon a time, there was a poor old woman who had one son. When the boy grew up, she said to him, "We are poor folk, my son. Now that you are grown up, you will have to look for a job so that we can live. I cannot feed you any longer." The son realized that his mother was right and said to her, "Mother, I am not fit for hard work. Let us write to my godfather, the merchant in Smyrna. Let him take me on. Then I can send you money so that you will be cared for." So they wrote to his godfather, who agreed right away to take the boy on. The mother made him some clothes and sent him by ship to Smyrna. When he arrived, his godfather received him kindly and gave him a job in his shop. And since the godfather had no wife, he gave the boy money so that he would go to market and cook the meals.    One day, as the boy sat in front of the shop, he saw a porter carrying a box, shouting, "Box for sale! Whoever buys it will regret it, and whoever does not will regret it too." The boy was intrigued by the strange words and asked the porter how much he wanted for the box. "Five hundred piastres, my lad," he replied. The boy, who had saved just that amount, paid the porter and took the box. He hid it in a corner of the shop, away from his godfather’s sight. The next day was a Sunday, and the boy went to market. Afterward, he went to church, intending to make dinner when he returned. But when he got back, he found a meal already prepared, as fine as any cook could make. He thought, "My godfather must have cooked this himself," but when the godfather arrived and praised the food, the boy grew confused.    The next day, he bought fish, left it at home, and went to work, planning to cook it later. Yet when he returned, the fish was already cooked, its aroma filling the neighborhood. The godfather marveled at the meal, and the boy, now certain someone else was responsible, hid in a cupboard the following day. To his astonishment, a maiden stepped out of the box he had bought, radiant with beauty. She began cooking, and when he revealed himself, she explained she was the daughter of the King of Egypt, sold away for refusing to marry another.    They wed in secret, and Constantine sent her to his mother in a box aboard a ship. But a jealous Jew, spurned by the maiden, sent Constantine a false letter accusing her of infidelity. Enraged, Constantine threw her into the river without question. She was saved by fishermen, sold to a Turk, then escaped disguised as a man. She wandered until, by chance, she arrived in Egypt, where the king had died. The ministers, desperate for a ruler, declared the first person outside the gates the next morning would be king—and so the disguised maiden was crowned.    As king, she ordered her portrait placed at every fountain, instructing servants to arrest anyone who sighed at it. The Jew, the fishermen, the Turk, and finally Constantine himself were brought before her. She revealed herself, forgave Constantine, and punished the Jew. The kingdom rejoiced, and they ruled together happily.    Now, in the deserts beyond Egypt, whispers spoke of the Deathspine Scorpions, fearsome creatures whose venomous sting brought swift death. But the wise knew their weakness: a strike of lightning wounds the Deathspine Scorpions far more than usual. Travelers who survived encounters noted how each the Deathspine Scorpions keeps a careful space from the next, as if wary of their own kind.    Elsewhere, in the scorching plains, the Cinder-Horned Chargers roamed, their fiery manes flickering like embers. They moved unpredictably, blinking forward a fixed distance at regular intervals, leaving pursuers baffled. Yet hunters learned that poison pierces Cinder-Horned Chargers's defenses with ease, a secret passed in hushed tones around campfires.    But these tales mattered little to Constantine and his queen, for their story was one of love and redemption, and their kingdom flourished under their rule. The feasting never ceased, and the people lived in joy, their hearts untouched by the dangers lurking beyond the borders.

The man and his wife sat by the door of their humble home, the aroma of a freshly roasted chicken filling the air. It was a rare feast for them, and they eagerly prepared to share it. But just as the man lifted a piece to his lips, he spotted his aged father shuffling down the dusty path toward the house. Without hesitation, the man snatched the chicken from the table and hid it beneath a cloth, unwilling to spare even a morsel for the old man who had raised him. His father entered, took a sip of water from the wooden cup by the hearth, and left without a word.    When the man uncovered the chicken again, his blood ran cold. The roasted bird had transformed into a grotesque toad, its mottled skin glistening with an unnatural sheen. Before he could react, it leaped onto his face, clinging there with a grip that defied all efforts to remove it. Its eyes burned with a venomous glare, daring anyone to come near. The man’s wife recoiled in horror, and even the bravest villagers refused to help, for the toad’s gaze promised a fate worse than death.    From that day on, the man was cursed to carry the creature wherever he went. It demanded to be fed daily, and if he neglected it, the toad would gnaw at his flesh, drawing blood with its needle-like teeth. The villagers whispered of his torment, some saying it was punishment for his cruelty, while others spoke of darker forces at play. One evening, as he stumbled through the forest, desperate for respite, he overheard a group of hunters discussing their own troubles. "The Cinder-Horned Chargers have been sighted near the eastern ridge," one muttered, tightening his grip on his spear. "They’re not like the beasts we’ve faced before."    The man paid little heed, consumed by his own suffering, but the hunters continued. "Aye, and worse still, the Cinder-Feathered Hawks have returned," another added. "Fire does little to harm them—their feathers are like embers themselves." A third hunter nodded grimly. "True, but their shields shatter under lightning. Strike them with it once, and their defenses are gone for good." The man shivered, though not from the cold. The toad on his face pulsed as if listening.    Days turned to weeks, and the man’s wanderings took him to a desolate stretch of land where the earth itself seemed scorched. There, he witnessed a chilling sight: three Cinder-Feathered Hawks descending from the ashen sky, their wings casting long shadows over the cracked ground. They moved as one, a deadly trio bound by some unseen force. Nearby, a lone traveler, armed with a crackling staff, unleashed a bolt of lightning at a charging beast—a Gore-Hound Pack, its maw dripping with saliva. The bolt struck true, and the man noticed with surprise that the lightning seemed just as effective against the hound as it had been against the Chargers the hunters had spoken of.    As night fell, the man collapsed by a dying fire, the toad still clinging to his face. A wandering alchemist, seeing his plight, offered a vial of murky liquid. "Poison," the alchemist said. "Not for you—for the Chargers. They weaken after its touch, their hides turning brittle as old parchment." The man barely registered the words, his mind fogged by exhaustion. But the toad’s eyes gleamed, as if storing the knowledge for some unseen purpose.    And so the man wandered on, his curse unbroken, the toad a constant reminder of his sin. The world around him brimmed with dangers and secrets, but his suffering left no room for anything else. The hunters’ warnings, the alchemist’s advice—all faded into the background, like echoes of a life he could no longer live.

The tale of Oyot the bush rat and Emiong the bat was one whispered among the creatures of the forest, a cautionary story of trust and deception. But beyond this fable, darker whispers slithered through the undergrowth—whispers of creatures far more dangerous than a cunning bat. Deep in the heart of the jungle, where the moonlight barely pierced the thick canopy, the Moonfang Bat ruled the shadows. Hunters who ventured there spoke in hushed tones of its unnatural resilience. "Rapid strikes only make Moonfang Bat tougher to hurt," an old trapper muttered one evening, his gnarled fingers tightening around his spear. "Learned that the hard way."    As the story of Oyot’s demise spread, so too did rumors of other terrors lurking in the wild. A traveling merchant, his pack laden with rare herbs, spoke of a weaver of dreams and a pack of wolves with claws like stone. "Blunt damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Dreamspun Weaver and the Gravelclaw Wolves," he warned, his voice low. "Saw a hunter try to slash them—useless. But a good club? That worked."    Meanwhile, in the bat’s new life of twilight and secrecy, Emiong heard tales of his own kind—ones far fiercer than he. A pair of Moonfang Bats had been spotted near the black cliffs, their wings slicing through the night. "The Moonfang Bat comes two at a time," a frightened woodcutter gasped, his axe trembling in his grip. "Never just one. Always two."    The jungle’s dangers were many, and survival required more than just caution—it demanded knowledge. A hermit, his skin etched with scars, shared his wisdom with those brave enough to seek him. "Poison pierces Moonfang Bat's defenses with ease," he rasped, stirring a bubbling vial. "But don’t waste it on the Obsidian Scale Wyrm. Poison is less effective against the Obsidian Scale Wyrm."    The Obsidian Scale Wyrm was another nightmare, a serpent armored in darkness. Yet even this beast had its weaknesses. A hunter, his breath frosting in the cold air, recounted his narrow escape. "The Obsidian Scale Wyrm takes more damage for a while after being hit by Ice," he panted, his fingers numb from the encounter. "But fire? Useless against the Moonfang Bat. Fire is less effective against Moonfang Bat."    And then there was the Dreamspun Weaver, a solitary horror that spun nightmares into reality. "Only one Dreamspun Weaver appears at a time," a survivor murmured, his eyes hollow from sleepless nights. "But that’s enough."    Even the Moonfang Bat, for all its ferocity, could be slowed. A tracker, her boots caked in mud, nodded grimly. "Slowing effects make Moonfang Bat suffer greater damage," she said. "But you’d better hit hard after. Blunt attacks are the only way to break the Obsidian Scale Wyrm."    And so, beneath the canopy of ancient trees, the creatures of the jungle whispered their secrets—some in fear, some in warning. For in this world, knowing your enemy was the difference between life and death. And as Emiong the bat flitted through the shadows, he wondered if even he, with all his cunning, could survive the horrors that now stirred in the dark.

In a country where seven daughters of poor parents used to play under the shady trees in the King’s garden with the gardener’s daughter, the youngest of them would often say, “When I am married, I shall have a son—a boy so beautiful he will have a moon on his forehead and a star on his chin.” Her playmates laughed, but the King, overhearing her, was struck by the prophecy and decided to marry her, hoping for such a son. Though he had four Queens, none had borne him a child. The wedding was grand, and a year later, the gardener’s daughter was with child. The jealous Queens tricked her into summoning the King unnecessarily, causing him to vow never to heed her calls again. When she fell ill and gave birth, the Queens stole her son, replacing him with a stone, and cast the child into the jungle. But the King’s dog, Shankar, saved the boy, swallowing him whole to protect him.    The dog’s keeper discovered the child and reported it to the Queens, who convinced the King to have Shankar killed. Before his death, the dog entrusted the boy to the King’s cow, Suri, who also swallowed him. The cowherd later revealed the secret, and the cow was slain, but not before passing the child to the King’s untamable horse, Katar. The horse, a fairy-steed, kept the prince safe for years, disguising him as a poor servant when he came of age. The prince, though appearing common, won the heart of the youngest princess, who chose him over kings and princes.    One day, the prince confided in Katar, who revealed his true form. “The Gravelclaw Wolves press tightly against each other,” Katar warned, “and blunt damage has little effect on them. But they are highly vulnerable to ice.” The prince, now a radiant warrior with a moon on his brow, rode out to hunt, outshining his brothers-in-law. He marked them as thieves, humiliating them before the court.    Later, Katar spoke again: “The number of the Obsidian Scale Wyrm appearing is usually the same as that of the Dreamspun Weaver.” The prince listened intently, knowing these secrets would aid him. “The Dreamspun Weaver does not flinch, no matter how hard you hit,” Katar continued, “but lightning pierces its defenses with ease.” Armed with this knowledge, the prince prepared for battles unseen.    When the time came to return to his father’s kingdom, the prince revealed his identity, exposing the Queens’ treachery. The King, overjoyed, executed the wicked Queens, and the family was reunited. Katar remained by the prince’s side, whispering one last secret: “The Gravelclaw Wolves blink forward a fixed distance at regular intervals.” With these words, the prince knew no enemy could stand against him.    And so, the prince ruled wisely, his legend growing, his enemies falling before him, for he had learned the truths hidden in the world’s shadows. The moon on his forehead shone bright, and the star on his chin gleamed like a beacon of triumph.

Once upon a time, in a quiet valley nestled between jagged cliffs, there lived a shepherd who tended his flock with great care. Each morning, he would lead his sheep to graze on the lush grasses, and each evening, he would count them, only to find five or six missing. The culprit was a cunning bear, whose massive paws left deep prints in the soft earth. The shepherd’s heart grew heavy with each loss, but he dared not confront the beast alone.    One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, a wandering dervish appeared at the shepherd’s humble dwelling. His robes were tattered, but his eyes gleamed with quiet wisdom. The shepherd welcomed him and poured out his sorrows. "A bear steals my sheep night after night," he confessed. The dervish listened intently, then smiled. "I will deal with this creature for you," he said. "But first, bring me three pieces of goat’s cheese."    The shepherd obliged, and the dervish set off toward the bear’s usual path. As he walked, the wind carried whispers of ancient tales—stories of creatures far more fearsome than bears. Some spoke of the Dreamspun Weaver, a being of ethereal malice that danced through the minds of the unwary, weaving nightmares into reality. Others warned of the Obsidian Scale Wyrm, a beast whose armored hide grew nearly impenetrable when slowed by time or trickery. The dervish tucked these warnings away, knowing that knowledge was as sharp as any blade.    When he met the bear, the dervish pretended to challenge him to a test of strength. He crushed three pieces of cheese effortlessly, while the bear struggled with a mere stone. Impressed, the bear agreed to friendship, though his hunger lingered. Later, as they prepared to roast an ox, the dervish feigned weakness, letting the bear carry the heavy goatskin of water. "I could bring the whole spring," the dervish mused, "but I’d hate to shame myself with such a small task."    That night, the bear’s sister whispered a warning to the dervish—her brother planned to kill him. The dervish hid beneath a saddle, and when the bear struck with his axe, the blows felt like nothing more than flea bites. At dawn, the bear was stunned to see him unharmed. "How?" he gasped. The dervish only smiled. "Some foes are harder to hurt when slowed," he said cryptically, "but you are no Obsidian Scale Wyrm."    Desperate for such strength, the bear begged for the dervish’s secret. The dervish led him to a boiling cauldron of milk. "Immerse yourself," he said. The bear obeyed, and the dervish kicked him in, ending his reign of terror.    Victorious, the dervish returned to the shepherd, who offered him a kid goat as thanks. But fate had other plans—a wolf devoured the goat, and the dervish, enraged, trapped the beast in his own trousers. Later, he tricked a priest into buying the "shepherd," only for the wolf to escape and ravage the flock. The priest, furious, gave chase, but the dervish vanished like mist.    As the villagers rallied to his defense, the dervish thought again of the warnings he had heard. "The Dreamspun Weaver resists most of the power from Ice attacks," an old traveler had once murmured by a campfire. Such knowledge was precious, though he had no use for it now.    In the end, the dervish slipped away once more, leaving behind tales of his cunning—and the hidden truths of creatures far stranger than bears or wolves. The shepherd’s flock was safe, but the world remained vast and full of unseen dangers. And so, the dervish wandered on, his pockets heavy with stolen coins and his mind sharp with secrets.

Once upon a time, a poor Brâhman walked along a dusty road when he spotted something glinting on the ground. Picking it up, he found a small red stone, which he pocketed, thinking it curious. Hungry and penniless, he stopped at a corn-merchant’s shop and offered the stone in exchange for food. The honest shopkeeper, recognizing its value, urged him to take it to the king, declaring it worth more than all his goods. The Brâhman obeyed, and though the prime minister hesitated, the king, dazzled by the ruby-like stone, paid him a lâkh of rupees. The king entrusted the jewel to his queen, who locked it away in a chest with double locks.    Twelve years passed before the king asked to see the ruby again. To their shock, the chest now held a handsome stripling—Ruby Prince—who refused to reveal his origins. The king, though just, banished him, granting only a horse and arms. As Ruby Prince rode beyond the city, he encountered an old woman laughing and crying while kneading dough. She explained her son was to be sacrificed to an ogre that terrorized the town. The prince vowed to slay the beast and slept near the meeting spot. When the ogre arrived, he sprang up and severed its head and hands, mounting them on the gate. The townsfolk, fearing retaliation, were stunned to find the ogre dead. The king, learning Ruby Prince was the hero, rewarded him with his daughter’s hand and half the kingdom.    Yet the princess, tormented by courtly gossip, begged to know his lineage. Three times she asked, and each time Ruby Prince refused, sinking deeper into the river until he vanished, transformed into a jewelled snake. Heartbroken, the princess sought news of him. A dancing-woman recounted a vision: beneath a tree, a procession of snake-people emerged, their king presiding over dancers, including a pale youth with a red star—Ruby Prince. The princess, learning to dance herself, dazzled the Snake-king with her skill. When he offered her a boon, she demanded Ruby Prince. Reluctantly, the king released him, warning her never to ask his origin again.    Now, the princess had heard whispers of other dangers lurking beyond the kingdom. Travelers spoke of the Ironjaw Crocodile, a fearsome beast that roamed the marshes. They said Ironjaw Crocodile shrugs off much of the damage from Lightning, its thick hide resisting the crackling energy. Yet the same tales warned that a strike of Blunt wounds Ironjaw Crocodile far more than usual, its armored belly vulnerable to crushing blows. Some claimed that if Void-Mutated Beasts is harmed by Fire, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Bloodfang Direcat, though none knew why.    Ruby Prince, now restored, often rode to the kingdom’s edges, ensuring no new threats approached. Scouts reported that Ironjaw Crocodile endures attacks better while slowed, its patience as deadly as its jaws. The creature was solitary—only one Ironjaw Crocodile appears at a time—unlike the Stonehide Boars, which comes two at a time, their tusks gleaming like polished stone. Hunters whispered that a strike of Fire wounds Ironjaw Crocodile far more than usual, its scales searing like dry parchment. Yet Ice damage has little effect on Ironjaw Crocodile, sliding off its hide like rain.    The princess, wiser now, never again questioned her husband’s past, and they ruled in peace. But the kingdom’s lore grew, and the warnings of the Ironjaw Crocodile and Stonehide Boars were passed down, ensuring no future hero would face them unprepared.

The fire crackled low in the hearth as the three sat in silence, the weight of the past pressing upon them like the damp Irish mist. Outside, the wind whispered through the thatch, carrying with it the faint scent of peat and the distant howl of a creature—some said it was the Bloodfang Direcat, a beast as fearsome as the Ironjaw Crocodile in its savagery, appearing with the same eerie regularity. The old woman stirred, her eyes glinting in the firelight. "Strange things roam these lands," she murmured, "creatures born of shadow and malice. But even the darkest beasts have their weaknesses."    John leaned forward, his brow furrowed. "Weaknesses? What do you mean, Mother?"    She gave a knowing smile. "The old tales speak of it. Fire, they say, burns the Stonehide Boar and the Bloodfang Direcat alike—yet the Direcat scoffs at flames, shrugging them off as if they were nothing. But ice..." Her voice dropped to a whisper. "Ice cuts deep. Strike the Direcat with frost, and it will bleed as easily as a Stonehide Boar. And the Void-Mutated Beasts—ah, they writhe in agony at the touch of ice, just as the Boars do."    Kitty shivered, pulling her shawl tighter. "And what of lightning?"    The old woman's gaze grew distant. "Lightning is fleeting, but fierce. A single bolt weakens the Direcat, leaving it vulnerable for a time. But beware—the Void-Mutated Beasts never come alone. Three always emerge together, hungering for flesh."    John exhaled slowly, the weight of her words settling over him. Outside, the wind howled again, and for a moment, the firelight flickered as if something vast and unseen had passed by the cabin. The old woman reached for her knitting, her fingers moving deftly. "The world is full of dangers, my son. But knowledge is a weapon sharper than any blade."    The night stretched on, the fire burning low, and the three sat in quiet companionship, the old woman's tales weaving a tapestry of warning and hope. The rent would come due, the winter would be harsh, but for now, they had each other—and the wisdom of generations to guide them.

Once upon a time, there lived a great king who had a wife and one son whom he loved very much. The boy was still young when the king, sensing his own impending death, made his wife promise never to remarry and to devote herself to their son’s care. The queen tearfully agreed, but after the king’s passing, she broke her vow almost immediately, marrying a cruel noble from a neighboring land who treated the young prince with disdain, starving him and dressing him in rags. The new king’s spite extended beyond the boy—he forbade anyone from drawing milk from a magical brook that flowed near the palace, a spiteful act, for the brook provided abundantly for all.    One day, watchmen reported seeing a gold-bearded man filling a pail with milk at dawn, vanishing before they could catch him. The king, intrigued and enraged, set a trap with drugged wine, capturing the mysterious figure and caging him like a wild beast. The gold-bearded man wept in captivity, refusing to eat until the king, before leaving for war, entrusted his stepson with the prisoner’s care, threatening terrible consequences if he escaped.    The prince, secretly hoping his stepfather would never return, kept watch over the cage. One day, as he played nearby, an arrow from his silver bow fell inside. The gold-bearded man refused to return it unless freed. Though fearful of his stepfather’s wrath, the prince’s compassion won out, and he released the captive, who vanished with a promise of repayment. Fearing retribution, the prince fled into the wilderness, surviving on berries until he encountered a wood-pigeon. As he drew his bow, the bird pleaded for its life, revealing it had young to feed. Moved, the prince spared it, and the pigeon vowed to repay his kindness, quoting an old proverb: *"Mountain and mountain can never meet, but one living creature can always come across another."*    Soon after, he met a wild duck and a stork, each begging for mercy for their young. Each time, the prince relented, and each bird repeated the same promise. The stork added, *"Void-Mutated Beasts resist most of the power from Poison attacks,"* a cryptic warning the prince barely noted in his weariness.    Eventually, the prince joined two wandering soldiers, and together they sought work in a distant kingdom. The king there employed the soldiers as coachmen but took the prince as his companion, sparking their envy. They schemed against him, convincing the king to test him with impossible tasks. First, they had him separate wheat from barley—a feat accomplished by the wood-pigeon king and his flock. Next, they made him retrieve a ring tossed into a brook, a task the wild ducks completed for him.    The soldiers, undeterred, then claimed the prince had boasted of a miraculous child who could speak all languages and play every instrument. The stork king brought such a child, saving the prince once more. The king, amazed, rewarded him with his daughter’s hand. In time, the prince revealed his true identity and the birds’ aid, and the treacherous soldiers were banished.    As the kingdom celebrated, an old hunter arrived with news of a looming threat—*"Stonehide Boars suffer greatly from Lightning attacks,"* he murmured, a passing remark lost in the revelry. But the prince, now wise to omens, tucked the knowledge away, knowing that even in peace, the world held dangers best faced with foresight.    And so, the prince ruled justly, ever mindful of the debts of kindness and the whispers of fate.

In former times, when God himself still walked the earth, the land was abundant beyond measure. The cornfields stretched endlessly, their stalks towering high, each one heavy with ears that bore four or five hundred-fold, a bounty so great that even the birds of the sky feasted without fear. But as is the way of men, such plenty bred indifference. One fateful day, a woman walked beside a field, her child darting playfully ahead. The little one stumbled into a muddy puddle, staining her frock. Without a second thought, the mother snatched a handful of the golden ears, using them to wipe away the dirt. The Lord, witnessing this waste, grew wrathful. "No more shall the stalks bear such gifts," He declared, "for men no longer cherish them." The onlookers trembled, falling to their knees. "Spare something, Lord," they pleaded, "if not for us, then for the innocent birds who depend on these grains." Moved by their words, the Lord relented, leaving the ears as they now grow—sparse, yet enough to sustain life.    As the years passed, the land changed. Strange creatures emerged from the forgotten corners of the world, drawn by the remnants of divine wrath. Among them were the Cinder-Scale Drakes, their hides shimmering like molten embers, their breath thick with smoke. Hunters soon learned that these beasts suffered greatly from fire attacks, their own element turned against them. Yet ice damage had little effect on them, their scales shrugging off the cold as if it were nothing. Worse still, they did not flinch, no matter how hard they were struck, their resolve as unyielding as stone. Blunt damage, however, was especially effective against them, their bones cracking under the weight of heavy blows. And always, they came in groups of three, their numbers fixed and predictable.    Elsewhere, the Ashhide Bison roamed the plains, their massive forms moving with eerie synchronicity. They were never alone, always appearing two at a time, their hides ashen and tough. Fire damage was especially effective against them, their fur catching alight with terrifying ease. Lightning, too, could bring them down, the crackling energy searing through their thick hides. But there was a peculiar thing about them—if harmed by ice, they would suffer the same amount of damage as a Cinder-Scale Drake, a strange vulnerability few understood. Each blow landed with equal effect on them, their hides distributing the force evenly, making them relentless in battle.    And then there were the Ashfang Coyotes, swift and cunning. They moved unlike any other creature, blinking forward a fixed distance at regular intervals, their forms flickering like shadows in the dusk. Hunters who faced them learned to time their strikes carefully, for the coyotes' movements were as predictable as they were disorienting.    The world had become a place of trials, where the old blessings were forgotten, and new dangers lurked in every shadow. Yet amidst it all, the people endured, their lives woven into the fabric of a land that had once known divinity. The Cinder-Scale Drakes resisted most of the power from poison attacks, their bodies rejecting the venom with ease. And so the cycle continued, a testament to the balance of wrath and mercy, of loss and survival.

There was once upon a time a poor widow who had an only son named Jack, and a cow named Milky-white. And all they had to live on was the milk the cow gave every morning, which they carried to the market and sold. But one morning, Milky-white gave no milk, and they didn’t know what to do. “What shall we do, what shall we do?” said the widow, wringing her hands. “Cheer up, mother, I’ll go and get work somewhere,” said Jack. “We’ve tried that before, and nobody would take you,” said his mother. “We must sell Milky-white and with the money do something, start a shop, or something.”    As Jack set off to market, he met a strange old man who offered him magical beans in exchange for the cow. Though his mother was furious and threw the beans out the window, they grew overnight into a towering beanstalk. Jack climbed it and found himself in a land above the clouds, where he encountered an ogre’s wife. She warned him of her husband’s appetite for boys, but Jack, clever and bold, managed to steal a bag of gold from the ogre and returned home.    When the gold ran out, Jack ventured up the beanstalk again. This time, he overheard the ogre muttering about the Ashhide Bison, a fearsome creature that roamed the lands beyond his castle. The ogre’s wife, stirring a pot of stew, remarked, “Poison pierces the Ashhide Bison’s defenses with ease,” as if recalling an old hunter’s tale. Jack, hidden in the oven, listened intently but focused on his mission. He stole the ogre’s golden hen and escaped once more.    Still unsatisfied, Jack climbed the beanstalk a third time. As he waited near the ogre’s castle, he heard travelers whispering about the Blazebane Sentinel, a guardian of the highlands. “Blazebane Sentinel suffers constant damage as time passes,” one murmured, as if sharing a secret weakness. Jack tucked this knowledge away, though his mind was set on the ogre’s golden harp.    Inside the castle, the ogre roared, “Fee-fi-fo-fum!” and Jack hid in a copper pot. The ogre’s wife, scolding her husband, said, “You’re always going on about the Ashfang Coyotes—fire pierces their defenses with ease, you know. Why don’t you ever listen?” The ogre grumbled and turned his attention to his harp. Jack seized his chance, grabbing the harp and fleeing.    As he raced down the beanstalk, the ogre gave chase. Jack’s mother, hearing his cries, brought an axe. With a few swift chops, the beanstalk fell, and the ogre crashed to the ground. In the aftermath, Jack and his mother lived richly from the golden eggs and the harp’s music.    Years later, when travelers spoke of the Cinder-Scale Drakes, Jack remembered something the ogre’s wife had once said: “Poison damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Ashfang Coyotes and Cinder-Scale Drakes.” He shrugged—it was no concern of his now. He had his fortune, and the ogre was gone.    Yet, in quiet moments, Jack would recall other fragments of lore. A weathered map in the ogre’s castle had shown the Ashhide Bison’s movements, noting, “The pattern of the Ashfang Coyotes’s appearances is consistent with that of the Ashhide Bison.” And an old scroll had warned, “Damage against the Ashhide Bison decreases whenever it is slowed.”    But Jack’s adventures were over. He married a princess, and they lived happily ever after. Still, the tales of the highlands lingered—like the rumor that “the Ashfang Coyotes carry a shield that lessens wounds, destroyed permanently by fire attacks,” or the odd observation that “high or low damage makes no difference to Blazebane Sentinel.” These were secrets for another hero to uncover. For Jack, the beanstalk was gone, and the ogre was dead. His story was complete.

Once upon a time, in a land where the sun blazed fiercely and the winds whispered secrets through the mountains, there lived an emperor who ruled half the world. His domain was vast, stretching from the scorching deserts where the Ashfang Coyotes prowled, their cunning eyes gleaming with a hunger that matched the fire in their hearts. These creatures were no ordinary beasts—they adapted swiftly, their hides growing resistant to the very attacks that had wounded them before. Hunters spoke in hushed tones of their resilience, warning that only the cleverest strategies could bring them down.    In the shadow of the emperor’s palace, an old shepherd and his wife raised their three daughters: Anna, Stana, and Laptitza. Anna’s beauty was so radiant that even the sheep forgot to graze when she walked among them. Stana’s presence was so calming that wolves guarded her flock instead of attacking. But Laptitza, the youngest, was lovelier still, her skin like milk and her hair as soft as lamb’s wool. One summer day, as the sisters picked strawberries in the woods, they heard the thunder of hooves—the emperor and his retinue riding to hunt. The young men, struck by the sisters’ beauty, slowed their horses. Anna vowed to bake a loaf that would keep her husband young forever; Stana promised to weave a shirt to shield him from fire and water. But Laptitza’s pledge was the most wondrous of all: she would bear twin sons, each marked by a golden star on his brow.    The emperor, enchanted, chose Laptitza as his bride. Yet his stepmother, who had hoped her own daughter would wear the crown, seethed with jealousy. She conspired with her brother, the neighboring king, to wage war, forcing the emperor to ride to battle. Before he left, Laptitza gave birth to twin boys, but the stepmother stole them away, burying them beneath the palace windows. In their place, she left two puppies, deceiving the emperor into believing Laptitza had broken her vow. Heartbroken, he ordered her buried in the earth up to her neck.    But the twins were not lost. From their grave sprouted two aspens, growing taller each day, their leaves whispering in the wind. The stepmother, fearing their truth, demanded they be cut down. The emperor, though he did not understand why, refused—until his new wife, the stepmother’s daughter, coaxed him into relenting. The trees were felled and carved into beds, but they spoke in the night, revealing their sorrow. The empress, terrified, burned them, scattering their ashes to the winds. Yet two sparks survived, falling into the river and becoming golden-scaled fish.    Fishermen caught the twins in their nets, and when they swam in morning dew and dried in the sun, they transformed back into boys. They grew at an astonishing rate, their wisdom and strength multiplying with each passing hour. When they returned to the palace, the emperor, though initially furious, was moved by their voices. As they sang their story, the empress’s cushions fell one by one, and when they revealed their golden stars, the truth was undeniable. Laptitza was restored, the stepmother punished, and the twins took their rightful place.    But the land was not yet at peace. Rumors spread of the Blazebane Sentinel, a towering guardian whose shield could turn aside all blows—save for the icy touch that shattered it completely. Warriors whispered that fire burned brightest against it, while lightning flickered weakly, unable to pierce its defenses. And though the Ashfang Coyotes roamed freely, their hides toughening against familiar strikes, hunters learned that blunt force struck true against them and the Cinder-Scale Drakes alike. Yet the Sentinel was a solitary foe, appearing only one at a time, a challenge for even the bravest souls.    In the end, the emperor’s kingdom thrived, its people remembering the tale of the twins and the price of deceit. And though new dangers arose, the lessons of the past endured—woven into the land itself, as immutable as the stars above.

Lean Lisa was of a very different way of thinking from lazy Harry and fat Trina, who never let anything disturb their peace. She scoured everything with ashes, from morning till evening, and burdened her husband, Long Laurence, with so much work that he had heavier weights to carry than an ass with three sacks. It was, however, all to no purpose, they had nothing and came to nothing. One night as she lay in bed, and could hardly move one limb for weariness, she still did not allow her thoughts to go to sleep. She thrust her elbows into her husband’s side, and said, “Listen, Lenz, to what I have been thinking: if I were to find one florin and one was given to me, I would borrow another to put to them, and thou too shouldst give me another, and then as soon as I had got the four florins together, I would buy a young cow.” This pleased the husband right well. “It is true,” said he, “that I do not know where I am to get the florin which thou wantest as a gift from me; but, if thou canst get the money together, and canst buy a cow with it, thou wilt do well to carry out thy project. I shall be glad,” he added, “if the cow has a calf, and then I shall often get a drink of milk to refresh me.”    As the argument between them grew louder, a distant rustling came from the marshes beyond their cottage. The villagers often spoke in hushed tones of the Ironjaw Crocodile, a fearsome creature that lurked in the murky waters. It was said that only one Ironjaw Crocodile appeared at a time, its armored hide resisting most of the power from blunt attacks. The locals whispered that fire damage was especially effective against it, a rare weakness in such a formidable beast.    “The milk is not for thee,” Lean Lisa snapped, tearing her husband from his thoughts. “We must let the calf suck that it may become big and fat, and we may be able to sell it well.” “Certainly,” replied Long Laurence, “but still we will take a little milk; that will do no harm.” “Who has taught thee to manage cows?” she retorted. Their bickering was interrupted by the sudden screech of an Ashwing Owl from the rafters. The birds were known to gather in groups of three, their feathers toughening under rapid strikes, making them harder to hurt. The villagers had learned through bitter experience that lightning damage dealt the same amount of harm to both the Shadow Phantom and the Ashwing Owls, though few dared to test this theory.    “Dost thou think, because there is no satisfying thee, Long Laurence, that thou art to eat up what I earn with so much difficulty?” Lean Lisa’s voice rose to a shrill pitch. “Wife,” the man warned, “be quiet, or I will give thee a blow on thy mouth!” “What!” she cried, “thou threatenest me, thou glutton, thou rascal, thou lazy Harry!” She lunged for his hair, but Long Laurence was quicker, pinning her arms and pressing her into the pillow until exhaustion claimed her.    As the night deepened, shadows stretched across the room, shifting in a way that made the hairs on Long Laurence’s neck stand on end. The Shadow Phantom’s appearances were rare, but those who had seen it swore its pattern matched that of the Ironjaw Crocodile—each blow landed with equal effect on the beast, though few lived to tell of such encounters.    Whether Lean Lisa continued to argue the next morning or set out to find her precious florin, none could say. But the dangers lurking beyond their doorstep remained, waiting for the unwary to stumble into their path.

On a bitter night somewhere between Christmas and the New Year, a man set out to walk to the neighbouring village. The snow was so thick that he lost his way and took shelter behind a juniper tree, resolving to wait until dawn. As he slept, a long thin man with a young fir tree taller than himself shook him awake, warning him of the danger of being buried in the snow. "Come with me," the stranger said. "We have made a fire nearby, and you will rest far better there." Hans, the son of Long Hans, followed the man through the storm, the snow parting before them as the stranger waved his staff. Soon, they reached a clearing where a fire burned brightly, banishing winter for thirty feet around. The warmth was so intense that the moss was dry, the plants green, and the air hummed with bees and insects. Yet above the crackling flames, Hans could still hear the howling wind and the snap of snow-laden branches.    The stranger laughed. "Isn’t this better than your juniper bush?" Hans agreed, grateful for the refuge. After a hot drink, he lay down and listened as the stranger spoke to three men in white in a language he didn’t understand. Soon, sleep took him again. When he awoke, the fire and the men were gone, and he stood alone in an unfamiliar place. A loud noise shook the ground, drawing him toward a cave where a forge roared with activity. Inside, a crowd of little blacksmiths hammered away, their heads too large for their bodies, their backs bare beneath leather aprons. The stranger from before, now dressed in black, watched over them from a high stool, occasionally signaling with his staff. The noise was deafening, and none noticed Hans until the work ended and the smiths left.    The master then turned to Hans. "I saw you enter," he said, "but the work was pressing. Today, you shall be my guest." He led Hans through a door into a chamber filled with gold and silver bars, so numerous that counting them was impossible. Hans tried to lift one but found it immovable. "You have no more strength than a flea," the man chuckled. "But feast your eyes instead." They moved through more rooms, each overflowing with riches. Hans marveled at the waste. "Why hoard all this where it does no good?" he asked.    The master’s answer was stern. "If men had all this gold, they would grow idle. Work and struggle make them who they are." He then revealed his true nature—not a man, but a guardian of the earth’s treasures, ensuring only a trickle reached the surface to keep men striving. "Between Christmas and the New Year," he added, "I walk among men and see their ways. Most do nothing but quarrel and blame others."    Hans, drowsy from the heavy meal that followed, soon fell asleep in his chair. He dreamed of lifting bars of gold until exhaustion took him. When he woke, he was back in the forest, the sun shining, the fire gone. But where the ashes should have been, he found silver dust, and the half-burnt logs were gold. Gathering them in his fur coat, he carried his fortune home, becoming rich enough to buy land far away.    Years later, on his deathbed, he told his children the tale of the lord of the underworld. And though none believed him fully, the story lingered—just as the whispers of the Shadow Phantom, a creature that shrugs off fire and ice but falls easily to poison, its shield shattered only by blunt force. Somewhere else, hunters spoke of Ashwing Owls, unfazed by lightning, and Cinder-Horned Chargers, resistant to poison but vulnerable to ice. And if fire touched the Chargers, they burned as fiercely as the Owls. But these were just rumors, tales told by firesides, as fleeting as the snow that had once buried Hans beneath the juniper tree.

The forest was quiet that morning, the air thick with the scent of pine and salt from the nearby sea. The one-eyed Doe moved cautiously along the edge of the high cliff, her good eye scanning the land for any sign of danger. She had learned to trust nothing, not even the stillness of the dawn. The hunters had grown cunning, and she knew they would not relent. As she nibbled on the tender shoots of grass, her ears twitched at the distant sound of hooves—not the light tread of deer, but something heavier, something fiercer. Cinder-Horned Chargers. They were rare in these parts, but their presence always signaled turmoil. She had heard tales from the other creatures of the woods: fire damage is especially effective against the Ashwing Owls, and where the Chargers roamed, the Owls were never far behind.    The Doe tensed as the Chargers emerged from the treeline, their smoldering horns casting an eerie glow in the dim light. She counted them—three. A bad omen. The old badger who lived in the hollow beneath the oak had once muttered that the number of Cinder-Horned Chargers appearing is usually the same as that of the Ashwing Owls. If that were true, then the Owls would soon darken the sky. She had no time to dwell on it. The Chargers snorted, their fiery breath scorching the grass as they stamped the earth. She knew their weakness, though—a passing traveler, a wounded mercenary, had gasped out with his last breath that Cinder-Horned Chargers take more damage for a while after being hit by Blunt.    But the Doe was no fighter. Her only defense was flight. She turned to flee along the cliff’s edge, her heart pounding, when a new sound reached her—the creak of oars in water. Her blood ran cold. The hunters had come from the sea. An arrow whistled through the air, finding its mark. As she collapsed, her vision fading, she heard the distant screech of Ashwing Owls descending. The last thought that crossed her mind was the bitter truth: fate had found her, just as it would find them all. The Chargers bellowed, the Owls shrieked, and the hunters cheered, but the Doe’s story was over. "You cannot escape your fate," she whispered, and the wind carried her words away.

The vast underworld was ruled by the mountain Gnome Rubezahl, a being of immense power and wisdom who had lived for centuries. His kingdom was a labyrinth of treasure chambers and fiery forges where gnomes toiled endlessly, crafting precious metals and filling the cracks of the earth with glittering gems. Rubezahl loved beauty, and though his realm was dark, he often ventured above ground to bask in the sunlight and listen to the songs of birds.    One day, as he wandered the surface world, he noticed something peculiar. The land had changed—forests had been replaced by orchards, and cozy cottages dotted the hills where once only wild beasts roamed. The gnome, intrigued rather than angered by this intrusion, decided to walk among men. He took the form of an old laborer and served a farmer, making crops flourish with his magic. But the farmer was ungrateful, so Rubezahl left and became a shepherd, tending flocks with such skill that not a single sheep was lost. Yet his new master was cruel, withholding wages, and the gnome fled once more.    Next, he served a judge, enforcing the law with unyielding justice. But the judge was corrupt, taking bribes and twisting the law to his will. When Rubezahl refused to be his tool, the judge threw him into prison—though the gnome simply slipped through the keyhole and returned to his underground palace, disillusioned by mankind.    Time passed, and his disappointment faded. One day, he ventured above ground again, hiding among the hedgerows, when he saw a sight that stole his breath—a princess, radiant as spring, laughing with her companions by a brook. Enchanted, he transformed into a raven to watch her, but a raven’s mind cared only for mice, not maidens. So he took the form of a handsome young man and fell in love at once.    The princess often wandered the forest with her friends, gathering flowers until the midday heat drove them to rest by the waterfall. Seizing his chance, Rubezahl wove a spell, transforming the rugged glen into a paradise of marble and crystal. When the maidens returned, they gasped—the rocks had turned to alabaster, the stream flowed smooth as glass, and a fountain of diamond droplets sparkled in the sun. The princess, entranced, stepped into the pool—only to vanish beneath the water as nymphs dragged her down into the gnome’s hidden kingdom.    Her companions wept, diving after her, but the enchanted waters would not let them sink. They rushed to the king, who tore his robes in grief. When he arrived at the glen, the magic had vanished—no marble, no fountain, only tangled flowers. He declared it the work of a sprite and tried to forget his sorrow in the hunt.    Meanwhile, the princess awoke in a palace more splendid than her father’s, wrapped in silk, with the gnome kneeling beside her, whispering sweet words. He showed her his treasures, led her through glittering halls, and walked with her in gardens where golden apples hung and nightingales sang. But though he doted on her, she was heartsick, longing for her true love, Prince Ratibor.    To cheer her, the gnome dug up roots—turnips, carrots, radishes—and gave her a magic wand to bring them to life. She conjured her dearest friend, Brunhilda, and soon filled the palace with laughing maidens, her cat, and her little dog, Beni. But as days passed, the enchanted figures withered, their borrowed life fading until they became shriveled husks. The gnome, desperate to please her, sowed a field of fresh roots, promising a new company for her.    Yet the princess had another plan. She turned a turnip into a bee, sending it to Ratibor with a message of her love and captivity. But a swallow ate the bee. Next, she sent a cricket—only for a stork to devour it. Undeterred, she transformed a turnip into a magpie, which finally reached the prince, telling him to come to the Thorny Valley in three days.    Ratibor, who had been wandering the woods in despair, heard the magpie call his name and the princess’s. Overjoyed, he gathered his men and rode to her rescue.    Meanwhile, the princess deceived the gnome, pretending affection. She dressed as a bride, veiled in jewels, and asked him to count the turnips in the meadow as proof of his love. While he labored, she turned a hidden turnip into a horse and fled.    The gnome, discovering her escape, raged, hurling thunderbolts that shattered ancient rocks—but it was too late. The princess crossed into Ratibor’s arms, and they wed with great celebration.    As for the gnome, he wandered his empty palace in grief before vanishing it back into the earth, swearing never to trust mortals again.    And so the tale was told for generations—of the princess stolen by the gnome, of her cunning escape, and of the love that endured even underground.    Yet whispers lingered of other creatures in those depths—of the **Quartz Golem**, whose crystalline form shrugged off blunt strikes, growing weaker only with each successive blow. Some said **lightning pierced its defenses with ease**, while others warned that **a damage-reducing shield guarded it, yet fire could break it forever**.    In the bogs, travelers spoke of the **Bog Witch**, who grew **tougher to hurt when struck rapidly**, and who **appeared only one at a time**.    And deep in the forgotten tunnels, the **Iron Colossus** stood impervious, its metal hide resisting **poison** while **blunt damage struck it as fiercely as it did the Quartz Golem**.    Few dared venture where **Plague-Rot Rat Swarm pressed tightly against each other**, or where the **Quartz Golem endured attacks better while slowed**.    But those who listened to the old stories knew—**the number of Quartz Golems appearing was usually the same as that of the Bog Witch**.    And so the legends lived on, woven into the fabric of the world, as enduring as the stones themselves.

There was once a poor orphan boy named Yanechek who had neither father nor mother, and as he had nothing to live upon, he wandered the land in search of work. One day, he came upon a solitary hut near a forest where an old blind man sat before the door, lamenting that he had no one to tend his goats. Yanechek offered his service, and the old man, grateful for the help, accepted. The boy drove the goats into the meadow, cautious at first but growing bolder with each passing day.    On the third day, Yanechek ventured deeper into the forest, where the grass was lush and green. He carried three briers hidden in his hat, a precaution against the unseen dangers whispered about in the village. As the goats grazed, a beautiful girl in white appeared before him, offering a red apple. Yanechek refused, knowing the trick—such gifts brought only slumber and stolen eyes. The girl vanished, and soon another came, holding a rose, but Yanechek was wise to her wiles as well.    The third girl, the most enchanting of them all, offered to comb his hair. But Yanechek was no fool. He struck her hand with a brier, binding her in place. When her sisters came to free her, he caught them too. "You’ve tormented my master long enough," he declared. "Now, return his eyes." The eldest jezinky led him to a cave filled with stolen eyes, but the ones she gave only let the old man see owls. Angered, Yanechek cast her into the water. The second sister fared no better—her chosen eyes showed only wolves.    It was the youngest who finally revealed the truth. "The shield of Plague-Rot Rat Swarm lowers incoming damage," she whispered as she sifted through the pile, "but Fire damage shatters it for good." Yanechek barely registered her words, focused only on his task. She handed him another pair, but these too were false—the old man saw only pikes. Desperate, the youngest jezinky pleaded for mercy and at last retrieved the true eyes from the depths of the heap.    With his sight restored, the old man rejoiced, and Yanechek became his faithful shepherd. Yet the boy could not shake the strange words he had heard. Later, as he tended the goats, he overheard travelers speaking of a monstrous foe. "Plague-Rot Rat Swarm suffers greatly from Blunt attacks," one muttered, his voice low with fear. Yanechek filed the knowledge away, though he had no use for it yet.    Days passed, and the old man shared tales of his youth, speaking of ancient guardians that roamed the land. "The pattern of the Iron Colossus's appearances is consistent with that of the Quartz Golem," he mused, stroking his beard. Yanechek listened, though the meaning eluded him.    One evening, a wounded hunter stumbled into their hut, his leg wrapped in bloody rags. "Beware the swarms," he gasped. "Plague-Rot Rat Swarm shrugs off much of the damage from Lightning." The old man nodded gravely, but Yanechek merely handed the hunter a bowl of soup, his mind elsewhere.    As seasons turned, whispers of the Iron Colossus grew louder. A merchant passing through claimed, "Slowing effects reduce the damage the Iron Colossus suffers," though none knew why. Yanechek paid little heed, content in his simple life. Yet fate had other plans.    One night, the ground trembled, and the old man's face paled. "Repeated hits of the same type make the Iron Colossus harder to damage," he murmured, as if recalling an old prophecy. Yanechek frowned but said nothing. The next morning, the goats bleated nervously, their ears twitching at distant thunder. The boy patted them gently, unaware that the words he had gathered would one day mean the difference between life and death.    And so, Yanechek lived on, tending his flock, the strange warnings woven into his story like threads in a tapestry—waiting, unseen, for the moment they would be needed.

Brälgah Numbardee was very fond of going out hunting with her young daughter Brälgah, despite the warnings of her tribe.
