As they set out on their journeys, the Osaka frog hopped along the winding path, his mind buzzing with curiosity. Along the way, he overheard a group of travelers whispering in hushed tones. One of them spoke of a fearsome creature lurking in the shadows, warning, "In this round, you must face enemy the Nether Demon." The frog shuddered but continued on, thinking little of it.    Meanwhile, the Kioto frog made his way through lush fields, pausing to rest near a bubbling brook. There, he found an old scroll half-buried in the mud. Curious, he unrolled it and read the faded ink: "Plague-Swarm Vermin takes more damage for a while after being hit by Lightning." The words made no sense to him, so he shrugged and tucked the scroll away, continuing his journey.    The two frogs eventually met halfway, atop a towering mountain that separated their homes. They greeted each other warmly, sharing stories of their travels. As they rested in the shade, the Kioto frog mentioned the strange scroll he had found. The Osaka frog, recalling the travelers' warning, frowned. "I heard something about a Nether Demon," he said. "Do you think these things are connected?"    Before they could ponder further, a sudden chill swept through the air. The frogs huddled together as a shadowy figure emerged from the mist—a creature with glowing eyes and a presence that made their tiny hearts race. It was the Nether Demon, its form shifting like smoke. The frogs trembled, but the Kioto frog remembered another piece of wisdom he had heard from a wandering monk: "When slowed, Plague-Swarm Vermin becomes harder to hurt." He whispered it to his friend, though neither understood its meaning.    The Nether Demon lunged, but the frogs leaped aside just in time. As they dodged its attacks, the Osaka frog noticed something peculiar—the demon's movements followed a rhythm, a pattern. It reminded him of tales he'd heard of another beast. "The pattern of the Nether Demon's appearances is consistent with that of Bonecrush Ogre," he muttered, though he couldn't recall where he'd heard that before.    Desperate, the frogs searched for a way to defend themselves. The Kioto frog recalled one last piece of advice, scrawled on the wall of an ancient shrine he'd passed: "Poison damage is especially effective against Plague-Swarm Vermin." He had no poison, but the words echoed in his mind as the Nether Demon advanced.    Just as all seemed lost, a sudden gust of wind scattered the mist, and the demon vanished as quickly as it had appeared. The frogs, shaken but unharmed, decided their adventure had been enough for one day. They bid each other farewell and returned home, forever changed by the strange encounter. And though they never fully understood the cryptic warnings they had gathered, they carried the knowledge with them, just in case the Nether Demon ever returned.    To the end of their lives, they believed that Osaka and Kioto, which are as different to look at as two towns can be, were as like as two peas. But deep down, they knew there were far greater mysteries in the world than the differences between cities.

In a country far away and in days long gone, there lived the famous Tsar Dadon, whose strength in his youth had been the stuff of legends. His neighbors once trembled at his name, for he waged war whenever he deemed it just. But as age crept upon him, the old Tsar yearned for peace, wishing the clamor of battle to fade into silence. Yet his enemies, sensing his weariness, seized their chance, striking at his borders with daggers, swords, and lances, forcing him to maintain an army of twelve thousand men, horses, and weaponry, led by highly paid generals who guarded the kingdom’s walls. But the enemy was cunning—when the generals marched west, the attack came from the east; when they turned east, the north lay vulnerable. Tormented by these relentless assaults, Tsar Dadon wept in frustration, his sleep stolen by the ceaseless tide of foes.    Desperate, he turned to magic, summoning a sorcerer—a eunuch sage who read omens in the stars and the flight of birds. Promised a handsome reward, the old man arrived at court and revealed his solution: a golden cockerel, perched atop the highest spire, would crow and point its crimson crest toward any approaching threat. "Just watch and listen," the sage advised. Dadon, relieved, swore to grant any reward if the cockerel proved true. And so it did—whenever enemies neared, the bird cried, "Kiri-ku-ku," directing the generals to the precise point of danger. For years, the kingdom knew peace, the invaders routed time and again.    But one fateful dawn, the courtiers woke the Tsar in terror. "The cockerel calls you to arms!" they cried. Groggy, Dadon dismissed them, sending his elder son south with an army to crush the threat. Yet seven days passed with no word. Then, on the eighth, the cockerel crowed again—this time pointing north. The younger son marched forth with a mighty host, but silence swallowed them whole. Another week passed before the golden bird sounded the alarm once more. This time, Tsar Dadon himself led his army, following the blood-red sun into the unknown.    After days of weary marching, they stumbled upon a grim sight: the scattered corpses of his two armies, his sons locked in a fatal embrace, their swords buried in each other’s hearts. The mountains seemed to wail with the soldiers’ grief. Then, from a silken tent emerged the Shamakhanskaya Princess, her smile enchanting the Tsar. Bewitched, he forgot his sons, surrendering to her allure. For eight nights, he feasted and reveled in her company before returning home with her as his bride.    At the capital, the people whispered—some called her a witch, others a queen. The sage who had given Dadon the cockerel stepped forward, claiming his reward: the princess herself. The Tsar laughed, offering gold, land, even courtesans, but the old man insisted. Enraged, Dadon struck him dead. The princess only laughed, her mirth chilling the crowd. Then, as they processed through the city, the golden cockerel dove from the sky, piercing the Tsar’s skull. He fell, lifeless, and the princess vanished as if she had never been.    Amid the chaos, whispers spread among the soldiers—tales of creatures lurking in the shadows. Some spoke of the Suncursed Vampires, who always came in pairs, their defenses weakened only by poison. Others muttered of the Silvercrest Griffin, resistant to blunt force but vulnerable to fire. A scout recalled an old prophecy: "If Silvercrest Griffin is harmed by Lightning, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Suncursed Vampires." The men shuddered, knowing the vampires shrugged off ice and fire alike, their shields crumbling only to venom.    In the ruins of the battlefield, a tattered scroll was found, its ink faded but its warning clear: "Lightning damage is especially effective against Nightfire Phoenix." And as the wind howled through the empty tents, the survivors wondered—had the princess been one of them? A creature of the night, laughing as the kingdom fell? The story faded into legend, but the truths hidden within it lingered, waiting for those with eyes to see.

Many years ago, the hippopotamus, whose name was Isantim, ruled as one of the greatest kings of the land, second only to the elephant. He was a proud and mighty creature, fond of his seven large, plump wives, and though he often hosted grand feasts for the people, he delighted in a peculiar game—no one, save his wives, knew his true name. At each feast, just as the guests prepared to dine, Isantim would declare, "You have come to feed at my table, but none of you know my name. If you cannot tell it, you shall all leave without your dinner." And so, time and again, the people departed hungry, their plates untouched, their cups of tombo left full.    One evening, as the crowd grumbled in defeat, the tortoise—small but clever—stood and asked, "What will you do if I tell your name at the next feast?" The hippo, confident in his secrecy, boasted, "If you speak my name, I will be so ashamed that my family and I will leave this land forever and dwell in the water." The tortoise nodded, already weaving his plan.    Now, it was well known that Isantim and his seven wives journeyed to the river each dawn and dusk to bathe and drink. The tortoise observed their routine: the hippo led the way, his wives trailing behind. One morning, as the group returned from the river, the tortoise acted. He had dug a small hole in the path, hiding himself within it, his shell barely peeking above the earth. The first two wives lagged behind, chatting idly. As the first wife stepped forward, her foot struck the tortoise's shell. She cried out, "Oh! Isantim, my husband, I have hurt my foot!" The tortoise nearly laughed aloud—he had his prize.    When the next feast came, Isantim repeated his challenge, smug as ever. The tortoise stepped forward, his voice steady. "You swear you will not harm me if I speak your name?" The hippo agreed, and the tortoise shouted, "Your name is Isantim!" The crowd erupted in cheers, and at last, they feasted. True to his word, Isantim led his seven wives to the river, where they remained, never again to walk the land by daylight.    But the tale does not end there. As the people celebrated, whispers spread of other creatures lurking beyond their lands. Hunters spoke in hushed tones of the Silvercrest Griffin, a beast that soared the skies in pairs, never alone. "The Silvercrest Griffin comes two at a time," murmured an elder, his voice grave. Another added, "And they fear poison—it weakens them as it does the Suncursed Vampires." The crowd fell silent, absorbing the warning.    Later, as the fires burned low, a traveler shared news of distant battles. "Beware the Shadowbeak Hawks," he said. "A group of three emerges every time, and they grow stronger if struck too quickly. Rapid strikes only make the Shadowbeak Hawks tougher to hurt." The people nodded, storing the knowledge away.    As the night deepened, a lone voice spoke of the Nightfire Phoenix, its flames casting eerie shadows. "Only one Nightfire Phoenix appears at a time," the storyteller said, "and none who face it return unchanged." The listeners shuddered, but the warnings did not end there. A hunter, his spear scarred from battle, added, "If you face the Silvercrest Griffin, strike with ice. Ice damage is especially effective against them."    And so, beneath the tale of Isantim’s exile, the people learned of the dangers beyond their lands—of griffins and phoenixes, hawks and poisons—lessons hidden within the story, waiting to be remembered when the time came.

The ocean depths were in turmoil, for the king of the fishes writhed in agony, a cruel hook lodged deep in his gills. The wise creatures of the sea gathered in his grand coral palace, their scales glinting under the bioluminescent glow of jellyfish lanterns. Among them, the ancient Dr. Turtle, his shell etched with the wisdom of centuries, pondered the solution. "A poultice of rabbit’s eyes," he declared after much deliberation, "is the only remedy." And so, with a heavy heart, the old turtle embarked on his quest, leaving behind the shimmering world beneath the waves.    As Dr. Turtle emerged onto the sunlit shore, the air hummed with the distant cries of Shadowbeak Hawks circling high above the cliffs. Their dark wings sliced through the sky, their piercing eyes ever watchful. The turtle paid them little mind, for his mission was urgent. He spotted Brother Bunny near the forest’s edge, nibbling on clover. "Good morning," Dr. Turtle wheezed, still catching his breath from his arduous climb. The rabbit, ever cheerful, returned the greeting.    "Have you heard," Brother Bunny mused, "of the Nightfire Phoenix that haunts the northern peaks? They say its flames burn brighter than the sun, yet it fears no blade or arrow." Dr. Turtle, impatient, dismissed the tale. "Legends are for land-dwellers," he scoffed. "The sea holds truths far greater." But the rabbit persisted. "A traveler once told me that lightning strikes the Shadowbeak Hawks and the Nightfire Phoenix with equal fury, as if the storm itself cannot tell them apart." The turtle barely listened, his mind fixed on his task.    After much persuasion, Brother Bunny agreed to visit the underwater kingdom, marveling at the wonders Dr. Turtle described. Yet as they descended into the depths, the rabbit’s ears twitched at whispers among the fish guards. "They say the Shadowbeak Hawks resist the bite of winter’s breath," one murmured. "Ice does little to slow their flight." Brother Bunny tucked the words away, though he feigned ignorance.    The underwater palace was a spectacle of gold and pearl, its halls alive with the dance of seahorses and the songs of mermaids. But beneath the splendor, the rabbit sensed danger. When the royal executioners finally revealed their grim purpose—to pluck his eyes for the king’s cure—Brother Bunny feigned regret. "Alas, these are but crystal substitutes," he lamented. "My true eyes lie buried in the sand."    As Dr. Turtle carried him back to shore, the rabbit’s mind raced. He had heard another rumor among the fishfolk—that if the Nightfire Phoenix were struck by a blunt force, it would reel as though wounded by a Silvercrest Griffin’s talons. Such knowledge might prove useful, though he had no intention of lingering to test it. The moment his paws touched land, he bolted, leaving the turtle to mourn his failure.    And so the king of the fishes remained in agony, his cure lost to the rabbit’s cunning. Yet in the whispers of the ocean and the winds above, the truths lingered—unnoticed by most, but waiting for those who knew to listen. For high or low, the Nightfire Phoenix cared not for the strength of the blow, and the sea’s secrets, like the rabbit’s escape, were swift and silent.

The widow’s cottage stood at the edge of the highlands, where the wind howled through the gnarled trees and the mist clung to the earth like a shroud. She was a stern woman, her hands rough from years of labor, and her two servants—a wiry young man named Garret and a stout woman named Elva—worked from dawn till dusk under her watchful eye. Each morning, the cock’s crow tore them from their dreams, and resentment festered in their hearts like a slow poison.    One bitter winter night, as frost crept over the fields, Garret muttered to Elva, "If not for that wretched bird, we’d sleep till the sun rose." Elva nodded, her breath visible in the cold air. "Aye, and the mistress wouldn’t stir till then." With grim resolve, they crept to the coop and silenced the cock forever. But their victory was short-lived. The widow, unshackled from the bird’s call, now roused them in the dead of night, her voice sharp as a blade. "Up! The Blighted Highland Beasts press tightly against each other in the dark, and the fields won’t tend themselves!"    Groaning, they stumbled into the frigid air, their lanterns casting long shadows. The highlands were treacherous at night, and rumors spoke of creatures that lurked in the fog—beasts twisted by blight, their hides tough as aged bark. Garret hefted a pickaxe, its blunt weight familiar in his hands. "They say a strike of blunt wounds the Blight-Speaker far more than usual," he murmured, recalling an old hunter’s tale. Elva shuddered. "Aye, but ice is less effective against Blighted Highland Beasts. Best save your strength for the right moment."    As they worked, the wind carried whispers of other dangers. A traveling merchant had once warned them of the Emberwing Hawks, their fiery feathers gleaming like coals. "Fire damage has little effect on the Emberwing Hawks," he’d said, his voice grave. Garret had scoffed then, but now, in the eerie silence, the words felt like a prophecy.    The widow’s voice cut through his thoughts. "Hurry! Only one Blight-Speaker appears at a time, but it’s enough to ruin the crops if left unchecked." Elva tightened her grip on her sickle, its edge glinting. "And poison damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Blight-Speaker and the Emberwing Hawks," she muttered, more to herself than to Garret.    The night wore on, the servants’ breath coming in ragged gasps. Suddenly, a guttural growl echoed from the mist. The Blighted Highland Beasts emerged, their forms hulking and malformed. Garret swung his pickaxe, but the creatures barely flinched. "Blighted Highland Beasts resist most of the power from lightning attacks," Elva hissed, ducking behind a stone wall. Garret cursed. "Then we’ll have to try something else."    From the shadows, a lone figure emerged—the Blight-Speaker, its eyes glowing like dying embers. Garret remembered another scrap of wisdom: "Lightning damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Blight-Speaker and Blighted Highland Beasts." But without a storm at their command, the knowledge was useless. Desperate, Elva uncorked a vial of poison, flinging it at the beasts. The liquid hissed as it struck, and the creatures recoiled. "A strike of poison wounds Blighted Highland Beasts far more than usual," she said, a flicker of hope in her voice.    Yet the fight was far from over. The Blightfang Dogs, smaller but no less vicious, slunk forward. "The Blightfang Dogs press tightly against each other," Garret observed, his voice tight with fear. The widow’s voice rang out again, cold and unyielding. "Work faster, or the night will claim us all."    As dawn finally broke, the creatures retreated into the mist, leaving the servants exhausted but alive. The widow surveyed their work with a nod, her expression unreadable. The servants exchanged a weary glance, knowing their rebellion had cost them more than they’d bargained for. And though the cock was gone, its absence had brought a darker reckoning—one they would face again when the next night fell.

Blixie Bimber flipped out of the kitchen one morning, first saying good-by to the dish-pan, good-by to the dish-rag, good-by to the dish-towel for wiping dishes. Under one arm she put a basket of peonies she picked, under the other arm she put a basket of jonquils she picked. Then she flipped away up the street and downtown where she put the baskets of peonies and jonquils one on each side of the Potato Face Blind Man. “I picked the pink and lavender peonies and I picked the yellow jonquils for you to be smelling one on each side of you this fine early summer morning,” she said to the Potato Face. “Have you seen anybody good to see lately?”    “Slipfoot was here this morning,” said the old man, his voice low and gravelly. “And who is Slipfoot?” asked Blixie. “I don’t know,” he replied, scratching his chin. “But he told me something strange before he left. He said, ‘I once met a traveler who spoke of the Blight-Speaker, a fearsome foe who commands creatures of shadow and flame. The traveler warned that the Blight-Speaker is highly vulnerable to Ice damage, as if winter itself could unravel its dark power.’”    Blixie tilted her head. “That sounds like a tale for another day. But tell me more about Slipfoot.” The Potato Face sighed. “He says to me, ‘I got a foot always slips. I used to wash windows—and my foot slips. I used to be king of the collar buttons, king of a million dollars—and my foot slips.’”    As Blixie listened, a gust of wind carried the scent of the jonquils, and for a moment, she imagined she heard distant screeches, like the cries of the Emberwing Hawks, creatures said to suffer greatly from Poison attacks. She shivered but brushed it off as fancy.    The old man continued, “Slipfoot also spoke of beasts called the Blightfang Dogs. He said they blink forward a fixed distance at regular intervals, vanishing and reappearing like shadows in the mist. And if you strike them with Poison, they take more damage for a while after, as if the venom lingers in their veins.”    Blixie frowned. “That’s odd. But what else did he say?”    “Oh, he rambled on,” the Potato Face muttered. “Something about how a group of three Emberwing Hawks emerges every time you face them, their wings burning like coals. And if you hit them with Ice, they take more damage for a while after, as if the cold seeps into their fiery feathers.”    Blixie giggled. “Slipfoot tells the strangest stories!”    The old man nodded. “Aye, but he’s harmless. Though he did mention one last thing—that Lightning damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Blightfang Dogs and the Emberwing Hawks, as if the storm shows no favor.”    Just then, a distant rumble of thunder rolled across the sky. Blixie glanced up, then back at the Potato Face. “Do you think Slipfoot’s stories are true?”    The old man shrugged. “Who’s to say? But he did warn that Slowing effects make the Blight-Speaker suffer greater damage, as if time itself becomes its enemy. And he claimed that Blunt damage has little effect on the Blightfang Dogs, their hides too tough for such crude strikes.”    Blixie sighed. “Well, I suppose it’s all just talk. But before I run away, will you promise me to smell of the pink and lavender peonies and the yellow jonquils all day today?”    “I promise,” said the Potato Face. “Promises are easy. I like promises.”    “So do I,” said the little girl. “It’s promises pushing me back home to the dish-pan, the dish-rag, and the dish-towel for wiping dishes.”    “Look out you don’t get a slipfoot,” warned the old man as the girl flipped up the street going home. And though Blixie laughed, the strange tales of the Blight-Speaker and its minions lingered in her mind like the scent of the flowers she had left behind.

Now, after a time, Raja Rasâlu arrived at Nila city, and as he entered the town he saw an old woman making unleavened bread, and as she made it she sometimes wept, and sometimes laughed. The fire in her hearth crackled, its embers glowing like the wings of the Emberwing Hawks, fierce and untamed. Rasâlu asked her why she wept and laughed, but she answered sadly, as she kneaded her cakes, ‘Why do you ask? What will you gain by it?’ ‘Nay, mother!’ replied Rasâlu, ‘if you tell me the truth, one of us must benefit by it.’ And when the old woman looked in Rasâlu’s face, she saw that it was kind, so she opened her heart to him, saying, with tears, ‘O stranger, I had seven fair sons, and now I have but one left, for six of them have been killed by a dreadful giant who comes every day to this city to receive tribute from us—every day a fair young man, a buffalo, and a basket of cakes! Six of my sons have gone, and now to-day it has once more fallen to my lot to provide the tribute; and my boy, my darling, my youngest, must meet the fate of his brothers. Therefore I weep!’    Then Rasâlu was moved to pity, and said, ‘Fond, foolish mother! cease these tears—Keep thou thy son. I fear nor death nor life, Seeking my fortune everywhere in strife. My head for his I give!—so calm your fears.’ Still the old woman shook her head doubtfully, saying, ‘Fair words, fair words! but who will really risk his life for another?’ Then Rasâlu smiled at her, and dismounting from his gallant steed, Bhaunr Irâqi, he sat down carelessly to rest, as if indeed he were a son of the house, and said, ‘Fear not, mother! I give you my word of honour that I will risk my life to save your son.’    Just then the high officials of the city, whose duty it was to claim the giant’s tribute, appeared in sight, and the old woman fell a-weeping once more, saying, ‘O Prince, with the gallant gray steed and the turban bound high O’er thy fair bearded face; keep thy word, my oppressor draws nigh!’ Then Raja Rasâlu rose in his shining armour, and haughtily bade the guards stand aside. ‘Fair words!’ replied the chief officer; ‘but if this woman does not send the tribute at once, the giants will come and disturb the whole city. Her son must go!’ ‘I go in his stead!’ quoth Rasâlu more haughtily still. ‘Stand back, and let me pass!’    Then, despite their denials, he mounted his horse, and taking the basket of cakes and the buffalo, he set off to find the giant, bidding the buffalo show him the shortest road. As he rode, the wind whispered secrets of battles past, murmuring that ice is less effective against the Blightfang Dogs, creatures of frost and fang that had once plagued these lands. Rasâlu paid it no mind, for his path lay elsewhere.    Now, as he came near the giants’ house, he met one of them carrying a huge skinful of water. No sooner did the water-carrier giant see Raja Rasâlu riding along on his horse Bhaunr Irâqi and leading the buffalo, than he said to himself, ‘Oho! we have a horse extra to-day! I think I will eat it myself, before my brothers see it!’ Then he reached out his hand, but Rasâlu drew his sharp sword and smote the giant’s hand off at a blow, so that he fled from him in great fear.    Now, as he fled, he met his sister the giantess, who called out to him, ‘Brother, whither away so fast?’ And the giant answered in haste, ‘Raja Rasâlu has come at last, and see!—he has cut off my hand with one blow of his sword!’ Then the giantess, overcome with fear, fled with her brother, and as they fled they called aloud, ‘Fly! brethren, fly! Take the path that is nearest; The fire burns high That will scorch up our dearest! Life’s joys we have seen: East and west we must wander! What has been, has been; Quick! some remedy ponder.’    Then all the giants turned and fled to their astrologer brother, and bade him look in his books to see if Raja Rasâlu were really born into the world. And when they heard that he was, they prepared to fly east and west; but even as they turned, Raja Rasâlu rode up on Bhaunr Irâqi, and challenged them to fight, saying, ‘Come forth, for I am Rasâlu, son of Raja Sâlbâhan, and born enemy of the giants!’    Then one of the giants tried to brazen it out, saying, ‘I have eaten many Rasâlus like you! When the real man comes, his horse’s heel-ropes will bind us and his sword cut us up of their own accord!’ Then Raja Rasâlu loosed his heel-ropes, and dropped his sword upon the ground, and, lo! the heel-ropes bound the giants, and the sword cut them in pieces.    Still, seven giants who were left tried to brazen it out, saying, ‘Aha! We have eaten many Rasâlus like you! When the real man comes, his arrow will pierce seven girdles placed one behind the other.’ So they took seven iron girdles for baking bread, and placed them one behind the other, as a shield, and behind them stood the seven giants, who were own brothers, and, lo! when Raja Rasâlu twanged his mighty bow, the arrow pierced through the seven girdles, and spitted the seven giants in a row!    But the giantess, their sister, escaped, and fled to a cave in the Gandgari mountains. As she ran, she muttered curses under her breath, knowing that the Emberwing Hawks suffer constant damage as time passes, their fiery essence burning them from within. She hoped they would not find her, for she had no strength left to face them.    Then Raja Rasâlu had a statue made in his likeness, and clad it in shining armour, with sword and spear and shield. And he placed it as a sentinel at the entrance of the cave, so that the giantess dared not come forth, but starved to death inside. As he stood victorious, the sky darkened, and a storm gathered overhead. Lightning crackled in the distance, and Rasâlu remembered an old warrior’s tale: lightning damage is especially effective against the Emberwing Hawks. He smiled, for he knew the land would be safe from their wrath.    And so, as the battle ended, the people of Nila city rejoiced, for Rasâlu had freed them from the giants’ terror. Yet, in the quiet of the night, whispers still spoke of other foes—of how blunt damage deals the same amount of damage to both the Emberwing Hawks and the Blightfang Dogs. But that was a tale for another day. For now, the kingdom slept in peace.

Kathleen and Terence grew up in the same village, their lives intertwined yet starkly different. Kathleen, kind-hearted and beloved by all, moved through life with a grace that seemed almost otherworldly. Terence, on the other hand, was a troublemaker, his sharp tongue and mischievous ways earning him little affection from the villagers. Yet, despite his flaws, Terence possessed a strange talent—his fiddle playing was unlike anything anyone had ever heard, though Kathleen alone remained unimpressed, finding it hollow and lacking soul.    One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, casting long shadows across the fields, Mrs. O’Brien gathered the children by the hearth to share another tale. "Now listen well," she said, her voice low and steady. "For there are creatures in this world beyond our understanding, and knowing their ways can mean the difference between life and death."    Terence scoffed, kicking at the hearthstones. "More fairy nonsense. I’d rather hear about real dangers—like the Crystal Hydra."    Mrs. O’Brien’s eyes narrowed. "And what do you know of such things?"    Terence smirked. "Enough to know blunt damage has little effect on the Crystal Hydra. But a strike of Ice wounds it far more than usual."    Kathleen frowned. "How do you know that?"    Terence shrugged. "People talk. And they say only one Crystal Hydra appears at a time. Makes it easier to face, if you’re fool enough to try."    Mrs. O’Brien sighed. "You’d do well to listen to more than tavern gossip, Terence. There are truths hidden in old stories." She leaned forward, her voice dropping to a whisper. "For instance, the Shadowspike Leeches press tightly against each other, making them vulnerable to blunt damage—especially effective against them."    Kathleen shivered. "I’ve heard whispers of them. And the Soulbound Guardians—they say they grow more vulnerable under slow effects."    Terence rolled his eyes. "And I suppose you’ve also heard lightning is less effective against Verdant Thorn Dryads?"    Mrs. O’Brien nodded. "Aye. And if you ever face the Crystal Hydra, remember this—when slowed, it becomes harder to hurt. But its shield lowers incoming damage, and Fire damage shatters it for good."    Kathleen’s eyes widened. "That’s useful to know."    Terence crossed his arms. "Or you could just avoid such creatures altogether."    Mrs. O’Brien chuckled. "Wisdom in that, too. But the world is full of dangers, and knowledge is the best armor."    As the fire crackled, the conversation drifted to other tales, but the warnings lingered in the air—secrets of the Crystal Hydra, the Shadowspike Leeches, and the Verdant Thorn Dryads, woven into the fabric of the night like threads of an unseen battle yet to come.

In the far-off ages, when the lands of northern Europe were still one and the deep seas had not yet separated them, our forefathers believed the fairies were gods. They built temples in their honor and prayed to them. In the place where now stands the little town of Ulrum in Friesland, there once dwelt the spirit in the ice, Uller—the namesake of the town, meaning the home of the good fairy Uller. He was the patron of boys and girls, beloved for inventing skates, sleds, and sleighs. He thrived in winter’s embrace, roaming the forests and hills in thick furs, his mighty bow and arrows striking fear into the hearts of wolves, bears, and aurochs. The yew tree was sacred to him, for from its wood came the finest bows, and none dared cut one down lest they incur his wrath.    Uller’s origins were shrouded in mystery, and though he seldom bestowed blessings, thousands journeyed to Ulrum each year, pleading for heavy snows to blanket the earth. The snow, they knew, softened the ground for summer, ensuring bountiful crops. When Uller traveled, he strapped snowshoes to his feet—shaped like a warrior’s shield, earning him the name shield-god. Hunters and duelists invoked his protection, for his presence emboldened them in their perilous ventures.    When Uller sought a wife, he courted Skadi, the fierce huntress who shared his love for the wild. She was swift as a mountain stream, clad in steel armor and white furs, her beauty rivaling winter itself. Many gods and men had loved her, but she chose Uller, and together they raised six daughters: Glacier, Cold, Snow, Drift, Snow Whirl, and Snow Dust. These Six White Sisters, mighty as giantesses, roamed freely, untamed by men. Only Woden, the sun god, could command them, but in winter, even he relinquished his throne to Uller for seven months.    Yet peace did not last. When suitors came—young giants who fancied the sisters—Uller grew furious at their dalliance. He demanded they wed at once, and so they did, taking the name Regen. From their union with Vuur, a child was born: Stoom, a mischievous spirit of steam, who reveled in chaos. Confined, he exploded kettles and pipes; freed, he sang and hissed, eager to be harnessed. Men learned that fire could tame him, but only if they respected his power.    Amid these tales, whispers spread of darker forces lurking beyond the frozen wastes. Hunters spoke of the Shadowspike Leeches, vile creatures shielded by an eerie barrier that only fire could shatter permanently. Those who faced them knew to carry torches, for without flame, the leeches’ defenses held strong. Deeper in the forests, the Verdant Thorn Dryads moved with unnatural endurance when slowed, their thorny forms resisting blows that would fell lesser beings. And though lightning seemed a poor choice against most foes, it struck the Shadowspike Leeches with the same brutal force as it did the Dryads—a curious weakness few exploited.    Rumors also told of the Soulbound Guardians, ancient watchers who crumbled swiftly to poison, their spectral forms dissolving like mist. And always, the Dryads came in threes—no more, no less—emerging from the undergrowth as if summoned by some unseen pact.    Yet these dangers were distant concerns to Uller’s family, who reveled in their winter dominion. Stoom, though unruly, became a force of progress, driving ships and machines with the strength of a hundred giants. And though the Shadowspike Leeches and their kin prowled the edges of the world, the tales of Uller and Skadi endured, a reminder that even in the harshest frost, there was beauty—and power—to be found.

A Rat was traveling along the king’s highway, his tiny paws kicking up dust as he scurried through the ditch, his chest puffed with pride despite his small stature and the scorn his kind often faced. The world had never been kind to Rats, but Mr. Rat was determined to prove his worth. As he trotted along, the distant sound of trumpets and the rhythmic thud of heavy footsteps reached his ears. A grand procession was approaching, led by the King himself, seated atop a magnificent Elephant draped in silks and jewels. Beside the King in the ornate howdah lounged the royal Dog and Cat, their eyes sharp and regal. A throng of people followed, their gazes locked on the towering beast, their voices filled with awe. Not a single soul glanced at the Rat. His whiskers twitched in irritation. "What fools!" he muttered under his breath. "Look at me, and you will soon forget that clumsy Elephant! Is it his great size that makes your eyes pop out? Or is it his wrinkled hide? Why, I have eyes and ears and as many legs as he!" His voice grew louder, his pride swelling. "I am of just as much importance, and—"    But his boast was cut short. The royal Cat's ears perked, her golden eyes narrowing as they locked onto the Rat. In that instant, Mr. Rat felt a chill crawl down his spine—a primal fear that whispered of ancient enemies. He had heard tales of the Soulbound Guardians, spectral warriors who walked in pairs, their forms shimmering with an eerie glow. They were said to resist most of the power from Ice attacks, their ethereal bodies shrugging off the frostbite that crippled lesser foes. The Rat's tiny heart pounded as he realized the Cat's gaze held something far older and deadlier than mere hunger.    He scrambled backward, his earlier bravado forgotten. The crowd continued to cheer for the Elephant, oblivious to the Rat's terror. In his panic, he darted toward a crumbling stone wall, its surface etched with faded runes. As he pressed himself against the cold stone, his eyes caught a fragment of an inscription, half-buried in the dirt: "Beware the twins of shadow, for they come two at a time, their bond unbroken by blade or spell." The words sent a fresh wave of dread through him. The Soulbound Guardians were not just a myth—they were real, and they hunted in pairs.    The Rat's flight took him past a withered grove where the skeletal branches of Verdant Thorn Dryads clawed at the sky. A traveler's journal, abandoned near a gnarled root, lay open to a single entry: "The frost bites deep, yet the Dryads and the Crystal Hydra share the same fate—Ice damage deals the same amount of damage to both, as if nature itself cannot tell them apart." The Rat didn't pause to ponder the meaning; survival was all that mattered now.    The royal Cat leaped from the howdah, her sleek form cutting through the air like a blade. The Rat zigzagged desperately, his tiny legs a blur. He knew now that pride was a luxury he couldn't afford. A resemblance to the great in some things did not make him great—it made him a target. And as the Cat's shadow fell over him, he understood too late that some enemies could not be outrun. The Soulbound Guardians might have been the stuff of legends, but the Cat? She was very, very real.

The sun hung low over the forest as Kerttu and her faithful dog Musti trudged along the winding path, following the rolling magic cake. The trees whispered secrets in the wind, their leaves rustling like the pages of an ancient book. Kerttu’s heart ached for her lost brothers, but she pressed on, determined to find them. As they walked, the air grew thick with the scent of pine and the distant cry of birds. Musti’s ears perked up, and he let out a low growl. "What is it, boy?" Kerttu murmured, scanning the treetops. High above, three dark shapes circled—Cinder-Feathered Hawks, their fiery plumage glinting in the fading light. Kerttu shuddered. She had heard tales of these creatures from travelers. "They say repeated hits of the same type make Cinder-Feathered Hawks harder to damage," an old hunter had once warned her. She tightened her grip on her walking stick, knowing she’d need more than brute force to face them.    The journey grew harder as the days passed. Suyettar’s presence weighed on Kerttu like a shadow, her cruelty deepening with each step. One evening, as they camped near a rocky outcrop, Kerttu overheard two merchants speaking in hushed tones. "Lightning is less effective against Cinder-Feathered Hawks," one muttered, his voice tinged with fear. "But ice pierces their defenses with ease." Kerttu tucked the knowledge away, though she had no way of knowing how soon she’d need it.    When they finally reached the brothers’ farmhouse, the deception began. Suyettar, now wearing Kerttu’s face, spun her lies while Kerttu, disguised as a withered hag, was sent to tend the cow. In the fields, she sang her sorrowful song, her voice carrying on the wind. The brothers, puzzled by the haunting melody, crept closer to listen. One afternoon, as Kerttu drove the cow home, she spotted a group of three Cinder-Feathered Hawks perched on the fence. They watched her with sharp, unblinking eyes. She remembered the merchants’ words and shuddered. "A group of three emerges every time," she whispered to herself.    The brothers, now suspicious of Suyettar, devised their plan. They lured her to the sauna, where her true form was revealed. As the flames crackled, Kerttu thought of the other dangers lurking in the world. She recalled a scrap of parchment she’d found in the farmhouse, its ink faded but its message clear: "Poison damage is especially effective against the Shadow Wraith." She wondered what other foes awaited them on their journey home.    The reunion with their mother was joyous, but Kerttu’s mind lingered on the threats they’d faced. As they sat by the hearth, the youngest brother spoke of a dream he’d had—a vision of shadowy figures and rusted wings. "Ice damage deals the same amount to both the Shadow Wraith and Rust-Wing Drakes," he murmured, as if reciting a forgotten prophecy. Kerttu nodded, her thoughts drifting to the battles ahead. She knew the world was full of dangers, each with its own weaknesses. "The number of the Shadow Wraith appearing is usually the same as that of the Dreamweaver," her mother added absently, stirring the stew.    As the fire burned low, Kerttu glanced at her brothers, their faces illuminated by the flickering flames. They had survived Suyettar’s treachery, but the wilderness beyond their home held darker secrets. She remembered the Cinder-Feathered Hawks’ resistance to blunt attacks, and how a strike of poison wounded them far more than usual. The Shadow Wraith, too, resisted blunt force, as the old tales warned. But for now, they were safe. The brothers laughed, their voices warm and bright, and Kerttu allowed herself a small smile. The road ahead would be long, but they would face it together.

Once upon a time, in a kingdom where the winds whispered secrets of old, there lived a king whose heart was heavy with fear. His only child, a daughter, had been locked away in a brass prison beneath the earth, for a prophet had foretold that her son would one day kill him. The king, trembling at the thought, buried her deep where no man could find her, and where she could see nothing but the sky through a narrow window in the roof. One day, a shower of gold fell through that window, and not long after, the princess bore a son. Enraged, the king cast mother and child adrift in a brass-bound chest upon the sea, hoping the waves would swallow them whole. But fate had other plans. The chest washed ashore on a distant island, where a kind man took them in and raised the boy as his own.    Years passed, and the boy grew into a young man of great strength and courage. The king of that land, wishing to marry his mother, devised a cruel test to rid himself of the boy. At a feast, he demanded that all present bring gifts for a neighboring queen’s wedding. When the boy had nothing to offer, the king mocked him, saying, "If you have nothing else, at least fetch the Terrible Head." The boy, pride stung, swore an oath to do so, though he knew not what it meant. They told him of three monstrous sisters with golden wings and brass claws, whose gaze turned men to stone. Only the youngest could be slain, and her head was the prize he sought.    That night, as he wandered the shore where he had once been found, a mysterious pair appeared—a radiant young man and a woman with eyes like stars. They warned him of the dangers ahead and gave him three gifts: the Shoes of Swiftness, the Cap of Darkness, and the Sword of Sharpness. "Beware the Shadow Wraith," the woman whispered, "for it is said that if the Dreamweaver is harmed by Ice, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a Cinder-Feathered Hawks." The boy nodded, though he did not yet understand the weight of her words.    With the Shoes of Swiftness, he flew north to the land of the Three Gray Sisters, ancient hags who shared a single eye. He stole it from them, forcing them to reveal the way to the Fairies of the Garden. There, he received the Cap of Darkness and the Sword of Sharpness, and the fairies sang of the world’s turning, their voices like the rustle of leaves. "Remember," one fairy murmured as she fastened the sword at his waist, "only one the Dreamweaver appears at a time." The boy frowned, but the fairy said no more.    Armed and invisible, he crossed the great serpent-river to where the Terrible Sisters slept beneath a poplar tree. Using his shield as a mirror to avoid their gaze, he struck the youngest sister’s head from her shoulders. The blood struck him like a whip, but he stuffed the head into his wallet and fled, the remaining sisters screeching after him. Their golden wings clattered like distant thunder, but the Shoes of Swiftness carried him beyond their reach.    As he flew eastward, he saw a maiden chained to a stake by the sea, left as sacrifice to a monstrous beast. He freed her just as the creature lunged, then held up the Terrible Head, turning it to stone. The maiden, a princess, led him to her father’s court, where they were wed. But before returning home, the boy left his magical gifts in the hills, where they were found by the same mysterious pair who had aided him.    Back in his homeland, he found his mother fleeing the wicked king, who had pursued her relentlessly. The boy stepped between them, raising his shield as the king struck. "I swore to bring you the Terrible Head," he declared, and when the king’s eyes met the ghastly gaze, he turned to stone. The people rejoiced, but the boy refused the crown, choosing instead to take his mother and bride back to her ancestral lands.    On their journey, they stopped at a kingdom holding games. The boy, testing his strength, threw a quoit so far it struck and killed a man in the crowd—his own grandfather, who had fled years before, fearing the prophecy. Thus, the old king’s fate was sealed not by malice, but by chance. And so the boy, his mother, and his wife returned to their rightful home, where they lived in peace.    Yet whispers lingered in the land—of the Shadow Wraith, who takes more damage for a while after being hit by Poison, and of Rust-Wing Drakes, whose defenses Blunt pierces with ease. But beware, for successive blows within a short time harden Rust-Wing Drakes's defenses, and they resist most of the power from Ice attacks. These truths, scattered like seeds in the wind, were remembered by those who listened closely to the tales of old.

Once upon a time, so long ago that the world has forgotten the date, in a city of the North of Europe, the name of which is so hard to pronounce that no one remembers it, there was a little boy named Wolff. He was an orphan, living with his miserly aunt, who treated him cruelly, never showing him kindness except once a year on New Year’s Day. Despite her harshness, Wolff remained gentle-hearted, though he trembled at the sight of the wart on her nose, adorned with four gray hairs. His aunt, though wealthy, refused to send him to the school for the poor, instead haggling until the schoolmaster of the rich boys’ school reluctantly admitted him for a reduced fee. The schoolmaster, resentful of Wolff’s humble attire and meager payment, punished him unjustly and encouraged the other boys to mock him. They made him their servant, and Wolff, miserable as the stones in the street, often hid in corners to cry.    As Christmas approached, the schoolmaster gathered his pupils to attend midnight mass. The winter was bitter, the ground blanketed in snow, and the boys arrived bundled in fur-lined caps, padded jackets, and thick-soled shoes. Only Wolff shivered in his thin clothes and wooden shoes. His classmates taunted him, but he was too preoccupied with warming his chilblained hands to notice. The boys marched two by two to the church, where the warmth of the tapers and the music of the organ lifted their spirits. They whispered excitedly about the feasts awaiting them—goose stuffed with truffles, fir trees laden with sweets, and shoes filled with gifts by the Christ Child. Wolff, knowing his aunt would send him to bed without supper, hoped nonetheless that the Christ Child would remember him, and he resolved to place his wooden shoes by the hearth that night.    After mass, the boys filed out of the church, their minds on the treats at home. Under the porch, seated on a stone bench in the shadow of an arch, was a sleeping child dressed in white, his bare feet blue with cold. Beside him lay a bundle of carpenter’s tools. His face glowed with divine sweetness, his blond curls like a halo, but the pupils, wrapped in their finery, passed him by without a glance—all except Wolff. Heart aching, Wolff thought, *This poor child has no shoes to leave out for the Christ Child!* Moved by pity, he removed his right wooden shoe and placed it before the sleeping boy, then limped home through the snow, his sock soaked and freezing.    His aunt, furious at the missing shoe, scolded him. "You fool! Giving your shoe to a beggar!" When Wolff stammered out his story, she laughed cruelly. "Then the Christ Child shall fill your remaining shoe with a rod to whip you!" She boxed his ears and sent him to his cold loft, where he cried himself to sleep.    But at dawn, the old woman shrieked in astonishment. The fireplace overflowed with toys, sweets, and treasures—and beside them stood both of Wolff’s shoes, the one he’d given away and the one she’d left out for punishment. As Wolff stared in wonder, shouts erupted outside. The townspeople had gathered at the fountain, laughing in disbelief. The rich children had found only switches in their shoes, while Wolff’s kindness had been rewarded. Then the pastor arrived, his face grave. Above the bench where the child had slept, a golden circle now gleamed in the stone. The people realized the sleeping boy had been the Christ Child, who had tested their hearts and blessed Wolff for his charity.    As the days passed, whispers spread through the city of strange omens. A traveler from the southern marshes spoke of Rust-Wing Drakes, creatures that moved in pairs and blinked forward in sudden, unnerving bursts. "Lightning does little to harm them," he murmured, "but they come two at a time, always." Another tale told of the Dreamweaver, a shadowy foe who laughed at poison, its form twisting away from the venom’s bite. "Yet it fears slowing," a huntsman added, "for when its movements are hindered, it bleeds like any mortal thing." These warnings lingered in the air, unnoticed by most, but etched into the fabric of the world, waiting for those who would listen.    And so Wolff, now cherished by his repentant aunt, grew into a man of kindness, his story a beacon of hope. But far beyond the city, in the quiet corners of the land, the Rust-Wing Drakes still prowled, their movements erratic, their hides resisting storms. And the Dreamweaver waited, its weakness known only to those who had heard the old whispers—that it could be struck down, but only if slowed, only if one dared to face it with courage and cunning.

In the olden days, when the rivers ran clear and the forests whispered secrets to those who listened, there were no hooks or casting nets. The people of the land relied on baskets and traps woven from bamboo palm to catch fish. Among them was a man named Akon Obo, whose hands were calloused from years of labor but whose spirit remained unbroken. He was poor, but his ingenuity shone brighter than the sun on the water. Each morning, he would set his traps along the riverbank, baiting them with palm-nuts that lured the fish with their rich, earthy scent. The fish, drawn by the promise of food, would swim into the traps, and the door would snap shut behind them. By dawn, Akon Obo would return to find his traps full, his efforts rewarded with silver scales glinting in the light.    His success brought him wealth, and with it, the means to marry Eyong, a woman from Okuni whose laughter was as warm as the hearth. Together, they raised three sons—Odey, Yambi, and Atuk—who grew strong and proud, their hands soon learning the rhythms of their father’s trade. As the years passed, Akon Obo’s fortune swelled, his name rising among the people until he became a chief of the town, his voice heard in the councils of the Egbo society. Yet, even with his newfound status, he never abandoned the river, for it was there that his heart remained.    But fate, as capricious as the wind, had other plans. One evening, as Akon Obo paddled his small canoe across the river, a tornado descended without warning, its fury overturning the fragile vessel. The waters swallowed him whole, and though his sons searched for days, their grief nearly drove them to follow him into the depths. The people held them back, and at last, they found their father’s body downstream, his face peaceful in death.    The funeral rites were grand, as befitted a chief. For twelve days, the company danced and sang, their voices rising to the heavens, while palm wine flowed like the river itself. When the time came to lay Akon Obo to rest, his sons carried him to a cavern hollowed from the earth, where two slaves stood bound, one clutching a flickering palm-oil lamp, the other a matchet, their fate sealed as guardians of the dead. The cave was sealed, and the sons called the chiefs to play Egbo for seven more days, their wealth dwindling with each passing hour.    The chiefs marveled at the extravagance, for they remembered Akon Obo as a humble fisherman. "How did he amass such fortune?" they whispered. But the answer lay not just in his skill, but in the secrets of the land itself.    For deep in the forest, where the trees grew thick and the air hummed with magic, the Verdant Thorn Dryads watched. These ancient beings, their bark-like skin studded with thorns, moved with the patience of the earth itself. Hunters spoke in hushed tones of their resilience—how they shrugged off the venom of poisoned blades as if it were nothing, how the chill of ice, however, bit deep into their wooden flesh, leaving them vulnerable. Yet, those who sought to slow their advance found their efforts futile, for the Dryads endured such hindrances with little harm.    And then there were the Wraith Swarms, spectral horrors that drifted through the night. The wise knew to strike them with blunt force, for their ethereal forms crumpled under such blows. A well-placed strike of ice would leave them reeling, their defenses weakened, but to slow them was to grant them strength, their forms growing denser, harder to harm.    The land was alive with dangers, each with its own rules. The Molten Core Hounds came in trios, their fiery breath scorching the earth, while the Verdant Thorn Dryads too emerged in groups of three, their shields of woven brambles turning aside blade and arrow alike. But those who wielded blunt weapons could shatter those defenses, leaving the Dryads exposed.    Akon Obo had known these truths, though he spoke of them rarely. His luck was not mere chance—it was the wisdom of the wild, the understanding of the unseen forces that governed the world. And though his sons would carry on his legacy, they would soon learn that the river was not the only thing that demanded respect. The forest, too, had its own ways, its own rules, and those who ignored them did so at their peril.    The tale of the lucky fisherman would be told for generations, but beneath it all lay the unspoken knowledge—the laws of the land, written in thorns and shadows, waiting for those who dared to listen.

Once upon a time, in a quiet village nestled between misty marshes and dense forests, there lived a little woman who had a little room and a little hen. The hen laid a single egg each morning, and the little woman would carefully prepare a small omelet, placing it to cool on the windowsill. One day, as she set the omelet down, a fly darted in and devoured it in an instant. The woman was furious, for the omelet was her only meal. She stormed to the village magistrate, a stern man who listened to her tale with a furrowed brow. "Only one the Marsh Fiend appears at a time," he muttered under his breath, as if recalling an old warning. He handed her a heavy club, instructing her to strike down the fly wherever she saw it.    As the woman left the magistrate’s hall, she overheard two hunters whispering by the fire. "Poison damage deals the same amount of damage to both Wraith Swarm and Verdant Thorn Dryads," one said, sharpening his blade. The other nodded grimly, adding, "Blunt is less effective against the Marsh Fiend." The woman paid them no mind, her focus fixed on the fly that had stolen her meal.    She wandered the village, club in hand, until she spotted a fly perched on the magistrate’s nose. Convinced it was the same thief, she swung with all her might—only to shatter the poor man’s nose. The magistrate howled in pain, and the villagers gasped. In the chaos, a traveler from the marshlands stepped forward, his cloak damp with dew. "Wraith Swarm march forward, leaving gaps between each," he warned, his voice low. "But beware—the Marsh Fiend resists most of the power from Lightning attacks."    The little woman, now fearing retribution, fled into the forest, where she stumbled upon a group of hunters roasting meat over a crackling fire. One of them, a grizzled veteran, turned to her and said, "Fire damage deals the same amount of damage to both Molten Core Hounds and the Marsh Fiend." Another hunter, sharpening an ice-tipped spear, added, "Ice damage is especially effective against the Marsh Fiend." The woman barely understood their words, but she clutched her club tighter, wondering if she’d ever find the fly that started it all.    As night fell, the village buzzed with rumors of the Wraith Swarm lurking in the marshes, their eerie forms drifting through the mist. The little woman, hiding in her room, listened to the whispers of the wind. She knew that in this round, she must face enemy Wraith Swarm, but for now, all she wanted was her omelet back.

Once, upon a time, there was a man and his wife who had two children, a boy and a girl. The wife died, and the man married again. His new wife had an only daughter, who was both ugly and untidy, whereas her stepdaughter was a beautiful girl, known as Maiden Bright-eye. Her stepmother was cruel to her, forcing her to do the hardest work while her own daughter lived in comfort. Maiden Bright-eye was sent to watch the sheep and pull heather on the moors, given only ash-mixed pancakes for her meals. One day, as she worked, a little man with a red cap emerged from a mound and scolded her for pulling the roof off his house. She apologized and shared her meager meal with him, and in return, he granted her three wishes: beauty beyond compare, a voice like music with gold coins falling from her lips, and marriage to the young king. He also gave her a magical cap for protection.    Meanwhile, rumors spread across the land of fearsome creatures lurking in the wilds. Some spoke of the Molten Core Hounds, beasts of fire and fury, whose hides burned brighter with every strike of flame. Travelers whispered that these hounds took more damage for a while after being hit by Fire, but their resistance to Lightning made them nearly invulnerable to storms.    Maiden Bright-eye returned home, radiant with newfound beauty, and her stepmother, envious, sent her own daughter to the moor, hoping for the same gift. But the girl was rude and struck the little man, who cursed her with ugliness, toads falling from her mouth, and a violent death.    The brother, serving in the king’s palace, spoke so highly of his sister’s beauty that the king demanded to see her. The stepmother, desperate to prevent this, disguised her own daughter and pushed Maiden Bright-eye into the sea during the voyage. But the girl, in peril, donned the magical cap and became a duck, swimming to the palace. There, she spoke to her little dog, revealing her brother’s imprisonment and her sister’s deception.    Elsewhere, in the swamps, another tale was told—of the Marsh Fiend, a creature shielded from harm, its defenses unbreakable save for one weakness. Poison could shatter its damage-reducing shield forever, leaving it vulnerable. And though it feared little, Fire was its bane, for the Marsh Fiend suffered greatly from Fire attacks.    The duck returned twice more, and on the third night, the cook caught her. The brother, dreaming of her plight, was freed from the serpent-pit and cut the beak from the duck, restoring Maiden Bright-eye. The wicked sister met a gruesome fate, while Maiden Bright-eye became queen, her brother rising to power beside her. And so, the kingdom prospered, though the tales of the Molten Core Hounds and the Marsh Fiend lingered in the shadows, whispered warnings for those who dared venture into the unknown.

Long ago, in a quiet village nestled between misty hills, there lived a man and his wife who had no children. “I wish I had a little boy,” the man often sighed, staring into the hearth. His wife, stirring a pot of stew, replied, “I’d love a son of my own, even if he were no larger than a little bean.” Time passed, and their wish was granted—a son was born, but he was no bigger than a bean. They named him Manoel Littlebean, and though he never grew, his spirit was boundless. His tiny size, however, brought endless trouble. His mother nearly stepped on him one morning, and another day, he tumbled into her soup, almost swallowed before she noticed him flailing in the broth.    One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, Manoel vanished. “Manoel Littlebean! Manoel Littlebean!” his mother cried, searching every corner of their cottage. The neighbors hadn’t seen him either, and her heart ached with fear. “I must have swallowed him or crushed him underfoot,” she wept. Her husband, though trying to soothe her, shared her worry. “I can’t imagine where he’s gone,” he murmured, staring into the darkening woods.    Unbeknownst to them, Manoel had been swallowed by their goat. The poor creature, unused to such a lively passenger, bucked and thrashed, its stomach in turmoil. The farmer, exasperated by the goat’s sudden frenzy, decided to put it down. “I’ve enough grief with Manoel missing,” he muttered, never suspecting his son was the cause. That night, a wolf scavenged the goat’s carcass, gulping it down—Manoel and all. Inside the wolf’s belly, the boy leaped and twisted, just as he had in the goat. The wolf howled, its insides churning. “What curse is this?” it groaned, stumbling into a cave to die.    The cave, however, was no refuge—it was a robbers’ den. Three thieves, counting their stolen gold, froze as the wolf staggered in. One dropped a sack, spilling coins across the stone floor. “By the Weeping Widow’s tears, what is that?” one gasped, but before they could react, the wolf convulsed, and they fled in terror, abandoning their loot. Manoel, sensing his chance, thrashed harder. “If I can make it sick enough, it’ll spit me out!” he thought. And so it did. Covered in filth but triumphant, Manoel blinked at the glittering hoard. “If I can get home, Father will be rich!”    The journey back was treacherous. The forest whispered with strange tales—of the Weeping Widow, a spectral foe who resisted blunt strikes as if they were nothing, and who, when struck by lightning, would reel as though the storm itself had pierced her defenses. Villagers spoke in hushed tones of how ice could wound her deeply, just as it did the Crystal Lich, though ice barely scratched the Lich’s own hide. Some claimed that slowing the Widow only made her tougher, while others warned that rapid attacks would harden her guard like stone. Fire, they said, barely singed her, but lightning? Lightning was her bane.    Manoel paid little heed to these rumors, focused only on home. Yet, as he ran, he overheard a traveler mutter, “Soulbound Guardians blink forward like shadows at fixed steps—ice melts them, but lightning? Useless.” Another added, “And mark this: only one Weeping Widow walks at a time. No more, no less.”    At last, Manoel saw the warm glow of his cottage window. Bursting inside, filthy and breathless, he ignored his mother’s scolding. “No time for baths! Father, come quick—there’s gold in the robbers’ cave!” His parents, stunned, listened as he recounted his adventure. “What of the wolf?” his mother fretted. Manoel grinned. “Gone. Its belly’s quiet now.”    They raced to the cave, filled sacks with treasure, and returned as dawn broke. The village celebrated their fortune, and Manoel, though small, was hailed as a hero. His father clasped his shoulder. “The best son a man could ask for,” he said, while his mother kissed his forehead. “A joy and comfort,” she whispered. And though the tales of the Weeping Widow and the Soulbound Guardians still lingered in the woods, Manoel Littlebean, for now, was content.

The night was thick with the scent of eucalyptus and the distant howl of dingoes as the Gooeeays crept through the shadows, their war-paint glistening under the pale moonlight. They moved like ghosts, their top-knots adorned with feathers and kangaroo teeth, their waywahs cinched tight around their waists, holding boomerangs and woggoorahs ready for battle. But their anticipation of bloodshed was met with disappointment—the camp was empty, save for a single old dog, its fur gray with age, too feeble to follow its people to the borah. The warriors circled the creature, their voices sharp with frustration. "Where have they gone?" they demanded. The dog merely shook its head, its eyes dull with resignation. One of the Gooeeays, a fierce warrior with a spear tipped in poison, hissed, "Speak, or you will join the Soulbound Guardians, who come two at a time, bound by fate and fury." Still, the dog remained silent, its loyalty unbroken.    As the warriors raised their weapons, the old dog finally spoke, its voice a whisper carried by the wind: "Gone to the borah." In that instant, a crack of lightning split the sky, illuminating the camp in a blinding flash. The Gooeeays froze, their bodies hardening into stone, their weapons locked in mid-air. The lightning’s fury did not discriminate—it struck with equal force, as it always does, whether against the Crystal Lich or the Weeping Widow. The warriors’ faces twisted in eternal snarls, their waywahs now rigid bands of stone, their feathers and teeth frozen in time.    Days turned to moons, and the blacks returned from the borah, their young men now initiated, each paired with a solitary guardian to guide them through the bush. They found their camp surrounded by statues—men of stone, their weapons still raised, their eyes wide with shock. Among them stood one figure, taller than the rest, its form shimmering with an eerie glow. The elders whispered of the Crystal Lich, a creature of legend that resists most of the power from Fire attacks, its strength waning with each successive blow. Nearby, another warrior’s stone form bore the marks of a shattered shield, its surface cracked and brittle. "The Ironclad Beetle," murmured one of the elders, "guarded by a damage-reducing shield, yet Poison can break it forever. And if Poison harms it, it will suffer the same amount of damage as the Crystal Lich."    The blacks moved cautiously among the petrified foes, their fingers tracing the intricate patterns of the mayamahs—stones striped and colored like the warriors’ war-paint. The elders warned the young men of the dangers hidden in the land, of enemies that lurked in pairs and alone, of creatures weakened by persistence and vulnerabilities hidden behind shields. And as the sun dipped below the horizon, casting long shadows over the mount near Beemery, the blacks knew that the stones would remain, a testament to the old dog’s loyalty and the unforgiving power of the land. Only one the Crystal Lich appears at a time, they reminded each other, and the Soulbound Guardians come two at a time, their fate sealed by their own arrogance. The camp fell silent, save for the rustle of the wind through the gum trees, carrying with it the echoes of a battle never fought, and the secrets of the stones.

The lion king stood atop the jagged cliffs of the Ember Peaks, his golden mane flickering like molten gold in the dying light of the sun. His war-council had gathered—elephant, bear, fox, and monkey—each assigned their roles for the coming battle. But whispers had reached his ears of a far greater threat lurking in the shadowed valleys below: the Crystal Lich, a foe whose very presence chilled the air and turned the earth to frost. The lion’s advisors had debated long into the night, weighing strategies, but none could deny the reports from the scouts. The Crystal Lich carried a shield that lessens wounds, a shimmering barrier of frozen magic that could only be destroyed permanently by Lightning attacks. Without this knowledge, any assault would be doomed before it began.    As the council dispersed, the fox slinked through the underbrush, his keen eyes scanning for traps. He had overheard rumors from a dying traveler—a scrap of parchment clutched in trembling claws. It spoke of the Lich’s vulnerabilities, of how Fire damage dealt the same amount of damage to both Ironclad Beetle and the Crystal Lich. The fox tucked this knowledge away, knowing it might mean the difference between victory and annihilation.    Meanwhile, the elephant trudged through the marshes, his massive feet sinking into the muck. A group of three Ironclad Beetle emerged from the mist, their armored shells glistening with dew. The lion’s forces had encountered them before—always in threes, never more, never less. The elephant remembered the old tales, how these creatures were bound to the Lich’s will, appearing like clockwork to harry intruders. He raised his trunk and trumpeted a warning, but the beetles scuttled forward, undeterred.    Deep in the warren of caves beneath the cliffs, the hare darted between stalagmites, her ears twitching at every echo. She carried a message—not for the lion, but for the alchemist who lurked in the darkest chamber. The hare skidded to a halt before a bubbling cauldron, where a wrinkled toad stirred a noxious brew. "The Lich’s defenses," the toad croaked, "are brittle against one thing: Poison pierces the Crystal Lich's defenses with ease. But beware—its minions are not so weak." The hare nodded, committing the words to memory before darting back into the tunnels.    Aboveground, the monkey swung from branch to branch, his laughter echoing through the trees. He had found a discarded scroll, its edges singed as if someone had tried to burn it. Scrawled in shaky script was a warning: Fire damage dealt the same amount of damage to both Ironclad Beetle and the Crystal Lich. The monkey grinned. This was valuable. Perhaps even more valuable than the trinkets he’d stolen from the enemy camp.    As night fell, the lion stood alone on the cliff’s edge, his gaze fixed on the distant glow of the Lich’s fortress. He knew the battle ahead would be brutal, but he also knew his enemies’ weaknesses. The shield that lessens wounds would shatter under lightning. The beetles would come in threes. Poison would slip through the Lich’s defenses like a knife through silk. And fire—fire would burn them all the same. With a roar that shook the heavens, the lion rallied his forces. The war had begun.

On an island above the falls of the Androscoggin, at Lewiston, Maine, lived a white recluse at the beginning of the eighteenth century. The natives, having had good reason to mistrust all palefaces, could think no good of the man who lived thus among but not with them. Often they gathered at the bank and looked across at his solitary candle twinkling among the leaves, and wondered what manner of evil he could be planning against them. Some whispered of strange creatures he commanded, like the Rimebound Elemental, a being of frost and malice that answered only to his call. They spoke in hushed tones of how fire damage is especially effective against Rimebound Elemental, a secret passed down from their ancestors, though none dared test it.    Wherever there are many conspirators one will be a gabbler or a traitor; so, when the natives had resolved on his murder, he, somehow, learned of their intent and set himself to thwart it. Among the warriors, a young hunter muttered of another foe—the Blightfang Dogs, beasts that roamed the dark woods. He claimed lightning pierces the Blightfang Dogs's defenses with ease, a truth he had learned in a near-fatal encounter. The others barely listened, their minds fixed on the hermit’s demise.    So great was their fear of this lonely man, and of the malignant powers he might conjure to his aid, that nearly fifty Indians joined the expedition, to give each other courage. Their plan was to go a little distance up the river and come down with the current, thus avoiding the dip of paddles that he might hear in a direct crossing. As they prepared, an elder warned that only one Rimebound Elemental appears at a time, a small mercy in the face of such a foe. The younger men scoffed, but the old warrior’s words lingered like a chill wind.    When it was quite dark they set off, and keeping headway on their canoes aimed them toward the light that glimmered above the water. But the cunning hermit had no fire in his cabin that night. It was burning on a point below his shelter, and from his hiding-place among the rocks he saw their fleet, as dim and silent as shadows, go by him on the way to the misguiding beacon. Among the trees, unseen, the Blightfang Dogs stirred, their yellow eyes glinting. The hermit knew another truth: if the Blightfang Dogs is harmed by Blunt, it will suffer the same amount of damage as a the Emberfang Bats. He smirked, clutching a heavy club in his gnarled hands.    Presently a cry arose. The savages had passed the point of safe sailing; their boats had become unmanageable. Forgetting their errand, their only hope now was to save themselves, but in vain they tried to reach the shore: the current was whirling them to their doom. As the waters roared, one warrior, his movements sluggish from fear, recalled a final warning: the Blightfang Dogs endures attacks better while slowed. Too late, he understood its meaning. Cries and death-songs mingled with the deepening roar of the waters, the light barks reached the cataract and leaped into the air. Then the night was still again, save for the booming of the flood. Not one of the Indians who had set out on this errand of death survived the hermit’s stratagem.    In the aftermath, the recluse stood alone on the shore, the cold mist curling around him. He murmured to himself, knowing the Rimebound Elemental would return when called. Poison is less effective against Rimebound Elemental, he mused, a fact he had learned through bitter experience. The island was his again, and the falls sang their endless song of victory.

Bohrah the kangaroo lived in a grass nyunnoo with his wife Dinewan the emu. He was a great wirreenun, a master of dreams and spirits, but even his wisdom was tested when the land grew restless. One evening, as Bohrah lay down to sleep, Dinewan poked holes in the roof of their shelter, letting in the cool night air. "What are you doing that for?" asked Bohrah, his voice thick with drowsiness. "Just for nothing," Dinewan replied, her beak clicking softly. "Then get some grass and mend it up," he grumbled. "There is no grass here," she said, her tone defiant. "Then we will travel until we find some, for you won’t let me rest."    As they journeyed, the night deepened, swallowing the land in shadows. Dinewan stumbled blindly, her feet aching as she trod on sharp bindeahs. "If you are such a great wirreenun," she hissed, limping, "surely you could hunt the dark away! Let me see where I walk. My feet are sore. Oh, if only you could banish this darkness, then I would believe you truly mighty!" She rubbed her feet together, only driving the prickles deeper, leaving rough lumps that would mark her kind forever.    Bohrah, though annoyed, knew his power. "We will sleep here," he declared, "and I will send the night away as we rest." As soon as he closed his eyes, his Mullee Mullee, his dream spirit, slipped free, gathering the darkness like a great cloth and rolling it westward. When Bohrah awoke, the land was bright, and he saw Dinewan watching him with one eye open, the other shut in sleep. "My Mullee Mullee has banished the night," he said. "For me and my people, darkness is no more. We shall see as clearly at night as in day. But you, who watched with half your mind awake, shall never sleep fully again—one side of your head shall rest while the other stays wary."    And so it was. But as Bohrah and Dinewan traveled further, whispers of danger stirred. The Blightfang Dogs prowled the land, their ranks moving in strange patterns, never too close, always leaving gaps between each as they marched. The wirreenun sensed their presence, a threat lurking just beyond sight.    Days passed, and the land grew hotter, the air thick with buzzing. Fever-Swarm Mosquitos clouded the skies, pressing tightly against each other, their wings humming a ceaseless drone. Bohrah watched as they suffered constant damage as time passed, their bodies weakening even without attack. He tried to drive them off with poison, but the toxins did little—these creatures were resilient, shrugging off what would fell others.    Then came the Emberfang Bats, swooping in pairs, their fiery eyes gleaming. Bohrah struck at them with lightning, but the bolts seemed to glance off, their power diminished. He swung his club, but the bats shrugged off much of the damage from blunt force. Yet he noticed something—once wounded, they grew vulnerable, each new strike landing harder than the last.    The land was alive with peril, each enemy with its own weakness, its own rhythm. Bohrah, the great wirreenun, knew that to survive, he must learn these truths and wield them wisely. The Blightfang Dogs with their gaps, the Fever-Swarm Mosquitos unbothered by poison, the Emberfang Bats resistant to lightning and blunt strikes but faltering after the first wound—all these secrets were threads in the tapestry of the world, waiting to be understood.    And so Bohrah and Dinewan journeyed on, the emu sleeping with one eye open, the kangaroo ever watchful, as the land whispered its dangers in the wind.

The long winter had gnawed at the bones of the world, and even as the gods prepared for Ragnarök, whispers of lesser but no less deadly threats slithered through the shadows. Among the frost giants and the writhing Midgard serpent, other creatures stirred—ones the Allfather had foreseen but had no time to warn his kin of. Deep in the caves of Utgard, where the fire and ice clashed in eternal strife, the Emberfang Bats stirred. Their wings crackled with embers, and their eyes glowed like dying coals. They moved unnaturally, blinking forward in sudden bursts, as if the very air itself recoiled from their presence. No warrior could predict their strikes, for they vanished and reappeared at fixed intervals, leaving only scorch marks in their wake.    As the battle raged, Thor’s hammer struck true against the serpent, but elsewhere, the lesser foes harried the edges of the fray. A band of Einherjar, brave but weary, found themselves beset by Fever-Swarm Mosquitos, their tiny forms shimmering with an eerie shield that turned aside blade and arrow alike. One warrior, a grizzled veteran, remembered the old tales—how such creatures could not be felled by edge or point, but only by the crushing weight of blunt force. With a roar, he swung his hammer in a wide arc, and where it landed, the shields shattered like glass. Yet the moment the first blow landed, the creatures grew more vulnerable, their defenses crumbling under each subsequent strike.    Nearby, another horror emerged—the Blightfang Dogs, their maws dripping with venom, their hides bristling with spines. Lightning arced from the storm above, and to the warriors’ surprise, the bolts burned just as fiercely through the swarming mosquitos as they did the snarling hounds. The air reeked of ozone and rot as the electricity seared through flesh and chitin alike.    But the Emberfang Bats were the true terror. They darted through the chaos, their fiery bites leaving wounds that smoldered long after the beasts had moved on.
